column2: you can bet this same biz is hot here in the states.
Very interesting. But did he put his visor up or did the Batallion in the front row do it for him?

"Bangladeshi law enforcement officials said that Mr. Shahed had been investigated in more than 30 other criminal cases connected to corruption, embezzlement and running fraudulent companies. He has served two years in prison, the authorities said. “He is a known criminal,” said Faizul Islam, a member of Bangladesh’s elite police unit, the Rapid Action Battalion."
- but that apparently was no obstacle to him running a hospital! I would imagine that there was more going on at that place than just selling fake COVID-19 certificates!
Besides you can buy a jenuine Covid 19 negative/positive both certificat, which you need. just pay 45 to 50 USD. Really superb businesse,  and Bangladesh is the country where everything is possible
Trust is probably the most important thing in business and economic success. By faking certificates this poor country Bangladesh may lose a lot more then foreign remittance.

One key fact is missing in this article, it's the fact that people were duped into getting the false report. Genuine patients as well as migrant workers paid that amount to be tested and get genuine diagnostic reports instead had fallen victim to the scam without even knowing that the report they had in hands were fake.  And the scammers did it because it's cheaper and more profitable to just print reports without tests. This  bit of information is crucial to understand that just because someone is covid positive with contradictory report in her/his hand doesn't mean s/he bought that report to dupe the authority rather according to most of the cases that person her/himself is the victim.

This is false and fabricated news. This article has been written intentionally to show world community so that they do not allow Bangladeshi workers to their country. 
This accused person did not sale certificate to the workers. This culprit gave false test report without any kind of test.

This Indian's intention is clear.
I don't find the validity of a news report regarding Bangladesh when it has been published with a New Delhi correspondence.

Bangladesh received 18.34 billion USD as remittance from its migrant workers last year. The government earned 2,000,000 USD on average every hour from these workers and sent the equivalent amount in local Bangladeshi currency, TAKA to their families with no problems.  Over 10 million Bangladeshis work as migrant workers.

Just one Shahid doesn’t change Bangladesh’s success story as one of the top remittance earners on the planet.

That some--not all--Covid-19 patients can be treated at home is game-changing. This gives the patient the comfort of being at home, reduces the chances of catching the virus or other diseases while in the hospital, and frees up ICU rooms for more serious cases.

At age 79 I am at very high risk of serious illness or even death if I contract the virus, so I have been following virus research closely. I am a psychologist, not an MD, but I am trained and experienced at reading and interpreting scientific research.
 
Reports of very high death rates (75-80%!) for intubated, elderly Covid-19 patients led me to have a long conversation with my Cleveland Clinic doctor, who supported my changing my health care directive to include the text:  Do not intubate except as a last resort. Aside from being associated with death if carried out on Covid-19 patients, intubation may cause cognitive deficits, compromise various organs and exacerbate pre-existing conditions.

So, it possible to treat some Covid-19 cases at home, and there are several steps that can be taken at home or in hospital before implementing the extreme measure of intubation. These include proning (laying the patient on his side or front, which eases breathing), and administering supplemental oxygen through a nose tube or mask.

As I am not an MD I cannot offer medical advice; however, I do advise those with concerns and issues similar to mine to discuss them with a health care provider.

Care of patients should be done in stages. If you have a mild to moderate case, supplemental oxygen delivered to the home with a machine is a first step. Prescription of anti-blood clotting drugs should be provided. Daily consultation with a team should be done. If the patient progresses to a moderate case, then IV fluids and other care can still be provided in the home with nurse visits to administer the fluids and do blood draws. If the patient needs more care, then, and only then, should they be transported to the ED for more intensive care. This would not be an easy system to develop but might ease overrun ICU units at the hospital.

Having managed many patients I think we can say we know much more about the disease that we can safely manage some very sick patients at home. Indeed we did manage some of my colleagues who got sick using telemedicine. If we have enough oxygen supplies and monitoring devices and a nurse to visit when needed some of the care could be even better at home. During the big surge modified units in hospitals were not really optimal for patient care and with the proper setup you could do better care at home. Germany has been doing it for awhile and now some of the Asian countries with inadequate beds are doing the same.

I hope to avoid the virus and I plan to become part of the army of vaccinators that will be needed when the time comes. In the meantime if I’m struck down with COVID-19 I hope to ride it out at home. This is so encouraging!
If there are shortages of nurses, I don't understand how there are enough nurses for home care?
fantastic story another feather in the cap of Northwell Health They are one of the hospital systems we are lucky to have in New York State

Yes! A wonderful idea/strategy! It has been done in Germany with excellent results and it's not only good for hospitals but for us, the patients as well!!! I hope Kaiser in San Diego follows this strategy! When I read what is going in hospitals, suddenly I feel like the commercial: the cockroaches motel: the come in but don't come out!

Remarkable that an enormous hospital system like Northwell (I think they are the largest non government employer in NYS) is able to be so agile and adaptable.

The patient gets professional and appropriate care at home.  The hospital retains capacity for critically ill patients and a combination of nurse managers and tele-health provides the appropriate regimen for wellness.

This is a model which can be exported to other parts of the country suffering the current tsunami of cases..
Great - now this gives Trump and other Covidiots further ammunition for their stupid anti-mask crusade.
Florida should be making preparations to convert The Villages into one very large Covid-19 care center.

I personally know about Northwell Health’s excellent Home Care program because I was one of its patients. 

My husband got the coronavirus.  He had to be hospitalized and placed on a ventilator.  At that time, approximately 80% of patients on ventilators did not survive.

When I got the coronavirus, I call my Northwell Health Primary Care Physician.  She called me 4-5 times a day every day until I got better.  She had a Northwell Health Nurse Facetime me every day.  I had a blood pressure monitor, a pulse oximeter, and a digital thermometer at home, so there was no need for someone to come to my home to take my vitals.

My Primary Care Physician sent me a portable oxygen tank in the middle of the night.  Thanks to my Primary Care Physician and the Nurses, I was able to recover from the coronavirus without being hospitalized.  They are my Superheros as are all other healthcare providers.  I hope you can hear me banging my pots and pans for all healthcare providers.

The coronavirus is far worse than the flu.  It feels like someone is tightly squeezing your lungs, and it hurts every time you cough, which is often.

Please get a pulse oximeter to check whether you or your loved ones are getting sufficient oxygen.  If you are not getting sufficient oxygen, you need to get to the hospital promptly.

Please wear a face mask when outside of your own home to protect yourself from others, and to protect others from you.  We can stop the coronavirus from spreading if we work together.

I’m already set up. As a retired doc with critical care experience, I know a CPAP machine with inline Oxygen is “half” of a ventilator. I own a pulse ox, home O2 concentrator, and am wondering whether to buy aspirin as clot prevention (yes). I know to make myself keep drinking so I void every 4 hours at least. And prone. And blow balloons up for lung exercise.

I was appalled at the rush to ventilate people but understood it. However, our airways have  has incredible reflexes that a vent overrides. I read of good results in China with people in CPAP rigs that look like their head is in a water cooler bottle.
 
Early oxygen gently delivered seems a no brainer. Remember oxygen bars? I’d set them up in assisted living to tide people over. 

Of course, when I share this with modern docs, the look at me like I’m nuts. Evidenced-based care is great, but I a lifetime of experience is also helpful. Yes, yes, I know not to treat myself,  but Geez we make getting care way too hard and way too dangerous.
This article is positive and encouraging. Yet, we are once again expecting people who are very sick, and very frightened, and possibly alone, to efficiently organize their own health care needs.
Too bad Florida didn’t put any effort into prevention.

I’m not surprised by this. I firmly believe my wife and I had this before it was named in January into February. Our Dr immediately put us on prednisone to help with inflammation and breathing along with inhalers. I think if we had been diagnosed a month later, we would’ve been taken to a hospital in the thick of this. Home healthcare is the way to go.

The UK has ‘’Hospital at Home’ for seriously ill patients who are long term. I saw it with mr brother. Amazing. No idea if they used it for Covid. Nurses have a lot of equipment in their cars, and a doctor is on call with them. Saved him weeks in hospital.

My brother contracted polio in 1954. If NIH signs off on a vaccine, I'll get it asap. The risk of harm by contracting COVID-19 is greater than the risk of an adverse reaction to the vaccine. It seems too many people confuse a choice of being a a "no-brainer" with having no brain.
If there’s a vaccine, I’ll get in line. But it won’t be the front of the line. Too much urgency here.
We also need more antibody studies to see if a vaccine will work, or if the immunity will wear off.

While it is sad that some children have had negative reactions to vaccines, those relatively few cases should not put millions at risk, which would be the effect if anti-vaxxers had their way about the MMR shots. The unvaccinated few generally avoided measles etc because the majority got their shots. We’ve already seen how quickly measles can spread in a community with unscientific objections to vaccines.

When Dr. Fauci says GO.
I GO.
We’ll get it ASAP! And we’ll avoid anyone who doesn’t. I’ve seen polio victims (including a child in 1980’s) and a woman die from chicken pox during her pregnancy. Ignorance isn’t bliss.

Why are these buffoons not being dispersed, fined, or arrested for violating the mask ordinance? Permitting them to be there sends a dangerous message: it emboldens their inane delusions and weakens the governor's ordinance. Zero tolerance, please, Gov. Newsom!

Anti-vaccine people are listened to mainly, because in contrast to their views, vaccines work.  If we still had memories of polio, not many of those anti-vaccine people would be so opposed to polio vaccines.  They don't remember mass deaths from flu, from polio, from other diseases.  So they can have their beliefs free from fear of the diseases.

Same will happen with Covid-19.  The people who get the vaccine will stay alive, be able to return to work, be safe going to bars, their children will be safe going back to school, they can have neighbors over, their can attend church, etc.

And the anti-vaccine people will continue to get sick and die.  

That will end the anti-vaccine talk.  People have to be hit over the head with why they should be vaccinated, and no amount of "education" about misinformation will work.

If those who are skeptical of vaccines DO NOT accept the help a vaccine offers then they maintain a higher risk of becoming infected and suffering due to COVID-19 - AND possibly infecintg those they love and care for, and maybe dying. And, oh by the way, they risk infecting or being infected by the other skeptics in their gatherings without even a mask. Those who have the vaccination and maintain their good health will then take care of them w.r.t. their physical condition. Not sure what we can do about their rational powers, though! It is understandable if there are those who have had bad (possibly really bad) results with vaccines and are therefore reluctant to accept the health benefits vs. risks of the new vaccine.  We have seen no numbers published on this, only anecdotes it would appear. But it is  a social choice that has risks either way and an informed public will, I believe, risk on the side of getting the vaccine eventually and thankfully!!

Several of the protesters' placards in today's NYT photo (7/18/20) make harsh and serious claims against vaccines and alleged damages that they attribute to them. Others in the crowd may be supporters of the belief that a well-known tech titan is using his support for vaccines as a ruse to 'chip' them, so that they can be tracked and controlled. It looks like and reads of a low-budget dystopian thriller served up with a tossed paranoia salad. These images, the placards, and the ocean of putatively scientific "proof" of their claims do little but provide a shoddy foundation on which one could popularly call for the abolition of entities and funding for all public health measures ... because such are incorrect. This, not Seattle, not New York, not anywhere else in post-Floyd America is mob rule. And the mob does not mask.

This is tough. I am a logical, fact appreciative person. I value and support vaccinations. I also acknowledge that there have been problem with some vaccines and the mega profit driven nature of medical corporations have some history of ethical shortcomings. There is also a climate of denial of any problems of any vaccines. I am not talking about things like the completely debunked autism theories. But, because of the fringe conspiracy theory folks, anybody who has any hesitation for any vaccine for any reason is now deemed a lunatic. And that can be a problem for proper evaluation of any new product-including new drugs and vaccines. Given the rushed nature of all of the stages of testing, I do and will have concerns about a vaccine. I think every logical person must. That does not mean I would not get vaccinated, but it does mean that I will weigh the risk at such time one is available against my (and my community) risk of covid-19.

In grade school I had a classmate who contracted polio and walks with the aid of two aluminum crutches that supported her legs.  She could not have gone far too if it were not for her sister assisting her by her side.
Yes, I know that there are risks to a vaccine, but it is the lies and misinformation that is doing the most harm.
I see protesters on their feet holding anti-vaccine signs, and the irony is without the polio vaccine some would not be on their two feet without some type of aid.

In order to help protect your community you must first protect yourself. One cannot give what one does not have. Look anywhere, this is always the way. One cannot give life if one doesn’t have life already. So, everyone must consider for themselves first what is best for me in order so I may give to others.
I’m reading that antibodies disappear after a few months so that immunity may not be possible.

I am by no means an anti-vaxxer but I don’t trust the Trump administration to put out a safe and adequately tested vaccine.  They are rushing it and we all know Trump’s disdain for regulations.  They will skip all the safety tests.  They’re going to just rush it to market so Trump can brag that he has “fixed” the crisis.  This vaccine is about Trump’s re-election, not public health.  If something that normally takes years suddenly gets done in months, I’m suspicious.  No Trump vaccine for me!
If you want to take a vaccine that has bypassed phases of clinical trials, by all means do so.  You will protect yourself from the many who will refuse.

Another example of "American Exceptionalism". The anti-vax movement is barely a blip in the rest of the civilized world. That would be due to governments recognizing the importance and apolitical nature of science.

The media can't divorce itself from contributing to the concern many have about the perceived hastiness behind the development of a C-19 virus.  In the course of reporting on the development of a vaccine they have (rightfully) described the normal timeline to be years rather than months; they have reported on a president eager to make a vaccine a political win, and they have described drug companies motivated by prestige and profit to be first to market. Don't recall reading anything where altruism was the centerpiece of the story. So yeah, I'll wait my turn; won't be rushing to be vaccinated.

I always stay up-to-date on my vaccinations.  However I'm wary of anything the Trump administration touts. Without transparency I cannot tell if a vaccine has been adequately tested and whether it is safe. I look at the Trump administration's treatment of scientists, science, the CDC, etc. and rewriting of guidelines. I don't trust them a bit with my life.

There would be two type of mistrust. One from those who generally oppose all vaccines and another from those suspicious of its safety - Trump opponents who think an unsafe vaccine was pushed to impact the elections.

I'd like to see a civil discussion between anti-vaccine proponents and a group of scientists who are also excellent communicators where each side brings their "facts" to the discussion. There will be a point at which the anti-vaccine folks reveal themselves as science deniers, embracing misinformation.

Like my mother always used to say, “Fast and wrong.”  I am a strong proponent of vaccines that have been properly developed, but there’s too much political pressure pushing COVID vaccines to market.  I will be very suspicious of any vaccine that comes out before the originally- suggested time frame of 12-18 months.

Let’s assume there is a vaccine, and that we’ll be able to know whether it has been approved and safety certified by other nations as well as our own FDA and CDC.  Media, that’s something you can help with if you want to continue to matter to the rational part of the population.

Under those circumstances it should be quickly established via an easily verifiable form of vaccine certification who is able to:
- attend school
- go to public indoor spaces without a mask
- purchase an airline ticket
- gain entry to other countries
- etc.
People without vaccination verification would not be allowed to do these things.
Those who choose to cut themselves off from society are welcome to do so.  They have that freedom of choice, but private businesses and government policy are both free to protect the best interests of society by excluding them from various activities.
I would expect nothing less from a sane nation.

The scientific community is by nature skeptical.  It is always about proof.  We should reserve our judgement about the hasty nature of these vaccine trials until they are over and can be reviewed dispassionately by the investigators' peers.  When there's a consensus among those scientists, we should all accept that and do the right thing.  No individual lay person, no matter how informed by the media they may be, is in a position to make a valid assessment of the science.  Getting your information from CNN, Fox, or OANN will never put you in a position to "make informed decisions for my family."
I have no use for the traditional anti-vaccination crowd, but I certainly understand people being wary with the Trump administration overseeing the operation.

The sight of Covid-19 patients dying in intensive care just days after they laughed in the face of a virus they considered a hoax is enough to get me to wear a mask now, and to get vaccinated as soon as a vaccine has been authorized by the FDA and had its safety verified by responsible, professional sources of drug information.
Easily dealt with: legally require everyone to be vaccinated, regardless of any excuse otherwise. It is like rationing during wartime -- strictly necessary

I believe in education. The government should release a series of TV commercials whose aim is to educate the public about 
the benefits and risks of vaccination.   There are people who are still living today who contracted polio before the vaccine was developed.  Historical figures such as FDR also were impacted by polio.  Educational commercials should also include and educate the public about the speed of transmission of infectious disease.   Most Americans for example do not understand the concept of exponential growth.     Anti-vaxers need to understand that vaccination has the potential to free the world of the scourge that is Covid 19.
Nothing is likely to change as long as politicians and experts fail to agree on anything. Don't blame the people. They are just responding to the absence of agreement.

An effective vaccine will be developed in spite of - not because of - Trump's wishes.  Heck, who doesn't want an effective vaccine sooner than later?

Trump will ALWAYS claim credit for anything positive because that's what a raging narcissist like him does.  In his deranged and self-absorbed mind, he probably thinks sunrises happen upon his command.

That said, I will get the vaccine when someone with credibility, integrity, and well-established and impartial scientific standing advises to do so.

I love to travel.  I’ve been to Madagascar - Morocco - Myanmar and many “exotic” locales.  I not only ask my doctor what “should” I get when i go someplace but what “could” I get.  I have my Hep A, B, C, yellow fever, typhoid, regular updates to my tetanus, just had both my shingles vaccinations last year.   I believe in science and that vaccinations have kept us healthy and safe.  BUT... I don’t believe THIS administration cares that we are safe or will safely monitor the necessary companies and agencies working on the vaccine or testing the vaccine.  I want a vaccine for this, I want to travel again and feel protected, BUT....  we need time and independent reviews.   That won’t happen with a president who only cares about himself.

It’s way too early to be making predictions about the efficacy and safety of the vaccine.

When one gains approval, we’ll have to see what it went through to get there and decide if that was adequate.

I am personally dubious of anything that Trump says or does. The right thing to do is ignore whatever he says about the vaccine and make your own decision based on either the science if you understand it or the recommendation of trustworthy experts(not anti-vaccine quacks) if you don’t.

Trump's anti-science administration has moved many in his science denying base into the arms of the anti-vaxxer community.

When a safe therapeutic or vaccine becomes available, there will be millions who will refuse, endangering the rest of us.

Only Trump can make the health and safety of the American people a political, anti-science football.  After all, he is a "stable genius".
Whoever wants to take the eventual vaccine takes it, let the rest deal with the virus on their own terms. Let’s see who will be the winners.

I assume the Trump administration will be gone by the time a vaccine will be ready for testing and/or distribution, so people will be able to rely on scientific input more than political expediency.  More important:  if the vaccine works, those who refuse to take it will have only themselves to blame as Mr. Darwin once again prevails.

Novavax is a company that never delivered a vaccine in 33 years of its existence, and was about to go bankrupt. Then it suddenly got $1.6 billion from the Trump administration, for fast-track development of a vaccine that bypasses the scrutiny of government scientists.

This was covered on this very site: "How a Struggling Company Won $1.6 Billion to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine".

Excuse me, in case I am skeptical, if three days before the election Novavax announces that they have or almost have the vaccine ready to go. 

The media, of course, will trip over itself to unwittingly become part of the last greatest con in American history - which would be our last.
Me, I’m just going to watch the Europeans. When Angela Merkel says, “use THIS vaccine, that’s when I’ll go ahead.
As far as I'm concerned, Trump Inc. can be first to get the vaccine.
As in so many other cases, large swaths of Americans prove undeserving of the freedoms they flaunt so carelessly. Make it a law to be vaccinated.

If a "vaccine" is released before November 2, I will not get it, and I'm as "pro" vaccine as a person can be. Trump has touted all sorts of miracle cures that end up killing people. If one shows up before the election, stay far far away. 

Of course, listen to your doctor, not me. But *anything* Trump has ever tried to sell anyone has been fraudulent or outright dangerous.

Sadly anti-vaxxers have been around before Trump, and they transcend political parties. On the right they have put on conspiracy hats and think it’s a new world order conducted by Bill Gates to inject 5G into are veins. The left at times go on about big pharma like Abbott and Pfizer to preaching natural methods like oils and reject medical science. Not everyone on each side fit in this, but the crazy fringes are sometimes on different sides of the same coin.

I’m not an anti vaxxer by any stretch. But I am concerned that, in America, something will be rushed to market for political purposes. Trump’s mendacity, coupled with his pattern of installing sycophants to run government agencies, could create a pathway for a flawed vaccine to be approved without proper testing and rushed to market. Trump is desperate to improve his poll numbers and would do anything to look like the savior before the election. I will wait for science to prove a vaccine is safe and effective before partaking.

The perfect vaccine would cure everyone, and sadly that isn't the case.  We aren't yet t the point in medicine where we have designer medicines for each known gene type of human, geared to each person's own DNA, RNA and other factors, that is where we hope to get.  Yet not being there yet doesn't mean we stop all vaccines, or medicines being taken.  

Fast tracking the current batches of vaccines to help the world with Covid-19 has it's risks, as does having no vaccine at all.  While I know there have been issues in the past, helping the planet get over a deadly serious virus is a must.  Even if some people won't want to take a vaccine for it.  It's a risk that 8 billion people will have to take, in order to protect as many as possible.

Trump might be a bane for the cure of the USA,  Yet he isn't the only world leader, we are only a small fraction of t he world and until we start thinking as a whole planet, we will be doomed to fight like babies on it.  Grow Up you Humans.
I won't be getting any vaccine (or anything else) made from Trump Snake Oil. If it is pushed by Trump and just happens to appear by November 3, no way.

Unfortunately, I would hesitate to try any vaccine that was rushed through the clinical trial process in time to be released under a Trump administration.   We have seen how the Trump administration at all levels politicizes and manipulates scientific and medical information (e.g. hydroxychloroquine's approval as a "game changer").  If you want to vaccinate a couple of hundred million people without killing or injuring many thousands, you need to take the time to get it right.

Save me from my fellow Americans, the most poorly informed citizens in recent decades. They imperil us more than anything, and they enable the ridiculous lack of leadership by our equally uninformed and ignorant "leaders." Maybe it's true, vaccines have made them all stupid.
Absolutely we need an effective vaccine ASAP, but not if they think they can use poor blacks and Hispanics as their guinea pigs.   Try it out on some rich white people and see how that goes.

Look at it this way - do you want to be the only country in the world too stupid to try to mitigate the pandemic? Me - masked, sanitizing and limiting crowd exposure. Maybe I can sneak back to Canada - self quarantined of course.

Before I get a COVID19 vaccination, I want to know how safe it is (after the 2nd shot, if there are 2 shots) for my age group, as well as its effectiveness to prevent or ameliorate the disease in my age group.  I also want to know how safe and effective it is if combined with a better vaccine when that comes out, perhaps a few months later.  Finally, I want to know how long the vaccine is effective.  If it’s only effective for a short but indeterminate time, how am I going to go about living a pre-COVID life?  If I’m going to still have to wear a mask and divorce myself from other humans what’s the point of taking it?
Just because the CDC, FDA, Dr. Fauci, the Republican administration, and hungry businesses want to push a hastily produced vaccine on us, doesn’t mean its ultimately safe. I’m not going to take their word for it this time.  I don’t like how so many people that are involved in this have either made serious mistakes because they didn’t know enough about the disease to recommend something (we’re safe at this time, no we’re not; masks aren’t necessary, yes they are, etc), or because they’re afraid of going against what Trump wants.
Finally, remember Thalidomide?  I don’t think that today we have a Francis Kelsey in the FDA to protect us.

This is not about creating a better marketing campaign for the vaccine. This is about the fact that it is not possible to ensure efficacy, much less safety, in such a short time period. I would say that any vaccine that's availabe at the end of the year or even two years from now will not have been appropriately tested. This has nothing to do with politics. It has to do with facts.

My children are fully vaccinated. We get flu shots every year.  We are not in a high risk group for covid-19, although we have elderly family members.  We wear masks when we leave the house. We have avoided large groups of people. However, I am wary of a vaccine that would make it to market so quickly. I would need assurance from scientists I trust regarding the safety of the vaccine.

This is a very disheartening article. In the 21st century in the US ignorance and lack of faith in science abounds. Any one not in a high risk category will have to wait to get a vaccine any how. So most people will not be in the first wave. Hopefully when their turn comes they will do the right thing for them and their families and get vaccinated. As some one who grew up during the polio epidemic, our working class parents and all Americans took their families to the vaccination centers as soon as they could. Today we have supposedly mode educated people but some of them are simply still ignorant. Once it becomes apparent there is a significant number that are so ignorant and selfish the will not get vaccinated, then sanctions will start. No vaccination? You are now quarantined. Period. Kanye West? Mark of the beast? Wow. Not just ignorant. Stupid. Flat earth as well? Methinks there is a lot of overlap in such thinking.....

The president could help all of us by not opining on scientific data.  It would also help if investigators and companies would not present incomplete and early data in press releases, which leads to the belief companies are not being careful.  However, the racial narrative is unfair as companies are being criticized for lack of racial diversity in trials at the same time they are being criticized for “experimenting” on minorities.

I have been out in public for less than 8 hours since March 1 (my wife, 0 hours) and then only to grocery shop.  I wear essentially a scuba outfit for these excursions.  This is a pain and a vaccine would mean finally being able to eat a meal not cooked at home.

But I'm not in any rush.  Turns out my life is pretty sweet isolated here in the woods.  So I can afford to be at the end of the line.  Let those who MUST be out get protected first, I can wait patiently.

Please notice just because I'm not champing at the bit to get a shot, I am not a brainless idiot.  I know not being vaccinated means I must stick to my once-per-three-week scuba outings, but I am very willing and able to do so.

I will get the shot.  But you first.

Given the current administration's lying, ineptitude,  and lack of transparency (not to mention our great leader's advice that we inject bleach), of course people won't trust the first vaccine out of the gate: let someone else be a guinea pig.

Vaccination, sure, for centuries.
This one?  Pushed by Trump?  You go first.

Start by taking away some of the free oxygen furnished to quackery shills whose claim to attention is a famous father, a centerfold or some hit records.
Let's limit the TV interviews to people with an immunology credential.
I will be first in line for the EU or South Korean approved vaccine.
I’m getting a vaccine and I’m gonna push it on everyone else too.

I want to bring attention to this comment by @Margareta from Canada:   "Would you be more confident of a vaccine if you knew it was approved by Health Canada, or by regulatory agencies in other countries? Any vaccine contenders that make it to the approval stage would be under review in multiple countries, not just in the US." I think this is a good point. The whole world is seeking a vaccine.

I am in the at-risk group of those hoping for a safe and effective vaccine.  I had hoped to travel again but that has to wait until a vaccine is available otherwise getting on an airplane scares me.  Being a pediatrician, I have dealt with reluctant parents in my practice.  They rarely have informed reasons to skip their child's vaccines.  The do however understand deep down that their child benefits from the herd immunity created by other parents efforts to protect their own children.
I doubt such a vaccine will be ready before November 3rd, but I don't doubt that one will be touted by the soon to be outgoing president.

Do people not remember all of the issues that vaccines have addressed? I’m old enough to remember my aunt crippled by polio and many others who suffered with a variety of diseases.

I’m over 65, diabetic and today I signed up to be a volunteer for the next round of testing. Bring it on!

If the vaccine is developed and produced outside this country I would consider it to be safe and effective.  After the unfathomable failures of the CDC, FDA, HHS and NIH over the past 6 months, it is impossible to believe that any product they develop has been rigorously tested and proven effective to scientific standards.

I am an adamantly pro-vaccine mother and all my kids get them regularly, but as a biomedical professional, I will not allow any of my family members to receive a COVID-19 vaccine unless it has been vetted for many years. Even the fastest-produced vaccines have required at least 5 years, and attempts to rush or "fast-track" them in the past--notably for RSV and dengue fever--have had catastrophic consequences, killing and injuring thousands of kids and adults and building a well of permanent mistrust. 

Appeals to headstarts in development miss why vaccines inevitably take a long time to get right. The development is the comparatively easy part. The time lag is because vaccines are given to healthy people, not sick patients, and there is very little margin for error in an area that is very error-prone. Vaccines aren't drugs--they're stimuli for our complex, still poorly-understood immune systems, and it takes many years to fully ascertain the unanticipated effects, unknown interactions with physiological components and other infectious agents, to make them safe. The rushed dengue vaccine had impeccable early results before it was found to actually potentiate fatal infection, and an HIV vaccine candidate would have itself recombined and led to AIDS in millions of people. We've already learned that COVID-19 antibodies wane quickly and people are getting re-infected, meaning boosters would likely be necessary. For such multiple immunizations, great caution and time are necessary.

This is fine.  Never mind herd immunity.  I will take the vaccine and be protected for at least a year when I will take a booster if needed.  Those who are vaccine skeptics are free to not take the shot and catch the disease.

Project Warp Speed is not about skipping or rushing through steps.  It's about taking the economic risk of taking product and process development steps simultaneously instead of sequentially.   Finding any drug (including vaccines) to be safe and effective requires clinical testing and most fail, so drug companies normally will rationally wait and see for success in one step before sequentially investing in the next step in the process of development all the way to manufacturing.  Project Warp Speed looks to cover the developer's financial risks carrying out overlapping steps to reduce timelines, for example, to invest in large scale manufacturing before safety/efficacy/FDA approval are achieved is normally not financially prudent so the government is subsidizing companies to take this risk.  Ideally, prior to approval, vaccine will be manufactured at risk and large inventory and distribution networks put in place to speedily provide widespread access to the public very soon after the vaccine has been proven safe and effective.  All due care should be taken to assure such safety and efficacy and this should be transparently communicated to the public to achieve a successful vaccine campaign.

	• Before it was withdrawn, the FDA assured consumers that Rezulin’s potential benefits outweighed its grave risks.
	• Since early 1980’s, drug companies knew the FDA might ban PPA, but it was not banned until after the NEJM published a definitive Yale epidemiologic study in 2000.

I am a professor in a microbiology department, and although I am not an immunologist, I can say that the safety of any Covid-19 vaccine is a very real issue.  Some coronaviruses, including SARS, MERS, and SARS-CoV-2 (the cause of Covid-19), are subject to something called "Antibody Dependent Enhancement", or "ADE".  This is when antibodies against the virus help the virus infect a subset of immune cells.  When there is ADE, low levels of antibodies can make the disease more severe than if there were no antibodies at all.  A recent paper about this is "Implications of antibody-dependent enhancement of infection for SARS-CoV-2 countermeasures" by Eroshenko, Gill, Keaveney, Church, Trevejo & Rajaniemi, Nature Biotechnology vol. 38, pg 789–791(2020).  (There are many other published papers on the subject.)  The fear is that with some vaccines, antibody levels will drop with time, and at some point (6 months, a year) will allow infection with SARS-CoV-2 and ADE, and the disease will be worse than with no vaccine.  Although this scenario is probably unlikely, it could be very, very bad if it does come to pass.  It is hard to be sure that a vaccine will not lead to antibody-dependent enhancement without lengthy testing.

Nearly a hundred years ago the Supreme Court declared that mandatory vaccination was permissible as long as four standards were met.

There must be “necessity . . .; reasonable means . . .; proportionality . . .; and harm avoidance.”

Is a vaccine really necessary? This is basically a risk/benefit analysis. We know vaccines cause harm. This is why there is a separate Vaccine Court to adjudicate those claims. But do the benefits sufficiently outweigh the harm?

Will herd immunity suffice? What about mutations?

So far there is still so much we don't know about Covid that should be sorted out before mandating a vaccine.

Another aspect of "necessity" is an examination of alternative methods of treatment.

Despite the sparse reporting in the mass media a number of front line doctors are using successful alternative therapies, some which have had 100% recovery rates.

Then there is Taiwan, Vietnam, Iceland, Costa Rico, even Japan with much lower infection and mortality rates than the US. All accomplished without a vaccine.

Even in the US 98.5% of those infected recover and 83% of fatalities have been in people over 65. Do we really need to vaccinate everyone to protect a discrete, identifiable population?

Finally, Covid disrupts our immune system. There is no drug remedy and even a vaccine is not likely to be more than 50% effective.

Why not a national program to strengthen immunity before resorting to an expensive, medically questionable vaccine that may not be necessary?

I want so much to have a Covid-19 vaccine--but I also want to get the new shingles vaccine, Shingrix, which is mentioned several times in the article, yet I haven't. Why?
1. In clinical trials, Shingrix was not associated with serious adverse events.
2. But people with with autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, were excluded from the clinical trials. So if you're one of the 25 million or so Americans, you don't know if the vaccine is safe for you.
3. In fact, the CDC says,"While Shingrix is not contraindicated in immunocompromised persons, it is not recommended by ACIP at this time." 
  Not one of my doctors seems to know this. They've told me it's a dead virus, thus safe. But Shingrix has a powerful adjuvant, never used before.
4. We now get vaccinated vs chickenpox, so the market for Shingrix is short-term: people who've had chickenpox. But it's huge dollars in profit.
5. Benefits are given in relative numbers, but adverse effects in absolute numbers--a form of lie. 97% effective does NOT mean that only 3% get the disease.

@Neil, the US has tested 45 million people. India 12 million. The USA is testing roughly 3.5x the number of people that India is.

India says it has 1 million positive cases. Let us multiply that by 3.5 to account for the reduced testing. So, India and the US likely have roughly the same number of positive cases.

The difference is that India has a population density of 455 people per square km. The US number is 36, which is less by a factor of 12.

Taking these numbers into account, if the Indian government was only as effective as the US government, India should have been reporting 12 million cases by now (even with its reduced testing rates). It is reporting 1 million - what does that tell you?

The local municipal officials quarantined the whole street and de-sanitized it. That’s a lot more than what I had expected, in fact more than what’s being done in most of California.

India had done quite well, given the circumstances.

I consider myself extremely lucky- I moved out of my NJ home after 33 years to NH last July.

It took every ounce of strength to leave family and friends for a quieter life, sort my priorities out and head 350 miles away.

In our 60's, with some health issues, we've been quite careful.  We're in an area with no county deaths, no hospital cases,
with beautiful scenery to enjoy while we've laid low.

Consequently, tourists have jammed our town for the summer, snapping up homes within hours of being listed, and we avoid mingling as much as possible when downtown, shopping off-times and staying masked around others. 

 I miss my son in LA who refuses to take a chance on a 6 hr plane ride to visit this summer, but I appreciate his concern to avoid inadvertently infecting us. My other son took a test, flew up last week on a 2 hr trip, and we enjoyed outside activities daily for a week.  

While I don't want to isolate for another year (or more), even though the death rates are extremely low, I don't want to take a chance of getting this virus or giving it to my husband.  
 
Everyone's life has been affected by this- we may be in a different boat, but it's the same storm.

We can only hope that the medical pros working on vaccines and treatment will have some lightbulb moments shortly.

At 74, with kidney disease, diabetes, I have not been in a store since March 15.  A younger sister in Michigan, died from Covid in April. A planned week at the beach in June with kids and grandkids, was them and my wife, I stayed home.

I’m 70, living alone, in good health with no conditions but age that would make me vulnerable to the virus. I also have been working remotely since our small office closed four months ago. Recently we were asked to return to work onsite 50% of the time. Protocols were in place with staggered work schedules, sanitizers, temperature taking etc. I was shocked, day after day, to find security guards doing temp checks without masks, younger people walking the halls without masks, and no safe ventilation system in place. When the person I share a workspace with - hired by her mother who heads Human Resources - decided to just show up on my day, I left the premises for my own safety. Imagine my further dismay to then learn that the Mayor of my tourist town won’t mandate masks for people, most from out of state, walking in and out of stores on Main St.

So what does an older person like me do? If we have to work and value our safety we could get fired by the organization that doesn’t want to be responsible itself, puts all its employees at risk yet puts the ‘blame’ on us for being older. The decisions we have to make to insure our safety and continue to make a living and the anxiety we live with can be daunting. My sleepless nights are about that as much as about getting sick alone.

Although old and with co-morbidities my husband and I are loners. Always were, always will be. Now that we are both retired, as long as I have a book to read, a garden to tend and he an old movie to watch we are quite happy by ourselves.
We've seen all we want to see of the real world and we can facetime the kids/grandkids.

We have also cancelled all plans of travel.

So, what to do:
 - Increase the charity budget, we found a local need and set up a matching campaign. Making calls to other friends to invite participation is a great way to catch up
 - Get politically involved. I now have more Zoom invites for organizing than I have time time for.
 - In the words of Buddha, "Get outside the castle." We connected with the bartender who provided excellent service and we got to know when we were in Manhattan last January. He and his family have been hunkered down in Brooklyn since March with jobs long gone. We are assisting their family with covering the rent. Their lives are not only different, they are difficult.

I have not been inside a big store since March 12th. I am 72 with a stent in my heart. I am lucky my kids do all my grocery shopping for me,my pharmacy still does curb side as does the liquor store.I do go to outdoor farmers markets and garden centers. I am lucky and live in Massachusetts where 99% of population wear masks. We can also open our windows a lot because we don't have to use AC all the time. I don't go to restaurants either inside or out. I do get take out and then eat with one other friend outside.I live alone so the winter and spring were hard,not able to see grandchildren except at a distance.Myself and friends will continue mostly distancing until there is a vaccine. Everyone has to make their own decisions but the least everyone can do is wear a mask.

This article completely misses the real issue with COVID deaths among the elderly:  nursing homes!

Half of all deaths nationally are due to residents of nursing homes and assisted living facilities.  This is due to spreading by low-paid nursing assistants and orderlies, who typically work odd hours in multiple facilities.  All such workers need to have their temperatures taken every day.

One other thing that elderly residents of nursing homes should be doing is taking Vitamin D supplements, 1000-2000 IU/day.  Recent research has shown a very strong correlation between low Vitamin D level and the severity of COVID.  This can save lives!
finally in my septuagenarian bliss I have become current in the prevailing millennial and below meme - doom-scrolling - thanks for this apropos and timely article

I am a senior. We are getting very mixed messages. On the one hand, we are being told to stay home and isolate. On the other hand, we are being encouraged to go out and help local businesses. Cases are surging. But, to be honest, I don't know anyone who has had Covid-19; only a few friends of friends who have been effected. Masks seem like a simple way of allowing more freedom -- to go out, to see others, to prevent the spread of disease but has become a weird political issue. It's all very confusing.

My husband and I are over 65, and are healthy and active. We've been isolating since March, and we go nowhere. I filled my gas tank yesterday for the first time since February. So what can we do? Every year we go canoe camping in the Adirondacks in NY, and we're thinking about a 3-night trip mid-week near the end of July.  Once we're there, we're totally isolated, but it is a 7-hour drive.  NY is doing so well, with new cases and deaths even lower than Pennsylvania.  Cross fingers that we can go.

Yes, there are lots of us 65+'ers who are making these benefit/risk calculations.  The NYT had a piece a couple months ago where they presented the risks of different types of businesses graphically--that was extremely useful for decision making and I'd suggest those reporters update and republish that analysis.

Now we're living in coastal DE--have to figure out how to update the location in my signature.  DE was doing pretty good vis a vis the virus, and then the tourist season started.  We've patronized restaurants via take-out, hoping to help them avoid going out of business.  Just one sit-down restaurant meal since this started--at a place that consists of an outdoor deck overlooking the ocean. No haircut in 5+ months--hair appearance doesn't register much on the benefit side of the equation at my age.  Big grocery trips spaced 2 weeks apart take care of need while minimizing exposure.  Brief visits to Home Depot and the like, because the risks there are pretty low.  Trips to places like NYC for shows and high end restaurants are sorely missed.

The total lack of a coordinated Federal response for Covid-19 is, for me, criminal.  No one in the W.H. or at presidential appointee level (with few exceptions--e.g., NIH Director Collins) should ever have any public or private role that requires responsibility again, since they've washed their hands of responsibility and just about every other positive human trait during our 3+ year long debacle.

My husband, who has survived 2 strokes, and I are over 65, and live in Florida.  I go only where I have to, but I'm always afraid, because people will not wear masks.  And they will tell you so.  Loudly.

“It is not clear that rationality is an adaptive evolutionary characteristic.“ 					
				Stephen Hawking

Good advice.
As always, take personal responsibility.
The article closes with a hopeful note on flying to London in September. It would be useful to add the notation that Europe is closed to Americans at the present time.

I will self-isolate at least until November.  

I owe that much to my grandchildren.

It shouldn't be too stressful if, like this older couple, you live in what looks like a spacious three bedroom house with a front yard. Lets hear stories about older folks who live alone or in small apartments.

Trump works to undermine health experts. Masks should have been mandatory months ago. Masks could have saved lives, and the economy. We are living in a country run by self centered ego maniacs who have no regard for human life even though they are against abortion. To make things worse, the government isn’t issuing helpful information that would help reduce risks. It’s every man, woman, and their family on their own. Figure it out and proceed accordingly. Even if the current administration started behaving appropriately, I’ve lost all trust in them.

It's so local.  Here in the NE hopefully seniors feel more at ease now, of course still taking precautions when out etc.  But down in FL my elderly relatives are furious.  They were just starting to feel more at ease then BOOM!  Cases start blowing up all around them.  Now they're stuck at home again.
It's fortunate if you can afford grocery delivery services. Gloves on the tennis court are no great hardship. Most essential workers probably don't get to play tennis at all.

I don’t lose sleep over a little old lost vacation. What worries me is having an accident or developing some kind non-Covid medical issue that forces me to go to a hospital or worse, one of those cattle call surgery centers. I don’t care who laughs that I put on my bike helmet to clean the gutters.

Is your life worth a visit to some friends/family or a trip to London?
After a vaccine is developed do what you want - for now, play it smart.

So while the Trump Administration has been communicating the same message for months about the virus for the elderly and others most at risk that the article conveys, the NYT’s narrative about the pandemic excludes that the message from the White House is no different concerning protecting the people needing the most protection.

So if the Trump Administration has been giving a false or over optimistic message concerning the pandemic as many media organizations including the NYT have been pushing since March, then what’s different about this New York Times article?

The answer is nothing is different. However, since NYT’s over zealous disdain for President Trump since the 2016 election is well documented in the NYT’s own archives, so if the message that the President and his administration has been “deadly” then the NYT is equally and directly contributing to the harsh realities of the pandemic by publishing this article. When this NYT article includes statements that people at risk need to assess their own circumstances, there is an underlying suggestion of go ahead and “take” the risk, because you might have other interests other than dying.
When your children are seniors you decide it is time to be very cautious in your own life.

Not really helpful. Advice that seniors whose only interest is not dying should stay home is the kind of snarky comment you'd expect from an economist. The ballyhooed Cleveland Risk Calculator asks what state you live in and whether there is a sick person in your home. Don't waste your time waiting for it to download.  A useful article on how to think about Covid and one's risk tolerance is yet to be written.
Good luck on the UK visit - hopefully the Nathans are aware of UK travel restrictions including a 14 day lockdown upon entry.

The President's inactions, and now actions, are going to kill many of us.  I am 72, in good health, and dare not venture out anywhere in public where there may be a crowd.  Too many are still not wearing masks even in progressive Minnesota!.  The pandemic is getting worse not better, and our administration is befuddled. Why are we not testing?  Why is the administration not pushing proper pandemic behaviors....like mask wearing and shutting down mass gatherings?  Why are we the only nation on earth that cannot find the will to get this under control?  Donald Trump needs to go.  I don't want to die because he is too stupid to act.
Has there been any research into the use of indoor fans when cracking a window is not possible?
Why are the disabled under 65 years of age left out of articles. I'm immune compromised. Give me some of that plastic wrap.

I'm at triple risk: Are 83, Type 2 Diabetes, heart problems, Fortunately, I live in a 3-level adult campus with truly excellent care and prevention. But I want to get out...go shopping someplace other than at 6 a.m., eat a fine dinner. But I don't. The thought of being on a ventilator makes me too afraid. I hope the gov't. decides to give the vaccine to Srs. first, as the death statistics for us are appalling.

I also stay away from friends not wearing masks. Whoever thought wearing a mask threatened their freedom? How foolish. You wear pants, don't you? Is this what our educational system as produced...idiots?

Let’s never forget:

August 2016, a campaigning Trump asked, “. . . what the hell do you have to lose?”

Answers:

- Your life
- Your health
- Everything 

VOTE

The one thing that rings clear as a bell in all these articles, in all media is, the lack of coordinated nationwide response and information. As an outsider, it's amazing to think that intelligent citizens would not know the answers to all of this by now (no blame being assigned other than at the top - speaking of which I gather the WH has removed the CDC stats from their website.) It's astounding to to the outside world. Reeks of banana republic.

That said, it's easy for me to say because I have trusted sources of information in Canada. Not that we will fare any better in coming surges - and there will be - no smugness here, we have anti-maskers and the whole nut bar youtube-as-news gang here also. 

But honest to god, what's a literate person in the US to do? I'd say, listen to Dr. Fauci. CNN has good doctors on also - Dr. Wen and Dr. Gupta. And for really good and balanced news, check The Guardian and CBC Canada. When you're not reading the NYT of course.

Being 80 and healthy, these days, means you probably have more years ahead of you. Being 80 and healthy, but catching the virus, means you probably don't. 
Seems a no-brainer to me. To maximize your chances of enjoying life with your extended family, stay home until there's a vaccine. Whether or not your state, county or town is 'open'. 
As for that London holiday (airport, airplanes, and sitting in a theatre crowd repeatedly at the end of it)...what is this loving wife thinking ?!?

Reading through the comments there is a thread of anxiety which is one of the worst effects from this illness.  In thinking about this I looked back at my own life and found that anxiety has always been part of everything.  There are no guarantees ever that disaster cannot strike and older folks understand this concept.  Each person needs to find a way to stay involved, study on ways to stay safe, maintain a regular schedule, and find something pleasurable to do each day.  I look at this as a temporary moment like many before and can be overcome with planning and intellect.

I'm an over 65 diabetic navigating the gauntlet, trying to getmy basic needs met in the safest ways possible.  Let's face it---life is much more restrictive than what we've known most of our lives.  One thing you can do that will make two people feel better is to get on the phone and touch base with others in the same boat.  No email, no texting.  Share voices.  Old bridge friends, church members, what have you.  Many folks live alone, and could use the social intimacy that a phone call could give.  We're all feeling the effects of the pandemic, but some of us cope better than others.  Reach out.  Pick up that phone.

Here is my take as a physician who has cared for hundreds of Coronavirus patients of different severities.  I am a dialysis doctor and my pateints are at the highest of risk in all categories.   What I tell them is that they should avoid COVID-19 at ALL costs.  BUT BUT BUT BUT , this is the most important part,  do NOT despair if you should catch it.   While many of my patients have been sickened,  far more shrugged it off quite easily.   Statistically speaking MOST of the deaths were in these risk groups, but do not foget that MOST people in these risk groups will be just fine after the infection.   We tend to look at the risk from assessing who got sick and died.  We often forget to look at the patients who got sick and lived!   Be safe and cautious but stay realistic about the risks.  Otherwise, life is not worth living for millions of older Americans who are shuttered up in their homes away from family for the rest of time.

Hopeful talk, but keep in mind:  (1) the virus has not changed, no matter how much you want to socialize.  (2) as more people become infected and carriers, your chance of encountering it increases too. (3)  you cannot identify unwitting carriers.  No matter how much you love your grandchildren, they may be carriers. (5) a carrier does not have to cough or sneeze to spread the virus. Talking and laughing can as well.  (6) air circulation, even indoors, can spread the virus beyond six feet.

This article focuses on a narrow swath of culture and class, ignoring the problems of multigenerational families. What about grandparents (or great-grandparents) raising or living with school-age kids? Age segregation is far more common in Bethesda, Maryland, than it is a few miles away in D.C. or in places across the country where families value age-integration or have formed multi-generational households under economic duress. 

For those seniors, the question is not whether to take a break by a lake but how to keep themselves safe while living with younger family members who must circulate—and who depend on them.

Being on lockdown was ok. Everyone was in the same boat. Now I have to make decisions on what to do, where to go. With no family nearby, it's quite stressfull. I might not get infected but corona virus has definitely made me sick with anxiety. Literally, I awake each morning feeling stressed. I'm sure it's taking a toll.

I'm 66, have mild COPD, asthma, and sleep apnea. You can be darned sure that I'm not going to Lake Placid or anywhere else.

Such is modern communications that sheltering at home is no great hardship, at least for those of us who don't live alone.

18 months is a long time in which to be taking risks. What seems like a small risk on a given day becomes a significant risk when multiplied by 547.

I don't gainsay anyone the right to take a chance, but as I don't want to spend the rest of my life gasping for breath or intellectually impaired or spending two weeks on a respirator, I'll stay right where I am.
It’s telling that travel to Lake Placid or London is even on the table when jobs and food are so scare for most people.

It's too early for anyone with comorbidities to emerge. We'll all have to wait for vaccines, and/or cheap rapid tests such that every American can test themselves every morning, allowing self-quarantine decisions to be made on a timely basis, as well as determining who may enter a closed space.

Every day is day one for me. I get up, make some coffee, and look at the news about the virus. This is so I can soberly assess the likely hood of my or my wife’s exposure to COVID-19. While there’s nothing big planned in our lives , there are still lots of little things for us , and little things add up. I’m 68 and plan on living to at least 85 (I’ll reassess that decision when I get there and may extend an option for 5 more years when the time comes).

For an 80 year-old, 18 months of lockdown is a heavy price to pay as it very well could mean lockdown until death.   This discussion of risk, therefore, has to include more than individual risk of becoming ill with covid-19; it must also include the risk that the elderly individual spends the entirety of his remaining life (or a very large percentage) stuck in his home away from family and friends. Yes, the social benefit of reduced hospitalizations is in the equation too, but all risks must be considered.

My husband and I, at 83 years, are in the same boat as many other financially stable and healthy older people who responded to this article.  It is with grateful hearts that we enjoy living comfortably in our own large home, not in a senior facility or nursing home.  Our park-like back yard with old trees, garden flowers, birds, bunnies, ground hogs and deer are a source of both pleasure and work.  Though we had to give up our annual family vacation reunion in Maine this summer,  I can relive memories with photographs of past ones posted on Facebook to the delight of grandkids who enjoy recalling their childhood memories of fun in coastal Maine.  We are grateful that all our middle-aged children are still working, mainly on-line, but their children, in college or graduated, are limited in career prospects just at the stage in life when fulfilling ambitions and dreams was about to happen.  It is their future, both professional and as citizens of this dying democracy and dying planet that we mourn...not our "golden years" tarnished by the pandemic as it may be.

If more Americans were consistent in wearing masks, observing the physical distancing rules, and not seeing taking precautions as a political statement some of the extreme caution we're seeing would not be necessary.  We would not be witnessing a resurgence in California, new hot spots and shortages of PPE, etc.  

Yes, life is full of risks.  But we have an administration and a number of governors who think that chaos is best.  So we're left to make our own decisions based upon a lack of good information.  This is what we get when we vote for people who vow to shrink the government:  bad government.

Wear a mask.
Wash your hands.
Keep your distance.
Laugh a little every day.

An otherwise healthy friend in his 70s just underwent a totally elective open-heart operation (asymptomatic mitral valve repair). So far, so good, but he just played Russian roulette. I think he was foolhardy. I'm not enjoying isolation, but I am reading more, learning more, thinking more, and doing other things in hopes of surviving to spend several more years enjoying "real" life after this passes. This is a time for prolonged patience, lest we all become short-lived patients.

Elders now know the risks.
If they choose to leave their homes, they assume the risk. They have the right to make that decision. 

Once they leave their house for anything other than food or medicine, though, they lose the right to worry or insist that other people undergo draconian measures to keep them safe.  

Just do not go out in public to nonessential places and then complain about what other people in those places are doing.
  
If the virus is airborne and can be absorbed by your eyes, all of the masks in the world will only a make a tiny difference.  Elders are responsible for keeping themselves safe.

Living in Arizona, where it's been in the triple digits most days, I'm  stuck in the house from 9 a.m. til bedtime anyway.  I swim or walk and go to the grocery store very early in the morning.  It's always like this in the summer.  I live by myself and am 75 with no health problems.  I call friends most days.  The anxious part for me is listening to and reading the news.

Arizona has the dubious distinction of experiencing the highest per capita incidence of COVID in the US. In fact, statewide, we have fewer than 200 ICU beds meaning we are overwhelmed. Nevertheless, republican Gov Doug Ducey refuses to implement stringent measures that have mitigated the disease in other states. Such a position is counterproductive to the safety of all people, especially seniors, but it's counterproductive for business which is that segment republicans are supposed to represent.

I call upon Gov Ducey to revise his stance, learn from NY Gov Cuomo, and implement policies so Arizonans can shop and enjoy this beautiful place.

The Cleveland Clinic calculator produces suspicious results.  After putting in my info... I got a result of 1.8%... encouraging.   I tinkered with it... I've never smoked.  The result if I was a former smoker is: 1.5% and as a current smoker: 0.5%. Cigarette companies must love this news.  I don't believe it.

My wife and I are 71. Our daughter and son in law moved to London in November’19. We’ve been to other places in Europe, but never London. We had planned a trip to see them in April. That of course didn’t happen. We had a flat secured and British Airways vouchers for a rescheduled trip in December. That trip will not happen. Too soon to be in airports or airplanes. We used to think travel was essential. Right now, a vaccine is essential before travel can resume that position.

Going “shopping” is a big NO! for me. As a cancer survivor, my sinuses are gone, removed during two separate surgeries. With zero filtration, air that comes through either mouth or nose, takes the same path: in and straight to the lungs. Mask is not even a question, it is a requirement. Food is either at home (home-cooked meal delivery) or curbside. Even curbside has risks, if I see missing masks, I walk away. Hungry beats dead. Apart from frequent outdoor walks (rural path), I am in lockdown mode, and will be for a while.

The headline reads, "How Do You Calculate Coronavirus Risk...?"  According to the article, as states and cities reopen, re-close, etc., "the calculations grow steadily more complicated."

This suggests that there is a rational basis on which to make such calculations, that the information is getting better, and that the article is presenting us with such information.  But it seems to me that this is not the case.  I don't see how we have good information about this at all.  Given the way areas that seemed to have the virus under control are now seeing more infections, the decision to get a haircut, to have book group meetings, or to meet with one's son, daughter-in-law, and two grandchildren seem to me largely subjective.  That is what the people described here are choosing, but I don't see what's rational about it or how we know that it's rational.  I am thinking of the article a few days ago by Edgar Sandoval about the families in McAllen, Texas.

It seems to me that if somebody really wants a haircut then they will get a haircut, but I don't see how any good information goes into a calculation about it.

Frankly I’m not behaving any differently from when all this began. It seems when people start taking fewer precautions the case numbers increase. I saw an article on what Fauci and other epidemiologists are currently doing — which isn’t a whole lot — and what they are NOT doing, which is more to the point.
Air travel — No! 
Dentist — No! 
Hair cut — maybe if no others in the facility and masks are worn and instruments and chair and so on are cleaned properly. 
Working out inside at the gym — No!
Seeing other people — only outside keeping distance and wearing masks

Being 82 years old, it terrified me to read that "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported, based on March data, that Covid-19 hospitalizations rise with age, from about 12 percent among those 65 to 74 years old to 17 percent for those over 85."  However, checking the graph provided in the linked CDC report, I found they were talking about hospitalizations per 100k (i.e., per one hundred thousand) rather than percent.  A little k makes a big difference!   Or am I missing something?  Please clarify.

I'm 70. I like to shoot. I used to shoot competition. I shoot indoors or used to. The range began with shutting every other booth, enforcing masks and limiting the number of people. That changed. 

I'd like to go but I'm not. My decision in part was based upon my experience working in a Toyota dealership (a few years back) where people would come in dripping sweat from a fever and we were supposed to get up close take their CC and drivers license for documentation. Up to that point I had not had the flu in a few decades. I got it twice. 

Back to the range, two young women in the next booth (supposed to be 2 booths down once upon a time)sneezing and hacking, I was gone. They do test for fever but still the distancing is not being enforced the last time I was there. I could get C19 and croak.

 I've come close to drowning a few times (dumb stuff as a kid). I would not recommend it even though once you're dead you're dead.

Like many writing here, I share the co-morbidities. My  tween grandkids are 2 hours away - it might as well be the backside of the moon - except for the ability to Zoom or otherwise videoconference. The grands are in our state's #2 hotspot but the kids' parents and our remaining local child (41) still have to work. We have marshaled our savings and frugal lifestyle to be sure we have the wherewithal to cover *their* daily lives when the inevitable job-income gap arises. 

Yes, we are sacrificing their company (painfully) against the day that recovery can start (Bill Gates' Science Day?). When I want to feel  lucky, more and more I look at video and picture coverage of the ROW, realizing they have to recover as well. Also, my parents were separated for much of the Cold War and our current separation doesn't hold a candle to WWI, WWII, Korean War, Vietnam War, Middle East Wars 1, 2 and 3.  The heartbreaking difference is the poor leadership at the top - but we can change that too!

The Governor of Florida keeps congratulating himself for "protecting Florida's seniors".

But what does this mean?

My wife and I have not been able to visit my 92 year old mother-in-law for 5 months. She lives in an apartment in a nice independent living facility, but she and the rest of Florida seniors are effectively "prisoners" in their own homes cut off from human interaction with loved ones. With the exception of delivery of meals they are cut off from any human contacts. Such is the life that Governor Desantis has forced upon Florida seniors in their final years because of his reckless "reopening" before Florida was ready and before he developed any plan for a safe reopening. 

And for what purpose did Desantis rush the reopening? Not for the benefit of Florida seniors, but more for the perceived political benefit of Donald Trump.

His incompetence is matched only by his callousness and as a result he is killing Floridians as Trump is destroying the United States.

As Florida Covid-19 cases and deaths skyrocket, Desantis refuses to order mandatory mask wearing throughout the state, which at this point should be considered the absolute minimum response.

Florida desperately needs another stay at home order immediately if we are to avert an apocalypse.

Clearly Nancy hasn't considered that, we Americans, are no longer allowed entrance into Britain or any other European country at this time. Though we can go to the Caribbean- there are 10 or so countries that will let us in to vacation there. of course, there's no telling what their Corona Virus rate of infection is.
Oh, the places we shall go once this virus is under control!
We need to get our own house in order so that we don't spread it more globally.

Let’s face it, this would never have gotten this serious if a rational person lived in the White House. Not too late to save the planet.

Vote Democratic in 2020!

Please don't use "seniors" to refer to this population. What does it mean: over 65, over 60, over 50? Pick a threshold and say it! My first reaction on seeing the headline was that the article referred to high school or college seniors. In that context, the word means something. Otherwise, it potentially refers to nearly half the population. In discussing a medical risk like COVID-19, more precise language helps.

Many of us responding to this op-ed have parents, Uncles, or Aunts who served during WW2 with many giving the ultimate sacrifice. That's just one war I'm mentioning. 
I can hang out with my wife, have groceries delivered and enjoy some nature for a few years if necessary and still not come close to the sacrifice of so many others in this country.
I'll have to say though it does blow my mind that someone would be willing to not wear a mask and die or infect a loved one just to make some stupid political statement for the likes of a con artist like donald.   Politics in this country has become nothing more than a scene from "The Joker."   There's not a person on this planet that can logically explain that mindset to me.

I am a healthy older adult. Yet, after several months, I am still practicing social distancing, avoiding most real life contact with friends and family until a proven vaccine is available. I see friends for short and distanced walks wearing face coverings, not spending time with them indoors. Aside from these walks we chat on the phone or Zoom. Being patient is more important to me than taking risks with short-term pleasures right now. Sure, it's stressful. But at least I know I will continue to live a healthy life and be able to socialize with my loved ones soon.
Do not go. It's very simple - do not go. I don't get haircuts either - I bought some clippers. Don't feel guilty, just don't go. The virus doesn't know, or care, about your family.

It is interesting that comments here identify class/wealth issues as fundamental and hierarchical, when the article was about the problematics of choice in an environment where risks are hard to calculate and calibrate - largely because the national government has failed and is deliberately making things worse. There is a continuum of circumstances in which choices are harder and more consequential - particularly for older people who still have to work, who live in multi-generational households, who are vulnerable to thoughtless, selfish behaviour by others. But even those can be exercised within a range that reflects an individual's personal consciousness and desires if they are based on rational assessment of potential outcomes. We all need the best possible information, provided in forms and language that are most useful to us; and governments that will intervene to direct and restrain the population to create conditions in which personal choice is meaningful. conservative writers have repeatedly emphasised for centuries, there is little or no personal freedom where the knowledge of risks is reduced to the point that decisions are chancing on randomness (or you withdraw completely and avoid all choice). The Trump administration has destroyed and continues to destroy the rational basis of social and economic life - whoever you are, no matter how economically comfortable. 

PS The Johnson government here in the UK is a feeble shadow of Trump  - avoid coming here at all cost!

A simple case of really smart people struggling with issues created by a simple lack of leadership.
I appreciate your OP-ED as it helps to know we're all struggling to find answers and because of a propaganda machine, Fox News, has turned the USA into a "Black and White" world where if it's good for me it has to be good for you as well because you're never going to infringe on my rights to be the perfect example of an idiot for my fellow cult members.
Age or  pre existing health issues which can translate to an almost certain death sentence mean absolutely nothing to the world revolves around donald's sick cult and the me crowd.
Georgia Governor's lawsuit?  Insanity.  
When a 5 year old could easily see a Governor chained to an object circling the bottom of the bowl yet cultist politics makes him desire to be directly responsible for hundreds if not thousands of deaths that could have easily been prevented?
