"We don't want science to stand in the way." That donald administration quote was applied to SCHOOLS of all things but in reality with this administration it applies to  everything.

Older people are more likely to have sickle cell disease????

Correction, please.
The link given in the article for the risk calculator returns an error message "502 - Bad Gateway".

Excellent column. I am a senior that can easily semi quarantine myself and have been doing it but having said that  have to make decisions now on a yearly physical, dental visits etc.

Coupling with a moron ego maniac demagogue as president with no leadership it makes it harder with no national guidelines.

If we had leaders who led and inspired, rather than terrifying us, who helped shape adaptive, science-based behavioral shifts in the populace,, we would not be in this bottomless hole. The entire country needs to pitch in together, not divided. Instead, we get young people whining that they can't attend big drunken parties, a legion of  people writing "risk checks" on other people's lives, and older people complaining that they can't vacation. Few refer to altruistic models of behavior like WWII (albeit imperfect).  To understand what each cohort must do takes some understanding of viruses and immunity, an understanding of shifting demographics, and the reality principle--i.e. science. We need a cheerleader in America for facing reality. What has been encouraging is that many Americans are finding their way creatively, and being neighborly. 
Some suggestions: Grocers offering drive-by, continue this until the end of this state of siege. People who are sharing their resources, keep it up. This is a duration. It won't be over for you until it's over for all of us.
We can sweep out the false leaders, all of them, if we are realistic. Those in power now might obscure the statistics and try to steal our enfranchisement--but we all can scream our heads off, can push to vote safely, and throw the bastards out. And after that we will all have a lot of real work to do, sharing, and healing as a country. I can't wait for the contagion of lies to end, so we can tackle the virus head on.

I am 71. I live alone and have no family. Financially I am fine. I have suffered from chronic pain for almost ten years (medical malpractice), but have no underlying conditions. I have been in lockdown since March. You can count the number of times I have been to a store since March on one hand. My doctor tells me that I shouldn’t leave the house for any reason. 

The only time I have been really sick was when I was 19 and had viral pericarditis (an inflammation of the sack the heart sits in). I was hospitalized for three weeks. Since it was caused by a virus, they could do nothing. Once in the middle of the night I felt so awful I thought I was dying. I saw a bright light in the upper corner of the room. I fought back and lived at 19, but don’t know if I can at 71. 

The good news is that I never get colds or the flu. My doctors have said that this is because I don’t touch my face. However, I can’t rely on this to protect me. 

The problem is that people need to be around and socialize with other people. Zooming is not enough. If I have to continue this for another 18 months I will be a basket case.
Dude, mow your lawn. LOL
The link to the calculator does not work.  Can you find a corrected link?  Thanks.

We are retired with its plus and minus: We are more vulnerable but don't have to go out.  It is going to be a long 18 months.   This virus has laid bare American indifference to our fellow man.  When I see and hear politicians and pundits writing us off because of our age, I know where my political donations are going.  You think seniors should be willing to die for the economy?  You first.  

My wife hates it when I state the obvious:  Every other person has an IQ of 100 or less, and people don't understand how limited average is.  Arguing about masks?  Really?  Just how stupid do you have to be to not wear one?

They must desperately want to get away from that h3ll-hole there in Bethesda!

On the other hand, knowing that there may be parts of Europe and Asia where live music and theater can re-start safely makes the above statement something other than just sarcasm.

This is the single best piece I have read on the risks for us geezers.  I am 69.  I walk for an hour five or six times a week, and am careful to give wide berth to anyone who comes along.  No going to the movies, eating in restaurants, in-person worship, or foreign travel.  We live in a dark time at the moment.  This is our reality and we simply have to accept it.  Sit back, relax, and just be.  Like everything else, this will pass.

Oops - you forgot other side of calculation: everyone that goes out can be a spreader regardless of age. It’s not just about what you want to do or your risk. People swanning about on vacations in the middle of a worldwide pandemic just looks stupid and selfish.

Risk assessment is difficult for medical providers to do, and your doctor will not only be thinking of your safety but also the risk of you suing him/her if you contract the virus.

Make sure you have your end-of-life paperwork done.  If you can't deal with that, then you haven't been watching the news lately.

Then compare your desire to engage in any activity with the degree of real risk it offers, the reward it offers, and the consequences of you becoming infected.  Include what will happen to others in your family   if you become ill.

Now you can make your decision.

My husband and I have been very torn in how to move forward. We both just retired at 60 and 61 after decades of planning for this very moment. Our dreams of travel and grandkids seem put on indefinite hold. I know how lucky we are, we own our home, are healthy enough to go on 30 plus mile bike rides and are comfortable financially. We are fortunate beyond belief. So if we survive this healthy then some day travel can resume (I hope)

With schools in Georgia still scheduled  to open in August we are planning to hunker down away from our grandkids again. I know there are plenty of people effected in awful ways but this is so painful to us to think about. We had a 6 week quarantine from them in April when I still worked as a nurse in a major hospital and were protecting them from me. Now it looks like the opposite needs to happen to protect us from them.  Out governor refuses to follow the science and mandate mask wearing. The very scientists are under attack while trying to help us live through this. Sigh...I try to stay positive and look to November.

We wouldn't need to postpone life until a vaccine comes along if we had a government. Even here in California, which started off so well with serious steps to control the spread, the pressure to "re-open" proved too great. But the ultimate blame rests squarely in Washington, D.C., where everything is sacrificed to careerism. It doesn't have much of a ring to it, like the "Roaring Twenties" of the last century, but we live in the Age of Fecklessness. When the history of this era is written, people will marvel about how we debated bar-openings, had political fights over mask-wearing, and wouldn't let "science get in the way" of The Leader's re-election.

I have switched from feeling deprived to feeling blessed if not privileged even with only a Social Security income living in a not well social serviced older central city adult apartment tower where few are COVID compliers.   
      If I do feel deprived from my going out and about city arts and entertainment and group meet-ups life or going back East to see friends and family, I can ask myself this question "am I a low income service worker younger woman with a parent with dementia, child with ADD, abusive husband living in a one bedroom apartment with my unemployment running out and the landlord threatening eviction?"  No.                                                                                   Also I did manage to get a safe hair cut, am able to walk not take public transit to buy groceries, am very computer literate able to afford a home internet connection and take part in at least two Zoom meet ups every day. Now I am taking a creative writing class online as well.   Compared to many other older adults even those with higher incomes than mine, all these can represent special blessings as well.

Another consideration is one’s place on the senior spectrum.  Most people in their 80’s, even when the very strong, are a bit more fragile than 65 year olds.  After all, the 80’s year old body has had about 20 more years of use than 60’s.   Sadly, 85 is definitely not the new 65 for most of us.  Just grateful for years though.

We are so spoiled as a country and as individuals that our response to this "crisis" is maddening. If we compare what we're going through now with a crisis in the past like a world war, the Black Death, Mongol hordes, yellow fever, malaria, war in the Middle East, etc., asking seniors and others to isolate, wear a mask and distance is such a piece of cake.  Protests to such steps in the name of balancing lifestyle shows most of the protestors to be spoiled brats.  Read a history book for heavens sake and make some minor concessions.

Well, my post is sure to get some negative responses. I am 74 and have followed with great care all of the preventative measures. 

Around 13 years ago I had cancer and was treated at Duke by fabulous doctors and nurses. I did take a platinum drug that resulted in neuropathy in my lower legs. It has gotten worse over time and I use a cane now. But 13 good years. 

For more than 20 years, I have gone to St John in the USVI. Last October, as I do every year, I booked flights (first class) and a condo for August 5th. Well if the plane flies and St John stays open, I am going. Next year I could be in a wheel chair with no chance of going. 

I snorkel for hours in the warm, clear, blue water and my legs work fine. It is my one spurge. 

I will take every precaution if I am able to travel this year. I know the risks and benefit.  I hope to make it to my beloved St John.

This is not how I planned to end my life.... we had plans, trips, adventures, treating the family to a YoYoMa concert, fishing with the dogs, summer barbeques with friends and families. Celebrating our grandson's job with the car we promised a year ago. Now we spend our days dusting a house no one will ever see. Repairing steps and railings, cleaning out the garage. Watching way too much television, knitting up all the yarn stashed away. The most we can do for the political campaigns we were once so active in is to make phone calls and write letters. Our stimulus check is given to the local Neighborhood Missions to help families who need it more. But we can not go to help distribute food and aid.
Being 80 and with health problems is the pits...but I look at my widowed friend who opted for living in a sr. residence who has not been allowed out of her apartment since March, meals are delivered and contact with others is by phone only. If that does not bring depression and senility I do not know what does. At least we have our yard, our dogs, some gardening....but no one to sit on our deck and share a drink or meal. 
Fortunately our zip code has not experienced a single case..., but it is summer and the National Forest with it's campgrounds and tourism surround us. 
No other country will allow us in, so moving to a safe place is out. I guess we sit quietly pondering what has become of the glorious life we once enjoyed and will our lives end on a down note?
The biggest risk factor I have seen in patients succumbing to this virus just isn’t age. It’s obesity. Americans need to lose weight.

I am 64 in excellent health and have been staying close to home.  I have enjoyed my time at home and have had no problems just staying put. My problems arise when I have to go out and other folks are not masked. But now my daughter-in-law is about to give birth in another state and I will be traveling there by car (long drive but I will not fly) to help take care of their two small boys so my son can be present at his daughter's birth. There is no one else who can do this job for them.... sometimes we just have to take that risk, face shield and mask in hand....

Next month I will be 86 years old. I am healthy now, but the risks of going to a hospital for any reason have made visiting friends, going to stores, eating out or making any unnecessary trips not possible.  

My best friend since childhood died a month ago, and I could not travel 2,000 miles to participate in her funeral, because If I got sick, the burden on her family and the already challenged health care system would be horrible.

I stay at home, and wear a mask and social distance if I must go out, not because I am frightened or because I just choose to, but because it is my responsibility.

Being a senior I do not take the risk of travel  by train,and that means for me that I don't go to the dentist nor have my hair cut. It may be best to find a new dentist and hair dresser withing walking distance. 
My food is bought at 7 AM and I do not visit other stores even though I need a new bed and many things to fix my condo.

My health is good and my only risk is my age. I life in a  country where corona virus is under control and we have only 8-9 persons in hospital. The risk here is low and nobody here  used face masks...but I do ! The tourist are pouring in now and infection rate is expected to rise.

The only risk I take is going into stores to buy food. To order online   turned out to be stressful,and food cost at least 25 % more. And all the pleasure of buying food was gone.
Now I plan for the second wave that might come in the autumn ,I store more food and try to adjust emotionally to our new life. The hard part is to learn to live with daily danger.In this country we are used to feeling safe all the time and suddenly danger is there non stop for us in the high risk groups. The strange thing is that I have never felt any fear or anxiety . Never and that surprises me. What I feel is a strong will to stay healthy and safe and part of that is to read up and learn as much as I can about the corona virus .
Calculated risk ? Only shopping food and noting else.

I do not suffer but understand that maybe I have to live like this for the rest of my life.

I at 65 and my hubby at 66 have been staying away from public places and friends.  We see our son and his family, who are also isolating, at outdoor, safely distanced dinners in our backyard once a week.  Five years ago I completed chemo for a cancer that few survive more than two years.  I am not going to get Covid after going through five grueling months of chemo, 8 hours a day, four days a week!  It’s just not worth it to me to take the chance.  Thankfully I gave myself the gift of a pool after completing chemo, so I can swim safely daily.

One hard reality - No one can get travel insurance to leave the country. Getting hospitalized with Covid would bankrupt most people.

There will be Canadian Snow Birds in the USA this winter, no cruises, no trips to Europe and Asia, no Caribbean...  

Just a lot of grumpy old people like me trying not to slip on ice.

Yuk!

These decisions aren't difficult to make if you care about other people. If they go to the party the risks of someone getting sick is high because family will be flying .I think 40% of spreaders are asymptomatic even in the nursing homes or also the over  65 group. Planes and bars are some of the most contagious environment.
Perhaps  he doesn't care about dying now though even though  Covid is a horrible painful devastating illness.This disease  may  leave permanent organ damage in half the people who go to the hospital.How will he feel if she dies or any member of his family gets sick or spreads it when they go back home.
The selfish part of this story is not considering the guilt family members will feel when anyone of them falls ill. .
This choice is simple and as they risk spreading the disease  not only to the  the family but to all the other people  these partiers  will encounter after this event. The family needs to decide do they want this burden and hey 40 yr old may suffer  permanent  organ damage also, Dad!
I read this and know this will never end as long as smart people make these kind of choices. STAY HOME! Pandemic look it up.

My healthy 80 year old step mother took a trip to visit her daughter in NC in late June. I got her the best mask I could find and hoped for the best. Most of her life these days is spent caring for my 89 y. o. father. She needed a break and who knows how many more chances any of us will have to see loved ones again. As for me, I am trying to choose risk carefully, seeing friends and adult children while taking reasonable precautions like masks and distance. Luckily people in my community are generally careful.

At this point, the UK is not admitting Americans, so Mrs. Nathan's deliberations on their trip are moot! -- But as a middle-class senior, I felt the article covered a lot of points that are relevant to our l lives.

Each person has their own perspective, their own life experience that affects how they calculate risks and benefits. 

Speaking for myself, I lost my father to cancer when I was 22 and my son to suicide when he was 26.  My wife has had cancer twice (three times if you count a melanoma) and I've survived prostate cancer.  

After all of this, our daughter fell and had severe injuries to her brain, face, teeth and more.  Luckily, 3+ years later, she is almost fully recovered.

Looking back on all these events, we feel that we have already endured the worst losses we are ever likely to suffer.  We feel that life is both precious and fragile, and that we don't only live for ourselves but for others too--family, friends, community.

We are economically secure, have jobs we can do from home, have all our necessities delivered, and recognize that our ability to stay home 24/7 is a luxury.  We have eliminated all non-essential forays outdoors, except for the few times we took a short walk with our dog.  

Our daughter is the only person we have allowed inside our apartment.  Since her brother died, she has been an only child.  On her behalf and also on behalf of each other we feel it would be irresponsible for us to risk our health by exposing ourself to avoidable risks.

That is just the perspective of two people.  Others have different experiences and points of view, and will draw their own conclusions.

I have to evaluate each thing I do these days.  I choose to live and not going out is difficult, but something I have to look at carefully.

The politicization of the virus and of mask wearing has made a bad situation far worse than it needed to be.  If you're a senior and have underlying medical problems, as most of us do, you have to take this as seriously as a heart attack.  Not a pleasant analogy, but a necessary one.

Not enough is being written about what this is doing to seniors and we aren't receiving the aid we should be receiving.  For the most part, we're being sacrificed, just like the poor and immigrants.

How horrendous this will ultimately end up being is an unknown now, but for we seniors, it's already horrendous.
"...a balance between safety and living": safety and living are not contradictory goals. A balance is actually easier for older, retired people, who do not have to worry about income from wages.

I’m 76 y.o. and prime meat for this virus. I don’t have to be a Fauci or a Jonas Salk to understand that a deadly virus is ravaging the country. I don’t need to calculate anything. Don’t go out unless absolutely necessary. Wear a mask when out. Strictly avoid places where people are not wearing masks or not practicing so-called “social distancing.”

Get an iPad and learn to use it, including using FaceTime, Skype, and Zoom.

Don’t take health advice from people wearing brown shirts with swastikas on the sleeves. Don’t be living in a state where the governor wears such a shirt or is a knuckle-dragging, right-wing ideologue. Vote Democratic from top to bottom in November.

My fiancee and I feel lucky to have found each other. We are sheltering in place together. (Next week we get married.) I'm 82 and she is younger. 

We realistically expect to shelter in place for another 12-18 months, until we can get vaccinated AND enough people are vaccinated--and the vaccine offers effective protection for more than 8 weeks--to create herd immunity. We feel we can shop for food--nearby Nashua requires face masks--and eat out using restaurants with outdoor seating.  

We each have health issues which make us particularly vulnerable.  So living in a single family detached dwelling in a town with 2-acre zoning (we all have wells and septic tanks) gives us enough flexibility to be comfortable. Sure, we'd like to feel free to do more, to hug children and grandchildren, to travel, to eat out more... Be what we have now is much better than dying alone in a hospital gasping for breath. 

We are thankful we are not in nursing homes or assisted living situations, which appear ti be convenient clusters of potential Covid-19 victims waiting to be infected.

We could get control of this scourge if people were smart, but as POGO observed, "We have met the enemy and they is us."
How sad.

I am 71 years old, and work on the "front lines" in a hospital, providing care to COVID-19 and non COVID-19 patients. I feel safer in the hospital than I do out on the street. In the hospital, we (for now) have the PPE we need, I wash or sanitize my hands multiple times an hour, and staff are generally scrupulous about taking necessary precautions in all patient interactions.

In the outside world, on the other hand, people of all ages think it's a badge of honor not to wear a mask, that they're not going to be infected by the virus, and that the imposition of mandates is somehow Communism. This is so very misguided.

Public health can frequently clash with the rights of the individual (think of mandatory quarantine of active TB patients) in order to protect the health of all individuals. This is what is happening here and now. 

The collective health of all people requires that we all alter our "normal" for the good of society. Older folks like myself, middle-aged and younger adults, teenagers and younger children all need to adapt to the new normal. Some may need help in adapting, but that's what society as a whole is supposed to do--help individuals who need it.

It's high time we worked for the collective good, understanding that the rights of the individual will mean nothing if the individual is dead.

I will be 75 next week. In 1970 I spent almost a year in Vietnam during the war. In 1986 at 40 I had double bypass surgery. Because of Agent Orange exposure I have a compromised immune system and diabetes.

And what have I done since 1986? I have set foot on every continent, almost always traveling on my own. I have two remarkable daughters and four wonderful grandchildren. I have lived a life of service to others. I am content.

Now? I isolate. Just this month I started doing take-outs. That helped. I haven't seen family since this all started. I do miss them. A lot.

For me, COVID-19 is just another challenge like so many I have addressed before. For now, I persevere knowing this too shall pass.

Ugh. Every senior writing here was complicit in creating the systems that lead us to this mess. Where was the outcry before your comfortable lives were disrupted? In 1987, the year I was born—the corporatocracy was already strong. My mother knew the medical system was broken then and as a healthy, strong, young woman knew it would be safer to have me at home (with a husband and wife OBGYN/certified nurse midwife team) than in the filthy for-profit hospitals. None of the mess was hidden but you all decided not to look, it would have been uncomfortable. I have no problem making *minor* concessions for the sake of all IF the leaders and country are working toward changing all of the systems that lead us to this mess. If I hear another older person talk about how they want things back to *normal* I will lose it. Everything was broken before Covid.  The level of comfort was never sustainable. Covid is but a symptom of a fatally ill society. We’re all going to die—are you willing to forgo all your freedoms and sacrifice the youth and the impoverished (more than you already have) for your own safety? So that you can take pharmaceuticals to live to 100? I’m disgusted with the elders in this country. Little lost sheep. Spending quarantine dusting your McMansion? Wondering when you’ll be able to attend a violin concerto again? I’m wondering if the planet will melt before by daughter doesn’t get to start kindergarten because we’ve filled up our oceans with disposable face masks.

Paula Span neglected to mention that the greatest risk for seniors is being deficient in vitamin D, our main hormone for resisting upper respiratory infections. 

Why is it that we cannot learn from century of sanitariums, and the rickets or scurvy pandemics? That everything now has to couched in lock downs and isolation, or the result of poverty?

The human mind is a fascinating sieve of rationalizations and denial. When confronted with the logic of isolating, and temptation of social mixing, extroverts lose and introverts win.

Easy for me to say, using Howard Hughes' hypochondria instructive in flu season but previously not OCD enough to have raw hands from adequate hand washing.

When the world is left to hermits and misanthropes, there will still be social media, obviously, but it will be quieter.

I’m 73, and enjoy a Clorox margarita every night with my Goya beans to ward off Covid.
Still, I’m staying home until April, when this virus will disappear, like a miracle!
Wait, it’s July??
Oh well, anyone who wants a test can get a test.
And speaking of tests...see you in a few weeks on the first day of school.

I live just outside of Lake Placid. We have the lowest numbers of cases in the North Country than in most of the country by far.
  Don't converse with anyone not wearing a mask. Face coverings are mandated most indoor public places and compliance is very high. Stay out doors in the cool mountain air.  Maintain your "bubble".  I would think your chances of  and accident on the way up here may be the biggest risk.
And please wear YOUR face covering when appropriate, so we can continue to welcome tourists !

i honestly don't get it:do people really think that there is less of a risk of getting Covid-19 now than a few months ago? What about asymptomatic spreading? My life will not return to normal anytime soon.

The elephant in the room in these discussions is that any risk one takes, one takes on behalf of other people as well. There is no simple calculus that can assure us that any particular activity is safe - if we're thinking of others' safety as well as our own.

Anything you decide to do, you might conclude the risk is worth it to YOU, but are you certain of who else you might encounter while doing it? And you will often have no way of gauging what risks the other person you encounter may face.

The answer isn't stay inside forever, obviously. But our entire society has trouble with the notion of considering COMMUNAL risks at the same time as gauging personal risks.

The couple in the article considering a trip to London in September .. . I feel for them, since that trip seems unlikely now ... but then we have to consider, they want London, but does London want THEM? There's a reason Europe has told Americans to stay home. The decision about the trip to London - even if the travel restrictions get lifted by then - is about more than whether they will be safe in London.

They may feel like, well, we're getting old, we deserve to have some fun! Sure. But the couple will also come into contact with older folks, or folks with other risk factors, while in London who didn't have any say while the couple planned their vacation. Wait staff in hotels, restaurants, flight attendants, etc. They will be making this decision on their behalf as well as their own.

Seems so straightforward.

But what if you're over 65, and still working full-time, like a lot of people?

What if you're under 65, but have a person who is over that age (maybe considerably over that age) living in your household?

As someone else said -- it was easy when the same rules applied to everyone.  My husband's mother lives with us -- so although my husband and I are in our 50s, we continue to limit ourselves pretty much as we did when NJ was on strict lockdown.

This is causing issues with my mother and siblings, who think I'm being "dramatic" by not attending the non-distanced family functions they've started to have.  But since my mother, siblings and their kids have pretty much all gone back to work and/or "normal" activities -- meaning their risk of exposure is going up, even in a state where cases are currently staying steady -- how can I justify the risk to my MIL?

I'm lucky that I work in a white collar job that can be done from home, and that my employer has maintained its remote work practices.  It just seems foolhardy to me to take risks that I don't have to take just to say that I've gone out

I am an octogenarian physician who still is working. I have no (as yet) serious health issues and exercise regularly, but nevertheless am fully aware of the potential consequences of contracting covid.I closed my office for almost three months, doing telehealth consultations where appropriate, but in most instances my specialty requires some hands-on contact. I have had a good life, and through it all, my work has been the compass that has allowed me to navigate the ups and downs of my existence. I have learned that in my case usefulness is all.So I am back at work, because I feel that enforced retirement would probably shorten my life almost as surely as this disease.

I’m just finishing a week on the jersey shore. First half, my son and grandson quarantined for 2 weeks before joining me. We brought our own food and ordered out for dinners. We wore masks when out near others and we were the rare mask wearers. Second half is with a dear friend from Park Slope who has been as careful as me. While I’m really enjoying being out of prison (aka my beautiful home which I love)and not being alone, I’m unnerved by the risks I see others taking. I also note that I haven’t seen a single flag at half mast although Gov. Murphy’s order To fly flags at half mast to honor those lost to COVID-19 remains in effect.

The statement that "age alone" carries increased risk is inaccurate and dangerous. Studies showing that older people are more likely to die (or get severe cases) do not account for other factors, such as comorbidities or living in nursing homes. Many people over 65 do not take medications and live active, independent lives. Locking them up will actually compromise their healthy immune systems, lower their self-efficacy perceptions, and drastically lower their quality of life. The WSJ reported on June 20 that the age relationship does not seem to hold in high-poverty countries; in Mexico, the virus is just as severe for people in their 40s because many have diabetes and high blood pressure. Mexico does not put older people in nursing homes. The NYT itself has noted that 42% of *all* Covid19 deaths nationwide are associated with nursing homes. When you take away those deaths, what's left? “An 80-year-old who is otherwise healthy and not frail might be more resilient in fighting off infection than a 60-year-old with many chronic conditions.” — Geriatrician George Kuchel (a UConn medical school professor) I wrote a detailed article on this for Medium, citing sources showing that age does not mean inevitable decline in immune system or acquisition of a comorbidity. The worst part of Covid-19 is the ongoing reinforcement of ageism, even from people who ought to know better. http://mycopy.info/agemed

1. About 1/3 of seniors live alone. Census 2. "Loneliness was associated with a doubled mortality risk in women and nearly doubled risk in men. Both men and women who felt lonely were three times more likely to report symptoms of anxiety and depression and had a significantly lower quality of life than those who did not feel lonely." https://www.healtheuropa.eu/loneliness-premature-death/86454/ 3. I'm 70, married, kids in town. We all have been hunkered down since March. Birthday party started well with everyone masked and distancing. As time wore on masks were at half staff and people were talking together as usual. No nobody got sick, but we all realized no one wanted to be the person who brought it in and spread it around. Back to Zoom and hunkering.

That photo, a couple hugging in lovely front garden in a full size home, is almost cruel to the millions of seniors in shared rooms, single rooms, studio, one-bedroom and larger apartment in continuing care and nursing homes and the like.   Most in assisted living and nursing care have not been allowed visitors for months.  I'm fortunate, dare I say wise, that I bought a 2b/2b with a small  6x7 balcony.   A retired diplomat, Peace Corps Volunteer, that 6'x7' is such a delight, treat.   Have not left the compound in 4 months and counting.   Know someone in senior housing, why not send them a plant or ask what they might want?   Don't know anyone, just bring a supermarket plant and drop it off at reception for a resident who would like a treat.  Thank you very much.

So far, there seem to be some best practices for seniors traveling. I'm 66.

Don't use planes, trains, buses, or ships. Your own car is OK.

Eat food from drive-through fast food windows. After you get your food, use hand sanitizer. If you want to sit while you eat, either eat in your car in the parking lot, or drive out to someplace natural nearby where you are alone. A sandwich by a rushing stream with birds singing in a farm field can be delightful.

Don't worry too much about gas stations, other than wearing your mask because you may be near other people gassing up. Worry more about going inside to the rest room or for a snack or soda. Use hand sanitizer when you're done and back in your car.

Hotels and motels are mostly OK; the check-in clerk is a much larger concern than anything in your room. If they aren't wearing a mask, don't even go in the lobby. Worry more about staying with friends or relatives. A motel would be safer.

Bring your own pen and use it to sign all credit card receipts.

Don't go where everyone else is going. Avoid the most popular national parks, such as Rocky Mountain, Grand Canyon, Great Smokies. Don't go on any group tours at an attraction.

This is not the summer to visit museums. Outdoor historic areas such as Gettysburg are ok, but don't go in the visitor center.

Enjoy the countryside! Get off the Interstate (and away from dangerous crowds) and travel the two-lane state highways.

In my late 60s, I'm more concerned with not getting COVID than I am about my quality of life right now.  I live in an area with a very low infection rate but I'm hopefully making sure I survive this and can resume a normal life later without the various post-COVID damage being discovered like lung scarring and cognitive problems.

Hence I'm continuing to venture out only for groceries and pharmacy.  I have to have blood work next week but my doctor's office has set up a kind of "tunnel" from entering the building directly to their lab and I'm going to use that while wearing gloves and a mask.

People seem to be frustrated and impatient with all these limitations and restrictions but my parents lived into their 80s and 90s and I don't want to sacrifice possibly another 2 decades of life because I'm bored, frustrated and annoyed by the current situation.  I'm all those things - but consider the possible payoff if I continue to be careful.

I grew up during WWII, the only truly popular war in U. S. history. We drove 35 mph, planted Victory gardens and bought War Bonds because it was patriotic. 

If we had a genuine leader in the White House, he would be setting a good example and communicating that Social Distancing and Mask Wearing are patriotic. 

Labeling mask resisters as unpatriotic would then be a very effective means of gaining almost universal compliance, which is what has occurred in many European countries. But that requires leadership. 

If you look at the countries with the worst Covid-19 problems, USA, Brazil, Russia, Spain, the UK, Italy and France, the “leaders” are all men. The countries recognized as having managed the crisis best, Germany, Taiwan, New Zealand, Iceland, Finland, Norway and Denmark, their leaders are all women.
Interesting article.  and a good reminder about the vaccines;  I had not realized that could play a role.

All of these kinds of articles result in a lot of sharing by my fellow "golden agers" ( my grandmother's silly euphemism in the 1950s).  I am 78, canceled travel, miss my grandaughter,  and I am trying to be careful and wish that more people would wear masks. However, in all honesty, the coping mechanisms of people I don't know personally are not that interesting.

The CDC is not updating guidance weekly according to Dr. Linda Fried.
States, on the other hand are being meticulous about documenting their positivity rates .
In New England, at least states are putting out guidelines about who can visit without quarantine restrictions.
I know I can't go from my county to Vermont, but elsewhere might be okay. 
The data is there, you just have to dig for it.

The calculator is not helpful for people who take medication that suppresses the immune system for treatment of systemic inflammatory diseases, such as RA, lupus, etc.  How about adding that to one of the drop-down lists?

Best wishes to Nancy and David Nathan.

However, I used to live outside Bethesda, which is one of the most expensive cities in the U.S.  

A   4 - 5+ bedroom house in Bethesda typically sells for 1.7 - 3 million $$$.

Wasn't it possible for Paula Span to interview an older couple who live in a more representative middle class community instead of uber wealthy people?

Most seniors in the U.S. are grappling with how to live with the current restrictions in smaller houses, condos or rentals, many living on Social Security and retirement pensions that don't permit them to live in the equivalent of a small mansion.

The NYT spends too much bandwidth profiling outrageously rich people as "representatives" in real estate, cultural and life style stories.

Why is that?

While I am in my early 60's , my partner is in his late 70's with a number of serious health conditions. For us, there are not many activities that would justify leaving home. We are fortunate because  have found activities to keep our bodies and minds occupied.

What has surprised us is how many people in this country are unable to sit still - even when their lives are at risk. I recognize that some people's home environment is not conducive to extended quarantine, but even people who live in great comfort who seem unable to stay in a beautiful environment of their our making.

It is not just young people who won't stay home. My 88 year old mother is downright cavalier about her chances of contracting covid, and claims she is immune from getting it!  I have  accepted that I will not change her mind.

What I cannot accept is that this president is lying to the American people and actually encouraging them to "return to normal.". It is sheer lunacy, but after reading Mary Trump's book, I understand Trump is so hollow inside that he needs a crowd like most of us need air. 

This hollow man is leading some of our most vulnerable population to their own demise. There are many, many ways we could be encouraging people to quarantine for their own protection. Instead, we are told that we older people must "sacrifice" ourselves to reopen. My response is, "You first."

Two thoughts. It should be made explicit that the numbers for hospitalizations per 100,000 (12 for 65 to 74 years old and 17 for over 85) are for everyone in those age groups, not just for those who test positive for the virus. And I don't think these are very useful number to help make the decision as to whether you should go out. The numbers to consider are the current prevalence of the disease in your area, to get an idea of the chances that you will get the virus if you go out, and the mortality rate for those who test positive in your age/vulnerability group, to get an idea of how serious your case would be. In my state, among those who test positive and are over 80, the death (not hospitalization) rate is about 1/3, a shocking number. For good statistics for Massashusetts, partitioned by age, see the state's COVID dashboard at: https://memamaps.maps.arcgis.com/apps/MapSeries/index.html?appid=9ef7ef55e4644af29e9ca07bfe6a509f My second thought is that the MIT economist's idea that the old should stay in isolation while we should open up for the young sounds good at first, but it actually carries big risks, as of course there are many connections between old and young - many young people living with parents and grandparents (especially now), and younger people serving as carers for older people. Also, there are risks for the young, and this strategy may be playing out in Florida now and many ICUs are at capacity. Economists, stick to interest rates!

I'm in my 70's. No comorbidities or medications. Calculator shows a 3.1% chance of catching Covid. That's nice.

Reality however, begs to differ. I had a 'mild' case back in early March, which I'm sure I picked up at my local Y while weight lifting. 

This is one mean, nasty virus that tests every one of your systems looking for vulnerabiliies. Took 2 weeks to totally shake, and another week to fully recover. 

My advice? By all means do what you can to limit exposure. But far, FAR more importantly - get healthy. Especially metabolically healthy. 

Stop eating *added* sugars of any kind, or hyper-processed or fast food. Learn to cook - really cook - all your food from scratch. Yup, bagels and pizza too. Do Intermittent Fasting by picking an 8 hour window and eating only in that time: one or two meals a day. NO COUNTING CALORIES. Eat good food until you're full, not stuffed. No food group left out. Tip: added sugar is not a food.

If you don't have barbells, order some. Squats, planks, pushups daily. By the tome there's a vaccine, you'll be in the best shape (literally) you've seen in decades. You might still get Covid, but you will have vastly increased your chance of getting a mild case.

We live in a rural area on two acres so mostly eat at home anyway and we stay very busy with yard projects so we are outdoors a lot without ever being in contact with other people.  So the virus really has not had much effect on our everyday lives but it has put a big dent in our travel plans. We decided the risk of planes, airports, hotels, and constantly eating in restaurants is way too high for our liking and so we are staying put until the risk is much much lower; basically for us that means waiting for the day that face masks are no longer needed. We are about 70, both retired.
Good decision. Family members flying in from Oregon and Florida (!) opens the door to all kinds of risks -- including infections contracted during flights.

Are the hospital rates that low, really. I wis they had continued to interpolate and say that the rates are .012% (a little over 1/10 of 1%) and .017 ( closer to 2/10) of 1%.  Please correct me if I am wrong. I am generally all in for isolation if possible, and curtailing any event that is not necessary. Also, for a couple each one should have veto power on anything that is the least bit risky. 
  But these numbers are way lower than I would have imagined.  THey seem low for the population at large and when they are for the most vulnerable among us, even lower.

Good decision on Lake Placid. Several weeks ago we gave up our 2 weeks in Nova Scotia in August because we didn't feel safe. Now Canada has decided to keep the border closed so we couldn't get in anyway! 

And you can forget about the UK in September. By then it will be much worse in the U.S. than it is now, and no country with any sense will let us cross its border. Besides, theaters are closed everywhere. If you want London theater, watch National Theatre productions on YouTube - terrific!

We are in the middle of a deathly Pandemic, thousands are dying while many others are suffering terribly because of medical and financial reasons.
       It's time we (seniors and others) show some solidarity and empathy.  Maybe you want to go to Lake Placid and London BUT you are endangering others -- think of the hospital and service workers that don't want to risk their lives for your holiday but need to go to work daily to feed their families.
       Stay home, be generous with your local food banks, and vote in November.

I am reading biography of Dr Benj Rush, and his experience during the Yellow Fever epidemic in Philadelphia in 1792 has many echos of our current situation.  
Exactly how the disease was transmitted was uncertain and much debated by the public and by the physician 'experts'.  Most people had the sense that physical proximity to infected persons was risky, so they would cross the street to avoid houses with sick people inside, avoid shaking hands, etc (but no masks).  Nobody wanted to touch the body of  somebody who had  died of the Fever - so African-Americans (freed former slaves) were hired to cart the dead to cemeteries. It was at first thought that Blacks were immune to the disease - based on the false analogy to malaria.  Then these Blacks were accused of stealing from the dead and looting their homes !  Most were unpaid and did this work for altruistic reasons.  These African-Americans also helped Dr Rush in caring for patients (and bleeding them as the main rx), because hardly any other doctors remained the city, having fled to the 'safer' countryside.
Yellow Fever also became politicized: Federalists and Republicans favored different treatments and approaches to containment, and  followed different "experts" accusing the other side  of various things, including favoring "foreign" (i.e. French) remedies.  Alexander Hamilton was said to have caught the Fever  because he had a inordinately high level of fear.
In the end, the epidemic went away after the first hard frost

Those 6 years separating them are key. 
She is that much younger, and looks more vital than he. Not that he doesn't look good, he does!! -- but at some point, age and numbers do start to matter or factor in more.

Since he is a Dr., and thus wise to so much of what is going on, his decision seems all the wiser. 

Can be harder, though, on the younger wife, having to life the tandem experience. I get that. 
This is where the vows really come in ... in sickness and health, in good times and bad, etc., etc.

I appreciated this article because not enough articles deal with older people who have no other special vulnerabilities aside from age.  My husband and I are in this position, though both in our 70s, and we’re finding it very hard to figure out what may be safe - or maybe safe enough.  The main decision is whether (and how) to spend time with the local family : my grandchildren (ages 3 and 8) and their parents.  It’s comforting to see that apparently we are not more likely to catch COVID on account of age, but only more likely to get very sick (and possibly die or have long term ill health problems).  My husband happens to have type O blood, as well, which apparently may give him a bit more protection.  Mine is B which apparently is sort of a neutral risk factor, with A type possibly putting people at higher risk.

I think social distance restriction are harder for some people than others. When my mom  lived with us, and had Alzheimer's, as long as she could walk for exercise,  I imagine she'd be fine, but she was such a social butterfly, that I'd have hard time convincing her  that she couldn't go right up to a neighbor  who was at the mailbox to say hello. My mom was an extrovert, by dad was an introvert, and I'm an ambivert: somewhere in-between the 2, so I'm just  as happy watching TV and reading indoors, as I am being outdoors. Like the man in the article felt (according to his wife,) if you're always going to look over your shoulder when you're out and about, like in a restaurant, some of the enjoyment would be gone. Hubby and I would rather stay here, (even with my so-so cooking), than be in an indoor restaurant where some people may inadvertently come closer than 6 feet to you.  Take-out complements my cooking, (even if no one compliments it).

Great article.  I’m 75 and live alone. The full blown close down affected me more than I expected. I became very sad and depressed. It’s one thing to live alone quite another to be locked in with no social contact. FaceTime and Zoom didn’t cut it. One daughter decided on a driveway visit. That helped but also made me realize how I longed to interact with people again. 
I resumed food shopping with care. I started long walks. The silence was eerie. I was a medical professional so I get the recommendations for the elderly but they don’t take into consideration that we only have one day at a time left. While I’m healthy and vibrant, I don’t want to live like a recluse. 
It’s a hard path. Like children going to school. 
But my heart tells me, we need to resume life.

My wife and I are both over 70, relatively active, and have few underlying medical conditions. We have sequestered in our home, except for walking the dogs, going to the vets or a restaurant (outside pickup for both). Our daughters grocery shop for us, we all wear masks but haven't been within 10 feet of them. Since February, no one has come inside our house. Trips have been canceled and gatherings postponed until it'll clearly be safe to do so. Despite "wanting" to do many things socially, the risk/reward of doing so makes no sense. We're no longer the careless "heroes" of youth and have exchanged that for the wisdom one can get from living longer.  With the misguided willingness of some risking the health of others in our community, we're much better off erring on the side of safety. The inconvenience, given the alternative, is something, hopefully, that will enable us to live much longer.

There's a great awkwardness these days because even among well-informed people there's no consensus on what amount or type of contact is reasonably safe. 

I have friendships that have been strained because I won't have dinner with them. They swear they'll follow safe practice though I've seen them talking to others at close range with no masks.

Another friend is angling to come and stay awhile at my house, as we've often done before. How to tell him he'd have to quarantine the first 2 weeks; he can't just show up. Of course he assumes he's "safe".

The name of this column is "The New Old Age". In the real new old age, the use of the word "senior" has long been discarded for having been recognized as a creation of the advertising and marketing industry to create a false homogeneity among a group of people the characteristics of which are all bad. Do a survey asking for free  associations with the word "senior". It isn't pretty. I never own the term, I never will and I eat full fare, thank you.

Now that I'm past 76 and in my fifth month of sheltering in place, I wonder if I will ever attend another baseball game, another opera, another symphony or theater production? I remember them all lovingly, and the trips to exotic places, and wonderful parties and celebrations, I miss them all but thankful that my life was full.

As for lockdowns of people over 65? At 67, I am probably in better health than a lot of people I see who are obese and wheezing and in their 40's. What a stupid, draconian, Orwellian horrific idea is that put forth by scientists at MIT! When the order comes down that tells me I'm locked down for 18 months, I'm booking my flight to South America. I'd rather take my chances with this virus than live in a country that takes away my freedom because it's too incapable of doing what other developed nations have been capable of doing. The damage to those of us who have been fighting the stereotyping and negativity directed at older Americans in this country may be one of the most detrimental unintended consequences adding to an already totally horrible stereotype of older Americans as almost useless and subject to any and every infirmity and disability that is known to man the second they hit that magic milestone- 65.  Just reading this made my blood boil.

Forget going to London.  Forget the West End.  Going to be 70 this year.   My 70th birthday blowout of a cruise around the West side of the UK up to the Shetlands, then 8 weeks in a Scottish seaside town, with a mid vacation 10 day excursion to the Faroes all cancelled.  So  I have given up ALL my future travel plans and decided it was the time to get my last dog. He has a Scottish name: Fergus.

We are 60+ vulnerable retirees whose LIFE is travel, so this has not been trivial for us. In summer 2018 my husband had a cancer diagnosis—surgery, and then one year of immunotherapy. We upped our travel planning and did numerous trips abroad last year—trying to maximize our time as long as we are still healthy. Now we’re donating to charity as we one by one cancel the other numerous trips we had booked this year and next. I don’t subscribe to trying to shame people with means over those who are suffering without. We are being affected by the loss of our reason for living as well. In the meantime, I grieve for our world, and the suffering the ignorant covididiots inflict on all of us.

Thank you for this article.  Back when we were in lockdown, everyone at home had something in common.  But recently, those of us over 65 and not in nursing homes have become invisible.  We are told to be "vigilant".  What does that mean?
For myself, I've decided I would rather spend the next few months hunkered down and well rather than sick with miserable effects of Covid 19.  I'm hopeful that a therapeutic like monoclonal antibodies may become available soon.

May I ask a question about vaccines? My pharmacist advised against getting the second of two shingles shots. It’s supposed to be given two to six months after the first. I’m now at more like seven months. The pharmacist says the vaccine depresses immune systems for two weeks.

This article states that the opposite is true.

I’m a healthy 72-year old.

Thank you for any information!

Grateful. For every day my husband and I are healthy, secure and able to pursue our hobbies and zoom with friends. We're among the lucky ones.
The most important thing is to VOLUNTEER and vote and fill D.C. with Democrats.

I am soon to be 65 and was planning to retire next year. It’s depressing that there is nothing to retire to now. I might continue to work from home because my dreams of extended travel have shriveled up. Might sound privileged given what others are dealing with, but I feel that I am being robbed of my last good years.

"They proposed protecting people over 65 by having them isolate for an estimated 18 months until a vaccine becomes available; younger people, facing less health risk, would return to work."

The younger people are taking more risk right now causing the  infection rates to go way up and preventing school from re-opening.  
As they take more risk, they put everyone at risk.   Age and comorbidity are not the only risk factor.  How an individual's adaptive immune system respond to the virus is unknown as it depends on genetics.

We are vulnerable seniors with pre-existing conditions that would make our survival of a bout with the Wuhan, China, coronavirus fatal.

Early in March we agreed to socially/physically distance and put health and safety above every thing else.

I exercise vigorously daily. She swims, but not every day. She plans menus with my chronic kidney disease in mind. Every meal is a wonderful adventure.

My time is taken up by exercise, sleep, trading stocks and options and my news junky life. She reads lots of novels, The Wall Street Journal and fun family and friends' emails and text messages. And she talks on the phone.

Like 30-year-olds, we search the Internet for a new home with a pool for her and good nearby health care for both of us. We've been doing this for years.

Feeling strong and kinda immortal at our age seems strange and unreal. Our brains still feel like they did 50 years ago, but our bodies are showing our ages.

We just wish more people would wear masks in public, exercise, stay at home and physically distance. But even our older friends often seem to forget themselves when they get together.

We've known from the beginning that we have to look out for ourselves, because there are plenty of people who don't worry about who they might infect and kill.

That's about all virus vulnerable people can do. Be careful and alert to risks, and don't get too angry, because it won't do anybody much good.

That March projection of up to 2 million American deaths is hard to square with hospitalization rates of 12-17 per 100,000.  If all 300 million Americans got Covid, then using the pessimistic over-85 figure of 17 hospitalizations per 100,000 cases, my arithmetic yields about 50,000 hospitalizations.  How can the potential fatality figure be 20 times greater than this?  Am I missing something?  

On another topic, does anyone have numbers for "...the possibility that we never get back to the same level…".  I've seen this sort of thing from multiple sources now, and it's starting to feel irresponsible to keep scaring people without attempting to quantify the risk.  

From its title, I had hoped this article would have been a nice place to actually quantify risk (and check whether the numbers make sense).

To the Dr Schaffner of the world,

You can get your hands on surgical masks because you are a Dr.   
The rest of us have to make do with whatever face coverings we can get our hands on.  Go ahead take your risk and please don't try to downplay the risk for the rest of us.
I am a 59 year old white female with a BMI of 22 and no co-morbidities. The  calculator  it won’t work for someone with my characteristics. Paula, or anyone, can you explain why?

It would be great if everybody over 65 who wanted to stay home could stay home, but for many, there isn't enough money to live on if they don't continue to work. More and more people are saying they'll have to keep working until they die because it's hard to save money on the pitiful pay most people are expected to live on. One of the cashiers at Walmart told me she was 85, and that her ankles were swollen to the size of footballs from standing all day.

This is the reality of old age for millions in America. Scanty Social Security since they never made much to begin with, and scanty pay at tiring jobs to make up the difference.

Being just 70 I harmonize with the tactical decisions that other older folks are sharing. Thanks. But with a larger focus we must realize that we are all in the same leaky boat several months into the pandemic: Not enough tests to establish how many asymptomatic cases are out there and no guarantee of rapid test results: no ready task force to do contact tracing as the numbers expand: no readily available humane quarantine options for people who live with family, friends, and others; no backup funding for ICU expansion; spotty health insurance for those with or without symptoms; no weekly testing of front line health, sanitation, restaurant, and other public servants. As a public we seem to be relying on the equivalent of the "hail Mary pass," "best guess," "wing and a prayer," and "muddle along" national and state policies. Half-hearted, half- funded, and half backward. We can do better.

Where  you are is indeed so important.  In DC (at least in my current limited circumference of operation) everyone wears a mask, and the stores and food carry-out places are set up for limited contact.  Restaurants are opening for outdoor sitting only.  Food delivery is left at the door.  Service repair workers show up with face masks and often foot mitts.   In my 70's, I long to travel, but otherwise am well and feel safe.    

I called to my brother in California yesterday.  He said now that masks are required many people (even in a hospital setting!) wear their masks without covering their noses.    

The article's point about lack of statistics imposed by trump adds to the insecurity.   Unfortunately, we are alone, not together, in this time of coronavirus.
So...who's going to the dentist!?

You are at 70% more risk of dying from Covid-19 if the epic pandemic you are currently trying to ride out is being "handled"
by an insane president.
It's considered to be an underlying condition, so it's even worse than you think.
But one advantage to becoming older, is that you are not aged 18-40 and having to be the delivery person bringing you your groceries on a hot day, wondering if you'll ever be able to get a real job because the economy is tanking. 
Another advantage to being an elder? The chance to gain perspective and maybe a little wisdom. Growing older is painful, full of unexpected wonders, humiliating, mystifying, you name it...but you are here on this planet, take some time to reflect during your short time of staying home...

If you want to stay alive:

VOTE  ALL  REPUBLICANS  OUT,

MAKE THE RICH PAY THEIR FAIR SHARE.

Then we can refund the public health system. There will be other pandemics on the heels of this one. Globalization and climate change will see to that.

I'm 76 and my beau is 79 and we're grateful to be living in a state where most people follow the governor's and state CDC Director's recommendations.  We have been able to see friends, kids, and grand kids once it became warm enough to stay outside.  An added benefit is having become better acquainted with our neighbors; lots of roadside chats while masked and distanced.  Strangers have become friendly as they walk their dogs by the house.  Not a bad life.

I am over 65 and have some underlying health conditions. Worse than that, I live in Florida, the hot spot of the universe, Covid-19 or no.

I live alone. My hurricane plan has always been to take a plane to my daughter's house in the Midwest, should I need to evacuate, which I have done twice. That is not an option this year, for I had rather go maskless in a crowded protest than get on a germ-infested plane.

So, aside from the ennui of self-isolation for five months, I am accepting whatever groceries the "shopper" brings me despite my online list; cutting my own hair; doing my own nails; and cleaning my own house. As to the latter, if my cleaning lady ever does come back, she will need to wear a hazmat suit.

Yes, I know this sounds like privileged whining to some, but the toll of isolation, even with Zoom and phone calls, won't replace seeing my children and grandchildren in person.

As I type this, I repeat my mantra: Buck up. You've been through worse. Except I know I am kidding myself. I've never been through anything as bad as Covid-19.

AC is a problem. Indoor gatherings plus air conditioning are probably more dangerous than indoor gatherings plus heated air. This is logical based on the discussion of the viruses structure and vulnerabilities. -It has been mentioned that the integrity of the viral outer coat increases the infectious capacity of the virus. Soap and water destabilizes the lipid outer coat, the increased energy in heat or sunlight also destabilizes the outer coat.- The viral outer envelope is, by contrast strengthened when exposed to cooler temperatures in the 50's F range. The air conditioning coils chill surrounding air to the 40's and 50's F - then send it out into the room air. So, the viral envelope is stabilized and reinforced by circulating through the air conditioning system. Any coronavirus present in the room air, which is recirculated through the 50's F, air conditioning would be more virulent. Coronavirus recirculated through a heating system would by contrast, be weakened or killed before entering the room area. Air exchange systems which do not recirculate room air, but rather bring in exterior air would avoid this.

Next door neighbors grandson recently died from covid-19.  He had gone to Las Vegas in mid July with the entire extended family.  Most of whom got ill.  Just know, you travel, it could be your final trip.
Quite frankly, I would rather read in the new age blog stories about how older Americans are flourishing and rocking it in this pandemic!

Once again Paula Span has categorized those over 65 as vulnerable, weak victims.

We worry about our younger  “out of shape friends “ in their late thirties  ....They huffed and puffed struggling 
On a  recent bike ride that was a piece of cake for us who are conditioned mentally and physically.
Any one who has lived decades should be able to intelligently process their local risk  and  assess appropriate choices without a generic, condescending article.

My wife and I are retired physicians in our early 70s. It is not a simple dichotomy of live/die, as many seem to believe.  There are residua like lung scarring, cardiac and neurological damage, which quite frankly are unknown for the young as well, and should (but won't) give them great pause. We don't want any part of this virus. 

I can no longer volunteer as a math tutor in person, but I can answer math problems online, do trail work with other like minded folks, socially distancing in the outdoors hiking and clearing logs and brush, opening trails.  I have led socially distanced hikes for a hiking club.  For once, being an introvert has had some value.  

There is also zooniverse, where I am inputting data from cards of those American soldiers who died during World War I (many of whom from pulmonary conditions) and names for the Arolsen Archives of those who died in concentration camps.  When that is depressing, I can switch to wildlife identification.

I am reminded daily how lucky I am to have lived the life I have.

“Lots of people are really agonizing about what to do and whom to have faith in,” said Dr. William Schaffner

Coming from blue Chicago, we're not having any doubts about what to do and to whom to listen. 

News reports to the contrary seem to be coming in from some other world of halfwits and Fox News consumers, very few of whom we associate with here in the blue part of the midwest.

Maryland has had 73 cases of coronavirus per 100,00 people in the last 7 days, and new cases are increasing (NYT “Coronavirus in the U.S.: Latest Map and Case Count”)

Lake Placid is in Essex County, New York, which has had 51 confirmed cases to date and 0 deaths. Total – not just the last 7 days, not on a per capita basis. All of them, ever.  (Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center) 

Mr. & Mrs. Nathan: You don’t have coronavirus now, but are you certain that one or both of you won’t pick it up anywhere on the 8-hour (plus breaks) drive? I can’t imagine that you want to contract the virus or deliver it to Essex County. 

Stay home, open a bottle of excellent wine, and be grateful that retirement has spared you from spending Mr. Nathan’s birthday working on the front lines of this terrible pandemic.

No, this isn’t what I planned for retirement. But the virus has given me pause to re-evaluate what and who is really important to me, has forced me to stay home and learn to enjoy solitude, and to savor the occasional outdoor gathering with relatives.
I have decided to be patient regarding travel, dining, socializing indoors with friends, etc., at least until we get a better picture of where a vaccine stands. Until then, I’ll continue on a path of self discovery and contentment with what I already have.

My husband and I have been very careful and drove three hours to visit his 80yo parents for the first time since this all began just two weeks ago. We told them ahead of time that we would bring our own chairs to sit outside, wear masks, follow what we thought were agreed-upon rules for serving food, and only go indoors to use the bathroom. We got there, and they immediately threw all that out the window. They had set the table indoors because it was “too hot” outdoors (it wasn’t). We insisted on eating outdoors anyway. They were hurt by our wearing masks with them, and we caved (never mind that I was hurt that they wouldn’t wear masks for us). They kept breaching the six feet distance. They actually hugged my husband. Eventually they got my husband to come into their air-conditioned house, where he sat with them for over an hour, unmasked. I stayed outside, which I know they saw as rude behavior. It was awful, and I can finally breathe easily today as it has finally been 14 days since then.

I will not be returning until this is over, and my husband is faced with three difficult choices: don’t see his parents (possibly ever) again, see them while offending them, or see them on their terms and risk compromising their and our health. How do you get parents/in-laws who are sensitive to follow the rules? This isn’t even a partisan thing. They aren’t anti-mask. They just don’t think the rules apply to family, and sharing stories of family spread doesn’t sway them.

At 73 and three years older than any male in my direct family line has survived, I feel quite comfortable wearing a mask for eight hours straight and choosing stairs over an elevator. Four more years of relative isolation is my current plan, as well as avoiding any vaccination for the Trump Virus that is in any way related to his comically named "Warp Speed."

To Paula Span- I think what bothers me about this article is your use of a white privileged couple standing outside a beautiful home.  That image while indicative of a life of elitism that was considered normal for the "equal" under the law communities of the USA in the past no longer is the future. 
WE witness now that those lifestyles had major impact on people of color and was based on exclusion, prejudice and economic exclusion. 

So why use them ? They have had so much already. 
I have family that is similar to that couple and they stay put. 
Please explain,

Ellen

With no school this fall we want to help care for our grandchildren while their parents are working. Our kids are reluctant to expose us to the risk, but really need the help. We’re all doing algorithms.

This is entirely an unnecessary choice.  We have seen most countries get infection rates down low to make it reasonably safe for seniors as well as open up the economy.  This is about bad, incompetent leadership.  It should not be about whether seniors should take risks.

The Nathans sound like very nice people but...please don't come to NY, and if you do, please don't invite your children from Florida.  Surely you can wait to celebrate until it's safe!  Plus, someone in Lake Placid may very well report you.  Is that how you'd like to remember the big eight-zero?
The Cleveland risk calculator gives a percentage number but does not explain what the number means. Anyone know where to go to find out?

I am 71.  I live by myself in Bogota, Colombia - a city at a mile and a half in the Andes.

I have house help to manage my penthouse apartment but otherwise, I do shopping, cooking and exercising.

I used to swim at my country club every day for an hour.  But it is now shut.

We have been in the lockdown - aislamiento -  since March 20.  In the beginning, there were strict but allowed you to go for groceries. 

But I shop at 7:00 am when the only folks inside the grocery store are clerks waiting for you. 

Using groceries as a loophole, I walk almost 10 miles a day.

Knowing Wuhan kills your lungs, this walking at this altitude - I think my lungs stay strong.

If folks follow simple precautions of staying as much away as you can from strangers, wear masks indoors with strangers around, and most importantly, stay healthy.

Hard for me to believe Wuhan will get you.

2 decades back when I was younger, I lived in Indonesia in another outbreaks of Chinese viruses, H1N1 and SARS.

Same attitudes and I never got sick.

Folks giving in to irrational fears - I hate to say - are their own worst enemy - worse than Wuhan.

Have patience. Try out something new. Though, indeed, every minute seems to count more past 65. This will end. Things will get better, possibly way better. Countries across the world will have been challenged and changed. New solutions to issues will arise. I am looking forward with eagerness though I am in my 70’s, helping my spouse get through more chemo, missing the grandkids like crazy, doing all the driving,  grocery-shopping, cooking and housework myself (as per usual) , etc. Meanwhile, being very smart and careful. Helps a lot that I know Biology!
These people are hysterically cautious. A family gathering. They’re not going to a bar with 20 year olds. Have fun sheltering at home when your best years past you by because of the Dems narrative.

Well u say seniors over 80 are at the most risk wouldn’t u say you are blessed if u live that long so myself do not care   If I pass away at over 80 but some older people are really scared n that’s ok we are all different I will be 80 next year it really is in Gods hands if he calls me n I pass away I’ve lived a good life!

The Cleveland Clinic link, which is the most useful part of this article, is not a direct link to a survey senior readers can take to assess their risk of getting infected with Covid-19, as was implied by the article (or I inferred). It is a link to a technical looking NIH set of documents. Please remove or rewrite the paragraph so it does not appear to connect readers to a survey they can take - because we can’t, or at least not easily or obviously.

A good vaccine has maybe a 80 to 90% effectiveness rate.   That means that for every 10 people that get the shot, 1 or 2 won’t be protected.  For people in very high risk groups that would mean that they will still have a problem even if a great vaccine becomes available

I am 72 years old.  I wear a mask when I go out, keep safe distance and wash my hands as often as I think I need to. I also carry a bottle of Alcogel when I go out.
I am not willing to stop living my life in a way I can enjoy it.  I refuse to stay home and isolate myself from the world.  I don't consider this way as 'living'.

Oh! to have the luxury of to proceed or not with a family visit .
For me ,my wife is in hospice care in a NYC Nursing home that is
still prohibited by New York State to allow visitations and when they do it will most likely be by regulated appointments .
I have not seen my wife since last May. she calls from the nurses station and cries that she misses me and then I do as well.
What a netherworld to be in ,with seemingly no end in the immediate  future .

My husband and I are older and feel vulnerable given the federal government's abject failure to protect Americans. To this day there's not enough PPE. What will happen as cases keep going up? When the flu arrives? Will governors and hospital admins still have to make midnight runs in unmarked trucks to get the supplies they've ordered and paid for, or will the feds pirate them? No way we want to chance ending up in the hospital.

We are as strict now as we've been since March except we're not being maniacal about disinfecting the groceries. We still leave the mail outside to bake in the sun, and we don't go anywhere. Our son lives nearby but is so afraid of getting us sick, we spend our time together out in the yard, 6-ft apart, wearing masks.

And these people who are commenting that they are very careful when they go out, masks, gloves, social distance... these are the same people commenting on other articles that young children should not be attending class in-person next fall. Oh no no no. If you are at high risk from covid-19, then please do not leave your house. If you think the children should stay home from school next fall, then you should also help contain the pandemic by not leaving your house. If you think it’s too risky for children to return to school (with masks and social distance), then your activities (with masks and social distance) are too risky too

what is the matter with these people? the korean government advises even people in the same family do not eat together and not talk to each other. my parents live together but use seperate bathrooms bedrooms and communicate via text as they are 60.please americans its not so hard!

We are somewhat younger than the Nathans, but we are still seniors and our experiences have been similar to theirs.  We cancelled our usual trip up North this summer.  (I know: boo hoo, the ultimate first world problem.)  But I don't want to get this virus.  And the more we know the better.  May God protect us from this disease and a President who is now doing his level best to hide data from Americans and the world.
But ..... what if you are over 65 and still working?  What then.

This is an interesting article but the title is misleading. I thought it would give more concrete advice outside of a) don't get old b) don't be an American and c) a link to a calculator.  So how do you calculate the risk of Coronavirus? Just like with our failed leadership, we are all left on our own to figure that path and just hope it isn't the wrong one.

Risks, risks, risks. Everyday I calculate my risks. At first, I was sheltered at home, my daughter and grandkids were very good about picking up anything I needed. But after 4 weeks...I’ve gone to the grocery myself, picking a time and a store location where the traffic was less. I gauge the parking lot, if it’s full, I just keep going. 

Been to the doctors and dentist, but still haven’t gotten my hair cut or a pedicure. 

Taking French lessons thru zoom at the library. And I’ve been to the library twice, where some of the strictest distancing rules are in place. Return books are quarantined for 72 hours, reserved books are put on the scanner to check out, all you have to do is scan your card. And only one person in at a time. 

I’ve given up my volunteer job at the local farmers market, I think I miss that most of all. I’m considering going back, very early and helping before the market opens now that we have a mandated mask order by the governor. 

We have a long planned family vacation on the Outer Banks that everyone is keeping their fingers crossed for. We’ve all agreed to quarantine ourselves before we go because there is me, the grandparent, and one family member who has an compromised immune issue. If we can get tested, we will. But it’s hard to find a test here in NC, unless you’ve been exposed. 

Mentally, it’s been getting harder and more frustrating. I find solace in my small garden where at least I can see the bugs I’m battling.

An unspoken aspect of this conversation is the assumption this situation will continue into an unknown, limitless time frame. Look at Europe, New Zealand, South Korea, Ben China. If we could all (or a huge majority even) act in a way to drive the infections down, we would be "out of jail." With the rate as high as it is, I don't know if it's three weeks of wearing masks and social distancing or 5 weeks, but it doesn't have to be an indefinite time frame. 

There is no magic to reducing infection rates. I'm not for shaming people into wearing masks.
