I take my daily walk and pass a very few people without masks, and they and I widen the distance between us just as those who are approaching with masks do. I greet them either way with my (hidden) smile, a wave or a "hello." 

One way to keep personal help afloat economically if your income continues is to send money to those who have provided personal services during the break of their service -- people who clean your home, cut your hair, do your nails, provide training or massages, etc. and buying take out from a favorite restaurant. 

Fear can be useful to guide healthy practices, but it shouldn't keep us from doing the right thing, whether that pertains to health or the economy.

The real point is a significant proportion of the population is alive today due to artificial interventions.  Meaning medical procedures, which are man made and therefore artificial, such as surgery and pharma is what's keeping them alive.  environmental as well, like air conditioning.

Those interventions function with in a very narrow set of parameters to be successful.  Change something and the outcomes change.  That's all we're seeing.

I went to the COVID calculator. Unless I'm misunderstanding it, it's no help at all. It seems to predict who will get the virus based upon who has tested positive for virus in a large sample (correlational study). But most of the variables they ask about, like age and pre-existing medical conditions, predict who will get a more severe case, not who is more likely to become infected. My understanding is that the only variable that really matters in that regard is: have you been in contact with somebody who has the virus? That's there, but why are all the other variables there? For example, race is included. That seems to make sense since e.g. Blacks are more likely to become infected than whites. But that's because of moderator variables like income and type of employment (which may put Blacks in more contact with people, some of whom may be infectious). So once again, it's not race that predisposes somebody to become infected -- it's how race influences contact with those who may be infected. And if you are Black but staying at home, then the race question is irrelevant or misleading. So -- what is the point of the survey? (Correlation does not imply causation)

I went into a non-grocery store for the second time the other day. Very exciting! My husband and I would like to go for a drive today, but I'm calculating. . . will the outdoor places we might go to be crowded? We won't eat at a restaurant, so what happens if we need to use a bathroom? It's tourist/summer home visitor time here. So. we'll probably keep our drive very local.

Given the range of life's possible horrors, however, this is quite manageable. We're pretty healthy. We have food, and plenty of it. Our home is intact, not ravaged by floods, tornadoes, fire, or bombs. Our children all live far away, so it's nothing new not to see them for long stretches of time, and usually there's one who's put out with us anyway.  I have a job that permits me to work remotely.  If we stay alive, there's a good chance we'll get to take the vacation we missed, go to a concert, get together with friends. That puts us in the category of the elite compared to much - no, most - of the world. So we don't get whiny very often. 

The only thing that makes my blood boil is that ineffectual - no, BAD - leadership in the White House and an absence of coordinated public education at the federal level about preventing the spread have made this a circus of difficulties for people in life or death situations.  And we are lucky to have Governor Mills in office rather than her bombastic predecessor. Can't imagine what a hash he would have made of this.

With all the extra risk factors for seniors, why are some states, like California, still insisting you show up in person at the DMV office,  stand in a line (even with an “appointment”)  to get your drivers license renewed?  Then there is getting a jury summons.  How in the world can that process be made free from Covid-19 exposure?

Too many friends and family members make proximity and activities a matter of trust and not science. We’re fortunate to have a group of friends as careful as we are so, for at least the summer, we get some in person, outdoors socializing. We hear stories of people taking distancing and other precautions as a personal attack, “you don’t trust me”. Weariness and fear is understandable, disregard for other people’s concerns and precautions is not. Under the circumstances, if you can’t be satisfied with seeing/communicating with a close one with some restrictions, you’re the one in need of readjustment. The next many months need to be about patience and resilience.
The link to the Cleveland Clinic calculator is useless, why even put in the article?

Our calculus is simple. We’re in our 70’s. If we run out of meds, we run out of life. We stay home.

Luckily, our iPads have not run out.

I tried the riskcalc.org/COVID19/ link using a chromebook and a windows 10 laptop and kept getting the 502 Bad Gateway message so I tried riskcalc.org alone and got into the Clevland Clinic Risk Calculator Library. Clicking the SELECT A CONDITION drop down menu brings up several conditions including COVID19. It's not user friendly enough for this 65% centenarian with no medical background, but I already know that my age and physical condition, infection could result in death or serious injury. So should I go to my favorite AA meeting with roughly 25 people sitting 3 feet apart in an air conditioned room, some wearing masks, some not, with people now shaking hands, talking with their masks pulled down.....or should I stick with the zoom version? Here's my thought process: According to Georgia Tech exposure risk calculator https://covid19risk.biosci.gatech.edu/ in McHenry county, IL, there's an approximately 25% chance of at least one person in a communicable state of infection attending that meeting. No warm fuzzy there. Masks are mandated by the club rules but there's no enforcement. If I do go I'd only feel safe wearing an N95 mask and use a hand sanitizer making me really look out of place. Where do I sit? Between mask wearers is preferable but I can't control that. Any comments about my dilemma?

At age 80 with assorted medical preconditions (I have survived three heart attacks), I--and my wife--have reduced our world to the confines of our property: 5/8 of an acre.  We expect this siuation to continue well into 2021.  We had to have a service tech come on the property (with full PPE) to change the modem (we can't live without the Net), but that's it.   We'll talk with family on the phone.  And our cross-Canada train trip has now been moved (again) to 2021.   

There are some plusses.  Our gasoline bill has all but disappeared. The yard's getting long-overdue attention.  We're starting to clean out stuff that's needed to go.  We've rediscovered jigsaw puzzles.  Thanks to Magnificat, I've learned to say Mass at home.  The world has not changed: the old world---the way it once was--is gone.  To stay hunkered down is a vote for being here whenever the new world emerges.

In a normal year with no covid there are 2,800,000   people that die in the United States every year.

Two winters ago 65,000 people die from the flu and nobody said a peep about it.

This year the Chinese Flu has caused that figure to double.  Because there was no flu shot to damp down the figure.

The risk of this thing has been outrageously overstated.

If you want to be afraid of it, more power to you.  But anyone under 40 has nothing to fear.   

If your heath is such that a normal bout with the flu could kill you, you've got something to worry about.  No one else does.

I am 65 and work at a job where social distancing is impossible and only a handful of the workers (mostly past 50) wear masks. Thanks to the administration, the federal agency for which I work does not mandate masks.

The risk flowchart is as such:

1)  Do you plan to vote for Trump in November?
    a) If Yes, go shopping without a mask, because the fake Chinavirus hoax is a liberal commie plot to take over the world.
    b)  If No, continue to wear masks, social distance, wash your hands, and monitor your health for symptoms.

We are faced with very similar choices. Our only grandchild turns 1 in August, have not seen him in person since New Years. They live in Virginia, We are in our early 60s. Only health issue is I have hypertension but it is fully under control with medication. Regularly exercise and we have been very careful although have not restricted ourselves as much as the couple from MD (we go to the grocery store and home improvement stores, both of us go to our places of work but very few others are there and we are able to stay way far away from the others, wear masks in public, frequent hand washings and use of sanitizer).

We are also scheduled to go to Yellowstone in early fall. Bucket list item planned for over a year. Have cancellation insurance but really do not want to do that.

I tend to lean Republican but I cannot understand the sheer stupidity of people not being willing to wear masks. It is even more boggling that anyone with an ounce of common sense would ever think that this is a personal freedom issue (but we are frequently seeing how common sense is not included in the Venn diagram circle for many people.

Forrest Gump had it right - stupid is as stupid does. As a consequence where making trips like this, family gatherings, etc. would not be an issue we find ourselves closer to lockdown again.
Sorry! NYT attached this incorrectly. It was a reply to Robert’s comment on the Nathan’s as hysterically cautious.

For those of us with elder care responsibilities, these risks apply to us as well. I'm a healthy 55 year old with a number of elderly relatives who need my support. I weigh every activity carefully because if anything happens to me, they would be without the help they depend on. The article could have mentioned that protecting our elders also means that caretakers need to stay healthy too.

I'm 70. It broke my heart but I recently withdrew from a long planned role as the officiant at a dear friend's daughter's wedding in spite of their thoughtful plans for distancing, masks, etc.  As the officiant, distancing from wedding guests would be difficult and disheartening for all.  And I couldn't, in good faith, participate in planning the ceremony when I had one hand on the mental rip cord if local conditions worsened.   My decision was sealed by the fact that we and a small group of friends have developed protocols for meeting; outside, distanced, careful.  We cherish those meetings.  I knew that my participation would concern members of that small group, some of whom have medical conditions. It would make them uncomfortable and concerned about my exposure.  Maintaining and building relationships now have a whole new "trust" factor that must be considered.

There are reliable indications that I'm immune to Covid-19. That's consistent with 78 years of very high resistance to infections. But for years I've been told by doctors that I am a potentially hazardous "asymptomatic carrier" of contagions. That haunts me,  so I stick to the rules.

Having no fear of infection, my personal reaction to the pandemic is a growing grief for its impact on the people, the nation I love and the way it has exposed and exacerbated the malignant dysfunctions in our culture and its government. It's as if a shadow has fallen upon the land to block out the truths and the values we once pursued with hope and confidence. 

I thought I saw hope in a video; there was a little girl marching with  an ethnically mixed group, peacefully pleading for justice. But then I had a PTSD flashback from an older film where the little girl wore a red coat. 

I'm too old to fear dying. But I didn't want to do it with a broken heart.

We had a planned reunion to celebrate my husband’s 90 year old mother’s birthday. People coming from all around to stay in a lodge together. The children and grandchildren cancelled for the safety of his mother. She agreed of course. Everyone is sad. Why doesn’t this man’s family do the same? While he struggles they plan their fun. Ultimate selfishness. Come on family get a grip!

I’m over 65, imuno-compromised, and working in a warehouse. I was one of the first at work to wear a face shield which I pair with mask I'll pull over my nose when I feel the social distance requested by my employer is not available. By lucky coincidence all of the soap and paper towel dispensers are motion activated. My employer already had a pandemic plan in place when the pandemic was first recognized - the fact is work and home are my safe spaces. Grocery shopping and picking up prescriptions are a nightmare I’d gladly Saran Wrap for those activities!

This will pass. I have trust in that. Meanwhile, these 2 seniors (spouse, me) will be sticking close to home, limiting socially distanced meetings with 2 friends to outside only, all of us masked. 

We anticipate this will last at least a year, likely  longer, until a solid therapeutic or vaccine comes along. Living modestly and being in a position fo avoid exposure, we plan to be 2 less Covid patients for the health care system to handle.

Looking on the bright side I think this has cost Trump the grandma vote. His plan for fixing Social Security and MediCare seems to be to kill off a lot of seniors. We can sacrifice ourselves for the economy or live in isolation without seeing our grandkids. The Trump presidency already feels like at least eight years. I realize I am fortunate to even have the choice to socially isolate or risk having a small careful family group and extremely limited and occasional masked visits to a store. Not tired of winning as he promised, we are mostly just sick and tired.
@Paula Span   So 4.6% means I have a 4.6% chance of becoming infected?

As older people, my wife and I started social distancing and "lockdown" before any state or local stay-at-home orders were put into place, and we haven't changed our behavior much when the lockdown orders were eased nor when they were reapplied.  The only major change came when the government flip-flopped on mask use.  I avidly read the media for new developments, but in reality little has changed over the the past few months concerning risk factors or behavioral guidance, and so we're unlikely to start doing anything different.  At this point a vaccine is nothing but a mirage, and if something comes along that is only 50% effective (the FDA criterion for adequate efficacy) we're unlikely to change our behavior, although I have no hesitation getting vaccinated assuming no major side effects.

Not complicated for me at all.  At my age, I’m in a high risk category.  I’m still in Phase 1 now and if I see any more crowds of people partying in bars, I’ll have to put myself in quarantine or perhaps Saran Wrap!  And yes, my “only interest lies in not dying.”

Excellent article. We are 66, retired, we have limited our socializing to our immediate family. Our adult  and their families have quarantined and have down their best to adhere to wearing masks in public and social distancing. We are 15, but get together outdoors where we can social distance, until the weather changes and then we will meet in small groups with windows opened and masks on. Even going camping we wear masks and social distance, a small inconvenience so we can see each other, once in a while...we’ve met twice now, in five months and our county has flattened the curve nicely, thanks to everyone cooperating! 

We could squash Covid19 IF everyone would please wear masks and social distance.
Death from COVID is not the only negative outcome of infection.

It’s our 50th wedding anniversary at the beginning of August. My daughter and family live in the US, not allowed to visit France. My son and family live in Dublin advised by the Irish government not to visit France. We are not big party people but it would have been nice to do something special together. On the whole we won’t lose any sleep over it, not worth the risk 😷

In science, there is qualitative data.  This is data that is derived from portraits of conditions, not numbers.  

As a data management/designer/specialist I can state with authority that this article is exceptionally flawed. 

What has arisen since the beginning of June 2020, in the United States, which reports on the facts and particulars of Covid-19 infections, and the increase in cases and deaths in my state of California, are qualitative facts, that it is the youth, as young as 18 who are acquiring the disease and dying.  

A disproportionate number of young individuals, who clearly thought they are immune and made of steel, acquired the infection while grouping "outdoors" not indoors, in the state of California. 

This article is false, and subjects like so many of the ill informed articles of the New York Times, the actual qualitative data of the new Covid-19 infections, hospitalizations, ICU hospitalizations, and deaths. 

Reference California's Covid-19 datum.  The number of new deaths are in the zone of persons older or equal to age 18, but not more than 49 years of age. 

I am licensed as a certified Contact Tracer.  I am college educated in virology, biology, and genetics.  I worked in a genetic engineering firm.

I am angry. We all should be angry. We have an incompetent managing the coronavirus defense. He says he is commander in chief. He has over 135,000 deaths.  Over 3 million wounded. And he claims he is doing a great job.  He refuses to follow basic science. All of us are restricted in our normal activities. Our children are at risk.  But he can put troops in cities to harass protesters.   This incompetent must be fired.  Vote him out.

Really, why do you need a rona calculator?  You're probably not going to become infected if you stay away from other people, keep you hands off your face, and keep them and your face clean.  Of course, I'm not a Dr. or a scientist, so I'm pretty sure I don't know what I'm talking about.  No matter what is used to calculate your odds of being infected, if you're negligent and practice risky behavior, it only takes a little virus getting on one of your mucus membranes and you're fried.  Just stay away from other people.  If you want to go outside, wear a mask.  And, as far as the haircut goes, go online, order a barber clipper for 20 bucks and give yourself a buzz cut.  Takes about 10 mins. and you'll look great.  You can even select from numerous lengths.  I use 3mm.
It is very difficult to weigh the risks of exposure to the virus against isolation.  Thank you for this helpful article.

This article reflects the dilemmas in my family. My sister and brother-in-law have regretfully given up seeing their grandchildren for a week, because the Oregon resort where they planned to stay seems to be doing not much about protecting its guests. They are heartbroken, but it's better than possibly being dead.

My brother and sister-in-law plan to gather their large clan as ever at their vacation home in the high Sierra. 

My brother will be sad but not heartbroken to hear that both I and his sister (the one who will miss her grandchildren in Oregon) won't be seeing him until two weeks after he returns infection-free from the high Sierra. 

At our age, the downside is enormous.

We are 70  seniors who love to travel. In 2019 we travelled for approximately half the year to Japan, Canada, New England, England and Cuba. We went by air, rail, ship and personal auto.  This year we canceled all of our travel plans.

We are anxious about staying in South Florida during hurricane season. But any travel mode we consider is just too risky for us now. Mostly, we worry about encountering mundane medical problems away from home. A sprained ankle, a car accident, or a dizzy spell could expose us to the chaos of an unknown hospital system at best; and at worst, COVID-19. So we’re staying home, enjoying early morning and evening outdoor activities and hoping for the world to get better. We miss our families and friends who are spread across 4 continents, but no one thinks getting together is a good idea now.

I have a friend who, like me, is in her early 50s. She has been living her life the last few months as if there’s no pandemic—seeing lots of friends, going to small parties, etc. I’ve asked her whether she was worried about getting COVID, and she said she was willing to take her chances.

The other day she texted me in a panic: “I had a terrible cough today! My worst nightmare is getting COVID!”

I said, “But I thought you weren’t worried about getting it? 

She said, “Of course I’m worried about getting it!”

Luckily, the cough disappeared, and she felt fine the next day. 

Isn’t it interesting how the COVID scare caused her to quickly change her tune?

Why do these discussions never include risk to others? No matter what age you are, the more risks you take, the more likely you are to spread the virus to others. 

The question shouldn’t be, “How do we live our lives during a pandemic?” The question should be, “How can I stay physically and mentally healthy until we have a vaccine or treatment, and avoid contributing to the spread of this horrible illness?”

I am a senior folk. If and when I leave my house I take my mask without fail ( even if I have to return home to get it) and do not enter any (to me) place where I cannot have spacing between others.  I space myself from those to whom I am talking.  I think it is incumbent on all of us to care for others  as well as our self.
You just have to be careful and alert at all times

No masks?  Better have good health insurance, a will and
prepaid funeral plans.

Hey he data here is sketchy

Anyway

You are the at risk group. You could die if you catch it

Wear a mask
