It’s easy. No voodoo here. Common sense

Seniors who speak to medical professionals in ICU’s dealing with elderly Covid 19 patients on respirators quickly learn the awesome reality that those who survive are almost invariably compromised and “never the same”. The reality is that for seniors there are no “2nd chances” after catching Covid-19. Staying home and away from crowds/shopping may become tiresome.
But it does bring the great gift of waking up to enjoy another day.

I am 73 and sealed into an apartment in California. I was relieved to get to the end of the article and discover that Dave Nathan did not to to Lake Placid. Dave, please don't let anyone talk you into going to London in September. 

It just isn't worth it. There will likely be a vaccine sometime next year. London will still be there.

Many older people getting covid do not make a full recovery, or recovery may take a long time. Just not worth the risk.

I'm 72, in good health in Ohio, have a BMI of 25, and the calculator yields 4%. 

Nevertheless, except for exercise, picking up groceries, and buying gasoline, I expect to stay as far away from others as possible at least into the fall months. If it takes longer for the pandemic to truly die down, then I'll continue to isolate myself. I know I'm fortunate to be able to do this.

I live in Europe. Does the wife know what's happening in the UK? Of course she shouldn't come to Europe and definitely not go to the theatre.  My husband and I are both 67, living in Prague, healthy, but would not consider taking an airplane at all not to mention one across the Atlantic Ocean. Certainly wouldn't go to the UK where the government handling of the virus is a mess. I am amazed how little Americans seem to understand about the severity of this virus, but what's happening around the world. It doesn't hurt to keep your sights on local friends until the cases go way down and there's a vaccine.

50 years ago, I chose to move to Denmark, and at that time most people would have said my prospects for a comfortable life would have been at least as good, probably far better had I remained. Today, it is shocking to read what my American cohorts are facing.
The fatality rate from Covid-19 in Denmark has been almost zero since May. My wife and I are planning a canoeing vacation to northern Germany, a country with ¼ of America’s population, yet has just about 10 fatalities per day. My wife, a teacher, will face students in several weeks, which we can accept, since the virus appears to have been tamed. Should it reemerge, anyone who wants a test can get one quickly, and anyone who needs treatment gets it for free. There is no doubt that the government will once again execute a plan based on science if needed.
I just turned 75, and the local authorities called to see if I needed any form of assistance, such as housecleaning, therapies, etc. Yes, America is truly exceptional, and that is by choice, many years of many bad choices.

I’m 66 year old widow and live alone in Paris. My son who lives in the US gave me a hard time last night after seeing a picture of me having lunch on a terrace with friends (one lady my age and her parents 90 & 91). He would like me to stay home and see nobody. I have grandchildren (3 & 5) in Paris I have only seen outdoors from a distance and wearing a mask. I have had picnics in the Luxembourg garden with friends my age. We don’t share food. My son who lives in the US with his girlfriend doesn’t understand that I need to weigh between sanity and safety. I haven’t had any physical contact since March 11th but I can’t live without any social time. No, you don’t have the same conversations or laughs on zoom than when you meet people for real. My mother died the week before confinement. There is a limit to what I can take. The calculator gives me a 3,5 risk.

Sitting outside the pool (in the shade) in my Tel Aviv apartment building. It’s virtually empty but it’s my splice except when it’s closed which could happen again. 

My NJ and California pals are terrified after five months in the midst of COVID. If I had taken the plane for which I had tickets in March I would have been stuck with them. They envy me. I agreed until we opened too quickly and a mess ensued. 

I’m under self selected semi quarantine. Everything gets delivered. See grandkids sometimes. Go to a class at a friends apartment once a week. Lots of spacing and fresh air. Live on zoom WhatsApp and kindle. Had to give up my part time teaching job. And I live alone which is either a blessing or a curse. I pray for RGB’s health and that the election ends Trump’s Reign of Error.

Stanton’s Best Advice For Surviving Trump As An Octogenarian:

--- Tune out of all further editions of Trump’s daily fake news follies. He cannot be wished away, but do your best.

--- Take a walk in the fresh air every day in a place that isn’t crowded. Masks optional.

--- Keep in mind that there are always a lot of people worse off than we are, and find a way of helping a few of them.

--- Call some relatives and friends you haven’t talked to recently.

--- Eat and drink in moderation, but happily.

---  Adopt a dog, cat or a horse if you can or do something else that helps animals.

--- Read books and watch movies that make you laugh. This is no time to improve your mind. P. G. Wodehouse and Buster Keaton are always good. (I personally frown on tales of murder, horror and dystopia, but they seem to work for some people.)

--- Think about the times in your life when you were at your happiest. Many of them were simple things that didn’t cost any money and didn’t require any miraculous improvements in our politics.

--- Pray every day, or -- if that doesn’t work for you -- complain to G-d. Someone may be listening.

Perhaps most important of all, do not embark on any personal improvement projects like learning to speak Hebrew, becoming a master chef or cleaning out your closets. All such activities are doomed to ignominious failure throughout these calamitous times.

I’m one of those seniors who would like to leave the US. After experiencing a continual decline in all areas of life here, it has become too frightening to remain. The president’s total denial of COVID and his encouragement of racism and violence is no longer avoidable. His ignorant and hateful words and actions leave me no choice but to move elsewhere. 

I feel this country may never repair. And if it does, it won’t happen in my lifetime. I’m entirely disgusted by his supporters. I have dropped friends and family over their racist, religious and sexist beliefs. So, as soon as US residents are allowed someplace, I will go. And just as I’ve sold off most of my belongings, I will rid myself of this vile nation. Leave it to the white, male dominated, homophobic, xenophobic, racist, war mongering, infantile, shortsighted .....

I know there’s no perfect country. But I also know from decades of personal experiences that the of the developed countries, the USA is the most unhealthy and least happy place to live. I just wish that a few of these COVID lemmings would mask up so the cases would slow down enough for me to leave. Then they can party on.

“Older people in New Hampshire or Maine — where new cases were falling last week — may reasonably opt for less restrictive behavior...”
This quote from the article should be clarified. Perhaps they may opt for less restrictive behavior in the locale where they live, but I’m sure their risk increases when they decide to travel outside their local environment.
I might be missing something but I don’t see how to interpret my risk calculation which is 1.6. What does that mean?

My father lives independently in an continuing care community where they have had no deaths from COVID, but his quality of life has gone way down due to all his usual social activities being cancelled. His lifetime contribution to family and to solving environmental problems for our world was enormous. Yet at this time in his life when he should be enjoying the fruits of a life well lived he can not have family visit and he has to watch much of his environmental work be dismantled. He ended our phone conversation last night by saying he is discouraged by the country his grandchildren and great-grandchildren are inheriting. It made me sad.

Normally, Dr. Fried pointed out, seniors would find decision-making less knotty because the C.D.C. would be providing detailed, science-based guidance for at-risk groups, updated weekly.

“It’s immensely atypical, I believe unprecedented, that we’re not seeing this,” she said. Without that leadership, seniors confront a crazy quilt of changing state and local policies, and “everyone’s on their own.”

That's a very very bad statement. If the CDC actually had done that ... they would have been giving guesses. That's all they have. They've changed their statements over and over. 
That's actually good science ... its seems so many people want them to be dogmatic, even if wrong.

My husband and I, both 65, have been locked down tight since the beginning of March. I’ve entered a grocery store once since that time. Connecticut is in a very good place right now so we both did get haircuts wearing masks in places with great safety procedures. Always masked when leaving the house.
The hardest part is not seeing our children and grandchildren who live in the DC area. So, we’ve made what seems to be a good arrangement. One of our daughters/son in law and their 2 boys quarantined for 2 weeks. No stores, no socially distanced get togethers, etc. They drove straight here and stayed for a week. It was wonderful. Our son is coming up today after doing the same quarantine procedures. Not everyone can do that with work and other obligations but it’s worked for us. Who knows what the winter will bring, so before school and other restrictions are upon us we thought it was the perfect time. Unfortunately, my older daughter and her family are required back at work and have started camp with their boys so a shut down for them is not an option. It could be a very long time before we are together.

Open a window?  Really?  Blow all those droplets around instead of them falling to land on something to die?

Probably moot for many, since air conditioning will certainly blow the particles around.

'Dave and Nancy were dreaming of Lake Placid....' Standing in front of their big house... Granted these are real people, and The Times seems to be writing TO and FOR these people, very well-off, white, planning on a vacation, but worrying about that 'pesky virus'! No, New York Times, most Seniors in this country are NOT the couple that are pictured at the beginning of your article. Most Seniors have other, more pressing concerns than 'Lake Placid'.

Judging by the comments, most readers are over 65 and this is not your first pandemic. I am curious as to how you handled the previous ones, did businesses and schools shut down? you were young and they mostly affected the over 65.
This is what I found on the CDC website: the 1957 pandemic, killed 116,000 Americans (US pop. then was 172 million).
 It also killed 1,100,000 worldwide
And the 1968 pandemic, killed 100,000 Americans (US pop. was 200 million). It also killed 1million worldwide.

“People of color, obese people and men face higher risk.”  So the Times grudgingly got the British Study’s conclusion half correct, the other half ordered incorrectly by likelihood of severe consequences from the virus.  The Study concludes that it is males who suffer most from getting the virus.  The Times also is flatly wrong about the language used by the Study to describe the conclusion.  The term used in the Study to describe the group suffering most from the virus is ‘Males, not ‘men.’  The NYTimes needs to stop manipulating the conclusions of the British Study!

We live in a pleasant older home on 1/2 acre in a pleasant small city.

Until the infection rate hahs dropped way down or the vaccine is widely distributed, we will:

Shop at stores with everyone wearing amask and social distancing;

Occasionally buy take-out from our favorite restaurants,

And maybe just a hair cut once in a while.

We will not be traveling or flying anywhere. It's not worth the risk, especially in a country when no national response plan led by a lunatic.

Without an economy people will end up homeless and starving, but the vulnerable need to protect themselves. Given that the elderly and people with preexisting conditions deathrate is hundreds of times higher than for healthy, young people, it doesn’t make sense to treat everyone the same. Have basic precautions for everyone, mask, distancing, etc, and further isolation for the vulnerable.

Most people in the 40-55 age group will choose to wait awhile before getting any vaccine that comes along.  

People under 40 will likely skip it altogether rather than risk possibly lifelong side effects from a rushed vaccine; that age group is hardly threatened by Corona at all.  

So don't count on a vaccine for herd immunity; most of the herd will decline the vaccine (which probably will be less than 60% effective anyway).

We have flu vaccines that almost all elderly people get every year and yet tens of thousands of elderly Americans die from the flu every year anyway.

The idea of elders being shut in for 18 months is profoundly unrealistic.

For one thing, a lot of older people still have to work.  I’m 64 and I’ll be working for at least another 2 years.

For another, a lot of us have to take public transportation.  Many older people are no longer able to drive.

But most importantly staying inside your home for 18 months is a good way to go insane.  

Limit your outings.  Wear masks.  Stay 6 feet apart.  But forget plastic wrap or solitary confinement.

my friends who just got back from a trip abroad are having an intimate dinner - social distancing outdoors with people that they haven't really seen in a long time.  my husband immune compromised and we are all over 50!  there will be one person who is over 80!!!  what are they thinking???  and we are in california!  this is madness to think they will be immune from any of this. the risk is not worth the price.

I'm an epidemiologist who, quite understandably, follows the SARS-Cov-2 epidemic closely. It's actually pretty easy. Under no circumstances should people, especially at risk people such as seniors, spend any more time than is essential in indoor environments, shopping infrequently only for necessities for a brief a duration as possible, wearing a properly fitting mask for the whole time indoors. Bars, cinemas, restaurants, churches, public transit and especially aircraft are very dangerous. So is any crowded outdoor space where it is difficult to maintain at least 6 - 10 feet distance from others. Fomites, transmission of virus from surfaces, are less of a problem than initially thought, but practicing vigorous hand hygiene remains essential. Travel, any travel, is simply a bad idea, even with precautions. Outdoor activities where spacing is possible are highly desirable for mental and physical health & should be incorporated into every single day. People who must go into indoor environments because of work should take every precaution, knowing that being inside with others puts them at very high risk of Covid-19. It's not very complicated, but it is difficult to accept.

I’m 77 and I just drove from Massachusetts to Montana.  Along the way, I stayed in places that had no contact check-in and digital keys.  I carried my own cleaning supplies and wiped everything down as soon as I entered the room.  I was careful at all stops and felt no more at risk than when I am home where I’m more likely to be out at a market or walking a fairly crowded bike path.  Montana despite having hotspots has fewer actual cases of infection than all of Western, MA.  I am visiting with my daughter for a few days and then I will be camping most of the time for two months.  I will take all reasonable precautions.  

If someone my age doesn’t feel safe, they should do whatever makes them comfortable.  There no real point in doing anything else.  On the other hand, it doesn’t hurt to take a deep breath, gather as much good information as possible and try to assess the real level of risk to you.  Spending 18 months in a hermetically sealed room is, I have to think, an utterly stupid idea.  As I said, I’m 77. I could be dead in three years. I’m not going to put my life on hold for 18 months.

How they should calculate their risk depends to a great extent on their living situation. 
 Your photo depicts a well to do white suburban couple whose privilege lowers their risk factors .  They can afford to have all supplies delivered, their home is a distanced, self contained unit, they have access to the best of communications, internet, phones etc.,and the best medical care. 
   Many ,if not most, New Yorkers lack this.  NYT plays to the high end, to the white, to the fortunate once again.

We have relatives in New Zealand, and were planning a trip down under when the virus hit the fan. That's now on hold for the foreseeable future. Americans aren't even welcome in the country right now.

Thanks to real leadership, N.Z. has all but beaten coronavirus. I exchanged emails last week with one of our relatives in Christchurch, who was on holiday on New Zealand's west coast. Except for international tourism, things are getting back to normal. He expressed his condolences to us Americans who are headed full speed in reverse.

The link to the calculator worked for me, and I was able to fill out the form with accurate date; however, the number it returned is meaningless without more context. 

What I mean by that is: the result is a number expressed as a percentage, labeled as "predicted probability" but probabilty of WHAT is not defined. 

For instance, if my calculated result is 2%, does it suggest I have a 2% chance of contracting Covid-19? Over what period of time? With what precautions? Does it mean a 2% chance of death (or perhaps of survival ;-)) if I contract it?

Etc.

It feels like it is more dangerous the more things reopen. Our supermarket used to only let 15 people in at a time and had someone sanitizing the carts. Now it’s back to “normal” except that everyone wears masks.  Restaurants that would bring take out to the car now require that you wait in a line, sometimes indoors.

Why not let folks decide for themselves, what feels right for them (instead of subtle pressures/shaming for people to conform with whatever the current mindset is)?  The angle of this story, which is focusing on Seniors, is clearly more or less asking 'how can Seniors protect Themselves from getting sick and very possibly dying (due to their age/health condition).'

Do we have articles asking how seniors can protect themselves from dying in a car crash (which is far, far more likely to happen), or from a litany of other ailments that will eventually do a Senior in?

There are in fact many reasonable old folk out there who are not in denial about their own mortality, and just because they want to be able to continue to Live Life, does not have to necessarily mean they are, therefore, being reckless.  Just like everyone else, seniors should take basic precautions.  Aside from that, they should enjoy life, for however many days/ weeks/months/years may remain for them.

My mother is 102. I’m 72. We’ve been staying at home since March 12. My mother goes nowhere. I go almost nowhere. Our house and yard is a Covid-19 free zone.

We are grateful for grocery delivery, online shopping, the good practices of the drive through pharmacy and bank, the precautions implemented by the local post office. We are fortunate to have a pleasant backyard, ebooks form our local library, entertainment from several streaming services. Our socializing is by phone or Skype.

We are so fortunate to be able to live this not unpleasant life and plan on doing so until there is a vaccine. We are alive and will survive.

Mostly staying home and doing a little outdoor walking and hiking.  Getting lonely; but, have a wonderful roomie.  Psychologically, I take it in increments.   For instance, "For the next three months, I will continue to isolate."  The best thing I can do for myself and for society is stay out of the way.  

Although there are ways to minimize risk and still engage socially, my concern is that it is difficult for people to maintain the mask and six feet dance consistently.  I went to a socially distanced event (outdoors) not to long ago.  But I noticed people in the group were starting to remove masks after a half hour or so.  Do I want to be an enforcer?   Not so much ...

After complying with restrictions, I’ve had it. I’m old, not dead, mask in place we need to lead our lives. It’s the most insane year I’ve seen on so many levels: there are people about to be evicted, people standing in line for food, and goon squads of a Federal government gone mad beating on peaceful protesters. Our constitution is in danger. I think we need to ask ourselves if sitting out this historic year is the way we want to be remembered. Seniors need to fight, too. We need a line of seniors between fascist goons and peaceful protesters. #SeniorsAgainstFascism!
Paula Span's answers to readers' questions and comments added greatly to her article.

My 91 year old mother told me (over the phone) she is tired of staying home, so is going out with her friends. She says she's old, and doesn't care if she dies.  But what about all the people she might infect?  Like most, she can't see beyond her own 'need' to get a haircut or eat in a closed restaurant. It's demoralizing.

My husband & I are old. We live in Ohio, where the numbers are rising fast and our county is the worst.

We go to the grocery store. He still has to work, but keeps his office door closed all day.  We don't go to restaurants. We don't see family as they're all too cavalier about this to suit us. (Them: But we're family.  Us: And your point is?) If we get McDonald's from the take-out window and the amount is $4.83, we give them a $5 and drive away. My husband has said he'd rather have a Willie Nelson ponytail than go get his hair cut. (His hair isn't that long yet, but it will be soon.)

We're getting sick of only being with each other, but the alternative of NOT being here together is much worse.

We have returned to near  full isolation here in Missouri.  Our state is chock full of nuts of the Rightwing type.  Masks were not mandatory nor used often in public with 35% or so non compliant at the highest times.  Wish we could move to a safer state but cannot now.

Dont travel this year and live to travel many more years. We simply dont trust anyone else outside our bubble of two as we have heard some pretty hair raising stories about what people are risking. N95 mask and swim goggles for entering any place.
Start by listening to Dr. Fauci, and turning off Traitor Trump TV.

According to prospect theory (Danial Kahneman, noble laureatte in behavioral economics) our fear of losing something is greater than what our reason tells us is probable. I think we should keep this in mind in our calculations. The horrible images that come to us through the media, day after day, has undoubtedly distorted out judgements.

Too many friends in health care in NY/NJ and a daughter who's a health policy analyst/modeler drove us into serious isolation. Trips to doctors, to the grocery store and to pick up food from our favorite restaurants have been our only risky activities. That's not likely to change soon. 

The biggest surprise has been obsessive interest in gardening, an old hobby. With little else to do, I managed to add an astonishing number of vegetables to the herb garden ... and then to four new beds. We'll be feeding ourselves and a couple close friends from now till October. I hope I can do it again next year.

I am 84. I live in the county in South Florida just north of Palm Beach. I have been in self quarantine since the first day of March. I do not go any place except on Monday morning at 7 o’clock I do the curbside pick up at Walmart. Every few weeks I go to the pool store for supplies and I don’t go in unless no one else is in the store I constantly wear a mask. I have no ailments or any conditions to worry about except for my age. My children and grandchildren who live south of me wanted to come up for Father’s Day I turned them down, I don’t know when I’ll see them again, but if I get Covid I may never see them again.￼￼We will see what happens next year.

Nice idea except this 70+ male with three underlying conditions lives in a house with a 17 year old that will soon be going back to school....

We have collectively been very careful all summer
What happens next does not look good

My husband and I have been inside for most of our waking hours since mid-March
We followed the guidelines with masks, distancing, etc.
My work pivoted to remote, but it was a nightmare because I teach hands-on lab courses, and I do not live in a lab.
The amount of twisting in the wind to find a way to deliver my courses was painful and so, given the option of running the courses as a mash-up of a hybrid version next month, I took it.
I will double-down on whatever safety measures are supplied, by bringing my own backups.
I know I am taking a calculated risk, but there are just some teaching and learning experiences that can't be replicated online in the classroom or on the job.
So I will take it one day at a time, carry sanitizer as a personal force field, and de-contaminate when I get home as if I am in a re-make of "The Andromeda Strain", but outside of work I will continue to semi-hibernate until when (and if )we ever get an all-clear.

First and foremost is to obey the laws and directives everywhere you go, if you choose to go.

Second, if you're not comfortable doing something, don't do it.  Don't let other people make your decisions for you.

Third, don't decide on what you're going to do or not do based on politics.

Cost versus benefit analysis.  Risk versus rewards.  Only you can answer the question but remember you'll get no do-overs.

My opinion is that it's too dangerous out there for most seniors to be traveling about very much.  The situation is bad and getting worse.  Stay home for now.

Wear a mask.

The chances of the Times publish this "blunt" assessment are slim, but here goes..  

This article provides no guidance.  Zero.  Nada.   It's just a confusing cacophony of "should we stay home" or "should we go out" with no real conclusions.  It's essentially worthless.  There's more solid information in some of the reader's comments than the article itself.  

The author might just as well have said, "I really don't know how you can protect yourself from COVID without going stir-crazy, but I have an article to write anyway".  

This is New York Times "click bait", taking advantage of older folks' need for solid guidance.  Unfortunately, there's none to be found here..

It's surreal being a senior. Where has the time gone?  And they funny thing I have so many memories and can remember what it feels like to be young. I wish these young people would realize with luck they might age also. Aging is not a curse; it is the result of life lived. I am blessed in that I am remarkably healthy ( I still ski every winter) and am retired owning my home. I feel for those that have to work. If everyone would just wear the mask this virus would be contained. How can people be so thoughtless and ignorant?

I'll turn 66 in a couple of weeks. Five years ago recovered from Stage 4 lymphoma. Train yearly for the Bay-to-Breakers foot race, including this year altho' this year's race is "virtual". I always wear a mask, run three times a week, mostly in the streets against traffic, weaving back to the sidewalk as needed. Here in San Francisco, on narrow sidewalks, a lot of folks dart out of their doorways onto the sidewalk and many of them aren't wearing masks. I think I'm being careful enough in public and have had a few outdoor restaurant meals with friends I trust.

Some of us download the NY Times data daily from https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data and reduce the data to Cumulative and Daily Cases and Deaths in both "raw" and "population-adjusted" measures (per 10,000). These are both in graphical and map form for the entire US by State/Territory and County. They are preset for Maine and the Northeast States (since that is where I live, but can be easily configured for your own locale). You can find this at https://public.tableau.com/profile/clinical.metrics.llc#!/ The source code is in the Public Domain.

Tell us something we don’t know. What is missing from all discussions is actual data from the millions of cases and thousands of deaths. But expecting actual work and organization from the current administration is just too much to ask. And worse, they are getting in everybody else’s way, so we are left with bandanna masks, social distancing, & hand washing. Tell us something we don’t know.

To Josh Hill who writes

﻿, If we had a real president, we could use masks and social distancing to bring it under good control as Europe

This is an incorrect and uninformed statement


France has a real President, and far from getting corona deaths under good control, wound up with a higher mortality rate than the US

As did Sweden, the UK, Italy, Spain ...

Kindly see today’s NY Times

Headline:

Europe Said It Was Pandemic-Ready. Pride Was Its Downfall

"The coronavirus exposed European countries' misplaced confidence in faulty models,”

Really remarkable priority discussion-when there should be all hands on deck for the elders who have no choice but to go to Nursing Homes which have been shielded from lawsuit liability -even as 'granny massacres' were  going on.                                       The same owner-operators are running theses facilities...the same Lobbyists and equity stakes Wall St investors commodifying old people.                                                           Unless elder reporters like Span and the NYT will get on this and demand accountability for the frail and vulnerable-and finally-years too late-persist in a deep dig into the NYS DOH and its licensing arm -the PHHPC-the evil status quo remains. 
This is elitist parsing and disdainful of journalistic responsibility-the calculations are couched in antiseptic data but not with any pretext of warranted indignation.

With what I have been reading recently, I figure my chances are about 100% sometime in the future. And I am a recluse by nature, still cutting my trips out of the house. But at 70 and type 2 diabetes,  I just hope I survive or it is over quickly.

I don’t mind Self isolating until next spring. Ask me around next April how I feel. Hopefully if we get rid of the maniac masquerading as a president we might start to see some light at the end of the tunnel by then￼￼.

Its shocking to me that so many Americans need to be counseled by health care professionals and  journalists to not act like spoiled children. is it really so bad to enjoy your husbands 80th at home together? how fortunate you have one another. stay at home as much as possible and maybe he'll see 81.

I am 65 and see only trouble ahead. I worked hard. Did an ok job with my kids. I’ve had heartache and some good things happen. I miss my old life. I miss my friends. I miss my kids. How many years do I have left?  Barring catastrophe, probably many. My parents are still alive. My grandmothers lived long into their 90s. I just don’t see much of a future though. I’m terrified to go out. I’m terrified of strangers. I’m terrified of everyone. I’m terrified that I don’t matter because I am getting old. I’m terrified that no one cares. How sad. No one cares.

I'm tired of hearing that we have to strike a balance between staying safe and re-opening the economy.  This is a false choice.  Countries like Germany, Taiwan, Vietnam, and New Zealand have proven that the pathway to re-opening the economy lies in protecting the populace.  There are easy ways to do this.  Social distancing, mandates for wearing masks, frequent hand washing, testing with quick results, tracing, and quarantining.  Where the government has led the efforts to keep the populace safe the economies are bounding back.  In the US where we have tried to force the re-opening of the economy without having a strategy to keep the population safe we are failing at both.  It's time we Americans get real.  It's not an either/or choice it's a both/and imperative.   Once we get a government that leads in laying out a strategy to protect us and the testing in place to track the virus we'll slowly and safely get back to business.

Good story of the lives of older Americans.  We may be at greater risks, but have so many less challenges due to the virus than younger people who have children and need to work.  Not sure I'd want to trade places with them.  As we should all realize, we are ALL in this together.  And, together, we will ALL get out of this mess.

My wife and I are very old people who are white and who you'd call privileged.  With that out of the way, we calculate the coronavirus risk extremely high right now.  We haven't exactly locked ourselves in the house, but only go out for true necessities and some exercise.  We mask, we distance.  We read the science as best we can.   We make up our minds based on the science, not on the politics, i.e., phase 1, phase 2, etc.  We're tired of staying home, but stay we will until we determine it's safe to do otherwise via proven vaccine and/or community behavior, and not based on what the politicians say.

What about people over 65 looking for jobs and the growing discrimination against them, as they are seen by many to be expensive vectors of disease?

And what about people over 65 who used to be active and are now atrophying mentally and physically -- especially physically -- because are constantly being told to stay inside? Some might prefer to just die now, which I can only assume the many who downplay this illness as being the illness of people who were going to die soon anyway would be thrilled with. How about providing easier euthanasia for people who don't want to spend what may be the rest of their lives indoors?
When I feel bad about isolating myself, I watch the national news. Life will never be what it once was.
I only regret that I have but one life to give so that Gen Zers can get back to their raging parties and meaningless app-based hookups.

My husband and I are both over 65.  We would love to go for a walk and have tried.  We live in a very populous area where though masks are required many people are still not wearing them.  When you are walking whether on a sidewalk or on a trail and people are 3, 4. even more abreast and not wearing masks, what can you do?  

My husband finally had it when a larger group was walking toward us and asked them politely, where their masks were.  The one closest to us just smiled and told us if we didn't like it, we did not have to walk there.  

I really don't know what I miss more.  The freedom to go out or just good, old fashion civility.

It may take months for a vaccine, but there will eventually be one and it’s worth the wait. 
(If for some reason the elderly are too vulnerable to be vaccinated, this is where herd immunity comes in if all young and most adults are vaccinated).  I remain optimistic that we aren’t talking about a lifetime of isolation.

I urged my elderly mother to work in and enjoy her garden (for a New Yorker, she is relatively fortunate even if the plot is small), go for walks, climb stairs indoors, and stay in touch by phone with friends.

Limit subway use to medical visits if any, and a definite no to her offer to come visit, which would have meant either 4  hrs by train or bus.

It’s not worth risking her life, and the experiences described by those who have  been hospitalized are not anything I’d wish on anyone, certainly not my mother.

I don't think I've ever seen a better example of the central fallacy of the field of economics than the referenced MIT article. Not everything can be reduced to dollars and a society that asks older people to self-isolate so that younger people can get back to earning those dollars will lose its soul.

“We have to find a balance between preserving safety and living”

As an 80 plus senior this is the most important thing I took from this column.  This, and a recognition that the “we” is a very personal we.  Nancy extended her we to include Dave, who as he puts it “finds no need to be daring.”  Finding the balance for Nancy and Dave comes down to Nancy and Dave as individuals and as a couple.  

All us 80 plus seniors are looking for that balance as individuals, some as couples.  We balance the joy of having an older grandchild come to share a beach house that is large enough to allow moderate self isolation while working as a take out waiter or summer lifeguard, and a wish to be around for another summer. We balance the wisdom of passing up a burger night that has  a 6 year old violating your safety space as he talks with about the baseball season opening, so important to him.  It feels like the need for finding a balance has become a full time occupation for some seniors, the lucky ones.  I say, let them do their thing.

First off:  Be well, all!

I am 77 and my wife is 68,  We live in Warsaw, Poland.  The last air travel we did was to a medical business meeting in Frankfurt in mid-February.  Two attendees at that meeting later came down with COVID-19.  We mask in stores, but we do eat in a restaurant (our favorite one does adequate social distancing as do most shops throughout Poland).  Since late April we have been shuttling back and forth with my wife's 92-year old Mom, both to her small country cottage and a nearby town.  We play tennis regularly.  

I hope we will be able to visit my kids in the US in late Fall.

Meantime, we have been reading reports in the Times and elsewhere that Italy has gotten the pandemic under control, and that one of our favorite cities, Venice, has taken some strong steps like banning cruise ships from its harbor and basically removing the glut of day-trippers from its pathways, canals, and lagoons... The finest hotels are offering good prices and personalized service, So masked, gloved and disinfectant doused, that is where we are going for our 17th Anniversary next month... hoping not to emulate Thomas Mann's aging protagonist.      

My bottom line is this:  Nobody lives forever.   Everyone can do some simple things to reduce their risk of infection.  If you play by a few new rules, at least you can continue to play.

This article made me a little depressed thinking about older people who have to keep working.  There are several custodians where I work, for example, who I'm sure would love to have the option not to leave the house.

Canada has handled the pandemic better than the USA, but like nearly all the affected countries failed miserably to triage care for the elderly and known medically vulnerable in some obvious ways, so that infection and mortality have been much higher than needed.  Also gives rise to the question whether locking down everybody for so long would have been necessary if the medical eye had been on the ball instead of the grandstand. 

The idea of vacation travel seems absurd, what can (and can't) you do when you get there?  One of the early stories out of Spain was the island beach hotel where one surprise case caused a mandatory lockdown of all the guests in their rooms for two weeks.  Even at best, as "reopenings" regionalize and the locks click open and shut again every week or two, it's nearly impossible to dependably keep up with rules governing recreational venues or predict what they might e, in one's hometown not to say some resort.

NY Times should set up permanent FAQ page about Corona virus for elderly that is constantly updated. This will be a great relief for older adults. 

There is lot of information on COVID that is still not clear. For example, is the risk of getting infections higher for older adults? It seems like immunity declines with aging but the risk is no higher says in  the article.  Are we sure about it? Or we just don't have enough data.

Oh okay.
So in March-June, any young and healthy person that questioned the strict lockdowns that saw ridiculous measures such as the halting of preventative medical care and the banning of socially isolated sports like surfing, were dumb, redneck trump supporters that didn’t mind ‘sacrifing’ the elderly so that they could continue with their frivolous lifestyles.
But now, with case numbers truly sky-rocketing, it’s completely fine for people who actually are at increased risk to “Find a balance between preserving safety and living.”
Yep, not hypocritical at all.

My wife and I, both in our mid-sixties, walk the parks each day here in NYC. It is disheartening and baffling that many unmasked younger people will not take a step to the side as they walk towards us. Some of the paths are quite narrow and we ALWAYS step to the side to try to create 6 feet of social distance. I have Type-2 diabetes and high blood pressure. Where is the basic civility, the common courtesy, the care for one another? How difficult is it to move aside a little? What’s with 3 and 4 people walking abreast on narrow paths?

It’s not just younger people-plenty of mask-less center-walkers are older as well. I’ve gotten into two verbal altercations just by politely asking people to step to the side. I’m biting my tongue as hard as I can, but it gets harder and harder, and my patience is wearing thin. One fellow cursed me and menaced me physically.If not for the fact that it would be even stupider and more unhealthy to have an actual PHYSICAL altercation, I wouldn’t have minded having a go at it.
Only one person to blame for the confusion and chaos: Donald J Trump.

Missing in this is a discussion of what individuals can do to significantly reduce their risk of poor outcomes if they develop COVID-19. Prevent and treat the underlying conditions, such as type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure. Lifestyle matters. Don’t smoke, eat a predominately plant-based diet, exercise and get enough sleep. Where is the national call for good self care?

I'm 75 years old and have received chemo, radiation and immunotherapy for lung cancer. I am high risk and my husband and I have self-quarantined since March 12th. When our children and and their families come visit us, they self-quarantine for two weeks before. It's not fun - it's awful and it makes me sad. But I do feel safe.

Ironically, I am pressured by my doctors to come to their offices rather than Zoom or FaceTime! I'm told it's the best way to 'evaluate' my condition. Doctors should be finding ways to safely do their jobs (mobile blood draws for example) instead of telling  high-risk patients to break quarantine. At least screen via video appointments which patients need to break quarantine, leave their homes and take the risk to come into their offices.

I have recently had first hand knowledge of two cases- one ending in death, the other overcoming the initial stages of the virus but then with lingering conditions that are till serious....

A health worker's 25 year old son owner "clubbing" , came home and infected his mother who then went to the senior living complex and infected my friend and his wife- he died and she is still in the hospital seriously ill..

Another friend ( 66 years old) was infected by her beau's son who is in a band and brought home the virus home  to his father who then passed it to his girls friend ( my friend).

Once your bubble is pierced  and you never be certain), you are in trouble, especially if you are a senior.

The next wave- the flu in the Fall- along with the next virus iteration- will be devastating to all of us who passed the first wave.

Will young people suddenly grow intelligence and respect  for others ?

More like Russian roulette ......

Were we all this stupid when we were young adults ?

What all these mask libertarians are missing, is that they are not snubbing their noses at the liberals (which is all that this is about for them -  do they complain about having to wear shoes and socks or even Jackets and ties into restaurants, of course not), but they are destroying our economy.  Republican/conservative  governors are closing businesses to combat a growing virus. Wear the mask, control the virus and those businesses will open.  These irresponsible “adults” that can’t go without a party for 6 months are only prolonging the pain.  Read a book, indulge in Netflix, learn to cook, eat healthier, make it an opportunity.  And when you do go out for groceries, thank everyone working in the store for showing up to work for the rest of us. We lack leadership and since most of our populace act like sheep, we are in a heap of trouble.
Japan’s population is to a large degree elderly and many live in remote places with few services. How are they managing the pandemic?

I know plenty of seniors over 70 traveling to see their children. I am struggling to understand high risk individuals needing to travel and be in close quarters with others. Why can’t people wait until it is safe to travel? Why do adult children want to put their parents at risk? I am staying at home and though I would love to travel , the community as a whole comes first. I am just waiting for the shoe to drop and find out someone I care about is infected.

The hospitalization rates as corrected are lower than the mortatlity rates.  That is incorrect.  I think the previous were closer.  Most data has the overall hospitalization rate around 14%.  It is an easy calculation.  number positive/number hospitalized.

Most people in our neighborhood, even those 40 and over, are choosing not to travel.   To travel, also means to have to use the bathrooms on route, and risk contagion at many points during a trip.  Our family has decided that travel comes with too big of a risk ; this risk taking does not contribute to relaxation.  We can all enjoy our back yard without risk.  Families around us with small children have made their homes a virtual playground, adding trampolines, above ground pools and swings.  Everyone wonders, will they be one of the 40 year olds who dies from this virus, or will their small child be one of the kids who does not make it.  The risks are too big for many people to enjoy traveling now.

Here are my suggestions to survive wanderlust until there's a vaccine. 1) Take out photos from a trip you have already taken and enjoy some conversation about THAT trip. Prepare (or order in) cuisine from that country for dinner. 2) Looking forward, take the trip you had planned for September and just make it for same time, next year, when we're more likely to have a vaccine. We all know that the more you prepare for a trip, the more you get out of it so the pandemic offers an ideal time to read about a country's history in depth, read key literary works, study the art and antiquities of that country. After that, sketch out your itinerary and choose hotels, even if you don't book them yet. It's just a matter of exchanging activities that you will do in the future for those you CAN do now. And since our stay-cations are likely less costly than vacations, the next trip that you take can be a little longer and more leisurely, and/or in upgraded accommodations.

Yes, 80 is a milestone. But the Pandemic is a menacing creature that can strike anywhere and at any time. Even the most vigilant are susceptible to carelessness. Stay home and  Celebrate on line!  You’ll live to be 90+.

I am a 74 year old male in good health. The calculator gave me a .024 chance of having a positive test result. From the article I also learn that for my age group, the chance of being hospitalized if I have Corvid 19 is .08. Assuming that a non-hospitalized case is not serious, my chances of having a serious (hospitalizable) case today is .024 x .08. 

.024 x .08 = .0019 = .19% 

Thus, out of every 526 people in my situation, today one will require hospitalization for Corvid 19. By exercising a bit of prudence, I have little to worry about.	 Probably I have more to fear from overreacting and not going outside to enjoy life and getting sufficient exercise.
The Nathan’s should only think of themselves about Lake Placid. And then, only the two of them go. Me personally? I am staying in my cocoon.

The article brings back fond memories of a visit to Tanglewood last year for a performance of Wagner's Die Walkuere in The Shed. Just as Nelsons lifted his baton for Act III and the Ride of the Valkyries, there was a tremendous flash of lightning and rolling thunder just outside the open Shed. Even Nature got into that performance!
And extremely sad for the kids who qualified for the Young Artists Orchestra who will be missing the experience of a lifetime.
Every year we come to the Berkshires to hear James Taylor and spend time at Kripalu.  Feeling really sad.
Fantastic performances by The Who, Miles Davis, Santana, and Chicago from Tanglewood's 1970 summer season are on YouTube. I imagine there are others as well. Check them out!
What a beautiful place! Let's hope next summer will be better!

One of my fondest memories of Camp Lenore in 1967 was a visit to Tanglewood.  It was my first outdoor concert and hooked me for life.  Every summer in our years of living north of Chicago we would take a picnic and our children to Ravinia.  It too has an expansive lawn and pavilion.  For not much money, we were able to introduce our children to classical music in a setting that was comfortable.  They could quietly play games while listening to great music instead of sitting in uncomfortable clothes in a symphony hall.  And we never missed Peter, Paul and Mary who annually made an appearance.  They were pure joy.
I hope one day soon we will all be able to enjoy experiences like these again!  Until then, wear a mask and stay safe!

It is not just Tanglewood that I and others miss.  It is the entire artistic, cultural, and scenic summer festival that the Berkshires were and are.  For a number of years I spent a week in the Berkshires to sing the masterpieces of Bach, Verdi, and others in the Berkshire Choral Festival, at that time located in a private school near Sheffield, a few miles south of Lenox. There were rehearsals in the morning and evening, leaving the afternoons free for sightseeing---and there was much to see---or golf, hiking, or swimming.  There was no rehearsal on Friday night, and many went to Tanglewood for a concert.  I expect and hope that the Berkshires and Tanglewood will be back next summer as good as ever.
The summer of '69. B.B. King, The Who, The Jefferson Airplane. Lawn tickets for $3.00. Transportation courtesy of Westover Air Force Base for the local Catholic Youth Organization.  Awesome.

I spent a glorious summer studying at Tanglewood in 1980. It changed my life. It must be the only such place in the nation that is solely devoted to classical music, with the rare exception of a Boston Pops concert, which would be a mixed bill. I have to wonder, with the absence of people, is there also an absence of mosquitoes, or are there just as many as usual? 
And if there was rail service from New York to Tanglewood, to Lenox and/or Stockbridge or with connecting buses, how many more people would flock there, normally? I think attendance would soar by at least 40 percent, between New York and Boston's populations. 
The BSO is basically the finest orchestra we have, and Tanglewood is the ideal summer festival.
The  photos accompanying this article are gorgeous.  Thank you.

Pre-virus Tanglewood was always a special treat.

Despite the virus, bucolic Western Mass. is still a treat.

Tanglewood is magical. Whether sitting in the shed on a Saturday morning listening to a rehearsal, picnicking on the lawn and feeling the music wash over you, or just wandering the grounds and visiting the lovely buildings (what beautiful wood!), it is both exciting and blessedly tranquil. The dreadful traffic and the messy parking are the penance. The eclectic programs are matched by the equally eclectic audiences. 
I have a wonderful, tangential memory: playing tennis in the court next to Yo Yo Ma and Emmanuel Ax in a loud, joyful match.

Norfolk Music Festival in Norfolk CT is a little known gem.  Come see a performance next Summer. Acoustically perfect red cedar shed. Top notch musicians. Grounds for a picnic.  No traffic. Gorgeous grounds.

I love the Saturday rehearsals as much as anything else. I had a great seat in July, 1998 and I listened intently to the dynamic between Itzhak Perlman and Seiji Ozawa as they discussed minor changes to the score. The orchestra would swell and carry on for perhaps 24 bars until one of them would call for a stop. It was amazing to eavesdrop on that. I love Tanglewood!

I still miss the five summers spent at Tanglewood as a member of its high school summer music program.  We tramped from the dormitories through the Tanglewood grounds, hearing the Boston Symphony rehearsing to the right, and Yo Yo Ma rehearsing to the left.  We hopped the fence -- much to the chagrin of security guards -- and mozied down a side road to the lake where we found more musicians swimming in the summer heat before making the return journey.  In the evenings, we journeyed into Lenox for ice cream cones and pizza.  What wonderful days.

So many things have been lost this year.  Sadness is epic.  But for some reason, when I heard on the radio that Tanglewood concerts were cancelled this summer I wept -- spontaneously.  It just seemed like the last straw.  Not that I get there as often as I like, especially now when I live a bit further away than in the past, but I try to do at least ONE Sunday afternoon a summer, and always listen to the concerts on a local station, WMNR in CT.  A summer Sunday at Tanglewood, on the lawn, with friends or alone, with spectacular views, music to soothe the soul, a nice picnic,  (and for some reason no or few biting bugs on that beautiful lawn) -- all that is part of my life and my memory bank.  I hope to get back next year and for many more years to come.

I spent several summers in the ‘70s as a counselor at Camp Mahkeenac, a quarter mile from the Lions Gate entrance. The rock concerts were milder fare than a few years earlier; apparently the town fathers felt The Who had attracted an undesirable element. But a Jackson Browne show in ‘77 was very good, and I was thrilled to realize that the policeman controlling pre-concert traffic was none other than Officer Obie. Besides, just down the road was the late great Music Inn, which offered some terrific acts, including a ‘75 just before Born To Run Springsteen.

I had my tickets already purchased for the season and planned the rest of my summer vacation time around those performances. The cancellation announcement was  later than most every other arts organization in the Berkshires, and I hoped against hope that there would be a way for some kind of live performance. (In hindsight, I now realize that management was spending the delayed period crafting a virtual schedule.) 
Lots of special memories, but the one that immediately comes to mind is the performance last summer by Yo-Yo Ma of the complete Bach Cello Suites. Glorious! Timeless music sensitively rendered by a national treasure.
The Berkshires. One of the more spectacular areas of the east coast.

Given how crowded the beach towns seem to be (from what I've heard), especially since Maine is not welcoming visitors from MA, maybe it makes sense to go for some quieter Berkshire action this summer. I'll be out there again first chance I get.

I dunno, presume that's some sort of an oak situation in that pic, but my lord, seems a complete hazard with those limbs cantilevered out so far. I do hope they don't allow folks below them. Beautiful, but deadly.
You're making me cry.

All is not lost in the Berkshires. There remains beautiful landscapes where enjoyable walking tours can take place. There is Theory Wellness in Great Barrington, open and serving all, and of course, Baba Louie's is available for dining in or take out. The Northeast's best pizza by far. Those simple pleasures are worth a day trip or even an overnight to lighten up a week.
The very well heeled residents are loving this.
I wonder how the natives, the birds, the deer, the rabbits, the woodchucks, etc. are enjoying the respite. I hope someone is keeping tabs on this phenomenon.

I have spent the past three Sunday afternoons at Tanglewood, listening to the BSO's streaming of a past Tanglewood concert posted 2:30 so I can pretend it's like every other summer Sunday of summers past. I'm not sure I will be going back. The spartan crowd and the spartan mood just add to the yearning for life to return to normal.

July 3rd and August 28th.  Those were the days I marked on my calendar for the start and end of the Tanglewood season.

Ever since coming to the Pioneer Valley, I've made a point of attending at least one concert, made a bit easier when our astronomy club set up telescopes for the general public or when I would drive our car service passengers there.

I didn't search the Internet to confirm whether or not Joni Mitchell ever performed at Tanglewood, but her lyrics sum up life in these times rather well:

"Don't it always seem to go
That you don't know what you've got
'Til it's gone"

For just one season, we hope!

My mother died of COVID-19 in May. We have been “attending” concerts for 50 years. As I walked the grounds this week, I was flooded with beautiful memories and felt her presence. But “attended” is an insignificant  word to describe the experiences of Tanglewood.

I grew up on the back road to Tanglewood, Cliffwood Street and everyone in my family had some kind of connection to the festival.
Although we moved to Boston, we returned in the summer and my parents were more relaxed at Tanglewood than anywhere else. They retired to the Berkshires and their greatest joy was bring their grandchildren to concerts. 

My own children are in their 20s, living in different parts of the northeast, and busy with careers.  But John Williams and film weekend are an annual ritual.  My daughter is one of the many lawn goers who brings a table, linens and the crystal candles. She was thrilled to learn that staid Tanglewood once had rock concerts. My older sisters saw The Who in 1970; just blankets, pot, and wine. 

There are many ways to experience Tanglewood; in the shed, on the lawn, running through the maze, and watching the fireworks over the Stockbridge Bowl after the 1812 Overture.  I never imagined walking the quiet grounds during a pandemic. But Tanglewood gave me a respite from this devastating pandemic and memories of mother’s favorite place.
I've been there several times.  Once, when the 1812 Overture was being televised live, I snuck up to the front row just feet from Erich Leinsdorf.  The good old days.
Great article on the Berkshires but she missed the fact that the premiere theatre in the county, Barrington Stage Company, has figured out a way to have a safe, socially distanced  summer season.
..... and not a word about Leonard Bernstein ? - really!
A wonderful place especially if you lived in Western Massachusetts.

My mother use to drive us down to Tanglewood from Vermont and listen and see Leonard Bernstein conduct Beethoven. After ward she would take Mr. Bernstein's pulse as she was a nurse and his health no longer robust.
My sister was there when the violinist, 14 year old Midori broke her strings and without missing a beat was handed a violin by her colleague and continued to play til the finish.
Great memories. My mother also use to drive down and listen to Andre Previn give lectures.
Thank you Tanglewood.

I read about Tanglewood decades ago, when I was a teenager living in the Canadian Pacific Northwest. I assumed the accounts of the place must be exaggerrated, it sounded impossibly magical; starry nights on the lawn listening to the best classical musicians in the world while picnicking. Who could imagine a place so elegant and so bucolic?

Well, I married an American in 2011, and we attend Tanglewood every year. I am still struck dumb with wonder at least half the time we're there. We've dined with friends and attended alone, the lawn is our favorite place on a summer night. (weather permitting)

Tanglewood is like a scene from a romantic movie. There are nights when there are telescopes set up to see the stars. They are older couples with crystal, china and cut flowers on their folding picnic tables, there are couples dancing cheek to cheek, as their grandchildren play on the lawn, like a scene from a contemporary Renoir painting.  The Berkshires are special, everything about the place is dusted with magic. We are spending our summer this year in the gardens and the forests of the Berkshires but we know those starry nights with James Taylor, Beethoven, Berlioz, and  YoYo Ma, and John Williams, (among many others) will return. We have faith in that.
Food is fundamental. If you are hungry, you do not focus on learning or work. A strong country feeds its people. Food comes first.

The SNAP program is one of the smartest and most beneficial ideas that this country ever enacted. I can't fathom anyone begrudging helping people buy food in hard times. The expanded SNAP has been a Godsend for me during the pandemic. It has meant the difference between scraping through the month, putting food items back or being creative in deciding who will get paid and who can wait. In Florida, the economy is never stable being too dependent on tourism and a focus too geared to growth, a lousy foundation. Gov. Ron DeSantis can be forgiven anything regarding the corona virus because he has made sure applying and qualifying for SNAP would be smooth. Children are out of school and thus, the poor are not able to get the free means that are often the only time needy children get a meal. SNAP has really come through in those situations. Single men, who in this state might as well not exist as they get NO help in bad times  (other than unemployment) can get SNAP benefits. Who in the world would complain about this program? One can only buy food, and that's something everyone needs. It helps inject money into the grocery stores, which in turn employ people. I hope those nay sayers especially President Trump see the benefits of SNAP.

We have an administration that drowned our federal government in the bathtub and rendered it incapable of responding to the pandemic.  Now states that didn’t expand Medicaid, states with the lowest minimum wage, states with no state income tax and no masking mandate - all now have the highest need for public assistance.  

Republicans can’t, won’t and don’t govern.  Please stop electing them.  Find another outlet vote your anger and resentment.
I've been getting food stamps for 2 years and it's a big help but there should be restrictions on what you can buy. Why not eliminate candy and soda? for example

Actually, you know what would be more reliable: giving people that need money: MONEY.

I am absolutely dumbfounded by the democrats inability to get this right. They have constructed labyrinthine systems that require inhuman attention to detail and perseverance to get because they are not simple and that complexity and non-transparency allows Republicans to throw up any number of roadblocks in the name of "draining the swamp."

To fight this pandemic, the democrats needed to loudly declare this multistep plan:

1. We will send 2k a month to every citizen until Mcconnell and Trump do their jobs and get the vaccine they promised.
2. THAT'S IT. THAT'S THE PLAN.

The fact that they cannot help but put their socialist agenda of government controlled food, housing, property and business above saving lives and the economy is unbelievably disheartening.

I knew Republicans were evil. That's the POINT of the party. I didn't realize just how dumb the democrats were.

We must not let people go hungry.   

“Oh my God, dude, I didn’t have to worry about whether I can feed my kids,” Mr. Baker said, recalling his relief. “I don’t want to be dramatic and say it saved my life, but it saved my mental life, “

Food stamps are an immediate stimulus to the economy, which support farmers, grocery stores, truck drivers, etc.. 

I can bare the embarrassment of not being able to travel to Europe, and our general failure at addressing the pandemic so that schools aren’t able to open but none of us should accept children or adults hungry .

Good program but as mentioned in article the benefits provided are not enough for a whole month and the income levels too low.   SNAP benefits are more efficient than food banks or food pantries because the person gets to choose what they want to eat and not rely on a food bank's choice.   Supermarkets are often closer to consumer in distance and open more hours.  Food banks and pantries waste a good deal of money transporting, storing, sorting, and cooling food.   Supermarkets already have distribution networks, and storage and are more efficient.

I got food stamps seven years ago during a bad illness. It was kind of embarrassing, because I eat so cheap and they gave me lots of money. Heck, my cat was eating like a king.

It's nice they give the little cards, so people can look like they are using regular credit cards.

On a tangential issue, along with financial help for the hungry I wish there were a way to help farmers who are dumping milk and meat producers forced to discard what they can't sell to get that food to market.
Republicans are always fighting to cut programs like food stamps while keeping wages as low as possible.

Americans believe in incentivizing the poor by taking everything away from them, including food, medicine and shelter.  This is what America has voted for since Reagan.  Only the rich should be incentivized by giving them taxpayer money for doing nothing. Only liberals think helping the poor is actually helping them. America needs to continue to vote GOP for more independence and real Freedom.

Food stamps help people in need fairly quickly. When people had a delay in their unemployment or stimulus check, they had no income. Being stressed about if you can eat or not was a wide spread worry in the United states. Now, they proved that getting rid of food stamps would be a big mistake seeing in the first 3 months of the corona virus the use of food stamps skyrocketed.

Ask the folks at the American Enterprise Institute if they’re concerned about corporations becoming “dependent” on tax breaks and bailouts to fund stock buybacks so that their CEOs can justify obscene salaries. SNAP is about putting food on the table for American families; spare me the moral shaming from conservative “think tanks” who happily ride the gravy train funded by the Koch Bros et al.

Mr. DeParle has focused on the food stamps that have made it to 6 million new enrollees,  and  featured  a photo of individual in supermarkets, while this paper featured a heartbreaking article  featuring  haunting photos of Americans  , including children, who have been forced stand on blocks' long lines, in the sweltering heat, wearing masks ,while waiting to receive a bag  food, because the government refused to give those people food stamps.

Did Mr. DeParle miss that heartbreaking  New York Times piece ? Had he missed the drone footage of  Americans lines up for miles in cars waiting for food donations ?

Is he unaware that 30 million American children  , many of whose one meal a day was the lunch that was provide  at schools,
were left  by the government to go hungry ?

He has painted a  false  picture that suggests the the government has ensured that Americans have not been left to go hungry as a result of the pandemic.  That may be the case of the  six million new enrollees in the food stamp program.

That is not the case of the  30 million American children who were left to go hungry  when their schools closed ,or of all the Americans who  have been forced to stand online   for entire days
waiting for a single bag of food.
Education funding needs to mimic food stamps: provide a stipend that follows the student and allow parents to choose the most appropriate school for each child.

For years I have argued with conservatives who have attacked people receiving SNAP food benefits and every other safety net program. All of the criticism from them about people receiving food benefits as being “ lazy”, “freeloaders”, and the classic, “get a job” line. I always said that there may come a day that you will be the one receiving these benefits and you will be singing a different tune. That time has come. And within a few more months tens of millions more will be applying for these same benefits that they complained about others receiving, and finally realizing how you cannot even survive healthily on the grossly inadequate amount of benefits you receive. 
My wife and I are both in our late 50’s, disabled, cannot work because of our disabilities, receiving a little over $1,000 total in S.S.I. benefits and just over $170 a month in food benefits. We cannot pay our monthly bills will S.S.I. and cannot feed ourselves on $170 a month. We only eat once a day because we cannot afford more. Many talk that if you received benefits you won’t want to work. They are insane. I wish I could work again because I am so tired of worrying about trying to survive day by day. Our roof is caving in from leaks, our bathroom floor has caved in because of a plumbing leak, and our toilet has been broken for over a year. No program will help us to get repairs. And things are just going to get worse for us. It’s enough to make you want to give up.

Food stamp relief should be increased during the pandemic.  Emergency food distribution by local food banks is a very inefficient and hazardous approach to helping ease widespread food shortages.  Access to increased food stamps allows families to select the food they need, distributed by professionals who can better practice safe techniques directly from farmers and wholesalers using existing efficient supply chains.  With farmers destroying food and many citizens experiencing hunger we need a different more efficient approach.  Food stamps is the answer.  Large supermarket chains should accept donations to add to food stamp allotments (with supermarket matching funds) and food stamps should be available to all who are collecting expanded unemployment.  It's a no brainer.  Congress should act to include this in the next round of economic support legislation.

SNAP alone is not going to be able to keep people from hunger. As a social scientist who has focused on aid programs in my research I’ve watched first hand as people went without meals to feed their children or put expired foods donated from supermarkets on their tables. And even then, when on top of SNAP they had access to food banks, they still had days at the end of the month where they went without food. And it isn’t like these people can work. Sometimes it’s grandma who took in her grandkids when her daughter became addicted to meth or a single mother with a three year old who she can’t leave home to work and she makes less than childcare costs. This was before COVID19 and the resulting pandemic. Now, with the newly poor putting strain on pantries, each family takes home even less help so that all can get some- so you are looking at adults & children going w/o meals at the end of the month w/ the current system. And this is just considering food security. The coming wave of shelter insecure and jobless households is a much scarier and more difficult issue to address. We have more than enough food in this country to feed the hungry so long as the wealthy choose charity over greed (as in they don’t simply waste food, they donate what they will not sell). I don’t know that we have near the kind of social safety net infrastructure anywhere  to deal with the magnitude of need we are about to have. I know we don’t have the capacity in rural places.

No one, NO ONE, should go hungry in the richest nation in the history of the world.

It should be as simple as that.

My income was destroyed 5 years ago. I now make about 1/20th of what I used to. Consequently, SNAP benefits have helped enormously. During the Great Recession, the husband (now ex) was out of work for 16 months following his retirement from the US Navy. No savings, so after a rather short time, I applied for Food Stamps. 

We had a small income, about $1500 per month gross for a family of 5. This did not even cover our mortgage and electric. Our Food Stamps award was $267 per month, about $0.59 per person, per meal--about average.

Yes, I put meals on the table for $3 each. For 6 months. 

The ex lost 20 lbs off a frame ill afforded to lose weight. Each of our children, age 10-17 lost 15-20 lbs. They were slim to begin with. Me, who has always been heavy, but was prone to skipping meals so the children and the ex could eat, lost 50 lbs (about 1/5 of my body weight). Despite heavy use of the foodbank (a monthly bag from the food bank was maybe 1 meal for a family of 5), we were starving. Everyone was hungry all the time.

The ex couldn't wait for a good job, he took whatever job he could get and remained woefully underemployed for years after. 

The take away:
* Food Stamps payments are not high enough. They cover roughly 1/3-1/2 your food budget. You are expected to somehow magically create the rest.
* Too much is taken away for existing income. Food is not the only required cost: shelter, utilities EXIST, and are often unchanged from when you had income.
* It is completely insane to assert that people won't want to work if they get Food Stamps. Your family STARVES on Food Stamps, just a bit more slowly.

SNAP does not cover some necessities. Booze and cigarettes are not covered...sensible. However, you need cash for soap, toilet paper and tampons.....not sensible.

One ancillary benefit of the SNAP program is the way those benefits are enhanced by the support of concerned citizens. 1000s of farmers markets accept SNAP cards, and many have some form of matching program that doubles the funds received up to a figure ($25 max is typical). Here's a story about a participant at the Evanston, IL market: 

"S heard about the program from the District 55 Family Center. She feels lucky and grateful to be participating in it. Though she works several jobs and receives public aid, finances are tight. Without the dollar matching program, she would not be able to buy the higher quality produce of the farmer’s market for herself and her daughter. She says that the program makes her food stamps go further and consequently, they don’t feel a sense of deprivation. This allows both S and her daughter to eat more fresh, organic food which she says is so important to her because she
really wants her daughter to grow up as healthy as possible.

I work with the group that raises funds for the match and coordinates with the city to see that the funds reach their target. Usage is heavier than ever, but our citizens have responded to the need with generous donations to the program. I also work at a farmer's stand at the market weekly, and I have heard many stories like the one above. I'll tell you, this method of distribution lets SNAP users just shop like anyone interested in healthy, local food. There is no stigma in the tokens they use to pay. It works!

NY Times - October 12, 2009 The Claim: Always Wash Your Hands With Hot Water, Not Cold - By Anahad O’Connor With swine flu sweeping across the country, health officials are reminding Americans to wash their hands often to reduce the spread of the disease. Soap and warm water have long been said to prevent the spread of infections, but is warm or hot water really more effective than cold? [...] ...in a 2005 report in the Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, scientists with the Joint Bank Group/Fund Health Services Department pointed out that in studies in which subjects had their hands contaminated, and then were instructed to wash and rinse with soap for 25 seconds using water with temperatures ranging from 40 degrees Fahrenheit to 120 degrees, the various temperatures had “no effect on transient or resident bacterial reduction.” They found no evidence that hot water had any benefit, and noted that it might increase the “irritant capacity” of some soaps, causing contact dermatitis. “Temperature of water used for hand washing should not be guided by antibacterial effects but comfort,”... https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/13/health/13real.html

As someone who worked their way through college and grad school as a janitor/custodian/porter/commercial, residential and industrial cleaner, this article really resonated with me.  But to say our "old job" was just "tidying up" is really insensitive, and it is the attitude that has led to such low pay for those of us who actually did the job.  

We have always saved lives.  It is just that most people didn't have an appreciation for what we do...

Even if all cleaning/disinfecting measures that various employers institute are actually instituted by ALL employers, they will certainly be shown to be inadequate, because it is nearly impossible to do a perfect job of cleaning and disinfecting.

Ideally, every airplane restroom would be disinfected after each use, not once a day, or even before every flight, because scores of people will have used them.

Ideally, every surface of a plane that passengers touch would be disinfected after each use (seats, seat belts, tray tables, arm rests, window blinds, overhead bins and their latches, etc), not once a day, or even before every flight.

Ideally, restrooms in office buildings would be disinfected after each use, not once a day, or every couple hours, after an unknown number of people have used them.

Ideally, every doornob and handrail in office buildings or multi-unit homes would be disinfected after each use, not once a day, or every few hours, after multiple people have used them.

Ideally, time and effort would not be wasted on repeated cleaning of phones and computer keyboards that are used by only one person.

Ideally, every janitor and cleaning person would be given extensive training in cleaning techniques during this pandemic, and would be provided with the some of the best protective gear and supplies available.

We are not in an ideal world, and have come to this untenable position because of political decisions made by our leaders.  We must hold them responsible.
