I am a physician working in a hospital. I sanitize my working area myself. Our janitors take the trash out, change trash bags, and vacuum the floor. Most people don’t sanitize their working areas. They just don’t.

Small wonder Republicans are demanding blanket immunity for employers when workers are infected on the job. Between poor ventilation and inadequate cleaning of office buildings and other indoor workspaces, they know how bad this could get.
We call them “essential workers” but what we really mean is “sacrificial workers”.

These workers are brave souls to be speaking out. We owe them a safe work place and way more pay. I work in a multi-location public service and NONE of our buildings have hot water. Not for the public, staff, or custodians. We rely on alcohol, bleach or harsh cleaners. Think about those long-term health consequences. No place is perfect, but we should be doing a lot better.
A once proud country  after 244 efforts at freedom,  has failed  miserably at protecting its own citizens from a health disaster of the fitrst order.

I believe the cleaners. Corporate America, Fix this. For once, do the right thing. Care about your workers. Care about your customers. Airlines, Stop sending those ridiculous emails filled with platitudes and lying about your cleaning practices.  I used to fly 10 to 12 times a year but I will not get on a plane until I am sure they are safe.

OSHA is MIA, part of Trump and the GOP's strategy to destroy America. What other plan do they have? Face it working America: POTUS and the GOP don't care whether you live or die in this pandemic, they only care about the stock market.

This is ridiculous. Janitors deserve hazard pay. These workers are being exposed potentially to Covid-19, which is absolutely unacceptable. I think it’s a violation of their human rights. And do all of these businesses really expect customers to trust the sanitation levels in their buildings, airplanes, etc.? I don’t, which means I’m will not patronize them until there is an effective vaccine because I am immunocompromised. A solid economic recovery cannot happen until both workers and customers feel safe and frontline workers are paid well for what they do.

As a teacher, I most likely will be expected to clean my own room with the cleaners I purchase (my room is never cleaned, except when I do it). I can't even purchase the appropriate cleaning supplies for my own home due to low inventory, so that means I won't be able to find cleaning supplies for my classroom.

USA. 

So much winning.

Are you tired of winning yet?

Not the least bit surprised, unfortunately.  And if there are no visible signs of ‘dirt’, how is anyone to know whether ‘deep cleaning’ has been performed on an invisible virus?  The assumption has to be that you need to wipe down your own space, which at most provides limited protection, esp on a plane. Nor do I count on the filtration systems either - instead jets of air blast and spread the air rather than confine it to your tiny personal space. Empty seat in between ? as if the persons in front and in back of you aren’t close enough, unless you can afford business or first class.

Besides, once drinks and meals are served, any remaining safety precautions are gone.

It has always been this way, but the virus has made the consequences much worse. In college I had 3 jobs. I cleaned 7 house each week, I cleaned 1/2 of an office building M-F, and I cleaned a kitchen at a home for disabled children. 

At the office building I split the work with another girl. I had the executive offices and she had the worker bees. One week my co-worker was off so I took her half too. It was a mess. I scrubbed the toilet stalls and behind the soap dispensers, vacuumed places that hadn’t been in years, etc. I guess they put me in the executive side because they knew she couldn’t do it. One woman stayed late one night and told me the staff thought it was deliberate. Not just two different cleaning people. 

Corporate America has always been like this. Look good, especially for the high ranking, and let rest of us fend for ourselves.

America, and Americans, used to be known the world over for very high standard of cleanliness and sanitation. One interesting fact is that the spread of American fast food outlets, such as McDonalds, introduced American sanitation standards to many parts of the world and quickly were adopted locally to improve overall sanitation standards in those areas. This famously happened with McDonalds in Hong Kong. So it is very depressing that due to the motive for profit, American places and things are being cleaned too quickly and not with adequate supplies, and by underpaid people who have had little training. What once was something America led the world in is now something that America is declining in— simply keeping itself clean.

As a former high school principal, with a district that had resources, our custodial staff had the materials and expertise to clean our classrooms. Having said that, there is no way, we had the staff to achieve the levels of cleanliness outlined in the CDC guidelines. I would add, that we had a major renovation to our building infrastructure that included a total redesign and installation of a world class ventilation system--that is the good news---the bad news---we just do not have the staff--both teacher and support staff---to make the school safe--that is the reality of decades of neglecting a public sector service that has been allowed to deteriorate to what we have now--- a very dangerous school environment for all who enter the schoolroom doors.

Cleaners have never been given the tools or the pay or respect the job deserves.  Years ago I was a cleaner in a hotel for half a year, and given the number of rooms each of us were responsible for every day, there was no way the job was performed to what we’d call really clean.  Bedspreads were changed about once a month, and not more often unless they were obviously stained.  Given that most guests throw their luggage on the bed first thing, how can that be called sufficient?  Let’s face it, if you want a clean place to eat, sit, travel, etc, you’re going to have to bring your own cleaning supplies and do it yourself.  This is the advice we are being given now anyway, and many travelers have already been doing that.  I now carry cleaning wipes (if I can find them) in my car to use on shopping carts and so forth.  Are we now expecting teachers to clean their classrooms themselves?  Library staff?  Any public office?  It’s that or call cleaners essential workers and pay them commensurately.  It’s hard work.

While still an undergrad in college, I had a class in a remote location. The bathroom was always immaculate, which I greatly appreciated. I met the custodian and learned his name. Then I wrote a letter to someone at the university telling them of this man’s service. I hope he was acknowledged. 

Whenever I am in a public bathroom and the cleaner is in there, I always thank the person for making the bathroom clean. Usually it is an immigrant. I am so appreciative. I hope others are too

As a paid custodian of many years -- and making a decent wage, but with no benefits or safety net -- it's nice to see an article where we're given our due.  Everyone's been lauding retail and medical, but even in the normal course of life, without COVID19, custodians are the ones who make your public life bearable.  The stuff I've had to clean up in my life before you saw it is horrific and it feels nice that here or there, people might start paying attention to the work we do.

America has gone far, far off the right track. Too many companies and too many oligarchs see human beings as disposable supplies. We must turn this around or we are doomed to decay and obscurity as the world moves on.

General Services Administration maintains individual departments and orgs are responsible for supplying their own buildings with these supplies/functions. One way to make companies more responsible is to install sanitizer machines and provide wipes every 6 feet apart or where there is a lot of hand touching ie:eating areas, near bathrooms, elevators of course the rides etc. The HEB grocery here in Texas was wiping down the carts buff they also had sanitizer machines and sanitizer cloths that I carried throughout the store. Same as the airlines once the cleaners have done a through cleaning companies need to provide supplemental supplies for help maintain. Have sanitizer at the planes entry and everyone must use it. Have the Lysol spray, wipes and things available so men as a flyer can wipe down frequently touched areas myself, the seat belt buckle, the shade, the air vent. I enjoy giving things a wipe myself such as in the restaurant i wipe the back of the chair, the seat where people put their hands go adjust themselves. There are spaces and places that cleaners and janitorial services just won't be able to consistently clean after every use. Its up to the company to protect the customer. If customers are allergic to any products companies need to have a cleaner(s) available. If companies are going to provide a service it is their responsibility to maintain the safety of the customer. Everybody is worrying about making the all mighty dollar. All these companies have more than enough money to provide the required services to provide and maintain safe conditions fir their customers as well as their employees.

The commentaries are all over the place with there dosis of ideology for good measure. Lets leave aside restaurants, offices and public buildings. Airplanes are much more important. Belts, arm rests, eating table and screen should be cleaned by the passenger with wipes. These should be provided by the airline al entrance to the plane. Contractors, contractors, contractors! The whole concept of "contracting out" work and essential services is utterly bankrupt. Our current "contracting" system reminds me of the old cartoon of Tammany Hall where a circle of folks are pointing the finger at each other, endlessly. The upper levels of our society - government, business, hospitals, finance, etc. - have become so irresponsible that the rest of us are entirely dependent upon the personal standards and basic human decency of janitors, cashiers, flight attendants, delivery workers, nurses, and all the rest. God bless them, but they are not compensated well enough or treated with enough respect to bear that burden. What a mess!

Good article. Again, it takes a pandemic to illuminate how much Americans are taken for granted. The filthiness of public spaces, like Subway stations, subway cars, public restrooms in airports, etc.  in the US is just more and more disgusting if you compare them to European counterparts. For example, last year I had the opportunity to visit the restrooms in the Venice airport (Italy, not really a country known for obsessive cleanliness), and they were just amazingly spotless clean and beautifully designed. Walking into a restroom at JFK or any other US airport is an insult on all fronts, as compared to that. Private office spaces are also falling behind, as outsourced cleaning crews who are paid the lowest possible amount aren’t really motivated to put a lot of work into your cubicle or office. People are also wondering, why nearly all US urban environments can neither control successfully lice, bedbugs, cockroaches or rats and other vermin commonly not even found in third world destinations in that abundance. I hope that the focus on more cleanliness will be at least one good thing which may come out of this disaster.

There has been a lot of research on how long the virus survives on various surfaces. The result was: a day or two, three at most, depending on the surface. If that is to be trusted, then spaces (offices, schools, airplanes) that get shut down and become unused for a while will be disinfected by time alone. In such cases, there is no need to expose cleaners to freshly infected surfaces or to douse everything with chemicals which may become an environmental problem.

I'm glad the airlines are trying harder, given the yucky condition of many plane interiors pre-pandemic, but I can't help feeling that these "deep cleaning" efforts, however defined, are mostly security theater.  The moment passengers board the plane, bus or subway car, it's contaminated.  Most of us have seen the video where one person with fluorescent dye eats at a buffet with a dozen other people, and after a short while, turning on the UV light shows everyone is contaminated.  All of the tables and plates and utensils were clean beforehand.  It didn't matter.  The reason I'm not flying now has nothing to do with whether the armrests were wiped down.  It's the people.

I worked in several  federal building.  InMinnesota in the 70’s, the custodians were federal employees and our offices were immaculate, restrooms spotless.  Then their jobs were given to contractors.  What a difference!  Dust collected under our desks. Coffee drips on the conference table stayed until the staff cleaned them.  Later, in Milwaukee, I found one of the cleaning crew sleeping in an alcove. If you pay the workers a living wage, you’re likely to get good ones.  The contractors weren’t that much cheaper but the cost included executives’ salaries.  Not much left for the workers.  You get what you pay for.

Working as a teacher in a NYC public school building, I know that the cleaning staff is greatly overextended. They only had time to clean the toilet and empty the wastebaskets of my classroom on a daily basis. As someone who used to clean for a living as a college student, I knew what to do and supplemented by cleaning student desks and vacuuming my own rug. I bought my own supplies to do so. 
Now the federal government is not supplying any extra funding for schools to fight Covid. What a joke! Of course, schools will not be "deep cleaned"! Let's not even talk about the poor ventilation systems!

I am in my mid-60's and I have a compromised immunity system due to undergoing chemo for the past three months .  When I observed the "greeter" at one of my local supermarkets wipe-down shopping carts over and over again with the same filthy rag and some unknown spray bottle mixture, and shoppers not wearing masks and refusing to observe social distancing, I switched to on-line grocery ordering with delivery or contactless pick-up.  At my first contactless delivery with Sam's Club, the young man who came to my car window to check my ID was not wearing his mask and stood 18 inches from me.  I have stopped ordering food through drive-thrus because the window attendants (usually teens or in their early 20's) either have their masks pulled down below their nose or sometimes don't wear it over mouth and nose at all.  I am now stopping contactless delivery of restaurant food after 3 tries because in each instance the delivery person rang my bell and stood less than 2 feet from my front door rather than leaving the food outside the door as instructed. Even before this Covid plague, when my husband and I flew we always brought cleaning wipes and scoured the seats, seatbelts, trays, buttons for air and lights, and window shades. The dirt we would see on the wipes! Disgusting. At the hotel we wipe down the remote controls, door knobs, faucet and sink, and toilet. No visible dirt there, but you can’t see germs. It’s these infected airplanes that are spreading this like Wildfire !

In my company a young “executive” once made a presentation where he boasted how he had managed to save a “whopping” 150,000 Dollars per year by cutting down on office cleaning to once a week only. This, in a company with a turnover measured in the billions and where 150,000 dollars is considered pocket change in the big scheme of things. Ah but this young rampant manager made himself visible and thanks to his handsome looks and slick suits sailed off to a big corporate career. Meanwhile, the cleaners saw their work cut by 2/3. 

Fast forward to 2020, that young executive failed miserably when given “serious” jobs and has fallen back in the ranks; meanwhile because of Covid we now have cleaning crews going around the offices 24-7, wiping cleaning and disinfecting every surface to make OUR work environment safe. Everyone now “sees” the previously invisible people: the always smiling Asian lady with the spray disinfectant; the big African guy with his mops and industrial cleaning fluids; the efficient eastern European ladies who move around at speed cleaning our desks, emptying our trash and wiping our bathrooms without breaking a sweat. 

Now we SEE them, and we hold doors open for them, and we THANK them, talk to them and treat them as colleagues, as peers, as human beings. I can see how the entire attitude and respect towards these essential colleagues of ours has radically changed. At long last.
This confirms one of my pandemic fears.

We - as a nation, but even more so as an socio-economic system - are such a disgrace; it’s the classic middle manager attitude (so different in other societies) of “I don’t care how, just get it done” combined with squeezing every dollar from the unfortunate and powerless, that exploits the minimum wage earners and now endangers us all. Shame on our system and on us for tolerating it.

Thank you, endlessly, for giving a voice to janitorial workers, who are often ignored at best, openly disrespected at worst. Also, even if we know how something should be kept what about fatigue with it all, too?!

I hate to bring this up, but for those of you who don’t know, in all my years as a teacher I’ve never taught at a school that had hot running water — not even in the staff bathrooms. I know this article isn’t about schools, but I don’t think the general public has a very good sense of what conditions are like and perhaps “unpacking” (as admins like to say) schools should also happen now.

Those who comment on the poor attitude or quality of work provided by contract workers might want to consider the possibility that they are just tired. Working for such low wages, they have to put in more shifts just to meet everyday expenses. The current system, with its emphasis on contractors and gig work has not only resulted in a concentration of wealth at the top, it has actually made life worse for most of society.
Petitioning an employer for cleaning supplies should not get a worker fired.

This isn't the proper forum for this comment, but I would love to commend Southwest Airlines.  A month ago, I took a flight from Chicago to Reno, with a plan change in Las Vegas.  Everyone wore a mask, no one complained.  On all segments of the trip, Southwest airplanes were spotless--and it is not hyperbole to write that when those cleaning team members got through with their pre-boarding rituals, the planes looked and smelled brand new.  The floors were clean without a speck of litter, the backs of the seats (thank you for the vacant middle seat as well!) were void of those little weird food-fingerprint stains.  The windows were hair gel smudge and fingerprint-free. I have never felt safer on an airplane than flying Southwest with their cleaning protocol.  If Southwest suggested paying an extra hundred dollars for this level of concern for passenger safety, charge me!

Over time I have seen the janitorial function of many businesses and hospitals outsourced to cleaning companies and the quality of cleaning rapidly deteriorate.
My impression is that this is a dead end miserable job. Like stories of people who “started in the mail room” and worked their way up, cleaning and janitorial work will only be done with a sense of pride in work and excellent quality if quality work  is rewarded  both financially as well as with career advancement in some way including perhaps a path to further education like on site classes after work.

As someone working as a custodian at a college I can confirm what others have already said. There simply aren't the resources or manpower to keep these buildings fully disinfected.
We're responsible for three buildings. The two largest are 400,000sq ft combined (obviously not including surfaces). We disinfect countertops, floors, and doorways daily, to the best of our ability. Thing is, our staff consists of three people right now. There's simply no hope of keeping everything up to our standards even with everyone working overtime.
Meanwhile, the contracted companies running most of these buildings have plainly demonstrated their only goal is profits. No provisions are made to assist the custodial department, and in some cases we're actively hampered. To give an example of the kind of service that can be expected from these contracted companies: when we took over the cleaning of these buildings, certain areas had layers of dust thick enough that a gum scraper was needed to remove it. 
Custodial staffing needs to be expanded, supported, and in-house. Meanwhile use of these buildings needs to be restricted and minimized. Otherwise the disinfecting of these buildings will remain, as someone aptly stated, "security theater".
There is more to it as well. Too frequent use of disinfectants (eg, lysol) has been linked to liver damage. I've seen only few cleaners with necessary protection from this.
The lack of cleaning is why I never drink out of the glass cups in motels and hotels.  I always use disposable ones.
All the more reason to resist, as best as one possibly can, the call to enter back into normal life. No one is looking out for us, so we have to do the best we can to take care of ourselves.

If you absolutely have to fly, bring some disinfectant wipes with you and wear a mask. 
Wipe down your area.  
If you can stay home, do so.

WOW! I spent several years after retiring from my job as an auditor for the state government as a janitor.  It did not bother me to do this work on a part-time basis because I believe all honest work is honorable and because my mother worked for the state as a cleaner, taking care of the offices and chambers of the state legislature.  This is how she put food on our table after father died. 

People have no idea how much EDUCATION is involved in being a janitor.  It is not just "pushing a broom" at all.  One must KNOW how to clean up an sanitize all types of horrific messes and all messes are NOT treated alike.  I will not recount some of my experiences, but suffice it to say that one must know how to sanitize every type of human and animal "spill" imaginable.  

The majority of people do not understand the level of skill involved and the attention to detail that must be maintained. For example, the chemicals used in janitorial service are generally concentrates that must be mixed in strict proportions according to use.  Furthermore, to properly clean a single public restroom stall requires that all surfaces be cleared of gross dirt FIRST, and then sanitized afterward. 

And it is especially NOW when the work of cleaners and janitorial staff is extremely important.  I believe that these workers MUST be paid more and that they are just as important as the people who maintain the rest of the infrastructure.

In the past, when bottom end jobs were done by in company employees, these were via stepping stone paths for career advancement. Today, the practice of contracting out to the lowest bidders have made the Horacio Alger stories pure fiction!

There is no such thing as true clean when you are out in public! At Disney, they clean the hand rails every two hours. That’s not going to help and is a waste of time and manpower. I have never forgotten the description of one worker saying they used the same rag for cleaning the toilet to clean the sink, shower,etc. Thanks but not thanks! I’ll stay safe in my own home that I’ve cleaned myself! When I was teaching, at the end of every day, I would clean every desk and computer with Lysol wipes I bought myself. People thought I was crazy. But if I didn’t do it, no one would. Certainly not the one janitor who had too much work as it was.  Cleanliness may not be that close to Godliness but it sure helps!

I'm watching as businesses are shuttered here in Burbank, CA.  It's heartbreaking.  We have several streets of formerly thriving businesses that are now just shells of their former selves.

Canada lost two if its biggest retailers in the last century.  The Robert Simpson company, with dozens of branch stores, was in business from 1858 to 1969.  The Timothy Eaton Company, even bigger, was in operation from 1869 to 1999.  The old saw is that the first generation founds a business, the second one expands it, and the third generation loses it.  It is the pandemic, yes, but also changing consumer habits, competition, and perhaps a bit of hubris.  Times  and tastes change, people move on, if not, we would be writing about blacksmiths and corset makers.

My husband and I were in a very large camping/outdoor store in WI this morning.  On the outside entrance door, there was a large sign that listed the symptoms of COVID-19.  At the bottom of the sign, it stated that if you have any of those symptoms, do not enter the store.

But there were NO signs mandating the wearing of a face mask.  There was a greeter inside the store, welcoming customers, but wearing no mask.  NO ONE wore a mask but us.

How can you have one sign telling you to not enter if experiencing symptoms but no mandate for wearing a mask?  What about people who are asymptomatic?  How many people did the greeter encounter while not wearing ANY face protection?

We were in another WI store, very large grocery store, and they saw a sign that read "Beginning Aug. 1, face masks will be mandatory."  And I was told that sign was put up on July 1.  Why wait an entire month?

Once again, mixed signals, mixed messages, mixed direction.

Everywhere I have been, albeit in WI or IL, there is NO consistent message or adherence.  That should have began at the top, from Trump, NOT each state calling their own shots.  Is it any wonder why this virus is out of control?

The article documents the failed direction and leadership of the Trump administration, a failure that is continuing today.  There are other huge, related issues that the administration has not addressed.
1.  What if the virus mutates and vaccines become ineffective?  The flu vaccinations given each year are reformulated to include the particular flu viruses that are prevalent. The possibility of COVID mutating by itself requires that we move as quickly as possible to stop the virus before it does mutate. 
2. What policies might allow us to open more quickly while still being safe?  Can we isolate or quarantine large groups so that with reasonable protections (distancing, masks, etc.) they can go back to work? Do we need Federal restrictions on travel?
3. What is the current status of the budget deficit? We know about stimulus and health expenditures, but how much will revenues decline?  We should be aware and concerned, although worrying about the deficit should be secondary to fighting the pandemic, stimulating the economy, and supporting social programs.  But we need to know where we are at, and will be, as it will affect the economy coming out of the pandemic.
4.  Who is coordinating Federal programs to make sure everything is covered and programs are managed as effectively as possible?  It seems there may be some small groups in the White House considering part of it, but not very effectively, and not transparently so the public is aware of the issues and options.

In United States law, depraved-heart murder, also known as depraved-indifference murder, is a type of murder where an individual acts with a "depraved indifference" to human life and where such act results in a death, despite that individual not explicitly intending to kill. 

In a depraved-heart murder, defendants commit an act even though they know their act runs an unusually high risk of causing death or serious bodily harm to a person. If the risk of death or bodily harm is great enough, ignoring it demonstrates a "depraved indifference" to human life and the resulting death is considered to have been committed with malice aforethought. 

In some states, depraved-heart killings constitute second-degree murder, while in others, the act would be charged with varying degrees of manslaughter or third-degree murder.

In the book 'And the Band Played On,' Randy Shilts made the comparison between the federal government's response to the 1982 Tylenol murders and its lack of response to the emerging HIV/AIDS epidemic.  Shilts wrote, "Federal, state, and local officials were immediately on hand to coordinate efforts thousands of miles away from where the tampered boxes appeared. No action was too extreme and no expense too great, they insisted, to save lives" and that "Within five weeks...new regulations on tamper-resistant packaging" were issued.
 Seven people were killed by poisoned Tylenol, but hundreds were dead of AIDS.  Shilts suggests the reason for this is that the victims of AIDS were largely marginalized gay men, therefore there was no political will in the Reagan administration to protect them as there was will to protect random Americans whom Reagan believed had more value.  If AIDS at the beginning had been leading to the hospitalization and deaths of hundreds of straight people, Shilts implies, of course the government would devote limitless resources to stop it.  
 Almost 40 years later, another GOP administration proves Shilts' hypothesis wrong.  Trump's administration can't even bother to put on a semblance of caring for human life.  Trump can't even play lip service to the idea that people other than himself might be suffering, and would rather cut resources to help end this pandemic than increase them. As a data analytics professional, I have examined the models provided by the University of Washington IHME, and I regard them as really good work.  The modeling is sound.  However, anyone who works with statistical models acquires a baked-in universal caveat:  models project the range of future values based on past behaviors.  They assume system inertia.  Fail this premise, and the model projections are going to be valueless.  Dr. Birx really ought to have known that.  I am astonished to read about her naive adoption of model-based predictions.  When asked, one _always_ expresses the prediction as : "given model assumptions A, B and C, and assuming stable system dynamics, and assuming the sample data are clean, then we can fit the model parameters within error X, and project outcomes Y with confidence Z."  It's a highly contingent statement.  One does not go around saying: everything is going to be fine because some specific model currently projects a downward trend.   The model may need elaboration, the sample data may be faulty, and the system behavior may change.  Trump's totally irresponsible advocacy of quick reopening and rejection of mask mandates changed the underlying system behavior.  Of course the projections were wrong.  Go back and review the current IHME projections, and you'll now see a pretty grim picture.  A virus simply spreads according to transmissibility and the density of contacts.  You don't need a model to understand that.  Dr. Fauci understands that.

Dr Birx's responsibilities involved PEPFAR strategic planning for HIV, a relatively chronic disease with a much longer time frame than the novel coronavirus we are now struggling to understand.   Thus her media reputation for her "infectious disease expertise" is hardly mobilization for an acute pandemic due to an unknown disease; her expertise is the approving of 5-year strategic plans in the PEPFAR program, a Bush era program that provided drugs to lesser developed countries struggling with the reduction of HIV prevalence and prevention of mother-to-child transmission, among other reduction and prevention strategies.  Key point:  40 years after the fact, HIV is not an acute illness, and thus modeling has time to play out.  An acute outbreak due to a new virus for which no one had any antibodies or even knew anything about should never have employed decision making based on these kinds of models.  The immediate (and current) need is for effective and timely response.  Today I read that Nueces County in Texas has 80 infants that have tested positive for covid-19.  Playing with models did not help those children and their families.

At a certain point the only tool we have against an out-of-control pandemic is lockdown. Unfortunately, I think we've reached that point in a number of sunbelt states. Half measures like mask mandates are no longer sufficient because community spread is raging, overwhelming the ability of contact tracing to contain the pandemic.

Contact tracing and isolation are not possible when you have a positivity rate over 8 percent. Contact tracing is also not possible when testing labs require days to return results. By that time, most infected individuals have already passed the infection along to others.

Italy contained its pandemic by enacting a complete lockdown that lasted for months. So did Spain. Their citizens didn't get into stupid arguments about whether masks work, and their governments spent those lockdowns preparing to reopen. Our government wasted that time.

This is a once-in-a-century pandemic, and we need to get serious if we're going to avoid 100,000 new infections a day. We need another lockdown in states like Florida, Texas, Arizona and California;. We need a national testing and  contact tracing strategy, at long last. We need real leadership.

Schools should be kept closed at least through the remainder of 2020, or realistically, until virus transmission rates have drastically dropped, and stay there.

April 1. 2020
South Korea, infections peaked at 1,062- truth disseminated, action taken
United States, still growing at 26,756-no action taken, truth hidden, lies

July 16, 202
South Korea, new infections 60, early action and truth.
United States, new infections 70,254, still no action at Federal level, more lies, etc.

To put this in proper context, the current 7 day rolling average for New York of 23 deaths/day ( see worldometer site ) is 8,380/year which if projected for the country's population would be 132,000. Wow, I did that in my head, but wait here while I check my math ... roughly correct, but here's the more accurate figure 
23/day * 365/year = 8,395 
US population 328 million / NY 19.45 = 16.86
16.86 * 8,395 = 141,540 deaths on an annual basis
Current US number of deaths? 142,869
You might claim that the number of US deaths will shortly rise well beyond 142,869, but that takes practically nothing from the claim that the media gives Gov Cuomo and Mayor De Blasio a free pass for a death rate that projects to a number deemed catastrophic. That's before making an allowance for the 142,869 including 32,552 deaths from NY.

The Fairness Doctrine means that the mainstream media must include some Fox-type coverage and Fox must include some mainstream media coverage.

There are a couple of rules that must be followed when drawing conclusions and making policy decisions: 

1.  if you want something too badly, you should require much more evidence (especially to the contrary) than usual to support your position (to counteract bias), and 

2.  evidence for something new, surprising, or profound requires there to be much more of it and for it to be of higher quality.  

The administration (and its advisors, like Dr. Birx) violated both, time and again.  

They wanted the need for lockdowns to be over, so they jumped on all evidence that supported their hopes.    Surprising "cures" were pushed and adopted the moment someone suggested that they have worked elsewhere on other diseases.     

You can't hope to win this deadly game by turning off the scoreboard, by ignoring what the other team (the virus) is doing, and by wishful (self-serving) thinking.  

You need facts, more facts, and the best facts.  That's the sort of thing this president should be able to get behind.

The policies of Ronald Reagan and the right have failed.  The pandemic shows it on a time scale that we can grasp.  The decline of the nation shows it in more substantial terms, but we cannot see it as easily.

We need to get rid of Trump because he is a feckless wretch.  But we need to get rid of Trumpism, the Tea Party, Libertarianism, and the right because it is all a proven failure.

As the world watches, we are failing as a country and as a former global leader, with unnecessary and enormous death and sorrow, and untold costs to the economic and social well-being of America.

Looking at national statistics in the USA is misleading. New York suffered a terrible outbreak centered in the metropolitan NYC area. Here in Upstate NY, the impact was much less.
People here railed at Gov. Cuomo and called him a dictator. They didn't see why our local economies had to shut down.
Now, Cuomo looks like a success. The curve is broken and, ironically, we don't want people coming from places like Florida to reinfect us.

We may want the story to be simple. As Trump recently observed, you test good one day and then you test bad. NYC tested bad and now they test good. Florida tested good, and, maybe, misled, and now they're testing bad. 
The point is that the virus is contagious and it will spread if conditions are right. Tragically, Trump and his minions seem to want to make the conditions right for the spread. It's hard to imagine what will happen as they persist in their magical thinking.

I still don't understand how it is that I - with access only to news and personal experience of the pandemic while working a full-time job - could clearly see that the only reason numbers were going down in April was because people were staying at home, but this obvious fact was not apparent to leaders of the government.

Dr Michael osterholm, who is quoted in other current articles, has consistently remarked that the actual number of cases far exceeded what the official tallies show (even now), and has specifically commented on the questionable reliability of the various models being used to estimated the next course of the disease spreading.

Speaking of data - something not really addressed here - dr osterholm has noted many areas that epidemiologists want to study more (like aspects of how the virus is transmitted, the precise effect of masks on aerosols etc) - however, the USA (unlike other countries) is not collecting complete data sets that would facilitate further scientific research.

You wrote:
“The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to mid-April, when the White House embraced overly rosy projections to proclaim victory and move on.”
Not.
“mid-April” is an unseasoned journalist’s error and an uncritical editor’s oversight.
Instead, try this:
“The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to November 8, 2016, when 304 electors in the Electoral College received their charge to install Donald J. Trump in the office of the President of the United States.”
That assessment is no less sharply political than the published sentence, and, on account of its relative candor, it is more palatable as well.
Or try this:
‘The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to 1980, when the Republican Party started its effective assault on funding for public education and, more generally, on science and critical thinking.”
Now we are getting somewhere. Keep thinking when you write and edit. Honor history and perspective. When you do that, the products will shift from superficial sound-bite quality analysis to important contributions to public understanding.

First, I am not defending President Trump. The man is not an effective leader, and is divisive, to but it mildly. At the same time, many of his policies have been appropriate.  The relentless dissing of Trump by the Times is counterproductive.

Next, lets not forget: the enemy here is the coronavirus. It is a bad actor, and there's not much any politician could have done that would have changed the long term outcome.  A country or state that is "in control" today will likely see a surge tomorrow.

Next, responsibility for public health largely rests with states and counties. We may wish to change our laws, but that's how they stand today.  It's also noteworthy that the Oregon is today suing the Federal government for interference with state prerogatives on protest management, and the Times sides with Oregon.

The Times accuses Trump of ignoring the risks of the virus, and putting other priorities first. Which is, of course, exactly what the Times itself did, with its long series of editorials and columns encouraging mass protects against racism. Mass protests which include shouting and which are impossible to contact trace are a very effective way of spreading respiratory viruses, and likely contributed to the current wave of surges, though the extent is not known.

What I found most sobering this week was a U.K. study that cast doubt on the potential of coronavirus vaccines to provide lasting immunity.  The study was published on July 11 on a preprint server (not yet peer-reviewed).   Antibody levels peaked 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms but then declined.   Levels declined to the point that re-infection was possible and concerning.  This aligns with what heatlhcare workers are seeing with re-infection.  This study result would effectively mitigate any hope of "heard immunity".  It would also mean that not only the presence of an antibody response would be required from a vaccine but one that is significantly more durable than the natural antibody response.   If this study is true, that is obviously not great news.  All the vaccine optimism has focused on production of an antibody response but not the durability. We all want our deaths to have as much of an impact as our lives, or even more. The old blaze of glory at the end. If it makes the terminally ill feel good to believe their wishes will be enacted, great, but I'd advise doing as much as possible while among the living.

I believe that the new reality has hit us all very hard and made us think about death and what we can do to prepare for the unexpected. I did my fair share of research on the topic and realized that there are hundreds of tools available, but I have decided to go with Stornest, a comprehensive tool that goes beyond sending last tweets and messages. I use it to actually store information about all my assets, my will, dear photographs as well as last messages for my wife and my kids. What I love most about it is that if I die, each of the beneficiaries will be given access only to what was meant for them. So, in whatever way you decide to do this, I strongly believe this is something that everyone needs to do, because none of us knows what tomorrow will bring.

The "trusted decision maker" form with no need for notaries or witnesses sounds nice. That said, folks should be sure that it is legally recognized in their state. Governments recognize various forms or require their own. This is not, though, about the government. Here is what can happen: a person designates a decision maker, say a close friend. Then when they become incapacitated up pops a sibling they haven't seen in years and don't want making decisions. If the "decision maker" is designated on a form not recognized by their state the state (and hence the hospitals/docs who have to follow the law) may hand decision making to the "next of kin," i.e., that sibling or other relative. The situation can also set off fights among family members who are not on board with the patient/deceased's expressed wishes. A legally recognized form can prevent all of that.  

Check with your state before assuming that any form will actually guarantee that your wishes will be respected.
I have an idea, contrary to a niche start-up. Talk to your kids and siblings. That’s what family is for.

So who are these experts that will be tasked with matching my signature?  How many years of training will they have in handwriting analysis?  Are there any legal requirements for a 'recent' signature, not the one I signed when I first registered when I was 18 or moved to my present location?

This is a serious issue and it is not being addressed.  The signature match requirement will disenfranchise many if not properly handled.

Georgia can recall Brian Kemp.

The Constitution of the State of Georgia authorizes the General Assembly to "provide by general law for the recall of public officials who hold elective office." This provision is found in Article II, Section II, Paragraph IV. Georgia law provides for the recall of ALL elected officials.

The relevant legislation requires at least one of the following grounds for calling a recall election:

-an act of malfeasance or misconduct while in office,
-violation of the oath of office,
-failure to perform duties prescribed by law
-willfully misusing, converting, or misappropriating, without authority, public property or public funds entrusted to or associated with the elective office to which the official has been elected or appointed.

The number of valid signatures required for a recall election is 15 percent of the number of persons that voted in the election.

In Georgia, 3.9 million people voted in the gubernatorial election. That’s 585,000 signatures. I bet Georgia could get that many signatures by this time next week. 

Recall your governor, Georgia. He is failing to keep Georgians safe.

My father was born in 1931 in the north of England. During the Second World War, there were long periods when everyone had to respect a curfew that started at nightfall. Families had to go inside and pull blackout curtains across the windows so that no light escaped from inside. Patrols would walk the streets to ensure no light could be seen. They'd hammer on the door if they could see even a sliver of light coming from inside homes. There were no streetlights, no cars, no shops or restaurants open after dark. The threat, of course, was the German Luftwaffe. It would conduct nighttime flyovers scanning for English cities and towns to destroy. My dad, just a little boy at the time, remembers hearing the bombers. Imagine the terror. Nobody railed against this ordinance, this need to behave in a way that was a matter of survival, a matter of protecting themselves against a genuine and imminent threat. There were no fights about loss of liberty or infringement on people's freedoms. Wearing a mask is like pulling blackout curtains across the window. It's about survival, of protecting each other against an imminent and deadly threat. Pull together, America. You can do it.

I am tired of people saying the government should spend more money. Hey, that is more taxes folks, or less of your pension.

Moreover, the quality thus far of online teaching has been abysmal. Our district had NO live teaching at all. Just some stupid templates on line requiring our elementary kids to jump from one website to the next, filling out Adobe forms that didn't work. 

I have yet to run into a single teacher who seems to want to go back. But the death rate for those under 60 without comorbid conditions is incredibly small; the media has over sensationalized or been irresponsible in many instances to convince people otherwise.

When I hear teachers saying online is so great, I think that is misguided. If everyone finds out their children learn just as much with Kahn Academy, many local teaching jobs will be over.

If we could find a way to integrate our info technology resources with our community teachers that include those who have changed careers and or have been laid off, we might be able to forge a model of smaller pods of students within communities, the one room schoolhouse model, that are remotely connected but personally monitored during the day.   

By having smaller pods, they are exposed to fewer people/germs and it is far easier to isolate a small group vs an entire school community.  

There may be people who would open their homes or expand their community daycares/church & community programs to look after these kids so that their parents can work, the kids can learn and have time away from the screen as well. Because of budget cuts, there are no funds to help with child care or instruction for poor and working class two earner families. I'm tired of people arguing that the $600 unemployment benefits are a "disincentive" for people to return to work, even if it means trying to find a new job in a new type of workplace.

The federal minimum wage is $7.25.  Many full-time minimum wage jobs require the worker to be there for 40 hours per week, but dock them for lunch break, and pay them for only 37.5 hours.  Thus, a minimum wage job pays only $271.87 per week.  This is barely above the poverty level for a single person, which is $255.20 per week.

Many states have a minimum wage set above federal level.  Let's put the "average" at $11 per hour.  Even at $100/hour, the worker earns just $412 per week, which is substantially lower than $600, and it's also below the poverty line for a family of 4, which is $503/week.

Even against the outrage of stingy Republicans, some states set a minimum wage of $15 per hour.  Even at $15/hour, a full-time job at 37.5 hours/week pays only $562.  Thus, for a single-earner family (i.e. one spouse stays home to do childcare), a full-time job brings in just $59 per week more than the poverty line, whereas the unemployment benefit by itself brings in $98/week.

So, the true disincentive about returning to work is that in our country, a job that pays minimum wage doesn't pay a salary that's reasonable to live on!

In six of his books about China, Navarro quotes a "Ron Vara", whom he describes as a China hawk and former Harvard PhD doctoral student in economics, and who says Sinophobic things about China and the Chinese. An investigation by the Chronicle of Higher Education found that no such person existed, and that Ron Vara (an anagram of Navarro) appeared to represent views that Navarro himself held.[106][107] Navarro has admitted to making up the character, an author surrogate, and quoting him in his books. Economist Glenn Hubbard, who co-authored Seeds of Destruction with Navarro,[108] has said he was not aware that Vara was fictional, and that he did not approve of Navarro attributing information to a fictional source.[109] In December 2019, a memo apparently authored by Ron Vara began circulating in Washington DC. The memo highlighted the "Keep Tariff Argument" and the use of tariffs against China a few days before an additional 15% tariff on $160 billion of Chinese made goods was set to be implemented. Navarro later confirmed that he had written the memo.[110]

Today’s tally of new coronavirus cases is about 65k. I am wondering if a bit more light could be shed on what precisely “today’s tally” means.

We know that there are non-trivial wait times when it comes to getting a test result back. Of course, one also hears that these wait times can range anywhere from 10  days to less than a day. (Depending on the location, broader testing regimen, provider, capacity, etc.) I figure that the CDC at best knows test results shortly before the patient. 

So would it be correct to infer that the ~65k cases reported today represent a combination of tests taken over the past few weeks? Not a simple lag, but a mixture of lags?

At the same time, I would guess that - conditional on a death being registered as Covid-caused/related (as opposed to people who may be dying “natural” deaths that are, in fact, undiagnosed COVID cases) - the reporting time is somewhat shorter. (I am, admittedly, ignorant of whether reported deaths all are based on autopsies - which could entail their own lag.)

So my follow-up is: to what extent does the apparent lag in death tolls reflect differential reporting lags?

Perhaps differences in reporting lags could be used to get a better nowcast of cases?

Finally, I hope this is obvious but these questions exist independently of conditional probability questions related to test availability, etc.

This question is really more applicable to to the stats dashboards but I thought I’d see if I could get a response here.

As a newspaperman who covered drugs and related topics from my university days 1974-1978 until a job-related injury ended my career in 2000 - one I had planned to continue until 2027 ...
1) The nation periodically undergoes a phenomenon involving “hard drugs”, addictive non-psychedelics that no one has ever been able to explain to me - or, as far as I know, explain at all: After a cycle of roughly a decade, primary hard drugs of choice switch between uppers - cocaine, amphetamines and the like, etc., and downers - from “mother’s little helpers”, diazapams (Valium and its analogs) to opioids.
The rate of use of more recreational psychedelics, from low and legal in many places marijuana, to LSD-25; what is now called Ecstasy (analogs, STP-64, etc.have been around for decades) psychoactive mushrooms and cacti have remained their steady place on the market for more than half a century.
Your article contains several misconceptions - “popular wisdom” that’s just plain wrong - fentanyl and analogs began replacing natural opioids in the 1980s, at least from info police and ER workers gave me when bad batches came into town and medical facilities would be overwhelmed with ODs. The why is simple - 24/7 factories easily outdo single-annual-crop production. And material 100 to 1000 times the strength of heroin is much easier to ship.

There’s an old brain teaser that goes like this: You have a pond of a certain size, and upon that pond, a single lilypad. This particular species of lily pad reproduces once a day, so that on day two, you have two lily pads. On day three, you have four, and so on. Now the teaser. “If it takes the lily pads 48 days to cover the pond completely, how long will it take for the pond to be covered halfway?”

The answer is 47 days. Moreover, at day 40, you’ll barely know the lily pads are there.

History repeats itself! We can take a 'lesson' from history to learn how to minimize  economic impacts. During the 1918-1920 Flu Pandemic those cities that promptly implemented and maintained practical measures such as social distancing, quarantining and mask wearing suffered less losses and had no additional long-term  adverse economic effects. 
Other cities didn't fare as well. 
There were a variety of responses to the reality of the illness then, as there is now. For example,  in San Francisco an 'anti-mask' bunch was protesting the wearing of masks back then, and there were conspiracy theories about the origins of the pandemic (first cases reported were rom Kansas. ) Now, just like then, there was dispute about 'actual numbers, of the sick and dead, suppression of the actual numbers of deaths (globally estimated for that epidemic to be between 50-100 million.) 
That pandemic came in  3  waves .starting in the Spring of 2018, then in August of 2018 with a deadlier pneumonia and death rate, and with a 3rd big wave in Winter of 2018..followed by a smaller wave in 2019.

Our local gym had begun to reopen under phase 3 guidelines (VA). There is an online tracker to see the percent utilization. My wife and I went in to try to restart workouts during a very quiet time. Of the few people in the gym (only 4) none were wearing masks. The corporate posture was that employees needed to wear masks but there were no such requirements for clients. My wife and I, although wearing masks ourselves, walked out of the gym.

I emailed the gym, outlining both the general medical concerns with links to several recent medical references (medical literature such as NEJM and PNAS, not the public press). There was no indication they would make masking mandatory--just a loose suggestion that masks were optional. 

My wife and I dropped our longstanding membership. With corporate behaviors such as the one described, it is hard to see how we fare better during re-opening attempts, where places such as the aforementioned gym are resistant to aggressively fostering public cooperation. The only reasons I can see for their policy would be a concern that some customers would be politically offended--or simply dislike masking during exercise.

Why would coronavirus transmission be different than other airborne illnesses such as tuberculosis, the common cold, influenza and meningitis? 

The spread of these other airborne illnesses has been proven to be significantly reduced with natural ventilation. Opening doors and windows directly makes the risk of contagion much lower than relying on shared over-recirculated indoor air from mechanical HVAC systems.

Greater attention to the spread of indoor airborne illness transmission should call for a re-think and a revolution in architecture of the future.

How much of our current built environment from mega-skyscapers to hospitals, luxury condos and hotels, and our climate controlled retro-fitted institutional facilities rely on HVAC systems?

This is very interesting, but there remains the issue of the infectious dose, the minimum quantity of virus necessary to infect an individual. Yes, we need science to get answers but long experience is also provides answers.  I was a army medical corpsman at the Fitzimmons Army Hospital in Denver Colorado in 1949 and 1950.
It was the Army’s Tuberculosis Hospital.  Every working day I wore a surgical mask whenever exposed to patients that were deemed infectious/contagious because they were providing sputum specimens containing live tubercle bacilli.  We changed our masks several times a day as the might become ineffective after use for several hours.  There never was doubt that one could become infected with TB either by aerosol particularly as expectorated sputum dried or by touching contaminated doorknobs or other fomites. 

There is no doubt that social distancing, masking, and hand washing are the most prudent precautions we need for the present pandemic.  Take it from an 89 year old Korean War veteran with lots of microbiological experience in the forty years following my experiences on the TB wards.

Thank you NYT for this excellent article.  The world needs more of these science based articles that are easy for everyone to understand.  It always seemed obvious to me that the primary mode of infection was via aerosols because otherwise the virus would not be so contagious and countries where people automatically wear masks (even without any government requirements) whenever a virus strikes clearly had much greater success controlling the virus.  If hand sanitizers were all that was needed we wouldn't see such a rapid spread.  Therefore, it should be also obvious that masks that can capture aerosols will protect the wearers.  The better the capture the better the protection.  How the CDC and WHO misunderstood the risks of aerosol transmission is astounding. Probably because they are medical doctors with expertise in the body but not in the science of fluid mechanics.   What are the implications of significant (if not primary) transmission via aerosols?  The country should have been mass producing N95 masks back in January.  Opening bars, restaurants other crowded indoor spaces before containment is sheer insanity. With respect to indoor ventilation, building owners should  install inexpensive HEPA filters in any recirculated air flow streams, which has always been required on airplanes.  Doctor and dentist offices should install HEPA air purifiers next to all patient treatment areas.  And so on.

What I really really cannot understand is why we all cannot have N95 masks.  Those are what we need to keep us a lot safer.  Yes, I get there is a shortage, and as a former RN I want health care workers to be protected. This article doesn't mention another important fact: your immune system is constantly on the watch for viral particles, etc., and clears them out.   If your immune system is healthy it takes hundreds of particles of a given virus to overwhelm your natural defences.  Improving ventilation should reduce the accumulated viral load in the air and thus reduce the chances of individuals becoming infected.
  Now, of course, it is possible that a single large droplet that someone has just coughed up contains enough virus to infect someone.  But large droplets do not remain airborn very long.  Reducing the load of smaller infectious particles might make a major difference in infection rates.
  Yes, good ventilation will probably reduce infection rates.  And masks reduce infection rates.  We need to do as much as we can to get this under control.

One aspect of aerosol transmission of the virus is the futility of any kind of face mask short of the N95 standard in preventing the virus from being transmitted. Surgical masks and masks made from cloth are too porous to filter out the virus, which when airborne consists of microscopic particulates.

People in enclosed areas breathe each other's air. A contagious person wearing a cloth mask exhales the virus through their mask and into the room's confined air, where it can linger for hours. A co-worker also wearing a cloth mask is at risk of inhaling the virus through their mask and being infected.

The CDC and WHO finally have acknowledged aerosol transmission but have not mandated the use of N95-level masks. Why? Because virtually none are available to the public. Due to the federal administration's failure to sufficiently ramp up production early on, current N95 mask production is reserved for first responders and medical staff. As a result, nothing short of HEPA air filtration and robust outside air circulation can create a safe indoor environment. The only effective precaution individuals can undertake is to avoid shared indoor spaces.

At this point, nothing short of total lockdown, combined with national testing and contact tracing, can save the USA from being overwhelmed by Covid-19. But it is doubtful that the chaotic national administration could mount such a campaign, and even if it did, whether a divided population would participate. Dark days lie ahead.

This is really no mystery or discovery!! Any infectious agent has an "infective dose" ID50. An aerosolized agent thus requires a particular concentration to cause disease. Obviously an enclosed space with no wind currents to dilute a pathogen is exponentially more conducive to transmit a respiratory pathogen. furthermore, indoors there is no solar radiation (ultraviolet or simply heat) thus virus can remain infective for longer. No fancy technology or high speed cameras required factual information known for around 100 years!

Betsy DeVos, we have a few questions for you:

• If a teacher tests positive for COVID-19 are they required to quarantine for 2-3 weeks? Is their sick leave covered, paid?
• If that teacher has 5 classes a day with 30 students each, do all 150 of those students need to then stay home and quarantine for 14 days?
• Do all 150 of those students now have to get tested? Who pays for those tests? Are they happening at school? How are the parents being notified? Does everyone in each of those kids' families need to get tested? Who pays for that?
• What if someone who lives in the same house as a teacher tests positive? Does that teacher now need to take 14 days off of work to quarantine? Is that time off covered? Paid?
• Where is the district going to find a substitute teacher who will work in a classroom full of exposed, possibly infected students for substitute pay?
• Substitutes teach in multiple schools. What if they are diagnosed with COVID-19? Do all the kids in each school now have to quarantine and get tested? Who is going to pay for that?
• What if a student in your kid's class tests positive? What if your kid tests positive? Does every other student and teacher they have been around quarantine? Let’s examine the role of government in public health.  Specifically Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis’ practice of public health.  According to the CDC Foundation, “Public health is the science of IMPROVING AND PROTECTING the health of people and their communities.”

Certainly it’s true that there must be metrics to measure whether improvement is being made or if ground is being lost.  In order to accomplish this there are leading an lagging indicators.

Leading indicators are proactive and predictive.  Measures that indicate the progress being made to reach a goal.  Lagging indicators are measures of where we have been.

In safety, leading indicators measure the things that are done to prevent injury.  For example, the number of gloves issued and the percent of the workforce to whom they were issued. It follows that the greater the number of gloves issued to those likely to suffer a hand injury and the percent of exposed workers to whom they were issued we should expect an improvement in hand safety.

Lagging indicators, tell us how we did.  They either reveal our improvement in safety or our failure.  It is not particularly helpful in measuring the actions we took to improve safety.  It only provides a relative indicator of pass/fail.

With respect to the management of coronavirus, the only reported indicators are lagging.  We talk about the number of tests performed, the number of new cases, the positivity rate and the number of deaths.

Where are our leading indicators?

Info on Swedish schools-apples and oranges from the US:
"School principals have been given increased decision-making powers so that they can introduce measures relating to the outbreak, including deciding to close the school or change how teaching is carried out, such as by adjusting the timetable.

For example, it's possible for a school to limit the number of students in school by only allowing in students with special needs, those who have exams at the end of the year which will impact their future education or career, and/or those with a vulnerable home environment. Or teachers may be allowed to conduct their lessons online, or at different times from usual.

Sweden has fast-tracked legislation that enables municipalities to offer childcare for parents in essential jobs, such as healthcare and welfare, if schools do end up having to close. This was not previously possible, because Swedish law states that everyone must be treated equally."

Public schools are funded mostly by local property taxes, so the threat of withholding federal funds is not that fearsome. I live in a state that was hit very hard by the virus from mid-March through the end of May. But we are led by a competent governor and a populace that was more than willing to abide by the double mantra of wearing masks and social distancing. We gradually reopened over the past 6 weeks and fortunately have yet had any "spike" in virus activity. My 91 year old mother lives in a senior residence facility that has done a remarkable job of insuring the health of safety of its employees and residents. My mother was able to withstand being quarantined in her small apartment for 2 1/2 months, my only source of personal contact being able to see her from her balcony twice a week as I bought her supplies that were left in the building's vestibule. 

If a 91 year old woman can "sacrifice" her personal freedom for a few months in order to ensure our safety, what does that say for the millions of younger people who wouldn't wear masks and continued to congregate dangerously at bars ,etc. in order to have a "good time."? My father "sacrificed" two years of his life commissioned in the Navy in WWII. He was proud of his service even though his college years were interrupted.

If the majority of businesses are closed then there's no sales tax being paid. If there's no tax revenue there's no money to pay for schools, fire, police, & countless other city services. That means you will start seeing many major cities declaring bankruptcy. You will start seeing towns defaulting on their municipal bonds. This is 2nd-grade math. The pandemic is disrupting life for some Americans much more consequentially than for others. If they don’t make enough money, they can’t survive. Flattening the curve has been the road to financial & emotional ruin for these people. Their future is being destroyed every day. How are they supposed to make ends meet? That doesn't mean we can ever return to the way things were. We can't. But moving forward we can quarantine those at risk & practice good hygiene. You can't keep the whole country on lockdown. Citizens are actively rebelling in ways both large & small. We need to find a better solution.

In this country where people advocate for economic equality, small businesses have been an excellent way for African American and Latin communities to reach the middle class and gain generational wealth. Now all of that will be destroyed for at least several years. Of course many of the readers here support Mr.Biden and say he will fix this after defeating Mr.Trump. However, do we really think democrats will help the small man and minority communities or will they continue neoliberal policies and help their corporate and banking friends? (see 2009 bailout)

It's a shame that our politicians don't seem to understand what small businesses are or how they operate. Nor does there seem to be an understanding how this ripples through the small business community. 

Most business rely on cash flow to pay their bills. Almost no small business has cash reserves for 9 months in the bank that could sustain them.

It's simple. Many folks are unemployed. Many folks are working from home. Many folks, even if they still work, are rather putting money away than to spend it. 

So, there are many small businesses that rely on, say, 1,500 customers a month. Those customers buy meals (or whatever) for $10 / day. Now that there are only 500 customers, the entire business model won't work. If they are lucky, they can fire all employees and do the work themselves. But even then the business might not be viable because of fixed overhead like rent, internet, phone, accounting, insurance, etc. That's why so many small business are folding. 

That's not where it ends. Next, with businesses shutting down, landlords don't get paid. Malls go empty, suppliers are impacted. Etc.

The federal and state governments need to help keep businesses in business, meaning they sustain jobs - otherwise none of the billions we are spending will help. Just paying unemployment, as important as it is in the short term, will not save jobs in the long term.

When the pandemic happened it was clear the something needed to be done to help small businesses. Sadly, the federal definition of small biz means that large public companies or largeish private companies got the most of the money.  
By linking funds to employees and not to important fixed costs for a business- like rent/mortgage etc. The small bizs face bankruptcy, mortgage or rent defaults and other business killing issues. Not surprising though, I am sure not many small businesses were asked what would help.

Sadly the PPP was never for main street it was always for K Street, private equity, wealth managers, high end attorneys snd connected donors. Main street got burned and the biggest states in fire are red. Sad state of affairs. I feel for my country, the unemployed, the old and the sick. The poor.

I live in Bogota, Colombia where the pain is even worse.

We have been in lockdown - aislamiento -  since March 20.

There has-been some reopening but in fits and starts.

Now,they have extended it to mid August.

I live in Bogota's Upper East Side - Colombia's richestman lives 6 blocks away.

How is it going even in this rich part?  In short, it is dead.

Offices have been closed so with no foot traffic - at least 20 restaurants have closed for good.  One went under even before it opened.

At a nearby intersection - as busy and as well known as Hollywood and Vine - a gas station went under along with street cafes,  and my favorite cerveza tienda.

It has been reported that over 10,000 restaurants out of 90,000 in Colombia are gone.

I walk around for exercise and at middday, its a ghost town.  The only folks you see are delivery men rushing on bikes and street cleaners.

Even, Venezuelan refugees - and there are many -  have quit begging or offering to wash windshield.

I have been here for 2 years.

I am beginning to think if I can stay in this dead town another year.

My estimate is Colombia will need more than a decade to get back to December 2019 - if not more.

But regardless of the approach, retreating back to a complete shutdown would be an economic disaster: harming businesses and employees, decimating tax revenue, and stripping municipalities of funds needed for social services. The next couple months will be critical, and our elected officials need to plan wisely.

Had we done exactly what the experts had advised us to do in the early stage of the pandemic, shelter in place, wear masks, social distance, and test, test, test, with serious and thorough contact tracing, we might have been able to reopen businesses after a month or so in most areas. But that would have required the government stepping in and handling the pandemic as the crisis that it is, rather than calling it a hoax, just the flu, and not that bad. God help our country and please for the love of science, vote Joe Biden in 2020.

It was expected that there would be surges as lockdowns were lifted. Thanks for this story. My wife and I opened our business in 1978. It has never been easy, always a little scary, never a sure thing. We have survived raging inflation and one banking and Wall Street bubble burst and attendant downturn after another. We both thought 2008 was the big one. We survived it but it has taken  pouring our retirement savings back into the business  as those "thin margins" so often mentioned, mainly by folks who have little concept of what living with thin margins feels like, caught up to us once again. Then came Covid19, the crisis every sentient American dreaded in the hands of an incompetent Administration. There has never been anything like this before. We are dealing with increased costs and unknown delays not to mention devastating illness and death, that hit us personally. To say we are hanging by a thread is by no means an overstatement. Yet I somehow feel lucky when I think about my brothers and sisters in so many fields, store front shops and restaurants and all the vendors, suppliers, employees, distributors and warehouses that support those businesses. The consequences of widespread failure touched on here are so far reaching as to be incalculable. And when I see smiling ads from the likes of Google selling how we small business owners are adapting, I want to scream. We are not adapting. We are dying and as we do we will take everyone with us. We need Congress to act. Extend UEI and fund small business grants across the country NOW.

I have read that the Trump tax cut cost the U.S. government between $1.7 and $2.3 trillion over 10 years. I think it's pretty clear where the money to help make America and American small businesses whole again needs to come from.

I worked 10 years to build my single-member LLC.  Nights, weekends, sacrificing time with a baby to fly across the country and pitch proposals to businesses who were in need of my services.   

I did well for myself. I was a proud, woman-owned business, in a small Northeast PA coal-mining town. I contributed to local charities, the local public schools and organizations that mattered to my family.  

I live in a simple house in a simple neighborhood and am fortunate that I squirreled enough away, despite many of my friends buying the 5-bedroom house with the inground pool.  My spoils were finally a European  trip taken with my husband and child last summer. It was beautiful and memorable and I daydream of it often during these dark times. 

My business completely evaporated in 8 business days. 8 days.  Long-time clients told me they no longer needed my professional services and paid my last invoice abruptly.  I haven’t had meaningful work since March.  

I spend my days with my young child, in my garden, playing hopscotch and feeding the birds.  I cherish the time I have with my child and realize this innocent age will pass quickly.    Yet, I miss the days where clients called me to fix a problem or solve a big issue.  As an extrovert, I miss people. 

I am not looking for pity.  I will be okay.  The point: there are hundreds of thousands of me out there. And we are all searching.   Be kind.   

And vote.  Please vote.

What the small businesses provide is wanted and needed by customers.  As the economy recovers, it will be provided by bigger businesses funded by deep pockets.  The deep pockets folk are already salivating, quietly behind their masks.  Reopening small businesses will find themselves competing with better-funded chains.

The purpose of the modern American economy is to enable as many Ray Krocs as possible, not as many small, independent hamburger joints as possible.  More Ray Krocs means more jobs managing a franchise or company-owned store under close supervision, and fewer jobs building a small, loved, unique business from scratch.  Success at such a job ends with selling to a large company or trying to become such a company and succeeding.  Retiring after a long run as a small business, and perhaps handing it on to someone who has worked there for years and shares its vision, is a form of failure.  It leaves money on the table by failing to exploit the local success of the small business to make it bigger and try for Krocdom.  

From a socialistic perspective, the question is what sort of jobs and people we want to make room for in our economy.  From a market perspective, this question is illegitimate; the competition of the marketplace will decide what sorts of jobs are available and how many.  

Small businesses that believe the market should decide are hobbling themselves.

NYC was hit harder than any part of the country.  Our state and city shut down hard and is slowly reopening based upon stringent guidelines and observable facts.  And the majority of our citizens are to the situation like mature adults.  If the country had the benefit of strong, reason and science based leadership chances are the states being hit badly now would not be bouncing around and seeing 30-somethings dying because they did not know to take this seriously.   Trump, Fox News, Right-wing media, you want to diminish the seriousness of this coronavirus, call it a hoax, or distract with blaming the Chinese???  Well, this is the result.

My courses of action are based on fundamental biological principles, the collective wisdom of epidemiologists and disease specialists and my choices of acceptable risk.  I hope we all survive the journey to the other side of this pandemic.
