Lesson 1: Do not open without strict restrictions to be only lifted slowly as and when new cases, hospitalizations, and transmission decline. Otherwise, the temporary bounce from faster reopening will soon tank as new infections rise and lockdowns are reimposed.

I will never understand why those who are caught in these circumstances, and for whom I have great empathy, are not fighting for the things that would allow them to recover later on.

Why has there been no discussion of suspending mortgage and rent payments?  (And don't tell me it can't be done - it is being done by many banks and landlords - at least the smart ones who know it doesn't pay them to drive their mortgagees and tenants to ruin secondary to unprecedented circumstances for which they bear no responsibility).

There are ways that could be implemented to allow those who so desire to "mothball" their businesses for an extended  period of time, but those have to be lobbied for.

I am not criticizing those who want to close, and have been thinking about same, doing so.  But those who never would have even given this a second thought should be giving activism to push implementation about things that would allow those closed by mandate to assume a state of "suspended animation" until something even vaguely approaching a "new normal" that can be expected to remain as such can occur.

From here, all we can see is that your country sacrificed its people and cratered its economy- all at the same time.  My heart aches for the people profiled in this story. Their extreme loss seems so unnecessary to those of us on the outside.  I am so angry for you all that you didn’t have the coordinated, federal response to this horrible pandemic.  You don’t have  the fiscal and health safety nets that have allowed those of us in Canada, for example (along with many other countries) to endure a hard lockdown, then a slow re-opening.  Our approach has saved families and small businesses- so those people who worked so hard to build those viable, vibrant businesses that give so much to our communities and country aren’t wiped off the map.  We aren’t perfect, for sure, but we have done everything we could to keep people hopeful for their health and hopeful their business could survive and come out the other side of this.  We locked down, then we tested, traced, isolated when needed and continue to do so.  We wear masks, we physically distance, we wash our hands.  We care about each other, recognizing that doing so is a benefit to all of us.  You could have nailed this-it isn’t  hard! 
My  family is very small.  Half live in Maine.  We have resigned ourselves to the fact we may not see them for years, because we just cannot open our borders until you have put out this dumpster fire.  And I am not sure you can. I hope you do. We hope you do.

I saw with sadness that another local small business closes its doors the other day; having worked in my parents’ modest store (before the advent of big box stores and the internet), I am particularly familiar with the precariousness of such enterprises, especially when ridiculously high rents are still due.  I can’t help wondering how many kept trying to stay afloat for a while by spending more or all of their savings, when they might ended up in a better financial condition by shutting down immediately back in March/April, only to be forced to give up now.

Small businesses are not only the economic lifelines for many families, they  are part of a community’s soul.

Places that crushed the virus - e.g. Vietnam and Korea - sealed off areas that had infections and/ or stopped domestic travel completely.  They tested a vast higher proportion of their population than we have and supervised the quarantine of those who tested positive.  They also traced and isolated their contacts.

In the U.S. the shutdown in March and April was not complete enough.  Too many businesses were deemed ‘essential’ and people were able to move around too much.  And we didn’t maintain the shutdown long enough in those areas of the country that are worst affected.

Wearing masks in public may now be a necessary condition of slowing the virus’s spread, but it will not be sufficient to get case numbers where they have to be.  That would require a few several weeks of genuine shutdown.  Think Vietnam, Korea, maybe Italy.

While that goes on we would need to develop coordinated testing, quarantine and contact tracing.

However, we are now in the awful position of having weakened the economy (and the spirit of many people) - with the first, underpowered shutdown and the subsequent infection weakened recovery - to the point that the kind of lock down we need to control the pandemic will have dreadful economic and possibly social costs.
The tragedy is that large protests are still encouraged.

I work in live entertainment.  I have been self employed for 22 years.  All the future work was gone within 7 days.  Being self employed and running a "single owner business" you learn to squirrel away as much as possible and to say yes to the work as long as it is offered.  I have been fortunate to be hired many times.  Did I sacrifice along the way.. yes.. on many aspects of life.  I made that choice and I knew going into my line of work that was a part of it.  I have very little debt.  I have put aside savings.  I have put aside an SEP-IRA.  I am almost 58.  Will my line of work come back?  Sure.. at some point in time.  Will I be as "desired"..maybe?  
I feel so bad for all the other small business owners and their subsequent employees.  This virus has been politicized past the point of logic.  The leadership on the federal level is abjectly terrible.  We are 7 months into knowing about this virus and yet we are in worse shape than any other country.  We desperately need a national policy. The first anecdote (the karaoke bar) perfectly illustrates one of the reasons why this country is struggling with the pandemic. Everyone alive experiences setbacks, disappointments and heartbreak at some point. However when Mr. Larkin didn’t get the outcome he wanted his response was to throw $1,000 worth of perishables and protective equipment (including masks and hand sanitizer) in the trash.  How many hospitals, nursing homes, food banks, clinics, home health aides, etc. could have used those supplies?  The selfishness some Americans are displaying boggles the mind. This complete inability to see beyond your own selfish wants and needs affects how you raise your children, how you contribute (or in this case don’t contribute) to your community and how you vote. No wonder we are struggling when presented with an enemy that requires teamwork and some collective inconvenience.

America needs the population to comply not at 60%, 70%, or even 80%, but at 99% need to be willing to do a proper lockdown if the US is ever to get rid of COVID-19.  It will take probably close to 90-days and would require zero travel and zero in-person contact outside the immediate household.

The virus doesn't care about the economy, your child's education, or your religious beliefs, it has only one goal to spread and evolve.  It is non-negotiable.  

The US needs to stop thinking it is negotiable and 100% need to take this serious and 99% need to comply with a very painful 90-days, otherwise the ruin faced by these businesses is just the first wave of the greatest economic depression to come that will last an entire generation.  

Betting it all on a non-existent vaccine where anti-bodies in the body don't last beyond two weeks of infection as we now have found out is like planning your retirement based on winning the lottery.

My wife and I have a small business serving two different end users. For almost 10 years we’ve been planning weddings and creating the floral arrangements and last December we opened a gift shop selling small bath & locally-/minority- made items. We converted a lot of cash into goods at just the wrong time.

As far as weddings are concerned many have been postponed and some cancelled. Now that Virginia has moved into Phase 3 it’s possible to have events up to 250 people. An Executive Order stipulates that anyone indoors over the age of 10 must wear a mask unless seated and eating/drinking or have a medical reason for not doing so.

We recently contacted those clients we’re providing day-of coordination to advising them of the rules (the law) which we’ll be upholding and giving them a way out of their contract with us if they so choose (or they could just wear masks). To our absolute amazement many clients have opted to cancel with us and work with someone else less restrictive. We are being held hostage by clients who want to break the law.

As far as our gift shop is concerned we shuttered this back in March and it’s still closed. We simply don’t want to face the harassment of people entering that won’t wear a mask.

Fortunately for us we made hay when times were good but we’re fast running out.

We’re extremely disappointed that clients are simply choosing to work with other vendors that will turn a blind out to the law rather than adhere to our Governor’s orders.

We are small business in Maine.  For the last 15 years we have run a gym for clients over 40 years of age.  When the state announced two presumptive cases of COVID, we shut down, recognizing that most of our clientele were at high risk should they contract the virus.  A week later the state mandated all gyms shutter their doors.  We had hoped that our closure was only temporary, lasting maybe three months at the most. But protests, political arrogance, and denials have only exasperated and extended this pandemic.  We continue to stay closed, even though the state allowed gyms to reopen early June.  We have chosen to ignore the politics and follow the science, which the CDC stated early on that there should be two consecutive weeks of declining cases before reopening.  We have not achieved that metric, therefore we remain closed.  Had this administration adhered to the advice of the scientific community from the offset, maybe we would not be in this mess.  I am not hopeful that we will survive should Trump be reelected.  Our only hope at this point is that a Democratic administration prevails in November.
There were just too many businesses and many  not viable, so this winnowing and the resulting reduction in tax revenues is a good time to focus on what is important, drinking in karaoke bars is not.

I read this piece an hour after strolling by the newly out-of-business First Street Cafe in Benicia, California, for 23 years a local institution in the small city my wife and I moved to last year. In fact, it was the very first place we visited as we started to check out Benicia, about 30 minutes north of Oakland. The fine impression the Cafe left started us on the road to settling here. Great food, friendly service, Sunday afternoon jazz and a nice part of a nice town. Now it's gone. A vibrant business shuttered, a dream shattered and lots of folks out of work.

Multiply the First Street Cafe by countless other sad, similar stories across the country. We end up with the consequences not simply of the pandemic but of a president too self-centered and incompetent to contain the contagion and the havoc it continues to wreak. November can't come soon enough. But it will be too late for this little restaurant and the people who were part of it.

"...there may be no end in sight to the crisis."

If it isn't clear yet, it will soon be clear that there is no end in sight to this crisis. We, all of us, need to be thinking not in terms of weeks or months, but in terms of years.

The information we now have available tells us that we're in this for the very long haul.

These business failures are the consequences of our decisions not because of the virus.  Stay at home orders and forced business closures are the result of decisions made by government in the name of "protecting the public" from Covid. So all of these failures are attributable to the governors and local officials who forced their closure in the name of public safety. These decisions have a cost. In this case the cost is the bankruptcy of small and medium sized businesses. Sure, some would have  suffered and failed if government allowed citizens to make independent decisions about whether to go out to a restaurant, bar or business in the face of this epidemic, but business could have innovated and some would have found a way to serve their patrons safely and survive. Now, they will all die by decree. And state and local governments will be responsible. These business owners will not forget.
Thank Trump. He did this to you.

I am really sorry all these businesses had to experience this once in a lifetime force majeur. Anger at government for closing is completely misdirected in my opinion. 

Small businesses, especially entertainment, food and beverage businesses, live on the edge anyway, so it is unsurprising that months of COVD shutdown might cause many to fail. I have seen business owners shake their fists and cry, “it’s not fair!” While passively doing nothing. I also have seen business owners use this situation as an opportunity to rethink their business model and find creative ways to adjust. Yes, everyone is hurting, but the idea that EVERY small business is quitting is wrong. Some are enduring, rolling with the punches and using this time to figure it out. In my opinion, we would be better off focusing on reporting about those who are creating new approaches and how ordinary citizens can better support local businesses in spite of the pandemic.

How hard would it have been to all pull together? We have been blinded by greed and idiocy. How hard would it have been? 
Not hard at all.

I used to own several small businesses.

It was exhausting. There is a thrill of being your own boss but the responsibility to your workers, the work/family balance and financial stresses are tremendous, especially the first few years.

It was killing me and so I took another path in life.

I can't even fathom trying to do it in 2020.

There is was no need to make public health and small business economic health a zero sum game. We could have had a responsive national pandemic plan that kept Covid cases low, small businesses afloat, workers finances good, and provided health insurance to anyone who list insurance due to a job loss or any other reason. Trump and his supporters are to blame.

Sorry, you may have gone out of business anyway, but once again, totalitarianism supports the few, the rich and power.  Liberty is hard because it allows for choice and change, things the left and right authoritarians reject because either side loses its power over you if the accepted liberty and equal protection.

It's really sad to hear small businesses closing their doors.  Honestly, it has felt throughout the pandemic that our leaders failed to set reasonable expectations for its citizens.  You can't just go on lockdown, you need a way to at least partially shutdown the economy without businesses going bankrupt.  To set the standard that your business existing and your employees getting fed does not rely on your business being open at full capacity.  The pandemic will last for years, as will intermittent lockdowns.  People deserve to know what's expected and be given reasonable expectation.

Maybe we should give some businesses a legal option to temporarily shut their doors (or be open only at half capacity) and just not pay their bills.  And the government will cover their employees salaries.  It really doesn't matter if the bankers and capital get paid as most of the rest of us aren't getting paid either.  This would trigger a really bad depression, but the alternative is probably worse in every way.

The biggest risk here is that not only will some businesses cease to exist and others like Amazon consolidate, but also that most businesses won't take risks and invest in growing their businesses.  Many businesses were probably taking risks and trying to grow before this.  Why ever take such an existential risk again?  This in itself can cause a recession or hurt workers.

President The Donald pontificated that "Small Business is the backbone of our country."

And like with most federal programs you just have to know how to exploit them which is sad for those who don’t know how or don’t want to (get caught.) I know one small business owner who owns a little clothing store in our small downtown and she’s its only “employee”.  She got enough “paycheck protection” to buy a brand new 30 foot RV for over $100,000. Oh and she hired a couple people she knows to work for her to satisfy that requirement so she didn’t have to give it back. I know another small business of one who was given $55,000 that he doesn’t have to pay back. This is somebody who made over $200,000 a year working part time prior to the pandemic.

The solution to this, which is painfully, infuriatingly obvious at this juncture, is to bail out small businesses (and people in general) for the duration of this pandemic and any lingering economic depression. For Republicans and neoliberal Democrats, this flies in the face of their idea of how the world should work. The question is, how many of us will suffer and lose everything before reality forces our political leaders to give people more money?

How would the COVID mortality statistics look if folks over 65 were actually self-isolating? How busy would hospitals be if folks over 65 were self-isolating? For those who don't know, about 100,000 of the roughly 130,000 deaths have been folks over 65. About 20,000 of the remainder were over 55 and/or had serious pre-existing health problems. Do the math. We are crushing people's lives and harming our kids because the media is relentlessly promoting the idea that COVID is a death sentence and we are all in mortal peril. Sure let's wear masks when appropriate and avoid crowding indoors, but wouldn't it be easier and less harmful to really isolate 15% of the population instead of pretending we can stop all social, educational, and economic activity for a year or more? Is it actually a crisis if record numbers of people get COVID but just go home and stay in bed for several days? Oh, but I saw a story on CNN that said COVID causes permanent brain and lung damage! Yes and people can get an infection from a scratch or a cold and end up dying of septic shock (one of the most common causes of death in hospitals). Life is not free of risk but in reality the number of healthy people under 60 who have died from COVID is very small. If you want to stop early, preventable death and needless injuries put down your phone and start driving the speed limit.

Why are there no articles pointing out that on average (using 2017 data but it’s all about the same, google it yourself) 7700 people die EVERYDAY in the US from all causes? Since we were at 25 deaths a day to now is over 120 days. So in a normal year over 900,000 people in the US would have died during the time we have been experiencing this, so just since February to now. Considering the data clearly shows that a vast portion of the people counted as covid deaths were very old (no offense but I’ll label very old as 76+). Every death is terrible, but with life comes death. No serious person would say that the shutdowns are not doing immense social/emotional harm to millions of children and us Times readers also know the reckoning is coming for the poor and some middle class; this is conjecture but I think a conservative guess would be that a couple hundred thousand American families that were on the brim of climbing out of poverty are likely facing a decade to get back to where they were. Can someone please explain how the data supports such draconian measures?? Almost 3 million Americans die EVERY year. I’m not saying I want a million more to but I see little evidence that is what we would face given the current numbers. I know some will say “that’s 20% of cases” but you know that’s not likely, with so many asymptomatics and given what played out in New York, millions more likely had this reducing the death rate substantially.

I'm a small business owner, a mom, and married to an educator. I didn't take PPP money. I paid my taxes, included quarterly estimates, on time and not the delayed due date. We're now gearing up for my husband to return to school in fall knowing full well one of us may get sick because of that. Every time I see anyone outside without a mask, I want to scream. EVERYONE must do their part. Businesses will continue to close at a fast clip until everyone realizes they have to do their part. We can't just blame Trump. We are a nation of individuals that have utterly failed each other.

I am NOT saying this to self praise but...how many times have we all talked about shopping local? How many times have then gone down to Home Depot or Target to buy things that we could easily buy from the Pop and Mom store down the road from where we live? How many times have we shopped on Amazon for something (sunglasses, sneakers, a smoke alarm) that we could have bought less than a mile from where we live? For too many years I've done this but this year I have stopped. Now if I need something I go out of my way (a bit) to the local store and I tell them I'm buying from them bc they support the local economy and hire local and they are important to me. So in the end I'm spending 5-10% more for all the stuff I buy each year - I'm happy (and so are the store owners) when I stop and shop local, tip well and remember what matters in my neighborhood. I'm just back from handing out 30$ to my barber for the haircut I did not go get in April, and I told him I'll see him in a month if things are better (and if they are not I'll give him another 30$ in August). This stuff matters. The time to help our community businesses is now.

Mr.  Larkin needs to realize just h what happened to his business. It was trashed by trump.  When the coronavirus was recognized as a major threat, Trump and the Republicans in Congress gave away 100 trillion dollars to big business with no strings attached. hope to see them open again once demand returns.

So I don't want to be mean about this but I have been running  a small business all my adult life.  What are you going to do after this defeat?  Work as a store clerk? I don’t rejoice in the shuttering of businesses any more than I rejoice at people dying of the virus. But just as a lot of people who called the pandemic a hoax and flouted social distancing protocols found out the tragically hard way that they were mistaken, a lot of small business owners who successfully petitioned their governors to reopen their states despite solid scientific evidence that it was premature to do so are now paying the consequences. And I’m sure in both cases a lot of them voted for Trump and will do so again if they live to see November. 

I still feel bad for them. But it’s sad to see how few people understand the reason this is such a catastrophe. People have been telling us for months what the situation is and how we a society could handle it a small other countries are doing. My heart bleeds for small business owners.  They are entrepreneurs who take big risks, create jobs, and courageously take on the challenge on making payroll.  It didn't have to come to this. How the Trump family and other large Fortune 500 firms get 'Small-Business' loans or grants over them is both mind-boggling and deeply insulting.

Struggling business will most likely never recover while [hopefully] our general anathema to a well-funded social safety net will wither away.

The loss of so many small businesses is terrible. So many of them are shoestring operations, depending on walk-in trade and casual buyers. These businesses are sometimes the heart and soul of certain neighborhoods, oftentimes having a sort of symbiotic relationship to each other in shared customers going from one store to another. 

If all the small businesses in a certain neighborhood close, it could have a devastating effect on everyone. This possibility could change city life for a very long time.

The first domino to fall are the employees of the small businesses.
The second domino are the small businesses and their owners.
The third domino are the landlords who won't have rental income and can't pay back their mortgages.
The fourth domino is the banks who will take great losses on the vacant real-estate they really, really don't want to have to deal with.
Not a pretty picture.

So, will this be an opportunity for chain restaurants and corporations to take a bigger piece of the restaurant business? If so, very sad. I'd rather the the government help these small businesses weather the storm, rather than leave it all to dog-eat-dog, which will actually be more like behemoth-eat-mouse.

I have tremendous compassion for small business owners and believe that their experience and grit will be essential to moving our small towns and our big cities forward.  However, laying debt on a low margin business during such extreme uncertainty may not be the best approach regardless of how cheap the rate or easy the terms.  I'm not sure how to structure it but it may actually be better to support the business owner closing and ensuring they have capital to restart or start a new business when it becomes more clear what their market needs.  There will surely be changes in consumer behavior and its worth considering how to put the business owner inthe best possible position to succeed in their "new normal"

Just forget about Main Street. The voters chose a government that doesn't care to save it, so now everything will be online orders fulfilled by warehouses, and large chains -- whose owners will all make the biggest donations they can to political campaigns and PACs, to lock in their power over the little folk for as long as they can.
For every nursing home life saved, a thousand young people's livelihoods are being destroyed, possibly for an entire generation.

I own a modest, older property in a working class/industrial area of town. Next door is a wonderful coffee shop, owned and run by a mother and her two hardworking sons. I see their business as a social anchor that benefits our community intensely, and frequently stop in for coffee and pastries. I certainly could brew my own, but I see the act as a way of doing my part to help. They have received no government assistance, nor have I - somehow, the lot of us have fallen through the cracks of the stimulus programs. All the more reason to help a truly local business.

Why were religious entities who don’t pay federal or state taxes allowed to receive funds from the PPE? The Catholic Church received close to a billion dollars. Mitch McConnell said that he didn’t want aid money sent to states that have huge pension obligations. I really wish these businesses could catch a real break. It's gut wrenching to watch small businesses die. They are the heart of our economy.

This is literally what you get when a country elects a populist who believes government is a burden. To all of those who didn’t see this coming from 2016, Shame on you. At the time, I was a 26 year old woman, even then I realized the disarray this POTUS would cause if faced with a real challenge. For the last three years, we have been graced by the fact he had not. To all of those in journalism who aren’t hitting that point home everyday, shame on you. POTUS has abandoned this country and I doubt we will recover. Lucky for me, I’m well educated and plan to ship out as soon as the virus is over. My personal tragedy: once I was a young person who wanted to run for public office in this country. But now all I long for is a home country complete with reason and logic. As an American, who loves her country dearly, It seems like the problems here are now insurmountable and beyond repair. I’m not one to give up, but this is such a foreseeable and tragic outcome with this POTUS, that I can’t help resenting everyone who enabled him. God speed, countrymen.

I’m a small business owner myself. One important point is that the owner needs to make his own judgement of how the pandemic will proceed, and not hope that the government will tell him.

People that try to open too quickly can easily be burned.

Here in Tokyo, restaurants offer takeout food, retailers start online shops and take other creative measures.

New cases are only 200 cases per day in Tokyo, but they are mostly from drinking establishments so these are running the risk of getting shut down.

This unnecessary and avoidable financial crisis falls in its entirety on the backs of the President of the United States and the Republican-controlled Senate. My heart broke into million little pieces reading this...

"Justin Norman, Yelp’s vice president of data science, said that the federal government should offer small businesses more help."--- that's funny!  That horse left the barn long ago. The federal government cares not one bit about mom and pop businesses.

Months and months ago, the head of the Federal Reserve -- Minnestota branch, I believe, was on any number of serious news and other programs saying to anyone who would listen that the government response needed to be bigger and longer than that of  TARP in 2008/'09 ... whenever that was.

This was a former Obama administration (or tertiary) member, who said if anything, the response then should have been much bigger and deeper and extended.

So with this catastrophe on the horizon, he had a 10-year perspective and could see the problems ahead if small businesses weren't adequately supported with enough money for a long enough period of time.

I'd say he was right, as I read about Norway -- Denmark? -- where they have had nary a ripple in their economy, no one is thrown into unemployment or bankruptcy, employees get paid, businesses continue to exist, all to be ready to go when things get better.
Republicans are failing. Trump’s empathy extends to pardoning Roger Stone. I guess I’d be for a dictator if it was someone organized.

The President declares he is wartime leader and continues to play gold like a frat boy.  Congress has no urgency to do the business at hand by going on recess. The atmosphere in DC is that of a country club cocktail party.

It’s undoubtedly true that the world will be little bit the worse off due to the non-reopening of Krank It Karaoke and its “booze-infused jello syringes” but I think, if we all work together, we might just make it through.
You have a choice. We had no federal management of this crisis, and if you have to close your business, look at the bigger picture. Who you vote for matters.
What's the opposite of "too big to fail?"

It's hard to put into words the disgust.  Who voted for this guy?  Which Representatives and Senators cover for him? He is a living breathing incarnation of willful ignorance, hubris, arrogance, spite, and malice.  We'll you've finally done it.  You got what you wished for.  Now watch it burn to the ground.  And it's not over.  I've been wracking my brain for months and I can't sort this.  Get ready for the denials, gaslighting and revisionism.  Never forget what Trump, Republicans and those who support them have done to us.

This is truly heartbreaking. So much of this medical and economic pain was unnecessary. There should have been a national shutdown with the country's full support, massive government economic help to get people and businesses through it, and clear messaging on mask wearing and social distancing and how they are the key to economic life. And no states should have re-opened with case numbers still rising and never having even leveled off.

And now we do it again, having already lost so much. Our leaders, especially but not only trump, failed us. Let's at least get it right this time. We were worried we'd be Italy. Right now, we should be so lucky.

The responsability and importance of a unified plan and response should have come from our President who is absent in all respects-- too busy with scheeming how to subvert the electoral processes getting Putin to help him the fraudster in chief can not and will not lead but he sure knows how to lie and cheat never mind the lives of the citizens of the USA are at stake.

The main reason why the US has prospered through the years is our stable governing system.  Businesses require predictable conditions to invest and grow.  We need a unified federal response NOW to this crisis, bringing all the states in order based on sound science.  Top down leadership, which Trump is incapable of providing.  My business will survive COVID, and it has been difficult, but we are lucky.  I feel awful for those small businesses that are failing.

As bad as the loss of small, indepenant businesses is what’s worse is that they will most likely be replaced by corporate franchises. And thus the generification of America continues. 

I grew up in a time when the vast majority of local businesses were independantly owned and operated. I knew many of the proprietors by name and they knew me. If I had a question, a product complaint, or a product request they were there to respond in person. They were directly accountable to their customers and had a personal interest in making sure those customers were satisfied with the products and service they offered. 

Corporate retail is precisely the opposite. They are utterly unaccountable to their customers because they don’t have to be. In many places they’re the only show in town, so if you want the accountability of a locally owned business you might have to go to the nearest big city to find one. The people who make the policies and product decisions in corporate retail are a million miles away in some headquarters and are unavailable to customers. If you don’t like their policies or politics you can boycott them, but unless you’ve got 50,000 like minded people to boycott with you it won’t make a scintilla of difference. 

This is no longer the America I grew up in and I don’t like where it’s headed.

When Trump won in 2016, I foresaw that something bad would happen. True, I thought it might be a senseless war and just a plain old economic collapse caused by sheer incompetence -- though in a way I was right about both those things -- but I'm so glad I went back to work at large corporation while my wife continued with the business. Now we have a good shot at making it through this, but I know many aren't so lucky. The business environment is rigged against small business to begin with and this COVID-19 Pandemic made it exponentially worse. If we don't get rid of the Trump graft regime and fix the way our regulatory laws work while also getting rid of the dreadful Citizen's United scam, we'll be headed for even worse times to come.

Small businesses have been going out of business everyday for millenia. They are not unique now except in their numbers. How can we help slow the fallout? How can we (as a society) help the new businesses get jump-started to avoid a deep economically painful period? I am not wise enough to make that policy. I suggest UBI is a great place to encourage optimism and find out where folks want to spend money to get small businesses going, but I am not a psychic. It may be as bad as we're seeing now.

Regardless of ones political affiliation or general persuasion, this is a sad story.  Having run, with my wife, a small business for seven years, I can only imagine the frustration and despair that the current crop of unfortunately positioned small businesses feel.    The fact that this is not their fault is small consolation.

This is tough - but also we need to ponder how much of our economy is based on businesses reliant on discretionary spending - small restaurants, the sports trinket shop, nail salons, gift shops, etc.  In the hardest hit areas, a lot of these won't come back anytime soon because of the cascading effect of so many people working in this kinds of jobs losing their incomes.  This will impact the number of evictions as people cannot pay rent.  Bankruptcy is probably the only answer for many of these small business owners, so those who they owe money too will also be out of luck.   Meanwhile, Wall Street and the markets still seem quite oblivious to what is happening on Main Street.  At some point the chickens are coming home to roost as we say.  I know I am trying to save a significant amount of money every month - being retired I don't have to go out, and I'm not.  I do not feel safe dining out, and frankly I don't need anymore "stuff".  Many people in my situation spend a significant amount of money on "experiences" - traveling, visiting family, etc.  At the moment that isn't possible.  I'm very concerned about the economic situation because I don't think we have seen the extent to which things could crash.

Considering how COVID-19 is spread, bars will have to close and restaurants will be limited to takeout until there is a vaccine.

At the end of July, when the music stops, we're in for a Great Depression the likes of which this country has never seen or dreamed of. The Republican Senate has sat on its hands, failing to agree on a renewed safety net, and it's already too late.

This is a sad and sharper turn towards an economic system that makes it exorbitantly expensive and now more risky to be a non-wealthy entrepreneur. As a small business owner in Manhattan who survived the 2008 financial crash to see business boom in the last few years, I can tell you... I've never seen anything remotely like this drop in business. It's about 80%. I can close my bricks and mortar space and sell online only, but online sales have also plummeted. There is no hiding from it and silly programs like the PPP loans won't help. Better to use the funds to support the workers with extended unemployment benefits. That will truly help sustain the economy. Small business is going to be hit extremely hard in this country until a vaccine is found. In the case of retail, it will be long after that as people have stopped spending and it's going to snowball. The stock market is going to crash in a spectacular fashion once all of this becomes clear. If you've made money, sell and take your profit now.

None of this economic tragedy had to happen. It didn’t happen in 1957 when a flu pandemic killed over 1.1 million people worldwide. No one complained about overtaxing the hospitals either. Back then, at least in the US, hospitals were run with 3 shifts of nurses daily instead of just two (3 eight hour shifts vs 2 twelve hour shifts today). PPE was stockpiled for emergencies instead of some MBA ordering a “buy when needed” policy that leaves hospitals unprepared for emergencies. Some countries combined three measures: (1) severe shutdown of any non-essential activities ordered by the federal government and supported by local governments, (2) government coverage of a large portion of wages for small businesses during that shutdown, (3) partial relief of the shutdowns (still no large gatherings in public – i.e. sports events) only after the new infection rates reached an tolerable level (now about 1 in 100000 in Switzerland per day).

The results here: most businesses and hospitals are operating at nearly normal levels, unemployment increased (but still below 4%), and travel to and from most European countries is unrestricted.  (but masks are mandatory when using public transportation).

Since the prospect of achieving “herd immunity” remains uncertain (thus risky), this may be the only reliable approach for returning to a normal life before a vaccine becomes widely available.  

My opinion is that this type of collective effort in a society required consistent messaging from government officials at all levels, as a well as a government that people trust.  These pre-requisites may be easier to find in some countries than others.

While the article doesn’t mention it, the justifiably heralded and soon-to-be-shuttered Beachwood BBQ in Seal Beach, CA was also a pioneer of the modern craft beer movement in Orange County. 

When it opened in 2006 with a tap list of some two-dozen artisanal brews from California, the country and indeed the world (mainly Belgium) — meticulously curated by co-owner and chef Gabe Gordon and his wife, co-owner Lena — it brought great beer to the greater LA area that we’d otherwise have to drive to San Diego County to find. 

Fortunately, their offshoot brewpub Beachwood BBQ and Brewing in nearby Long Beach, and other locations, are still open and operating. But while mourning the passing of the original Beachwood, Southern California craft beer fans should also brace themselves for the fact that it is likely not the last good-beer destination we stand to lose before this pandemic is done with us.

Re: "A choke point for the US Coronavirus Response: Fax Machines".  The truly sad part of this is that there is an alternative to Fax that is available in physicians' systems today - Almost every one of them can send a Direct Secure Message and the Public Health Department can receive it.  In Chicago, the city mandated the use of Direct for COVID reporting and the vendors were able to make modifications in just a few weeks to make it automated - no effort for the providers.  The other factor driving fax usage for communicating to public health is the low level of automation in public health settings - systems may be either antiquated or non-existent.  Setting up a Direct inbox in the health department as an alternative to fax would at least allow the data to be sent securely and in a usable format.  The cost and time to implement such capabilities is trivial, particularly when compared the effort to manage inbound messages by fax. - Scott Stuewe, President and CEO, DirectTrust

My wife and I flew back to Singapore last week after five months in the US. We were on a Singapore Airlines flight from Los Angeles. There were around 35 passengers in our Airbus A350 aircraft. 

We wore face masks throughout the 16 hour flight and at both airports. When we touched down at Singapore’s Changi airport, we were taken in a bus to a hotel assigned to us for our mandatory 14 day quarantine. The costs of our hotel stay and a Covid swab test are borne by the government. 

We have a comfortable hotel room at the Fairmont with a great view. But we are not allowed to step out of our room. We get text messages from the immigration authorities at random times during the day. The texts contain a link that we click on to confirm our location. Is this intrusive? Yes, but we accept that it is necessary in these extraordinary times. It boils down to trust in government.

While I understand the public health concerns of opening schools, there is another side of this equation. Denying in-person schooling to impoverished families is catastrophic for children. The children, often of color, already go to schools that have significant resource issues due to the funding policies of schools in the US, which causes a significant achievement gap. Online education works great for upper middle class families with wealth and educated parents, who may also be working at home. These families have high speed internet and multiple devices to allow for this type of education. Low income families are living in income distressed homes where the parents most like need to work away from home to just to meet weekly bills. A loss of schools in these low income communities will have devastating long-term effects. Meanwhile, wealthy white families who can send there students to private schools will likely have high quality in-person education or superior online education if the school has to close for a period of time. Sending students laptops and school meals does not resolve this opportunity gap that will only be heightened by the nature of COVID-19 making running giant districts like LA United difficult.

The social and geographic complexity of CA is such that there is no simple "reason" for the present outbreak of Covid-19 to alarming levels.

It is likely true that the State simply opened up too soon after first being a leader in stay-at-home shutdowns.  As a part-time resident of LA, when I was last there I could sense that folks grew increasingly desirous of returning to the region's legendary sun-splashed, care-free, LaLa-land lifestyle.

Complicating the situation was that while there were outbreaks in some areas, they came at different times and were often geographically scattered.  There would be an outbreak in the Central Valley which proved of little concern to Orange County etc.

Further, most of the early CA cases had arrived from China.  They were actually relatively few and the early shutdown muted the impact.

But now, with more "opening" plus the spread of the more virulent "European" strain from East to West the situation is far different.

Right now we are back in NY and face a dilemma when to return to LA.  We know we'll face the need to quarantine upon coming back if we go there.  But at the same time, much of our lives is truly "bi-coastal".

It's almost like living in one house where there is a "safe" room and a "dangerous" one.  And those two keep switching.

We just hope that CA finds a way to tamp down the situation there as much as we also hope NY now "stays the course" and continues to beat the virus.

What would be the ramifications of decoupling health insurance from employment? According to some quick research, almost 50% of Americans have employer-provided health insurance (pre-COVID-19 figures). Another 20% are on Medicaid and another 15% are covered under Medicare.   That leaves only 15% who seek insurance on the open market place, a relatively small percentage. That's perhaps the reason Obamacare was not the resounding success it was hoped to be. What if those 15% ballooned to 65%, i.e., those who would no longer have employer-provided health insurance, but would now buy on the open market, just like buying car insurance? The sheer volume of demand would lead to much greater competition, more choices and lower premiums, assuming market forces can be trusted. Employers would no longer have to deal with the expense and responsibility of offering health insurance as a fringe benefit, but pay that as cash compensation instead, which would help employees help purchase medical insurance. The health insurance would be portable and completely independent of employment. Just as employers already require things like valid driver's licenses, they could require proof of health insurance as prerequisite of employment, which would serve as an incentive for folks to purchase coverage.  I'd like to see an in-depth analysis of how such an arrangement could work or not.

World War Two was our last global disaster.  While the devastated industrialized world responded with efficient systems of government sponsored universal health care, the United States responded with a system of employment based health insurance.   It worked well with minimal unemployment and employers willing to provide coverage.  

Today, however, unemployment is an increasingly serious problem.  Though the quality of health care in the US remains superb on an individual basis, simply because of insufficient access for millions of us no longer covered by our employment based health insurance, the national indicators of health suffer - and the United States suffers for it.  We suffer to the point that, despite professional and technologic superiority, our health status in the United States is the worst of all industrialized nations; and it’s worsening daily.  For this dubious stature, we spend far more on health care than any country - industrialized or otherwise. 

This Coronavirus pandemic is now a global disaster greater than WWII.  Despite highly advanced science and technology,  the United States is not doing well compared to nations with national health systems - setting scary records in both job losses; and therefore record losses in health insurance coverage.  This health care war against the Coronavirus points glaringly to our urgent need for government sponsored universal health care.

So, our insurance system, even post-ACA, has left another 1%-2% of our population without coverage, down from 91%. 

That's just peachy.  Against 99% to 100% for the rest of the developed world.

About 1% to 2% of our now roughly 10% uncovered can thank the 13 red states for not expanding Medicaid.

Much of the maybe 8% remaining don't have affordable coverage because of serious weaknesses in the ACA from the start, from the Democrats  These need to be repaired fully, especially now that Single Payer appears politically impossible.

The ACA affordabilty issues revolved around deficiencies called the "subsidy cliff", the "family glitch", high copays, and some others.

One of my favorite, generally ill-publicized issues that I like to point out, is that much of the "coverage" that the country now counts as coverage in the statistics are forms of Medicaid, including ACA expanded Medicaid.   (Referring to non-long-term-care Medicaids.  The ordinary medical "coverage" people have.)

In at least 10 states, include blue MA, NJ, and MD, any Medicaid coverage, including ACA expanded Medicaid, for people 55 and older, is subject to Medicaid estate recovery.

We cannot address a real natural phenomenon as if it is a problem of perception. 

The first fact to accept is that it’s threat of severe medical problems from this illness is lower than many other pathogens but that it spreads easily and the infected often show mild or no symptoms. That means that the law of large numbers guarantees that big spread means catastrophic amounts of severely ill people. 

The second fact is that not knowing who is ill leaves controlling the spread to shutting down social interactions and the disruption of all aspects of life. It means greatly diminished economic activities by individuals and private enterprises. It means diminished revenues to support public services.

The third fact is that this is an international pandemic and using centralized authority is the most efficient means of addressing it. Resources are limited because of the interruption of normal ways of generating new wealth, so wealth must be expended carefully to minimize the long term costs from deficits and scarcity driven inflation. 

We are in this together no matter what are are attitudes and preferences, and we will harm ourselves by letting politics affect how this pandemic is addressed.

Foreigners are shocked how any interior space in an American summer is ice-cold.  In the past we thought about the environmental costs and the respiratory tract challenge, but now there's a much bigger worry.

Your unfiltered airconditioning also dehumidifies the constantly recycled air, so that the virus-laden air in most interior spaces, as on a cruise ship, constantly gets more potent and deadly, with no opening windows to dilute the noxious vapour.

I don't want to appear daft, because I'm not an idiot like Trump. I know that testing doesn't spread the virus or cause people to contract it. But I am confused by the media's use of the phrase "new cases." If these "new cases" are indeed the result of more people testing positive for the virus, then yes, more testing will equal more reported cases--in which case there's no cause for hysterical headlines. Alarm, yes, because COVID still isn't under control, but that would not call for the abject panic in headlines like this one, because more testing DOES result in finding more cases. Statistically, if the story DOES refer to new positive tests, you couldn't even call them "new cases" if the people being tested had not been tested before and found to be negative; this is just Statistics 101. OR, are the "new cases" being reported the number of people being admitted to the hospital with symptoms? The difference between the two groups is statistically critical. Would it be possible for stories like this to clarify the source of their "new cases"--testing or hospital admissions? I find stories like this to be extremely confusing.

Earlier today - I watched a screening of the movie "Jezebel" (1938) on Turner Classic Movies -- Seeing this film in our current climate was a one-two punch in the gut -- The film takes place in New Orleans - during the antebellum period - a term which has recently come under scrutiny, for obvious reasons -- At one point - the city is gripped by a plague - "...a deadly epidemic has swept the city. They fight it with cannon and smoke and, believing that yellow fever is highly contagious, a quarantine so rigid that people who try to escape the city are shot." - Then - in one scene - Julie (Bette Davis) risks her life being taken in a boat by a black slave to the house where Preston (Henry Fonda) is laying in bed fighting the disease - She enters the home and pushes her way past Dr. Livingstone (Donald Crisp) - up to Preston's bedside -- In the room - Julie and the doctor go over to Preston as he lies in bed, obviously ailing while covered in sweat -- Behind them stands the black maid-servant - who has been attending to Preston -- As Julie and the doctor stand closely over an infectious Preston - the maid stands behind -- with a cloth covering her nose and mouth (!!) The maid never removes the protective cloth from her face during this scene - even as she's sent off by Julie to fetch some ice -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jezebel_(1938_film) It's 90 degrees here in NY City today - but when I saw that scene - the chill I experienced made me reach for a blanket ...

This is one of the better articles to outline SOME of the issues with returning to school. It’s not just virus control that has to be considered. 
1. In every instance, countries that returned to school had infections under control.
2. Schools returned in phases with reduced schedules (the hybrid model in the US)
3. Schools were monitored with testing and either closed or some portion quarantined when an infection was discovered. 
4. All of the countries mentioned have implemented universal access to health care that would likely lead to higher health outcomes than in the US. 

To open in the US:
1. Teachers are part of the decision making process
2. Testing is readily available, frequently used, and has quick results 
3. The business community steps up to donate whatever is needed to get schools open: space, devices, services, expertise, supplies, PPE, and personnel to help manage students when teachers only have a portion of their students at a time. 
4. Health care and mental health professionals donate their time and expertise to make sure kids and essential school workers are healthy. 
5. Government rules established to help teachers care for their families, provide in times of illness, and provide answers to basics like how outbreaks are handled, restroom breaks, substitute teachers, time for teachers to use the restroom and eat, and teacher responsibilities for school discipline.

I am a public school teacher in Austria, and our schools have been open for several weeks.  We started with the senior class (they had exam preparations and then took the state exams), followed by K-8, and two weeks after that grades 9-11.  Numbers were closely monitored and stayed low throughout.  Masks were required for the first few weeks, and students came to school in half groups, group 'A' Monday-Wednesday, 'B' Thursday - Friday, and the following week they would switch.  Desks were spaced out and students were monitored for social distancing.  Disinfectant was easily available and students were responsible for disinfecting their desks, chairs, etc under teacher supervision.  PE classes were cancelled and music teachers were instructed to 'not sing' for the first few weeks.  Teachers aged 60 and up were not required to teach in person, and anyone with pre-existing conditions were also excused.

I think it worked out well because it was spring - summer, and windows were constantly open.  I think an airless room would be very disconcerting, but fortunately this is not an issue in my school building.

I think it was really good for the students to be back (and for me personally).  But our numbers at the time were excellent (they are rising slightly now).  Here it seems they will close schools regionally based on case numbers - one region closed their schools early because of a outbreak in the area.

Those "studies" sound like anecdotes to me. For every incident where transmission didn't happen, I can raise you one where it did. Just this week, I read about an Arizona summer school where three teachers sharing a school room got sick.

 One of the teachers died. That life may feel statistically meaningless to the selfish cadre of people who want to sacrifice teachers but I assure you she meant a great deal to the people who loved her. 

Children today are likely to live another 100 years. At a minimum. Would adding an additional year of education at the tail end of their school career really be so bad? Isn't that better than a viral legacy that might leave them with long term health problems?   

The truth is we don't know what kind of virus this is... it's characterized as a respiratory virus, but it looks more likely to be vascular. There is evidence of different strains and mutations. That would mean that we are literally gambling with the teaching and administrative and custodial staffs lives, yes, but also with an entire generation of American school children who might have vascular and inflammatory issues for the rest of their lives. Russian Roulette indeed.

A hybrid model is the best means to encourage as many kids and teachers as are able to to stay and work from home. Home may not be for everybody  for a myriad of issues including economic and situational but let's not force those who can shelter out to prove a point.

Don't gamble with lives.

My husband (now retired) was a general contractor with much of his work in large hospitals. One of the main concerns with working in that environment is infection control. During construction, special negative air ventilation systems with hepa  filters were used. Perhaps the school systems and other large facilities could install these special systems that get rid of or greatly reduce the amount of virus particles in the air. Something to consider.

So very easy for commenters to sit in their homes and telework, while saying that we just have to open schools.  Right now all but two states are failing to show decline in virus cases, and the majority of states have out-of-control rise in virus cases, hospitalization.  We are proposing sending children and adults into crowded classrooms and onto crowed school buses.  The adults working in school systems will bring the virus to school, and it will infect other adults.  Then they will go out into the community and spread the infections.  The school classrooms do not have enough space to socially distance children, sufficient ventilation of buildings, nor enough personnel to monitor children for safe hygiene practices.  And remember, these are children, whose impulse control and behavioral regulation are only gradually developing; they are not capable of consistently monitoring their own behavior. Envision masks dropped, sneezing and coughing, failure to wash hands after using the restroom, etc.. Re-opening schools cannot be considered until virus cases have dropped well below current the explosive levels.  Levels that have killed, at the very least, 133,000.  Levels that are overwhelming hospitals and that leave some recovering victims with lingering health problems and disabilities.

This is moot if states can't bring community transmission down to LOW levels and test quickly.  Opening schools with current high levels of transmission isn't feasible.  When/if virus transmission is low, then schools can reopen in a phased way, as NYC plans to do.  The idea that schools can immediately reopen completely to all students, as Trump and Devos are blaring, is unrealistic and dangerous.  Since 25% of public school teachers are over 50, teacher concerns must be addressed.  Providing adequate PPE in schools, installing hand washing in every class room, and opening windows and filtering air in schools, along with regular testing of students and staff could increase safety for the adults at schools.  But these improvements will cost money that most local school districts don't have.  However, given that $500B of federal stimulus funds went to large corporations, the feds should not be constrained from printing more money to support schools.  One way to use federal funds to protect older teachers would be to install large LED screens in classrooms that are hard-wired for real time video chatting between students in a spaced classroom and a teacher sitting in a different room at school, able to interact with their students.  Unemployed recent college grads could be paid to serve as teachers' aids, circulating in the classroom to help students with assignments and interacting with the teacher by video.  Teachers and aids could meet each morning to plan the day.

Many of the countries cited that have successfully reopened schools have a population accustomed to making personal decisions based on what is best for all. American’s zeal for individualism is a barrier to containing the virus in our communities. 
Our school systems are already underfunded. Many of our school buildings are inadequate and a large number of people care more about their so called individual freedoms than they do about others. 
To compare success in countries like Norway returning to schools to the possibility of Americans returning to school, ignores the myriad differences in both societal values and structural systems.

In Denmark, elementary kids went back first. My child's school: parents drop off at staggered times, don't go in. The class was divided in 2, different rooms, only saw each other outside. Within the room, there were defined playgroups. Hand hygiene is emphasized here (not masks), with new sink stations on the playground, and planned hand washing breaks throughout the day. Walks in small groups to neighborhood spots to be outdoors were frequent in the afternoon. In the beginning the school days were not as long as normal. By the end of the school year the class was reunited, full school day reinstated, and hand hygiene habits the new normal.

Recognizing that the data cited in the article is imperfect, doesn't it strongly suggest that NYC provide elementary school education on an in-person basis (spreading the students across all schools to decrease density) and intermediate and high school education remotely. If Americans cannot come together maturely and humbly and stop politicizing mask-wearing which is a very simple conceptual health strategy,  we cannot successfully coordinate safe societal school reentry for our children.

Safe societal school reentry for our children is a much more complex strategy and needs a proven foundation of national unity and cooperation to move forward.

NOW is the time for the federal government to increase funding for schools significantly.  If Trump wants schools to open then he should push for more money.  $400B for schools for in-person learning would allow needed maintenance (especially for air systems), testing, masks, training, and hiring.  This money would help the economy directly and also indirectly in allowing parents to work without having to effectively home-school and babysit.

The article missed an opportunity to mention that Swede, which kept schools up through junior high open at all times has not had any outbreaks in schools among children. The few large clusters we’ve seen was solely within the adults working at schools where they apparently did not practice social distancing between adults. Swedish and Finnish health agencies also studied the outcome and concluded that keeping the schools open in Sweden did not add to the infection rate among the citizens. Teachers where also not infected at a higher rate compared to other professions that could not work from home.

Seems like a lot of too little too late compromising will have to take place if schools are to reopen.  And then another health crisis most likely will unfold  Hard to even prepare for a plan B when plan A Isn’t even close to being formulated.  Any decision seems futile.

There is still a great deal that we don't know about Covid-19. For example, the data tells us that infection rates for the young are infinitesimally small compared to overall infection rates.

Presently we don't know why. I know in my neighborhood when schools closed kids of all ages continued to play outside among themselves. Among teens lack of social distance was almost the norm.

This doesn't mean that there is no risk. But it suggests that the risk is probably greater between adults school personnel than it is among students.

This argues for reopening schools. Most teachers agree that we can basically write off the spring semester. We can't afford to have a similar fall semester of hit and miss zoom classes.

But the lack of infections among the young raises other issues. Could it be that generally young people have a stronger immune system than adults?

Elderly persons (70 and over) in many communities account for over half the Covid fatalities.

If this hypothesis of immune function has some weight, shouldn't we employ methods to strengthen those defenses as part of any overall plan on school attendance?

And, shouldn't the parents of our kids do the same? There are simple, inexpensive ways of strengthening natural immunity, all verified by peer review literature.

In addition to wash your hands maybe we should be adding "and take your Vitamin C and D3."

Street fogging or store isle fogging is often observed in those Asian countries that successfully managed through this virus.   Basically they are disinfecting the dust on the streets.    Why?   Wouldn't it be logical to think that the virus can ride on the dust and float in the air waiting to be lodged deep in our lungs?    Also, wouldn't it be correct to think that we will never be able to avoid the virus 100%, and that it is all about managing to reduce the viral intake and time duration?     S. Korea recently started opening their K12 schools, and they are putting good size HEPA air purifiers in the classrooms, nation wide.   And of course the masks are must.    We, in the US,, are in more difficult situation, considering that fact that we tend to have more carpeted areas (carpeted floors are not common in Asia), and that our buildings do not pull in enough air from outside to save heating and cooling energy.    We need to be smart now.   Too many souls are lost.

It's all about the background infection rate and the use of wide-spread testing.

If the background infection rate is high, then moving desks around, improving air condition, pods, etc. is just rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic.

If the background infection rate is low, then many of these things might contribute to increased success (decreased transmission) but only wide-spread testing, with fast result read-outs, will really matter.  If infections can be caught quickly, schools will be able to remain open.

Every time wide-spread testing is mentioned, the cost of that testing is raised as some kind of excuse for why it isn't being done.  That's nonsense.  The cost to the economy of not being able to open schools dwarfs the cost of testing.  If other countries can test wide swaths of their populations frequently, then we can too.

Schools are not islands onto themselves. We can't wall them off from the surrounding community. The virus doesn't care about our good intentions or that in classroom instruction is best for children. It will enter schools and classrooms. Students and teachers will become infected, some will suffer permanent injuries, and some will die.

What is not being noted in articles on the school reopening debate is that in parts of the US the virus is not only spreading like wildfire amount young adults, it is also spreading rapidly among children. Are there any statistics available for Sweden? 
Sweden had a much wider community spread than it's Scandinavian neighbors which makes it a better country to compare with the situation here in the US. They did not close elementary schools or daycare at all, while high schools and universities had distance learning only. School days include lots of outside play and most schools are spacious and airy, but otherwise it compares well with schools in the US. 
As per the Folkhälsomyndigheten (Swedish CDC) keeping the children in school did not increase the spread. Teachers did get sick, and at least one teacher died, but it is believed they were infected by other adults or not at school.

We can divide the  states in this country in 3 categories (1) States in which the rate of infection continues growing, ( 2)  States which have controlled the rate of infection with great effort and loss of life and (3) Those in which the rate of infection was never threatening. The available data (some of which the article references) makes very clear:

- Young kids (<11 or so) don't really transmit or get sick.
- Older kids can transmit but unlikely to get v. sick

A straightforward solution would seem to be:

- Grades 6 and under attend school in-person, with low-risk educators and staff in the building. In-building teachers and staff minimize their own adult-to-adult interaction. 

- Grades 7-12 attend school virtually with higher-risk educators and staff supervising and guiding

Children in grades 7 and above should be self-sufficient and require less (if any) parental oversight (at least not the minute-to-minute kind a 1st grader requires). 

Middle and high schools can be repurposed for use by grades K-6 to allow increased social distancing.  

The current proposals (2 days/wk., etc.) seem like the kind of compromise arrived at when opinions and emotions are being considered more strongly than data.
No country has re-opened schools with so much transmission in the community as the US currently has.

This was reported by NPR and CNN.  Does anyone think that sending kids and teachers back to school will result in a different outcome?

The article says young kids are not at risk and don’t appear to transmit the virus.  Amazingly, from the comments, it’s almost like the article doesn’t say that.

Is anyone going to point out that every model tells us the outbreak in the fall and winter is going to be many times worse than this one? Why on earth would we send kids back to school precisely when the danger is greatest? Shut down schools at least until next March.

All we have to do is alternate weeks — and the pandemic will end. Not alternate days. Alternate WEEKS! We do not have to cancel school — shouldn’t necessary — school is good. From the day of infection, the 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th days (esp the 5th, 6th, and 7th) are the most important days to avoid having the contagious in school... because the virus has a 6 day incubation on average. Simply alternate weeks (or if you want less, instead do a 4day week then a full week off). If we alternate the students in 1-day cycles or 2-day cycles or half-weeks, that won’t work -- virus continues to spread, the situation falls apart, and the school declares remote-learning 100% within a few weeks later -- and that doesn't work for anyone. Nothing good comes from a rotation that doesn’t work, it won't persist. Three professors did all the homework on this -- and they published it in the NYTimes. I wrote a letter about the professors' '10-4' plan to my schools: https://medium.com/@jploflin/school-schedules-that-minimize-the-spread-of-covid-19-a-letter-to-educators-and-administrators-c4d4612b25d7?source=friends_link&sk=4f1247fc055a90596ad8820435e8964d Then I wrote a followup with more detail: https://medium.com/@jploflin/follow-up-q-a-on-school-schedules-that-minimize-the-spread-of-covid-19-a22f855b8e0d?source=friends_link&sk=3fe7214a00de02581cd5508b8505b5be The impact is large! Focus on week-over-week rotations rather than alternating days and we'll get through this pandemic.

My advice to teachers and school staff who are ordered to go back to in-class teaching after Labor Day is, do whatever you need to to stay safe for the first 2-3 weeks, such as:

*Wear an n95 mask if you have one.

*Distance from students, no matter what the exigency.

*If a student starts misbehaving or needs closer contact, call school security or the school nurse.

*If a student has to use the bathroom, call an aide or school security to escort them.

*Forget about any sort of interactive or collaborative teaching and go back to exclusively teaching from the lectern.

*Keep windows wide open, if possible.

*Etc.

In fact, Finland’s infection rate among children was similar to Sweden’s, even though Sweden never closed its schools, according to a report published Tuesday by researchers from the two countries. In Sweden, researchers also found that staff members at day cares and primary schools were no more likely than people working in other professions to contract the virus. “It really starts to add up to the fact that the risk of transmission, the number of outbreaks in which the index is a child, is very low, and this seems to be the picture everywhere else,” said Otto Helve, who worked on the report as a pediatric infectious-disease specialist at the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare. He said he sent his own children back to school." https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/schools-reopening-coronavirus/2020/07/10/865fb3e6-c122-11ea-8908-68a2b9eae9e0_story.html

Speaking as a high school teacher, reopening feels like a really bad idea to me. I walk around my school and find kids making out anywhere that they might be alone for a second. Soap is rarely in the bathrooms and when it is there, kids often break open the dispensers or squirt it all over the floor. Even when the bathrooms have soap, they regularly have to be closed because kids are getting stoned. What's more, most of the teaching strategies I rely on include giving students time to figure things out together as lecturing is honestly one of the least effective teaching strategies. 

If a hybrid model is adopted, am I expected to teach both to my kids in the class and kids online at the same time? Does that mean that I need to stay still throughout the class? Because that means I lose my ability to use proximity - my most valuable class management strategy. It also means that if I have a student who is struggling, I can't really go over and work with that individual student without being unable to see half my class. 

Let's also talk about passing period. My school has around 2000 students. During passing periods moving through the hallways is like wading through a sea of molasses. And you can't put all the kids in one place and have the teachers move to the kids because the kids are not all in the same classes. 

I simply don't see how reopening can be done safely while retaining decent instruction. And worse, as no one is telling me what is happening, I can't plan.

Secondary Teacher here. We went back to a blend of remote and in class teaching 7 weeks ago. No school access to parents, no access before and after school for students. We teach our classes then go home, so timetables are somewhat flexible to allow this model. I teach seniors so we made Friday a no class day and the building is empty. Older staff over 65 remain remote teaching and we have classrooms set up for those sessions so that students come to the room and they are supervised by an ‘extra’ teacher (paid for by the state not the school). Hand sanitiser stations everywhere in the building, staff desks - every second desk is vacant (I’m one of those desks and I just find a quite empty room/space). Everyone keeps social distance except the students with each other. Some of my students are online whilst I am teaching a class so they can hear the lesson and participate in group work. The students loved being back and there is no substitute for real time teaching (feedback, in particular, is essential for learning progress and this was the hardest part of online lessons). We’re about to go back to this model after our term break. I urge American colleagues to embrace a return to classroom learning, with modifications to suit their students and staff. Addressing the lost learning time must be a matter of urgency for educators. Honestly, the hardest part is My train commute! It’s the only time I feel worried so I shall be wearing masks and not touching any surface.

I live in Vermont, one of the two states seeing steady decreases in COVID cases, due to a lot of shared social agreements arounds mask wearing and social distancing, and incredible leadership from the governor on a slow and careful reopening. From this starting point (which seems the only place we should be talking about reopening schools), as a grade school teacher and mother of three grade-school-age children, I have two thoughts:
1. Children need face-to-face social interactions much more than adults do; parents and teachers have been seeing rising levels of anxiety and depression among children, from early childhood through adolescence. There is a mental health crisis brewing that we are just becoming aware of and that is going to have long-lasting effects; this worries me more than the academic losses.  
2.  Children are incredibly adaptable and will deal well with the new conditions in schools (when it is safe enough in each area to open them). In the elementary academic summer camps we are now running at our school, I see children masking, social distancing and following new routines of frequent handwashing and not sharing supplies. It's not perfect, but new habits are possible. They are SO happy to see each other that they are highly motivated to follow the rules and all these strange new practices quickly have become routine.

No amount of money will build enough additional classroom space to provide for the necessary social distancing required by September 1st. It's already too late. There aren't enough contractors or available portable units in stock. Reducing the transmission rate was the first step in opening schools and the economy. It didn't happen, and the person responsible wants to blame the teachers.

I urge everyone to think of school personnel, teachers, and students, as people, NOT as experiment subjects. These are lives, and we should never take a risk with lives. 

There will be a (rather extensive) learning loss. While I believe that education is one of the most important things; consider the elderly teachers that will be sacrificed if we re-open schools, or the grand-parent that will fall ill after their grand-child infects them, or the high-risk child that becomes dangerously ill when their sibling brings the virus home from school. 

Schools should not re-open in the fall. 

The lives of millions of people should always be prioritized over in-school learning. 

What we need now, is finding a way to work with what we've got. Make online-learning better, and more effective. Find a way to engage students online, and lessen the severity of the learning loss.
