Let’s prove how important it is to get students back in the traditional, physical classroom by doing whatever it takes to get the coronavirus under control first. Whatever it takes. So far, my state hasn’t done much of anything, and now it’s doing even less of that. No way would I send a child of mine back to a Georgia school this August.

The studies of countries that have reopened schools successfully are interesting, but beg the question. In general, those are countries that have done the hard work of getting the virus under control on the one hand, and value education for its intrinsic importance on the other. Americans, by contrast, have rushed to reopen everything and ‘get back to normal’ before the virus was controlled in their communities. And much of what we are hearing about reopening schools is for the wrong reason: to keep children occupied during the day so their parents can go back to work. Americans simply are not mature enough to do this.

When schools open there will be students, teachers and parents that will die as a result. It's statistically inevitable. Let's start the conversation with that and then see how it progresses from there.

One of the results of this epidemic is that it has shown that America has no imagination.  The title of the article begins with "How to Reopen Schools."  Schools can reopen next year with an innovative rethinking of remote learning.  The real issue for everyone seems to be how to get students back in classroom seats.  This goal seems partly  to be a selfish adherence to a fear of change.

As an educator, I always become excited as the start of the school year approaches.  All is fresh and new.  I am honored to be in a position to "guide" over 100 new human beings - moving in and out of my classroom each day - though the most challenging period in their development.  However, this year, I feel nothing but anxiety and fear for me and my future students.

Instead of writing article after article about how to reopen schools, let's expend energy placing our collective IQ on creating Remote Learning models that are robust and innovative while addressing equity and access.  

Teachers, Silicon Valley, esteemed colleges of education, researchers, and other stakeholders should be moving full steam ahead with new Best Practices.    I am not just thinking of a curriculum package, but a rethinking of how we deliver a new system of education for the technological age.   That we found ourselves deep in a pandemic with no plan is baffling.  That we continue to not see this moment as an opportunity is baffling.

The decision to reopen should be contingent on the percent of infected people in the community.  When infection rates are high as in the U.S., schooling should not be in-person. Rates have to be brought down to the single digits first.

Nobody knows the long-term consequences of infection. The newest research suggests a possibility of lasting brain and other organ damage. As with the discovery of post-polio syndrome long after the original polio epidemic subsided, we cannot assess the long-term effects of Covid-19 infection on children and should not risk their well-being by putting them back in classrooms now.

Despite concerns raised by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), research shows that children are extremely resilient in the face of trauma and adversity when they have a secure attachment relationship with at least one parental figure. There is no reason to assume that another semester or two of distance learning will permanently damage children even though many will experience temporary setbacks academically and socially.

The notion that testing will be adequate is an illusion. The few reliable blood tests are not affordable. Other tests produce too many false positives. Screening based on temperature scans is even less valid. Accurate testing and contact tracing are not scalable yet.

We must take our collective heads out of the sand! Schools cannot be reopened safely until community rates are in the single digits or we have a vaccine.

As a teacher myself our school will say dont come in if you feel ill, but so many days I and many others have minor symptoms like a slightly runny nose, a little cough, a sore throat, or a sense of being under the weather. If we stayed home all those days we will be absent a lot.

Ideas:
1. Space: use gyms, to hold multiple same size as normal classes. Noise concern? Each class has their own headset and mic per student and teacher, only connected to their class. Maybe use cafeteria. 
2. Lunch- in classroom. Staff takes sandwich,fruit,drink cart from room to room
3. Space: use nearby empty office space and churches.
4. Need more faculty, assistant teachers, support staff : Furloughed college teachers and unemployed.
5. Class schedule: one course in morning, one in afternoon. Eg, on Monday, English in am, Study in pm, Tue - Math, Tech, Wed - History, elective, Thur - Science, elective, Fri - foreign language, elective. Reason- eliminate crowded movement between classes.
Cut electives, study if want to go with 4 days a week.
6.Space: Use freed up classrooms from gym/outside classes (office building, churches). Current classes now split between 2-3 additional freed up rooms.
Teacher teaches 1/2 students say for 2 hrs, goes to next room to teach rest of his class. First room now has assistant teacher/sub supervising. During first 2 hrs, assistant teacher/sub supervising other half of class. Purpose: spread out students,6 ft apart.
7.Funding: emergency from state, fed.
8.Crazy idea: high school classes in evening, using high school building and empty middle school, elementary buildings.  Middle school, elementary-normal daytime, use empty high school. Rational: high school kids less likely to need parents during day while at home, so parents can work.

There are a number of intuitive, although yet to be studied / verified, factors that make sense as to children being less susceptible and less likely to spread the virus.  Old enough to have strong lungs and immune system response, but young enough to have few other debilitating conditions like obesity, high blood pressure, heart disease, etc.  Smaller bodies, thus (maybe?) smaller absolute number of virus particles expelled?  Lots of studies now have pointed to time duration and concentration of aerosols etc from infected persons affecting others catching it from them.  Finally, most kids have been away from confined groups of other kids (no school, no daycare) for months now, so maybe way less chance during that time to catch it if the local “wave” of infection has passed them.  Will that change going into school classrooms?  Maybe or not - not in communities where cases are still rising, but maybe where stable it can work - IF adults will help and encourage their kids make the best of it to be able to rejoin their friends, instead of repeating over and over how it won’t till the kids don’t believe so either.  Adults, lead the way.

There is no perfect, risk free solution,  but keeping schools closed will have terrible socio-economic and health consequences. We need to respect the seriousness of CV-19, while making policy decisions that are risk and age stratified.  We know who is vulnerable to serious illness or death from covid. It is not children or otherwise healthy teachers. In Massachusetts, the survival rate for those under 60 is better than 99.95%. Of the reported covid deaths,  60% were over 80 years old, none were under 20. 65% of the fatalities were nursing home residents. There are very few teachers or staff in the 65-90 age bracket interacting with students. The vulnerable population should be isolated and accommodated  to minimize their risk.  Schoolchildren are not at risk of dying from covid, and otherwise healthy people under 55 are at practically no risk of dying from it either. I mean “not at risk” the same way I would mean I am not at risk of dying as I drive to work, or my child is not at risk of getting kidnapped on his way to school i.e., it is so unlikely that it doesn’t paralyze me into fearful inaction, but I do take reasonable safety precautions for both. We cannot continue online learning and await a vaccine or curative treatment which may never come. Even if Trump (hopefully) is defeated, the virus will be around for many months or years, and we as a society need to manage risk and live with the virus while schools and other essential parts of society function.

Why is no one talking about the negative psychological effects of re-opening school buildings, only to have to shut them down again?  Isn't it more harmful for children go to their physical school for a month or two, then switch to remote learning, then go back to the physical school, and switch to remote learning?  Children need consistency, but no one is talking about this.  Wouldn't a consistent semester of remote learning be LESS harmful than a continuously disrupted school experience?

They should wait and open the schools in January after the holidays. This virus isn't done with us yet. We didn't get off on a great start to begin with. We need more time. Another 6 months may be the smartest thing we can do for the kids and teachers.

Education needs to move online.  The US has not acted responsibly and we are now paying the price. In other parts of the world schools have been re-opened only once a community has demonstrated a decline in cases and even then,  they have moved with extreme caution.  

The reality is that we do not have COVID under control and therefore the only safe solution in many states is to make classes available online.  Focus on core subjects only, with electives being made voluntary.  If companies can function online, so can schools.  

And yes, it will require parents to ensure that their kids are actually doing the work.

Each state should meet specified levels of transmission and positive testing rates before reopening schools. That is just common sense.  Contact tracing programs should also be instituted based on number of cases, which many states have inexplicably not bothered with.

Offer hybrid systems whenever possible so families can decide individually to send in the kids or use on-line learning.  We should also give teachers the ability to teach remotely, with kids in school or home, and the teachers and lessons shown on monitors.  We cannot risk losing our teachers to this virus - that would be a disaster we must avoid at all cost.

another good example to look at is Austria! they also only gradually brought students back once the virus was more under control. but the key difference between Austria and many of the other countries listed is that they have a social saftey net watch which is absent in the entire US.

Sending kids back to school is a tragedy waiting to happen. The assumption is all schools have the resources to do it safely, which in a country of glaring inequality, they do not. For every well funded school that has the money for cleaning, disinfecting, proper PPE, classrooms in a well ventilated building with space for social distancing there is one in a poor community that has none of those things. Do we really want to see communities of color receive another blow when children start getting sick and bringing the virus home to their families?  There is no solid evidence it is safe to send kids back to school when there is widespread community transmission - the counties that have sent students back have their outbreaks under control, more widespread testing and universal healthcare. That’s not our reality. We are nowhere near ready or competent enough and we should not be putting the health and safety of students, teachers and staff at risk.
I will not support keeping High Schools closed while allowing younger kids to return. It’s unfair and causes other problems even with 15-18 year olds.

I am a high school teacher in Western Australia where our schools, both public and private have never shut down nor seriously practiced social distancing [an impossibility in a school setting]. My average day in my school is currently no different than it was this time last year. So far there have been zero school transmissions in a state of 2 million people. Yes, I understand that our state has had the good fortune of largely avoiding widespread community infection but anecdotally it would it seem that schools are not greatly affected by the virus and opening them is worth the risk as the alternative of keeping them closed will produce other far greater harms.

Here in Finland, the kindergaten have been open during the epidemic. We opened schools two weeks before summer holiday in contrary to teachers tough resistance. Nothing bad happened. We see now max. 20 new cases per day, so the situation is in great control. The best method to prevent the pandemic spread for us so far has been to strictly prohibit travelling from countries (even inside EU) that have daily more than 8 cases per 100 000 people. I'm afraid all other means to suppress the virus are useless if you don't isolate disease centers. To limit movements is the smallest sacrifice.
Children almost never get sick from the virus, and don't generally give it to adults around them.  So there is little reason not to reopen schools.

Teacher in Stockholm, the hardest hit part of Sweden. We never closed schools for kids below 16 years, and there hasn’t been any particular surge in teacher illnesses. It is not really possible to distance in school either.

It has been weird, but my job days were pretty much the same this spring as they usually are. I can’t say why, just that it seems to have worked to stay open.

Sad to say, but Always Larry is correct on all points, given our horrible response to the issue of safely getting kids back to school. This article mentions one sentence about smaller kids having more difficulty in following distancing guidelines than older kids. There is also no mention of these European countries now having reports of % of positive cases way below 1% now, and in many states here it's currently between 10 and 30%!
Any parent who pays attention can tell you that kids of all ages simply won't follow distancing guidelines and constant mask wearing for very long, unless physically restrained beyond levels that could be practically implemented at present in our schools.  younger kids don't comprehend the danger or have the impulse control, older kids have the same problems at different developmental levels. 
We're now placing much more emphasis on costs of losing a year of classroom learning over risking the  health  and in many cases the lives of everyone involved.

I understand that school may be the best place for some kids but that the danger to them and all teachers, support staff, and extended family at home may not be worth it. Instead of "what if, what if", why doesn't each school district take a serious survey of its students whose families are willing/need to have them return to the classroom. Hopefully, almost half will still opt for online classes and at least the school systems will know how to plan for at least the first half of the year while, hopefully, this country gets its act together as far as this virus goes.
No amount of ignoring it, or spinning it to political advantage, is going to change the facts on the ground.  Wake up, people, stop wringing your hands - find, and let, someone lead this initiative who has the best interests of all at heart and is not just politically motivated. There is a solution to be found, we just need to get the political hubris out of the way.

Within days of opening most of these schools will be shutting their doors and transitioning back to digital learning.  How will this reopening vary from that of the current? 

Who will build statues to the scores of dead children and teachers forced into this impending nightmare? Not to mention the tens of thousands who will become sick with their families and friends. As a teacher I am still holding out hope that people will wake up and really consider the big picture of what is about to happen across the country. 

Let's stay digital at least until the November election. 
Perhaps by spring they can forgive themselves.

This is a thought provoking and interesting article on one of the most divisive aspects of the COVID era. Unfortunately due to the incredibly different healthcare and educational  systems and government approaches to COVID and their consequences, I don’t think you can extrapolate the experience of Denmark or Ireland to the US. I am an American trained American doctor working in the Irish healthcare system and enjoy being a public servant. What I don’t enjoy is the constant refrain I see from teachers who say “doctors and nurses signed up for this, we did not.”  Doctors and nurses (or healthcare assistants, hospital cleaners etc) are not martyrs. We have families and children too, and want the best possible opportunities for their health and educational future, and none of us went into healthcare to orphan them.

"How to Reopen Schools: What Science and Other Countries Teach Us" - Science? It is a foreign word for Trump and trumpists that they do not comprehend. And, we are so darn "exceptional" that we cannot learn anything from other countries. The solution to open our schools safely and responsively is very clear from both of the above. We need MUCH more extensive testing and we need contact tracing which is pretty straightforward in a school environment. However, Trump, the "stable genius", is against both of these obvious measures. Opening the schools on Trump's whim without these measures will lead to thousands of unnecessary American deaths and Trump should be held personally responsible.

In the UK we have gradually reopened primary schools but are being more cautious with secondary (high) schools due to the way teenagers are taught. In primary school, children stay in one class with the same teacher all day. This is easier to manage by way of bubbles. Older children at secondaries change subject every hour, thereby changing building, changing teacher and accessing different, shared resources. This constant movement around the school makes it more challenging to maintain social distancing, cleanliness and to isolate a bubble we’re they to be an outbreak. How does this compare to American Hugh schools?

No one seems to be asking about the short and long-term effects of exposure to all of the disinfectants being sprayed around. What is in the disinfectants - given the hazmat suits being worn by the people doing the spraying, it must be pretty toxic. In poorly ventilated rooms being sprayed repeatedly, how much of it are children and staff inhaling, or consuming inadvertently?

I've been reading about summer camps having to close because of widespread outbreaks, so how does that fit into all of this. Camps are generally more in the out of doors than are schools, but children and staff are being infected. 

That said, if schools can open because kids don't generally get particularly sick and are poor transmitters, does it make sense to quarantine a whole class if one kid tests positive? I would think that especially for younger kids that kind of disruption, which might happen repeatedly in a school year, would be pretty destructive emotionally and academically.

We have leaders who are private school advocates wanting public schools open so the economy can recover. They are not interested in the health or well being of public school children.

We not only have a high infection rate, but we have forty percent of the country thinking that covid-19 is a democratic hoax that any acknowledgement of is  just an attempt to embarrass the President.

Haven’t you seen the people throwing a fit because they have been asked to wear a mask on the private property of grocery stores? Wouldn’t you believe these people would pass their views to their children? They would definitely think that they have total latitude on public property. There would be low compliance with mask wearing especially when it is pointed out it is for the protection of others not the mask wearer. 

We have also seen without schools being opened that people have attempted to weaponize the virus by intentionally coughing on people when they get upset. Not to mention the assaults happening when people are asked to follow  rules or guidelines. Again, these people will send their kids to school with the same attitude. 

If schools are opened in the fall, be prepared for the acrimony and daily grievances that will occur. The United States is a country like no other and we will see American exceptionalism on full display.

First of all gym classes  can be held outside until November . Parks  can also be used for exercise. 
Entire classes can run around the school block 
Stretching   Push-ups, sit ups , and nutrition can be taught online. All science and math classes can be taught online easily. I suggested this years ago. Why aren’t films made by the best teachers for  all 30 classes taught in junior high school and 30 classes taught  in high school and at any time a student can simply watch and learn . All summer long students could study on their own time. Stop restricting education by not simply videotaping instruction. Algebra   Geometry , trigonometry, ore on calculus or ore calculus . An be videotaped. Surprise junior high school students will learn these four years before they enter high school at their own pace of it was simply put online the same  is true for high school students. .

What’s going to happen is that parents will have to come up w their own plans and it’s likely going to widen the gulf between economic groups. For example, parents in one of our well off neighborhoods are thinking of hiring teachers to come teach small groups of kids similar to the homeschool model. A teacher friend of ours is considering that should schools not open here. Virtual school has been tough. She said out 30 of her kids she’s heard from 15, the rest only once or not at all. 
My kids are still very young, but I joked w her that I should get on her waiting list for when they’re older. 
Joking aside what do the folks who can’t hire their own teacher do for their kids?

The one dilemma of opening schools is the fact that children attending K-12 are ideal Petri dishes for COVID-19.  When this age group is infected, generally they may get a case of the sniffles or symptoms no worse than a bad cold.  This makes them ideal spreaders COVID-19.

Then there is always the general mindset of children that age, if all can remember back then, of rebellion and ignoring adults.  How many will take mask wearing seriously?  How many will really listen to things like social distancing?  Then there is the backlash of "no mask" parents if their children are disciplined for not wearing masks.

Look to Asia for some guidance. Yes, the Asian culture us more compliant than the US and they are far more community oriented. But they have open schools with social distancing and other safety measures. School is important for the proper socialization and education of future generations at each age-specific level. Missing a year will lead to a generation of slowed development. Not catastrophic, but not healthy either.

Why do children need to be sent back to school? Because parents  and educators have to go back to work. Why do they have to go back to work? Because we—in the richest nation on earth, with skyrocketing police and military budgets and abundant wealth funneled to the one percent— have decided we won't pay them enough to stay home and stay safe until the virus is under control. We have decided to prioritize keeping the economy running (to enrich the very few) over life itself. If this doesn't call for a revolution and a thorough rethinking of our priorities and fundamental principles, what does?

Let's not forget that the countries that have opened schools successfully also have universal health care and a social net. So if kids get sick they get care and their parents get time to take care of them or care themselves if they get sick. Will parents also have to factor in health care and "out of pocket" expenses plus pay cuts (or being fired) into their going back to school decisions?

The lack of a coordinated, data-driven effort by the Trump administration to thoroughly assess the safety of returning kids to school, from pre-kindergarten through college, is stunning.

School districts and universities are not equipped to fund nor carry through such an analysis.

Why has Trump passed the buck on this vital duty of the federal government?

It's wishful thinking, not Science, to look at a few results in a nice little country school in Denmark -- a country which successfully controlled the virus, and has universal healthcare and parental leave -- and make conclusions that will affect millions of people's lives.  The situation in the US is completely different, with our crowded urban schools with aging ventilation systems, rural schools with long bus rides, lack of universal healthcare, and a population encouraged by its president to flout the rules and ignore the risks, all in an uncontrolled and still surging pandemic. "Data from around the world" does not tell us how to open US schools safely.

Anyone citing low fatality rates without accounting for the lung, heart, and brain damage being found in people of all ages who "recover" from "asymptomatic" cases is playing an important propaganda role to shield and deflect from folks who have minimized this public health issue from the start.

It seems we have become the world power we always wanted to be -- just not in the way we might have hoped or intended. Come to find out we are as good or better at bamboozling our own people as any authoritarian government, after all. 

Curiously, other countries seem largely immune to what works on Americans.

Somehow, in the rush to re-open and in our present inward focus, the travel bans recently imposed on us haven't caught more attention. Apparently, just one more symptom of the low-information pandemic.

This article is filled with information that families, communities, and leaders can use to prepare mentally for what happens next. Community spread is a critical, if not the most important, factor to study. 

Hope this knowledge can spread faster than the virus, but the first four months suggest otherwise.

It's wishful thinking, not Science, to look at a few results in a nice little country school in Denmark -- a country which successfully controlled the virus, and has universal healthcare and parental leave -- and make conclusions that will affect millions of people's lives.  The situation in the US is completely different, with our crowded urban schools with aging ventilation systems, rural schools with long bus rides, lack of universal healthcare, and a population encouraged by its president to flout the rules and ignore the risks, all in an uncontrolled and still surging pandemic. "Data from around the world" does not tell us how to open US schools safely.

Monday/ Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday format should be implemented for classes.Everyone would be off on Fridays.

Temperature checks and testing needs to be widely available. Masks worn indoors always. PPE provided to teacher upon request. If weather permits, teach in designated spaces outdoors.

We can’t open schools on the cheap and we can’t open them like there is no virus. 

P.s. :Has Kawasaki syndrome only been identified in New York?

Honestly Given the circumstances I'm already immensely gratefull and relieved that my husband's NYC college, after weeks of announcing that fall would be business as usual, let teachers choose wether to teach in person or not.

The social aspect of schooling is the primary benefit of collective synchronized education, otherwise custom student centered education works (home schooling, private schools), think Sir Ken Robinson. Many schools put kids in front of computers and feed them stored customized content for part of the day.
Of course, schools also serve the purpose of state sponsored daycare, so employers can keep the shareholders happy.  As always, it is risk/reward...the trick is to have the people who take the risk get the reward.

I was at the doctor's office having some tests done.  I was there about 6 hours, wearing a mask the whole time.
I was never so happy as when I could safely remove my mask in my car.
I really doubt small children (and even rebellious teens could wear a mask all day.  
It is difficult to talk through a mask (or should I say be heard through a mask.)
I have 8 cloth masks.  Only 2 of them are tight.  The others have air pockets and sometimes fall off.
Distancing?  With young children and adolescents?  For 6 hours?  Forget it.    Look at the picture.  So much for social distancing.  
The United States IS NOT Denmark or Norway.  They successfully contained the virus by community effort.  Look at all the people in the United States that refuse to wear masks and practice social distancing.  
And 10 students in a classroom?  Thirty students are in a classroom where I live.  That means each school would need 3 times the classrooms they currently have.  And 3 times the teachers.

If we are really serious about getting kids back to school, we need to go back to shelter in place until September. I have seen people out in the malls as if there is no pandemic. All of this "economic" activity will have us back where we started just in time for back to school. We need to crush viral spread as much as possible in order to go back safely. But as usual the almighty dollar is more important than human life, so it's off to the malls we go.

One problem lies in cramming lots of children into small areas, taught by people who commute.  Why not try to something like the one-room schoolhouse of the past, where kids in a neighbourhood are taught by someone in that neighbourhood?  

My guess is that every block in every small town has someone who would be happy and reasonably qualified to do this.  In a city, every apartment building likely has several people who could help.

No, this would not be the same as the big school, with a gymnasium and a pretty library down the hall from well-equipped classrooms and teachers who are keeping abreast of the latest theories of teaching. But it would be some form of education (a form that worked well for generations in rural areas), it would allow parents to work, and it would put up firewalls against virus spread.  Oh, and it would be wonderful for this new group of community-based teachers, who will realize what  a joy it can be, to teach, to inspire, and just to look after, the children of your neighbours.

I’ve open our schools when a state has a reduced replication rate, after we have a stable and low number of new cases per day. Otherwise the question isn’t when to open schools but what to do with infected children and teachers.

Another point omitted in this article is that teachers generally do not need to come closer than 6 feet to students, except in early childhood. Considering that children in general are not at great risk from the virus, it would seem logical to focus on keeping teachers socially distant from students, and not waste effort on impossible and likely useless goals such as preventing student to student contact in play, and sanitizing surfaces, despite much evidence that this is not the way the virus is being transmitted.
It's inevitable that with such high numbers of students co-mingling, the number of Covid cases will increase dramatically.  as is the case with young party goers.  Schools are the bars for children.

I can speak to transmission amongst teenagers from experience. I’m a high school teacher at a public school one block from Union Square in NYC, which in many ways is considered the center of the city as the Union Square subway station is a nexus of most of the subway lines that run across the five boroughs. I started to experience  COVID-19 two days after the last day that students and staff held in-person school back in March. However, unless weather is really bad, I bike to school every day - so I hadn’t ridden the subway in well over two weeks. That first week that NYC schools were shut down, I was tested and got a positive result while my wife’s test came back negative - and she had been working from home for over a week at that point anyway. So the only vectors that made sense for where I might have contracted it are school or the grocery store.  But in the two weeks leading up to when I contracted symptoms, I spent 8 -10 hours at day at my school building while spending at most 1 hour total I’m the grocery store. I know of two of my students were sick with something in that week leading up to the shutdown. Given my experience, I’m fairly confident high school students can transmit the disease.

The basic argument in this article is "Keeping schools closed for a prolonged stretch has worrisome implications for social and academic development, child development experts say. It also became evident this spring that denying children a real school day deepened racial and economic inequalities.

“There is really damage to kids if they don’t go to school,” Dr. Edwards said. “I think we have got to think of the kids and getting them back to school safely.”

Please share the  evidence that not going to school " deepened racial and economic inequalities". Also, the authors assume that all school experiences are the same. They are not. Haven't we been repeatedly reminded that there are effective and ineffective schools? 
Economic status, expectations, the parent's educational level, parental involvement, and the effective school instructional, and a safe learning environment are just some important factors leading to a child's school success. 
Some might point out that  children must attend school first and then these factors can be considered. Perhaps, one can also assume that schools can have a deleterious effect on children as well. 
BTW--  So , what happens when some children get ill from the virus? Well , we can just tell the parent's that we read an article in the NYT which essentally argued for their return. That should provide the parent's with a great deal of comfort.

For what it’s worth, here in Melbourne Australia we opened schools a month ago after getting the virus under control. We’re now right in the middle of a second wave in the middle of winter with daily case rates higher than they have been since April. Don’t do it!

Why aren't you doing research without being so Eurocentric? Show how countries in Asia (Malaysia, Taiwan), Uruguay in South America, or New Zealand are dealing with schools reopening successfully, while also having much lower tr rates compared to EU. There is no possible way we can reopen schools in urban centers or places where tr rates (virus reproduction rate or spread of transmission) are so high. All these countries have one thing in common besides low Covid infections, kids and adults alike wear masks. We could only dream to reach their low levels of infection. They also have governments that enacted national plans, universal healthcare, and scientific based approach to the pandemic (interdisciplinary teams), something we lacked from the start.

BTW --   from the NYT on July 7,2020

"An overnight summer camp in rural southwestern Missouri has seen scores of campers, counselors and staff infected with the coronavirus, the local health department revealed this week, raising questions about the ability to keep kids safe at what is a rite of childhood for many.

Missouri is one of several states to report outbreaks at summer camps. The Kanakuk camp near Branson ended up sending its teenage campers home. On Friday, the local health department announced 49 positive cases of the COVID-19 virus at the camp. By Monday, the number had jumped to 82."

It's possible to re-open schools in the fall, not completely safely, but with a lower level of risk. You need a lot of testing: everyone on admission and then those showing symptoms or who have been exposed Unfortunately we don't have that many tests available. From when this virus first appeared President Trump has taken tests to limit testing.  Kids have to mask at school and on the bus - so the schools are going to have to buy a lot of masks. In late APRIL, months after Covid-19 arrived in our country, my wife and I donated two N-95 masks we had to the local hospital. The Emergency Department nurses who got them, one of whom was assisting in surgery that afternoon, thanked us. They had had to wear cheap paper masks or homemade bandannas, not even changing between patients. And you have to have as much social distancing as possible. That means much smaller class sizes - not averaging over thirty kids like in some Republican states, but a maximum of ten to fifteen. You have to more than double the number of teachers, and hire some people to monitor the halls, cafeterias and playgrounds. You have to add temporary classrooms. When I was in high school double wide trailers were leased. This will cost trillions. But Trump, DeVos, and most Republicans in Congress want to reduce money spent on public schools. To them, the safety of children (and the people the children come in contact with) isn't worth paying for.

The rush to return children to school is in part the reasons cited by Pediatric Assoc. 

What really drivers this train wreck of a decision is the pool of employees needed to reopen businesses. These empty buildings cost money which continue to create red ink. This is  preventing companies from servicing their debt leading to defaults that reverberates through the financial system. Those who are Parents can't return to work leaving their children unattended and the below par average income of this much needed work force can't afford childcare. 

Reopening schools as the spread of Covid-19  has yet to be tamed is playing the game of Russian Roulette with all lives. We continue to make decisions with a multitude of unanswered questions and/or the validation of what we belive we already know. As this frightening journey continues the nuances of this virus are beginning to surface. 

The action plan to safely open classrooms is sound on paper but I fear the continuity will not be successful.  Additionally, it is impossible to monitor the behavior of a students family. 

This deadly pandemic we are living is in it's infancy. This rush to reopen our schools is a dangerous experiment placing our youth, all those that interact with them and the lives of our most important commodity, our educators in harm's way.  My 3 children are grown and my hearts stops for all those who have no choice.

Here we go again - "virus raging in America!'.  Raging where?  Absolutely everywhere?  In many parts of the country it's at levels comparable with those in the European countries quoted in the article.  The decision to reopen schools must be done district-by-district, with those districts where the virus is at the level of, say, Stockholm, being allowed to reopen fully and without restrictions.  

The lesson from the lockdown that was unneccessary imposed everywhere  and caused both so much unnecessary suffing and a backlash should have been to quit painting the entire huge country with a broad brush.

We can do this only with a huge influx of cash and the hiring of more staff, replacement of air circulation systems, higher pay and life insurance plans for teachers, smaller class sizes and testing on site. We live in the US so in most states this won’t happen, but this is the only way to open schools.

In the picture where nursing students showed first graders at Ethel Phillips Elementary School in Sacramento how to properly wash their hands, what happened to social distancing? The kids are sitting right next to one another!

This is what is wrong with reopening schools. It will spread the virus from child to child, and child to teacher, giving the virus a chance to spread like crazy. 

Until a vaccine is ready, have the children learn at home. Give parents an infusion of cash to have one of them stay home with their child, or to hire someone to be with the children during the day. 

Keep libraries closed as well. The virus can live on books for at least 3 days. Libraries will spread the virus if they are reopened.

After the disasters in Florida, Arizona, Texas and other southern states,  does one really believe that school openings will be managed any better than the re-openings by the governors of these states?

Virtual education is better than no education but brick and mortar classroom education in these times will mean more deaths. Deaths of children, of the teachers and other support staff.

There will not be a consensus on this and localities (at state, city, county level) will reach different conclusions based on medical (transmission rates), economic considerations of parents and communities, political pressure from both sides etc. Individual parents will have their own priorities and teachers as well. Like so many other issues with Covid it seems more is unknown than known. It looks generations to fully understand and treat tuberculosis and the development of a vaccine for polio was decades in coming. There is no vaccine for HIV and not for lack of trying but life did and will go on.

I’ve done the cost benefit analysis. 

I understand life has risks and you cannot mitigate them all. 

I have understood that if I want to send my kid to school, especially given where I live, I will have to accept and work on the assumption that some of the kids’ parents still believe believe it’s a hoax. 
They will not wear masks or socially distance outside of school and they won’t think twice before sending their kids to school with the sniffles. 

I would’ve maybe been willing to risk it, for my child’s mental health.

But ONLY if I knew for certain that when the inevitable outbreak happens, I or a teacher or a member of staff or a child or ANYONE who is feeling sick can get get a rapid test and result with no problem.

When I no longer have to worry about getting a hospital bed, a ventilator, or just basic medical supplies that no first world nation should be running out of yet again nearly six months into a pandemic. 

A massive infusion of cash into education and healthcare 3-4 months ago and we could’ve been on our way to a partial reopening. Money, going to the right places, that’s all it would’ve taken. 

The opening schools experiment will fail within a month of opening, with yet more unnecessary misery and death. You can’t go on foolishly living first-world lives in a third-world nation. 
Brace yourselves, America. There’s a terrible moon rising.

The decision to open  schools should be related to the community of such schools  I teach in a diverse, low income school..Our students need to be in school.  However, The concern is how to do this safely.  I am surprised at the lack of creative thought being reflected in some of the plans i am seeing. It seems like it is either stay home or come back full time with little social distancing and masks are optional.  why not change the schedule so kids are in smaller groups and meet for shorter periods?  how about older kids go to school fewer days and in staggered groups?  Given our current rise in cases and the increase in cases for 20-40s, it seems to me that we need to put in some more thought before mandating a return.  one size fits all is not going to work!

It is irresponsible to compare the US to countries with citizens who understand basic principles of science, comply with national mandates (i.e.,wearing masks), have routine testing, access to universal healthcare, paid parental leave, etc. In 27 yrs of working in schools, I have yet to see classrooms or buildings being cleaned well. Basic things like door knobs are never wiped or disinfected. Supplies like soap, tissues, and wipes are in short supply and teachers often spend their own money to supplement and/or ask families to donate materials. What teachers are being asked to do in the face of re-opening schools in the fall is ridiculous. The attention to social distancing, not sharing class materials and maintaining a clean classroom environment, is going to make the task of teaching even harder. Will anyone be checking every staff and student's temperature at the door each morning? How will proper ventilation be addressed? Windows can stay open now - if they aren't locked shut - but what about the winter? If we are so desperate to send kids and school staff back, why are we at least not considering the better model of the 4 days on/10 days off plan? Half days or kids coming in every other day will do nothing to keep transmission rates down if there are outbreaks because you will still have the entire school population infected. In addition to lacking a national CV19 plan, we desperately need a national science curriculum. You can't put the economy over public health.

It all comes down to leadership. And unfortunately, in the USA, we have none.  No matter what plan is devised it will be ridiculed by those who think they know better. How can you plan to send children back to school under very tight safety policies when 40% of the adults out there, following the lead of their President feel it is a waste of time and will resist and misinform. What some of the other countries have going for it, as it appears, is that most people are on the same page, are supporting the plan and have leaders who don't politicize  the issue.
One cannot know if social distancing was more effective than closing schools since the schools have not yet reopened.  It is an fraught assumption.

Per the UW report linked in the article, the following countries are not requiring that students wear face masks in schools: Denmark, Germany (if tested negative), New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland. Most of the Asian countries in the list, however, are requiring face masks. Apparently, wearing masks in schools to reduce viral spread is a cultural, rather than empirically-supported practice. The problem with our plans for re-opening schools is that we have made wearing masks the linchpin, it is not. I support mask requirements as a symbol of acknowledgement that the virus is real, highly communicable, and deadly. But I'm not going within 20 feet of a known covid-positive person, regardless of whether we're both wearing hand-sewn masks. This is what we'll be asking teachers do this fall?! There is scant evidence that wearing a cloth mask without eye protection prevents transmission in situations of prolonged indoor exposure. Look at the constant outbreaks in nursing homes from staff-resident transmission. Yet some bizarre consensus has emerged around the unfounded belief that if we only wore masks we could re-open things while containing the virus. A national mask mandate and widespread testing regime back in March would have been sound policy, now it's magical thinking. It's simply too late. Re-opening public K-12 schools and universities in this country is an exercise in herd immunity by Russian roulette.

We need to get creative and treat this like the emergency it is. 

If this was a tornado, we'd be reusing spaces like churches, warehouses, libraries, offices, etc as spaces to house homeless, wounded, and supplies. (Or look at WWII as example of the country coming together to supply the troops.)

Why not work with institutions like that to create separate pods of small classroom size? Keep teachers virtual, beam them to the smaller classes, and employ the unemployed(with considerable backround check) to be class assistants/chaperones to help keep kids on task and ensure cdc guidelines are followed. 

If some families can keep kids home, they can follow along virtually. 

Use emergency federal or state funds to cover the cost. Many of these places are/should be closed currently in places that are dealing with high numbers.

Considering the extensive safety measures needed and the risks associated with reopening the schools, will parents be willing to send their children, will children and teachers be willing to attend? There will surely be infections reported in schools and they will be widely reported - how will this affect the experiment? Children will be fearful, perhaps traumatized, they will refuse to go.  Those who are motivated by the economic benefits of reopening, and there are many in that category, including the Trump administration, will push for this, they will be distrusted by those who are asked to take the risk of sending their children back into the public school system.

This  will not work until the virus is defeated. With no vaccine  the virus will be defeated only with another total rigidly- enforced lock down.

This is a good article bringing together the available scientific evidence about the effects of reopening schools on transmission. 

It would have been very useful to include the pre-requisites for reopening schools as used by some of the countries mentioned in this article. For example: 
1) a signficantly low and decreasing 14-day incident rate (e.g. < 50 positives / 100,000 people)
2) a swift and robust local monitoring & intervention infrastructure (testing, tracing, isolation practices...)
3) hygiene plan to minimize transmission (distance, ventilation, masking (if necessary), cleaning, groups, ...)
4) physical infrastructure to implement specified hygiene plan
...
And the ask which states actually could fulfill these requirements. How much funding is required to make it happen?

I have been watching a sort of floor show out in the parking lot of the medical building where I work. A doctor will come out, in full PPE, and do a young child's exam from the car. In one case, they popped open the trunk, placed the sick infant in there and did the exam from the trunk.  

Parents and children are waiting in cars to go in for well exams. 

So I have to ask, if this is the way pediatrician's offices are managing, how on earth can the AAP recommend schools open? They are not allowing 15 or more kids in their waiting rooms, for even a few minutes, let alone hours. And they are suited up as if on a moon mission.

Education is important; it is critical. I am the child of a university professor and an English teacher. I grew up in a town in which education was the driver or our community.

But if we are still wearing PPE when a child sprouts a fever, we have not figured out safe management of larger groups of children.

A major problem with reopening schools, which this article does not address, is funding.  Many school districts lack the financial resources to purchase sufficient sanitizers and PPE.  The HVAC systems in many school districts are antiquated and lack sufficient filtration.    Add to this the problem of keeping school buses clean.    Meanwhile,  the primary source of funding, at least in Connecticut where I live, is property taxes,  which is not a flexible source of revenue.  Without centralized well planned funding assistance,  reopening schools safely will be an impossibility.
Children bring diseases home from school. Reopening schools is not a way to control  the spread of the virus. It will cost the lives of some parents and grandparents. It is not a good idea.

America, make the investment. Select 5-10 schools in areas with the very lowest per capita infection at present rates, open smartly with masks distances, soap everywhere and then test kids weekly and follow communities very closely. Test parents and teachers weekly as well. If this works, try the second to best per capita spots and do the same, repeat and advance only if no bump in cases. But either you test 1000-10,000 times more frequently than now or you open and our world crashes down again. In essence, our only way out of this is testing like it’s never been built before.

Most other countries have universal Health Care of some type, non-sociopathic leaders that actually care about the citizens, stable and consistent availability of PPE, educated specialists who are allowed to make decisions of import. The old USA was in very bad shape before this disaster, now the old USA is burned toast. It's not coming back, and we are going to see chaos and pain continue in education and everywhere else until trump and company are removed. If they ever are.

This article follows and attempts to support the editorial board’s recent insistence schools must open. 

But in reality we’re woefully unprepared to do so. We should be asking ourselves what problems do six to eight months of delay really present? (Plenty of time to have vaccines and treatments, or not).

But we already know the bulk of transmissions happen in households. Sending kids into ill prepared schools is almost guaranteeing perpetual infections and is essentially the opposite of any recommended prescription of social distancing. 

For six months of school we could recapture in two summers?

The answer to bringing back students is the same as the answer to bring back the economy: you have to attack the pandemic FIRST. If the spread of the virus increases, both schools and the economy will suffer. Period. Full stop. Sure, you can try to rationalize away how we can possibly do both using faulty logic but the virus doesn’t care about your opinions. It doesn’t care if you think it is a hoax, or created by ANTIFA or QANON or the deep state. 

The question now is: has the USA gone beyond the point so that now recovery is going to be really painful in lost lives, lost income, and very expensive solutions to repair what we destroyed? Were   politicians really the best minds to make these decisions especially those politicians that Evidence says no, but there also seems to be a large part of our society that shares their perspective. Snowflakes who refuse to wear masks for whatever reason. We needed educated adults to guide us in the means to reduce and deflect, what we got was COVIDiots.

While the need to bring back students is greatest because parents want to do something else, the rationalization is that children are less susceptible to the virus, they need human interaction for mental health, etc. What happens when all of the teachers get sick and there is no backup? We will be back to square one. 

So the way to get around this is to focus on reducing the viral spread. All energies should be on doing this now.

Having half the number of students come at one time is unlikely to allow for any kind of social distancing. Kids are much less than three feet apart in a normal school day. 

Will they line up 6 ft apart and get temperature checks? Who will do the temperature checks? How long will it take for 1,000 students to enter a building like this? 

What about cafeterias? Most serve lunch from 10-2 because of difficult schedules already, and the kids sit with elbows bumping anyway. So, cutting the number of students in half might allow them to sit 3 feet apart, talking and eating in a badly ventilated cafeteria. 

Has any school in America figured out how to do this? I call on Betsy Devos to show us one typical American elementary, middle, and high school that has a functional plan to open according to CDC guidelines.

This is a time of great fear and sorrow, and will no doubt impact this generation of children, perhaps in ways we can't even yet foresee. But we shouldn't blame schools for this, or expect schools to be the panacea that will make life normal again. I think that might be the underlying agenda here: a totally unrealistic hope that if we can just open schools, the kids will be okay. But we're living through a pandemic. And we're not okay.

Considering the US track record to date, school reopening will be a disaster.

1) We have national anti-leadership and a Party that has become a death cult.
2) We have a significant fraction of the population that rejects science and doesn’t understand it.
3) Decades of demagoguery about public spending have made it politically near-impossible to invest in anything like the levels needed.
4) Right wing media has been spreading disinformation about the pandemic since day one, and continues to do so.

This one gets at the root problem of why America is doing so badly.

5) As long as the oligarchs responsible for so much of the above don’t feel personally threatened by the pandemic, they will continue to undermine efforts to deal effectively with the pandemic. Unless the economy crashes and stays crashed, unless the super-rich feel our pain, they will resist anything that threatens their grip on our government. 

The fact that the rich have been getting richer during all this is a stark indicator of how they have rigged everything to their benefit, no matter what.
If kids going to school is important to the economy, wouldn’t we see those “negative“ effects every summer? Or during any extended school break?

It is time to face up to the facts  The US effort to fight the virus has been a monumental failure. No country in the world has been as ineffective as the US. There can be no return to anything close to normal until the virus is defeated.

It is easy to blame Trump, and certainly he deserves a big share of the blame, but so do many others, governors and other public officials, and  a large segment of the general population. It is the more disciplined societies that have succeeded, societies that trust and obey their governments, societies with a greater shared concern for their fellow citizens.

Is the US capable of winning this battle. Is there a leader who could unify the country to the degree necessary to win it?  Certainly  it is not Trump. Hillary could not have done it.  Is it Biden? Could Obama have done it?

The notion that children under twelve do not readily spread viruses which is promulgated by the Association of American pediatrics in this article, sounds to this retired teacher like a group of physicians who never spent any time in a public school. Schools are petrie dishes of viruses as anyone who has taught knows. Every fall and winter I patiently awaited the bronchitis  that would eventually enter my lungs and hang on for a couple of weeks. And I was/am a very healthy individual. Working in a school loaded with children exposes anyone to an array of illnesses that pass rapid fire among the population. Adding a COVID to the mix is a serious and imminent danger to anyone in that environment. Dismissing the risk is foolhardy and irresponsible.

Teacher-centered instruction will be the model to follow, if schools reopen. Is that what we want? The student-centered activities will be limited because of wearing masks and social distance. How is a student in the back of the classroom going to hear well a teacher who is wearing a mask? How can a teacher work  with a student who is having difficulty understanding directions when the student is 6 feet apart? Will students be able to break in groups and practice a conversation in a French 2 class in high school when they are six feet apart and the rest of the class is doing the same speaking aloud because they are six feet apart? We should compile a list of possible school scenarios when the premises for a safe environment will fall apart.

A little hindsight is worth raising here:  When the final study is written, it will include how Mayor de Blasio's delay in closing the the NYC public schools in March -- which he resisted in large part due to its perceived impact on working parents -- contributed significantly to the major outbreak that followed in NYC.
My child will not be attending school until I feel a coherent strategy for mitigation has been put in place. This has not happened yet.

As a teacher with 30 years in the ranks who adores her students, loves school more than anyone has a right to, and desperately wants to be back in my class, I have some say in this. As one who warned here in January that this would be a pandemic, that it would kill many and that the US would have the worst death and infection rate in the world (and I was told by fellow readers I was "crazy," an "alarmist,"  and a "hysteric") my critical thinking has been on target. As one, who has read obsessively about COVID and examined how other countries have dealt with it, I feel confident in saying this:

There is no safe way to open US schools. Period. 

All of the ideas being bandied about have great merit to them and should become the new normal. We DO need smaller classes, more fresh air, more teachers, better sanitary protocols. We also need a year, at minimum, to implement them and billions of dollars. Do journalists grasp that some schools open in a matter of weeks, not months? That many can't afford books much less PPE?

Lacking time and money, we must segue to enhancing and improving online learning. The countries that have the luxury of opening are the ones that took this pandemic seriously and did everything in their power to bend the curve. We didn't. We've put ourselves in a dire place.

 Are we really going to double down on that failure and send our children into harm's way? If so, I'm ready to bail on this country because that's not just benighted; it's indefensible.

I’m a physician and epidemiologist.  What is needed to get schools open for kids is more knowledge about exactly who is infected at an early stage or asymptomatically so they can be quickly isolated. Thus, what is needed is constant testing of every student and staff member in the schools twice weekly. 

An infected individual will begin to shed virus themselves after about 72 hours, thus testing everyone Mondays and Thursdays will catch most cases. But what about funding you say? Imagine if the US government asked private citizens to pay for building bombers in WW II; we’d all be speaking German today. Testing for COVID is the current equivalent. The federal government needs to simply pay, through deficit spending because it will be as expensive as a world war effort, for COVID testing of every person inside every school building in the country twice a week. Once we have this on-going monitoring system in place, we can safely design plans for kids to return to school. Without it we’re just guessing - and look how well that’s worked out here in the US so far!

I am disappointed by the lack of science in this paragraph:

In Austin, for example, which like cities in Florida and Arizona has seen a recent acceleration in new cases, the estimated infection rate now is about seven per 1,000 residents. That means a school with 500 students would have about four carrying the coronavirus.

Actually, that rate the is the prevalence (how many infected since the start) not the incidence (currently infected). Not sure what the incidence of "currently contagious" is since no one is clear how long that phase of illness lasts - likely shorter for kids. Also the rate is very different by age group. I doubt the rate is 7/1000 in children - more likely 0.7. And when people are infected, at least some have symptoms, and they won't go to school - screening would keep them out and hopefully so would common sense and common decency. So - the school won't "have 4 students" to isolate. More likely 0.07 students which is just a little less than one student in one school out of 100 similar schools. And that student may or may not be able to transmit to adults especially with safety procedures in place. So for that student's teacher's sake, we will consider keeping 50,000 (500/school x 100) students home indefinitely? 

Math can be boring and corona is definitely scary, but it's important to be accurate about both.

Since school classrooms do not accommodate six foot distancing between students and school ventilation systems are not designed to protect students from corona virus why not erect large temporary structures (e.g., tents without sides and/or with roof fans) on school athletic fields)?

This looks like a true generational battle between what is best for children and why is best for adult school employees.    We don’t have any data on the best way to learn outside of what we have done throughout human history - in person structured instruction which combines visual, verbal and physical cues.

It is definitely at shame that the US did not have a consistent approach to locking down. However, now is the chance for some consistency, while reopening schools that will give pupils and staff confidence, utilising lessons learned elsewhere. Opening schools is positive for so many reasons:
1) Their well-being overall - especially for those disadvantaged (providing safety and guidance, nutrition and dependability, especially where home life may not offer these elements).
2) Education matters and most educators agree that home learning is not as productive as learning in a community environment or context (school community/ classroom setting).
3) Mental health benefits (obvious)
4) Getting kids off the streets where they are already mingling, but in a less hospitable environment often.

I think most people here agree that opening schools is a bad idea until we get the pandemic under control.  It's been cathartic to voice our fears. The reality is that schools are going to open before we're ready. Most teachers are going to have to go back to the classroom. We have little to no say in the model our districts choose. The discussion needs to turn to what can be done to minimize the exposure risk.  We all know that schools aren't sanitary places and the cleanings will fall off after a short period of time. People get complacent. What do I personally need to do to protect myself and others? Should I wear a hazmat suit everyday?  If so, where do I get one?

Districts are not being honest with themselves or with parents.   Teachers will not feel safe enough to return.  They have every right to protect themselves.  They aren't going back.   So if we start from there, districts should be examining best practices for distance learning and engagement.  They need to find ways to be more creative and more effective.   The transition to online education was poor in most cases.  And parents struggled trying to teach kids and keep their jobs.   Along with this, there does need to be some type of safe way to bring in those kids whose parents have no choice but to be at work.  Districts should be frantically working on these goals right now.   Instead they are wasting time on these hybrid fantasies that teachers will not agree to.

There is an elephant in the re-opening room. If she could speak she would tell us that none of these plans can achieve any of the intended goals. Parents will be unable to resume regular work schedules and the covid safety protocols offer few improvements over remote instruction - for kids or teachers. And, the inevitable closures that will soon follow will make all the effort and expense to re-open an exercise in futility.

We are "all in this together". Really? Where have we heard this before? We are all equal. Yes, but some are just more equal.

The reality is that COVID19 is the great equalizer. It does care about differences in wealth, race, education, ethnicity, or political party. If we allow any difference to determine who gets something and who doesn't, we all potentially could suffer.

The reality is that those who are left behind can have unintended consequences for those of us that are privileged. Basic rights can no longer be ignored. 

Too expensive? How is the depression going for you?

The precautions schools required to take are way out of proportion to the risk to people under age 18.  All the US schools and CDC need to do is look to European countries for a great model on this.  But, like so much of what the CDC recommends, the recommendations are way off.  

We need to reform the CDC.  Look how badly they have performed throughout the Pandemic!

Most of the thinking about reopening is centered around the pre-covid model with modifications. Move the desks farther apart; stagger the days students go to the school; rigorous screening. Certainly that is necessary.

However, what is needed is a new (or perhaps old) model of education. The problem is that any venue where large numbers of individuals are indoors and in close contact with one another is very problematic for creating a localized epidemic.  

The temporary solution may be to resurrect the one room school house. Educating children in small groups isolated from one another will prevent at least the explosive spread of Covid that is possible in large schools.

Is that possible? Under certain circumstances, challenging but doable! As businesses have closed, there is an abundance of empty space. An important function of any school is to provide appropriate nutrition. The devastated restaurant industry could easily deliver student meals which would help that industry as well. Many supplies such as desks could be moved out of our present schools. Such as system might require far more teachers. Our society has laid off many teachers for tax reasons. The 40 million recently unemployed certainly includes a large number of teachers. This model works best for elementary and middle schools where a single teacher can remain with a single group throughout the day.  For higher levels, small supervised group on line education could also keep students in a school setting.

This may or may not be true, but my understanding in countries like Germany, students do not leave their classrooms. It's the teachers who move to each place, which will obviously stop potential transmission of the virus. Secondly, students are in school for shorter hours, but are given lots of homework to do outside of school to complete. All of this flies in the face of the American system. Germany also weeds students out at about age 12 to see what track they will put on, university track or vocational. This fundamentally changes the environment for most high school and middle school level children.

“There is really damage to kids if they don’t go to school,” Dr. Edwards said. “I think we have got to think of the kids and getting them back to school safely.” What will safely cost? Retrofitting schools ventilation and air purification must be first. Rebreathing air in a classroom will do far more harm than the damage from not attending school. The scent of perfume in a classroom tells us that airborne virus will infect.

Teachers must refuse to work in unsafe conditions. I want them all to survive this pandemic. There are possible solutions, clear physical barriers and micro phones, updated air handlers, increasing staff to lower class size,  but they all cost money that school districts don't have to spend. Absent the implementation of a plan that offers safety to all staff there will be more virus surges, deaths, and possible and permanent disability that has affected those who recover if school reopen. There are far too many unknowns. Teachers have been front line workers in this country's entrenched school funding inequality scheme, they must not enter ckassroom without proper infastrurcture to limit viral spread, but that will take funding local districts don't have.

In every article I've read on this, no-one addresses transportation. We live in a regional school district with both  academic and vocational high schools. The academic high school is in a neighboring town which is up to 15 miles away for some students. Our town is rural, virtually no elementary students walk to school. The vocational school serves nine towns, some students live 25 miles away! There is no money in town budgets for additional busing. How do these children travel back and forth to school in a safe environment? Why does no-one address this complex issue that won't be solved with simplistic solutions or, worse yet, by ignoring the elephant in the room completely.

When I  read my district's back to school plan where I work and my children attend a couple days ago, I began to go through the stages of grief. I visited a charter school which is planning to open fully with one of my children. The principal was so nice and had 3 children at the school. She is now begging me to go back to school shopping all the time for her new school. I have to remind her that school will not start for month and a half. I am also preparing her for the possibility that even this school may be closed. She is done with summer break that has been going since March. Those of us who work in schools and have children in schools are willing to do what it takes and risk our health a small amount for school to open.  Children need school for academics and socializing. Parents want school open for their children's wellbeing and their own. I  have an underlying health condition, high blood pressure from pre eclampsia that never went away. This pandemic has really shown to me more clearly than ever that it does take a village to raise a child. It would be much more feasible for my 12 year old to do online school than my younger children. Let's at the least open for them, since they seem not to transmit the virus at a high rate. Let's use federal stimulus money to help make it safe. Just a perspective from someone highly affected from schools being closed.

My three grade school children will not be returning to school this Fall.  My wife and I after consulting with school officials as well as several experts including a virologist have decided not to take the chance this Fall, and instead will take a wait and see approach.

Our decision came down to the schools telling us that while they are going to make the schools safer, they hesitated to say that the schools will be safe, and then added that we will not know if the schools are safe until probably November - December when we see how the children are fairing with the virus.  The idea that my three children would be used like lab rats in a school Covid protocol experiment is not acceptable to me or my spouse.

In our opinion it would be parental malfeasance to endanger our children in this manner, but we respect and support the parents who either disagree with our position or have no other choice.  Regardless, we are all in this together.

So, this week we have already begun homeschooling for the next school year for our three children with the hope that we will have them well prepared to start back in January 2021.  We should know a lot more by January what the impact to children attending schools in person represents.
Why should opening schools here be done any more sanely than everything that has been done.

All this happy talk of plans to achieve our goals, ignores the reality of the "United States" and our "Government".
We lack, in no specific order:  
  Competence
  Professionals to set standards based on knowledge
  Government to mandate consistent best practices
  Government to fund and organize needs

The data is clear: kids under 18 do not get seriously ill from Covid-19. In fact, they are much more likely to die from influenza and no one is suggesting we shut down schools because 197 kids have died from influenza this year (40 from Covid). So let’s take “keeping kids safe and healthy” out of the debate. 
The question then becomes, how do we help prevent teachers and staff from getting infected. Limiting the number of kids in classes and how close they are to one another curtails the spread amongst the kids themselves, but not between kids and adults. So if schools are going to open, they might as well be fully open. For elementary school, the data strongly indicates children do not spread the disease to adults so teachers/staff wearing masks when they come in close contact w the children vigilant hand washing should prevent risk of transmission beyond what those same adults experience outside of school.  For middle/high schools, classes could be held outside whenever possible and inside, teachers and staff should wear masks and maintain 6ft from kids & adults just as they do outside of school. We cannot eliminate all risk, but we can make the risk of infection on par with risks we accepted without second thought before Coronavirus. Furthermore,the measuring stick for whether it’s safe to reopen schools should not be an increase in cases but whether or not it’s leading to hospitals being overwhelmed which was the justification for shutting them down in the first place.

There's not enough time to configure classrooms. It's less complicated to stay online for now IF we impose bell schedules and force students to Zoom during their regularly scheduled class. We could cut the fat out of the curriculum. For example, in an English class. The teacher presents a short lesson, and then students complete a reading and writing activity or take a quiz.

We keep reading psychologists stating that children need the socialization that school offers. What kind of socializing will they be doing when they can't hold hands, hug each other, comfort each other, sit together, share a lunch, rough and tumble on the playground or any of the social interactions that make us human? How will they not be psychologically harmed when they are reprimanded by a teacher for holding hands, hugging a crying friend who fell and scraped her knee? It seems that this type of damage, that forcibly removes compassion and empathy from our human response, would be far more damaging than missing a few more months of school. We will be turning our children into unfeeling robots. How is this good for them and society? How will this not damage their psyche?

I am a retired teacher. I taught in High School for 33 years, and retired for the past 15. Many of us who have been retired school officials have had extensive chat discussions on line covering the social and community challenges that now present themselves. I am in a community of only about 120,000 and 28,000 public school kids. Usual building sizes from elementary through high schools that teach 1,500 to 2,000 kids faculty, staff and adminsistration a day five days a week. What to do in an informal discussion manner have been discussions included mostly on the high school level and categories... first priority 100% reliable testing of virus and antibodies. Second mandatorymask wearing of everyone in the building. Third of course extensive disinfection of school building, and daily intensive cleaning. Desks six feet apart. Then the contrast in viewpoints included how to schedule, who moves between rooms, how many in the building at the same time, regular versus block schedules, staggered start, staggered year round scheduling, virtual scheduling versus in person, sports, food service, etc., etc., etc...Far from quick decisions can be made. Extensive challenge to be sure. The safety, health, of the kids, staff, faculty, admins., parents, transportation aspects etc and the great community have to be met.  Good luck...

Schools should not open for physical presence of students until and unless there is clear evidence that the pandemic is subsiding in this country. To do otherwise is endangering everyone (unless they already have antibody protection).
