If my old classroom had to accommodate student desks spaced 6 feet apart, there would’ve been no more than 8 or 10 students in my classroom. My normal classes had 28-30 students, so this is less than half. (In order to fit 28-30 kids in my classroom space, I had them sit with their desks in groups of 4 or 5). 

If students are required to travel from class to class (which would be needed in my subject, chemistry), traveling while walking 6’ apart would take about 4 times the time required in between classes. 

Many schools have few or no windows that open. When I was teaching, I got multiple respiratory infections a year. My first year in retirement, I never got sick. 

Many schools bus students from miles away, because much of the US has done away with neighborhood schools. Busing will be a problem, even with a staggered schedule. Imagine the logistical nightmare of bus routes with a staggered schedule.

Unless the school administration is willing to have a backbone and enforce mask wearing, then teachers will now be faced with trying to enforce that, too. My experience with school administrators being consistent with enforcing rules tells me this is a fantasy. 

The only way to reopen a school is to reimagine what the concept of a school is. Right now that’s not happening. What’s happening now is like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole.

All countries that opened schools up have experienced a spike in transmissions.  It should also be said that American schools are very different than schools in other countries--These differences will exacerbate transmissions in American classrooms.

American schools have a very different culture.  Most American parents think nothing of giving a child an aspirin before sending their sick child to school, thus sick students will bypass temperature checks.  American students have a culture of resistance.  Many American students will ignore or fight against safety protocol.  

American schools are also massively underfunded when compared to schools in other countries.  To make things worse, most American school districts have had their budgets cut by 10%.  The custodians in American schools are stretched thin and never could keep classrooms clean before this pandemic.  They will not be able to keep them clean now.  Americans schools are also overcrowded.  If we break classrooms in to smaller bubbles, we need double the number of classes and double the teachers.

American doctors can't get the PPE they need.  Students and teachers will also not have the PPE they need.

Most school board members are not very good at what they do.  There is no way a school board will be able to design and implement a safe school system.  Although school districts will have no real safety measures in place, they will still tell parents that there are safety measures in place.

Local circumstances should be the primary driver of decisions. In MA, the situation is not far from that in Europe in terms of new infections and it would make sense for the schools to open and they should safely.  

Perhaps in certain communities in Florida, Texas and California, the decision could be different.

As for young children, it seem so strange that no one considers that they are SMALL and when the breath, cough and or otherwise potentially spread the virus, the force of gravity will cause much to fall quickly to the ground so adults cannot breath it (some may aerosol, so perhaps there is a small risk but it is a fraction of the risk otherwise).  

Obviously, in high school, the children are nearly full size and that benefit fades, but high schools can be made to wear masks when around teachers and staff thus making virus transmission much more difficult.

Ultimately, the problem is we can't know unless we try.  Schools must open and react to events as they happen. We should know within two to four weeks what the real impact will be.

There is no possibility that cases will go to zero and the virus eradicated without a highly affective vaccine, so waiting for such a perfect storm solution is a non-starter.

It is reasonably clear to understand the scope and sequence of the work necessary in order to open schools somewhat safely.

The question should be now: what have the federal, state, and local governments and school districts done so far to achieve this somewhat safe reopening of schools?

So, basically, no one knows anything for certain. Evidence is contradictory and unclear. Cases in the US are on the rise and breaking daily records. It just does not seem like a good idea to rush to reopen schools next month when remote learning is possible. It may not be the best, but it’s better than dying.

There will be then a lack of labor supply in the areas where Covid is a serious problem.  Isolation is the only way to get infections under control, and summer time is the best time to do it. It is the only way to save the next  school year.  

While I do agree that it is important for kids to attend school, the damage from missing a year of in class instruction is not irreparable.  Students take gap years, have their studies interrupted by wars and even family travel and they come out fine.

“I’m just going to say it: It feels like we’re playing Russian roulette with our kids and our staff,”

If we had a genuine leader in Washington, intent on trying to attain the vital balance between health and wealth there could be a constructive, unified way the country could handle the crisis.

I have a daughter who is an elementary school teacher. She teaches Grade Two and these students' hygiene is not great in a regular year, let alone now. Despite her going into her eleventh year of teaching, she always comes down with something spread by the kids in the fall. School boards must have finalized plans to the province by August 4th. The province has already said that returning to school is voluntary and remote instruction will be available for parents who choose not to send their kids back. Key advice the Ministry of Education is going by is "distancing" and "cohorting." Both approaches indicate a limit of 15 students in a class. How this is going to be accomplished with teachers responsible for remote learning for some and hybrid for others without increasing teacher numbers remains to be seen. On a personal level, I'm concerned for my daughter's health and safety and that of her soon-to-be husband who has underlying conditions. On top of it all, they want to start a family right away and I worry about my pregnant daughter contracting the virus. The health and safety of students and all staff must be a priority. Time to rethink schools - at least on a temporary basis. Abandon the industrial model where schools are like meat packing plants with up to a thousand or more students crammed into one facility. Where an outbreak might lead to hundreds of infected individuals. At least temporarily, reconsider the "one room school house" model with personalized education in small groups at satellite locations. Lots of challenges but also much safer. Many of the mundane tasks such as testing and assessments could then be performed and tracked on line through central locations. Even off site nursing services could be provided on line as is increasingly the case with primary health care. Food services can easily be managed through delivery services of local restaurants. If there is a covid exposure, no need to send home a thousand students - only a small number would require isolation and exposure tracking.

With all of the Hollywood producers, editors and actors out of work right now, isn’t there some way to make more engaging educational content to be distributed online and through regular television? Let the teachers work on assignments and one-on-one instruction when needed. When students do eventually return to campus, it will be important for them to be properly spaced out; this will be easy for me, as my students have been totally spaced out in class for my entire career.

This is the same fantasy nonsense as saying the most vulnerable people  will be isolated, taken care of as the society opens up. So who is going to be the sacrificial lamb bus drivers that will almost certainly get infected?  There is no way schools can or will reopen.  If they do they will close after 2-3 months tops when all of the teachers become infected.  How many will die?

Opening windows will not provide fresh air in FL in Aug., Sept. or Oct.. a governor who follows the Trump script will not provide necessary precautions, and poorly paid teachers are not martyrs.

Frankly speaking, the best school for the youth would be a coffee table piled high with the classics of literature.

Turn off the computer, make some cookies, give them a glass of milk, and set them off to reading.

When it's all said and done they'll be smarter, well-rounded, and ready to learn more (for that's what education is really about) than just about any ivy league graduate.

Fight evil, read books!

More than two weeks ago, I heard Dr. Fauci state that these four things HAVE to be in place for anyone/everyone--not just students and teachers-- to be safe.

1. Mandatory masks (almost all governors have backed off this no brainer, and even where governors have called for it, many sheriffs and mayors have refused to enforce it).

2. Strict social distancing; we now think 6 feet is the bare minimum; a letter writer here just noted that her school has arbitrarily changed that to 3 feet (?!?). 

3. Not staying in the same room for longer than an hour, and that room must be well-ventilated. Many schools have windows sealed shut and hundred-year-old air systems.

4. Avoiding places where people are talking/shouting/singing, as these all enhance aerosol spread.

Schools self-evidently meet NONE of these criteria. So why is this even a debate?

And for a vivid (almost hilariously tone-deaf) illustration of what those of us maintaining that this cannot be done safely, look no further than the photo accompanying this article.

Here in Massachusetts, Governor Baker is trying to tell us that the outer edges of students’ *seats* (not their desks) need to be only 3 feet apart. While accepting the fact that it’s unlikely that we can open schools safely in the fall, any type of planning for remote instruction has to consider factors 
—a home health aide who is a single parent of a 6 year old
—a low income middle schooler who has no internet access at home and whose parents will not provide any help with instruction
—a kindergartener with preschool aged siblings  whose parents are working demanding essential jobs from home and cycling into a mental health crisis
—the kid with IDD who needs professional 1:1 instruction 

Anything that is developed around remote instruction is going to be disproportionately bad for low income and already disadvantaged kids and families.

There’s a lot of “teachers aren’t babysitters” type of comments, but that is willfully obtuse to the fact that for decades, schools have performed a critical role in workforce support. Ignoring that fact doesn’t make go away. 

One of the better ideas I’ve heard is opening up school facilities, with staff (not necessarily professional teachers) who are lower risk, in order to provide a safe place to go for kids who need supervision, computer or internet access, and meals.

As a teacher in Houston, Texas, where we are at the epicenter of the virus transmission right now, I see it as pure craziness to open school for in person classes. At my high school we have on average 35-40 students in class and there is no way that I will be able to control those kids to socially distance and keep their masks on, and I am probably the best at my school in classroom management. My district has been providing computers to high school kids for a few years already and all our lessons are online 100%. There is no reason to get high school kids back to classes in this district and the rest of the country if they are transmitting the virus as much as adults (and they are given the equipment to work from home and provided hotspots if they need access to internet). If the people running this country want to open the schools fully then they need to allocate the funds that will bring the classes down to 10-15 children per class, increase teacher pay, give enough money for special ed and kids at risk, and increase funds to minority communities schools and english language learners. Can I imagine the hardship for working parents and the economy itself if schools stay closed, indeed yes! But what about the safety of teachers? It appears that Covid-19 is a recent mutation of a viral microbe that proliferates by a statistically successful opportunistic exploitation of a transmission vector that enables its reproduction.

Experiential evidence indicates that vector is provided by the interactive habits of the human host population upon whom it depends. When that population alters its habits to block the vector, the microbes begin to die out for want of a vulnerable host and the rate of infection declines toward zero. That is documented fact.

The continuing, greater hazard is the often endemic human potential for social incoherence that allows and promotes the irrational pursuit of  toxic delusions.

That switches the focus of our dilemma from epidemiology to another discipline; Chaos Theory. The math is beyond me but a frequent pattern shows that a deliberate disregard for warning signs precedes catastrophic consequences.

Can the 5 Nordic nations serve as an example for the US? 

When Iceland, Norway and Denmark locked down hard March 12-13, these nations were hit hardest among the Nordic nations. Iceland with 368 cases per million, Norway 186, Denmark 138, Sweden 57, Finland 41. Sweden never closed nurseries and primary schools, Finland later and diverse. After 4 weeks DK, NO and IS gradually reopened schools.

No Nordic nation registered large outbreaks linked to schools and nurseries, until now. However testing is sparse with only Denmark and Iceland in the world top 12, DK 208k and IS 277k finished tests per million citizens (US is about 126k), but Denmark has by far the highest population per Km2. (6 times Sweden and more towards the others).

For now the community spread in Sweden is about 30-50 times the spread in the other Nordic nations.

In the 0-9 year age group Denmark count 370 cases with 20 hospitalized, 0 deaths. Sweden 448, 0 hospitalized, 0 deaths. 

In the 10-19 year group Denmark count 648 cases, 22 hospitalized, 0 deaths, Sweden 2,945 cases, 13 hospitalized, 0 deaths.

Denmark has tested 3.5 times as many as Sweden, it's part of the picture. Denmark is 5.8 m and 12,888 cases, Sweden 10.2 m and 74,898 cases.

The 0-9 age group seems at low risk, but they can catch the virus and contribute to the community spread. However, reopening schools demand disciplin among all parents and staff, and to some degree the kids too. Swedes and Danes are in general rather responsible.

The picture of nursing students showing first graders how to properly wash their hands to reduce the spread of the coronavirus in March which accompanied the article demonstrates vividly how quickly our thinking about Covid-19 has changed. In the photo, no one was wearing masks or physically distancing themselves from others. Now just months later, the focus on hand washing without attention to mask wearing and physical distancing seems naive.More recently, the American Academy of Pediatrics  "strongly advocate[d] that all policy considerations for the coming school year should start with a goal of having students physically present in school" - a policy that the AAP has already had to "clarify" because it began with a goal of putting students physically back in classrooms which is scientifically insupportable. Another huge challenge to safety in NYC school: commuting. Most of our students get to school on public transportation. Teachers, school staff, and parents are not going to be on the subways and buses with the kids, which means there's no way to ensure the kids are wearing masks and social distancing on their way to and from school. Anyone counting on all the kids to be prudent and consistent in following these guidelines when they don't have to is deluded. Some will, but plenty will not. (Even in the schools, under the supervision of adults, getting 100% compliance is going to be a challenge, as most high school teachers will affirm.) With kids being on subways and buses -- many for a good deal longer than 45 minutes each way -- you can count on there being a surge of infections. I'm not saying that kids should not go to school, but if this isn't done with a solid plan that does a good job of properly minimizing risk of infection, it's going to be a disaster. (And for all the scoffers who say that life is full of risks and just get over it -- I wonder how eager you would be to shadow our teachers and school staff for even just one month.)

LONDON — Parents, teachers and union officials in Germany and Scandinavian countries have challenged President Donald Trump’s suggestion that schools in those nations were “open with no problems.”

Comparing the U.S. response to that of Denmark was “wrong,” Niels Larsen, a musician and the father of three school children in the capital Copenhagen, told NBC News on Thursday, adding that the way the two countries had approached the coronavirus pandemic was “quite different.”

“We took the initial hit to our economy and the hard blows, and now we are seeing the benefits with things like the reopening of schools, so that’s where the comparison is wrong,” he said by telephone.

It’s not complicated. Test everyone, isolate the infected, the others go about business as usual. Everyone needs to be tested at the same time, or very close. Mobilize the military for the testing. And everyone else. Cops, firemen. Test the entire country in one weekend. Starting up anything under present conditions is not gonna end well.

So, one sentence about the challenge the US faces with an out-of-control virus and then studies from other countries who have "opened" in ways that don't sound anything like what Trump has proposed.
As I posted a few days ago on another site -
The US has roughly 4 times Germany's population

we would have had 10, 092 new cases instead of 370,361

Water.  In the years when I spent a lot of time in classrooms in various cities I started to focus on children's access to water in their classrooms.  Children get a lot of viruses and need to wash their hands.  When ill, and they do come to school ill, they need to be able to freely drink water to get well.
Most classrooms lack access to handwashing and drinking water.  
Please, use this crisis to establish basic water access in classrooms.  It would improve health outcomes.

An entire generation of kids will be under-schooled, as  a result of schools not opening.   This is the risk folks.  I know first hand, as the parent of an 8 year old, who has not embraced online learning, nor did he “learn” very much, as a result.  He was an exceptional student before the pandemic.  Once schools shut down, his love of learning dissipated and he became incredibly anxious.  He missed his friends.  He missed the entire school atmosphere.  His teacher would drive by our house and wave, which only made him more upset.   

My viewpoint may be anecdotal, but it’s my personal opinion.  I understand the concerns teachers have and am more than sympathetic to them; yet, psychologists, sociologists and people way smarter than me, will be studying the downstream effects of prohibiting children from in-person schooling.  

 In my humble opinion, online learning is an inadequate substitute for in-person, social instruction, especially for elementary school children. 

I don’t know the answer here.  However, before you run off and declare, “close all schools,” think about what it is doing to our children.   More over, think of what it does to parents, who see their children sink further into isolation.  

Again, there is no easy answer.

It seems any discussion of school reopening must be focused on local data and information. The number of cases and rate of spread varies significantly between and within states. There may be some counties in some states that can consider safely reopening schools based on covid rates while in other areas, it is not safe currently to do so. I think it is important to pinpoint those places that have strong handle on covid and explore reopening. The country is not a monolith in terms of covid and school planning needs to reject this.

Schools should be reopened without a doubt - but, only if the following measures would happen to address health and safety concerns: the Federal government should coordinate with the states on acquisition and distribution of required PPEs particularly to colleges, universities and schools; the Federal government should provide emergency capital funding to schools for required partitions, hand sanitizing stations etc. and other protective equipment; and the Federal government steps in to coordinate all components and supplies necessary to provide accurate and reliable testing in all states.  These are just some necessary Federal actions needed to get schools and general everyday life up and running.  Neither POTUS nor DeVoss has stated any of these prerequisites in their careless threats and exhortations to resume.

In a community right now with exponentially rising cases of Coronavirus I think this needs to be addressed on the local level. We are being given a choice to send our kids to school in person or opt for online learning. Teaches are not being given that choice. Parents  who are already sending their kids to daycare obviously will opt for in person school. Essential workers, healthcare workers, many low income families. As a specialist MD myself opting to treat patients via telemedicine I have been so thankful for the option technology gives us to adapt. I’m going to opt for on line learning. Do I think it is going to be perfect? No, but my kids have learnt a lot on their own this summer. They are learning Spanish, writing books. Maybe we need to look at safety first, who cares about everything else if you are dead or very ill? And maybe we need to adapt as a society, utilize technology as well as science.  Viruses are very smart especially this one. People can’t behave stupidly. It’s simple evolutionary principles. So while it’s a complex question I think it deserves a complex answer- let’s look at local transmission rates, individual family needs/ risk levels, for students, families and teachers/ admistrators. And let’s also try to adapt to do things differently. Our education system and healthcare system were lagging prior to all this. I think we could adapt at least some of our schools to streamline what really needs to be learnt, allowing kids greater creativity.

In Canada, Quebec has decided to reopen schools this fall with various “social distancing measures in place.” With that, for sure infections will spike, teachers and kids will spread the virus, and the cycle will continue. The question will soon become, not, “should we return to school this fall,” but, “how much collateral damage are we willing to tolerate as a society?” As a parent, the thought of endangering teacher’s lives for my child’s education makes me sick to my stomach.

This could be handled much better if the following had not happened over the years
1. Cutbacks for cleaning staff and cleaning supplies and equipment

These are the two options we have to compare and it's horrible but the lesser of two evils is a distanced education as opposed to these families paying with their health and lives. The United States is not even close to adequately addressing the spread of the virus and they have for YEARS continued to defund public education. It is not on educators' backs to fix this. Science cannot teach us anything if we do not want to learn from it or if we want to learn selectively what is convenient to learn. The same goes with reopening schools. If we do not want to take safety precautions and have everyone uniformly follow the guidelines just like the school uniforms of a bygone era we are destined to fail and infections continue to spread like wild fire. 

There is not a cookie cutter approach or one size fits all for every school reopening. A careful thought process has to result in meticulously executing the sanitary requirements appropriate for every student, teacher and staff member. There is a risk involved in carelessly reopening and a proper risk benefit analysis needs to be done in every school. While children may not be considered as a vulnerable population with regard to Coronavirus COVID-19, they could be carriers to their vulnerable parents and grand parents making containment of spread and reducing deaths near impossible. Then there has to be special consideration given to special needs children who may have behavior issues, juvenile diabetes, autism, genetic immunodeficiency etc. Certainly the challenges to reopening will place an additional burden to already hard pressed schools with children that have minimal parent supervision.

Education administrators that I know in PA are working very hard to figure this out. Our PA Dept. of Ed is with them at every step. Perfection? No. But we are trudging through.
A common plan in a district:
2 days on for half of the students, middle day online ed for all (cleaning day), 2 days on for the other half. Masks, distancing and shields will be the norm and hopefully followed well enough.
Plus, in the same district, there will be some students online 100% and "online" teachers" to support them due to health concerns.  Special education is probably the hardest to adapt, which is terribly hard to acknowledge.
As a career educator - I trust our school admins and staff more than I trust the failing Federal leadership.  
Teachers don't go into this profession to be famous, powerful or rich. We go into it to teach and support the well being of all children. I trust that. Most admins are first teachers.
I think it helps for everyone to keep this in mind and trust that we are all doing our best. No one has "the answer". We have some data, not enough, and so we build the year as we face it - responsibly and compassionately.

Perhaps the pandemic can provide and opportunity for our nation to reimagine traditional schooling. This will give parents, teachers, disease care professionals and other stakeholders the opportunity to point out flaws and make decisions about opting in or out (in the case of parents, teachers and other school staff).

I live in San Diego County. Amazing weather here, almost year round. Districts around the country are clearly being left on their own regarding how to safely open schools. There is absolutely NO cohesive plan at the Federal level, as we are tragically being "led" by an evil idiot. 

So, one idea for many districts in  California is to temporarily redesign our school's outdoor spaces to accommodate students. Most schools already have picnic benches outside for lunch, snack and recess. Many also have outdoor amphitheaters for assemblies/special events. Tented areas and partitions can be set up in around the campus.  Bathrooms would be sanitized throughout the day. Small libraries with tech stations can be set up outside. A few indoor spaces can be safely used for administration including the nurse. School hours can be staggered so the schools aren't inundated with students in every grade. Schools can creatively use these spaces, on a rotating basis for a few months, as we work toward flattening the curve(s) again and have a vaccination. 
This is not an ideal solution. “There are different theories about why older children would be more likely to transmit the virus than younger children.”
One reason not mentioned: younger students often spend most of the day with a single classroom of students and a single teacher.  And there isn’t nearly as much passing in the halls. I am a physician at a major academic hospital in California. Our hospital system mandates COVID testing in certain scenarios (eg, patients undergoing surgery). In my community, we know the overall asymptomatic positive COVID rate in the pediatric population has risen from <0.1% to 0.2% in the past 3 months. This means that for an elementary school that houses 500 asymptomatic children, on average only 1 child is COVID positive. These data are consistent with published results: https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamasurgery/fullarticle/2766924 The available evidence indicates the chance of severe COVID illness in an infected child is very low, and the rates of transmission among young children is low. There has been no significant outbreak of community spread related to essential worker daycares remaining open during the pandemic, including ours which has 20 teachers and 150 kids attending daily. Kids play with each other without masks. Parents and kids must undergo daily temperature checks and attest to absence of symptoms at the door. The data argue that in my region it is safe to open elementary schools without requiring expensive testing or unenforceable mask and social distancing policies. Elementary school children need in-person learning most and pose the least risk to public health. Yet Governor Newsom has forced almost every school to move to 100% distance-learning. This decision is not based on data. It is based on politics and fear of the unknown.

I am a physician, so I thought I would add my thoughts to those already being expressed.

Lots of people are trying to decide whether schools should reopen. Decisions in medicine are never Manichean.."yes" or "no"...Nothing is that clear cut in medicine--it is always a question of balancing risks and benefits.

Sometimes benefits are very great and risks are minimal or there is minimal benefit and great risk--the choices are relatively easy. But sometimes the choice is much harder when risks and benefits are difficult to calculate. There is no "right" or "wrong" choice--only a choice.

No easy answers here, but do be aware that whatever choice you make the consequences will be very real.

"No nation has tried to send children back to school with the virus raging at levels like America’s."  Well, not exactly true.  The USA is far, far from a monolithic entity.  The rate of infections of covid varies enormously from one region to the next.  My state (MA) is not dissimilar to Lombardy, Italy, in terms of the size of the population and the current baseline levels of daily covid cases.  In other words, it is reasonably under control.  However, while in Lombardy children of all ages, as well as university students, prepare to return to their classrooms in a safe and responsible manner, over here we are dominantly operating in "remote only" mode.  I always believed that the US was the "can do" nation of the world...I am saddened by both the chaotic, rudderless response to the pandemic delivered by the federal government and the reflexive surrender on the side of local and state governments.

Remote classes are better than dangerous classes.  The ability of a student to walk into a school without their temperature being taken is trivial.  Most schools do not have a small finite number of entry control points.  In particular, in most schools, in you arrive about an hour before school starts, the school is open and vastly unsupervised.  One would think the number of school shootings we have endured in the last 10 years would have resulted in control points of entry to review book bags to prevent guns and knives from entering.  This simply has not happened.  So anyone infected with Covid-19 can wander into a school without a temperature being taken if they want to.  Unlike airport security, which is designed to eliminate a problem, school security is designed to deter a problem.  Let's be safe or at least safer then we've been.

When this is all over make up the lost time by having summer sessions or longer school days. It may take a  couple of years to completely catch up but I'd rather see schools open in the summertime and after-hours than sick and dead kids and teachers.

Extraordinary times call for extraordinary measures!

The murmur of a classroom comes to an abrupt stop, dispelled by the teacher's raps on a board. Notebooks open, pens uncapped — students seamlessly, albeit unhurriedly, refocus their minds to the lesson at hand. A projector beams, gathering attention to a now-lit screen — the faint, yet audible hum of the projector marks my class’s focused inclination to learn. 

A few short months later, my classroom is no longer illuminated by the luster of sun. Now, the classroom is illuminated by the dull brim of a digital screen. My classroom is no longer marked by the characteristic and audible activity of student and staff. Now, the notifications of Zoom and Google Hangouts are insuffice semblances of scant familiarity. 

In my time in quarantine and with virtual learning, I've growingly come to realize some of the stark discrepancies in learning, communicating, and finding normalcy within my daily lives. In turn, I've found myself actively hoping for a  return to school. Yet, as the article states, there comes inherent benefit and risk in doing so. 

As it was pointed out, the varying levels of success with reopening schools in various instances has a pointed difference with the situation at hand in America: "the (virus raging" at extreme levels. Reading the article, the poignant worries of transmission and infection are pivotal.

In turn, as I remain uncertain of future schooling and our future as a whole, I find strange solidarity in the uncertainty of the direction of our nation..

Niece #2 (Engineer working at home): “it was awful. I’m trying to work and teach them at the same time. The instruction they received was terrible. I don’t know what I’ll do if they don’t go back. I don’t think I was ever this stressed out. They miss their friends and I know one of them is fallling behind but I just don’t have enough time to give them what they need.”

Kids need to go back for so many reasons. Other countries are doing it. The risk is low for kids. At risk teachers shouldn’t go back. Let’s be creative here and do the right thing by our children.
I would have a lot more confidence in our schools reopening if Germany or Norway took charge of our strategy. I have no faith in our leadership doing it intelligently and responsibly.

Give all teachers and staff over 60, or with underlying conditions, a year ON SABBATICAL this academic year. Do what didn't happen with assisted living patients and take them immediately out of harm's way. They can have the year off, or concentrate on distance learning for the children who have underlying conditions and cannot be allowed back in any case. This may be a better way to do distance learning, in smaller pods with one teacher, while lower rusk children can return to classrooms with teachers who are slso less at risk. If you remove the most vulnerable, it turns into a scheduling/distancing oroblem.

If your country is run by a person who acts like a flea in a fit with attention deficit disorder then the outlook remains dire.

Unfortunately, half-hearted lockdowns, especially when the President argues against them, don't work and Australia showed Covid-19 can stage comeback from a mere handful of cases.

America needs to fix its leadership problem. 

Whenever groups of people gather in close proximity to each other they create an environment in which Covid-19 can spread aggressively unless good protective measures are in place.

Steady, considered and firm leadership is needed to ban or downscale problematic types of events and behaviours.

The best personally protective measures humanity has available now are wearing face masks; frequent hand washing; physical distancing; keeping your hands away from your face; self-isolation of people with symptoms; careful food hygiene; keeping away from crowds and enclosed spaces; and generally minimising contact with other people.

These must all be used with real personal discipline.

These measures can be backed up by aggressive disinfection and cleaning procedures for shared spaces and maintaining excellent ventilation in enclosed buildings and vehicles.

With these in place perhaps America can tough it out until the British Oxford vaccine is released for use, hopefully in September 2020.

If the vaccines fail, then the lock down America has been ducking may become unavoidable.

Let us hope Covid-19 does not mutate dangerously.

Look at what the experts are doing in the Sacramento school in the second picture.  Teachers, students, staff and film crew are not social distancing or using masks but what is worse is why are they inviting all of these people into a classroom during a pandemic?  This is the perfect example of what not to do when the schools reopen.  There should be one teacher per class.  No interaction between students of different classes or between staff.

How many people would support President Trump ordering an internal travel ban and mandatory contact tracing and mandatory anything.  If he had done any of the things people are complaining he failed to do, the same people would be accusing him of abusing his power and attempting a coup.  For Times readers, Trump is damned if he does and damned if he doesn't.

This is like the calls to “open” businesses. Somebody needs to stop the corrupt ethically challenged people calling for schools to open when the virus is spreading so widely! This corruption is going to backfire, especially if the vaccine is delayed!! This is pure corruption and ethical and moral madness. When will the corrupt money-minded people running the country have some shame?

American schools are very different from schools in other countries.  

American schools are massively underfunded.  There was no budget for cleaning schools before this pandemic, there is no budget to clean them now.

American schools are overcrowded.  

The Americans view public school very differently than they do in other countries.  An American parent will have no problem giving their child an aspirin and sending them to school.  Viruses spread easily and quickly in American schools because of overcrowding, underfunding, and pervasive culture viewing schools as daycares first.

Most other countries have contained this epidemic, while American transmission rates are going through the roof.  Comparing American school openings to countries that have contained this epidemic is illogical.  

America needs to contain this epidemic before opening its schools-Just like all other countries with leadership.  The path to containing this epidemic is simple:Wear masks, social distance, expand testing, and get PPE to doctors and nurses.  Democrats have been calling for these measures for four months, while Republicans have blocked most of these measures.

Biden and a Democrat run senate will contain this epidemic in a month.

We will come to regret the rush to put kids back in school.  Without evidence and some to the contrary, schools districts are opening for political reasons.  This is child abuse..they have no say in the matter.   Trump has successfully muzzled the CDC.  The new guidelines are simply a green light to experiment with kids.  No one can say for sure what the outcomes will be.

As to the damage, kids will suffer from not going to school for a while longer no one knows that either.  We have never been there.  The kids', for the most part, will not be neglected, mistreated, or in any way harmed by not attending in person school.  Kids are resilient. All of a sudden everyone is concerned about school-age children who you have neglected for decades and have cut funding time and time again.  Their short term and long term health is on the line here.  When this blows up, and it will, people need to be punished severely.  The only lesson that kids will receive is that ignorance and hubris are dangerous weapons when it comes to healthcare.
Reins Deli in Vernon CT is the perfect stop (and delicious) going north or south, and if you buy a bucket of pickles, you will have an empty container to take home lobsters. Be safe and sane.
On a Maine Island for a month. Getting tested 72 hours ahead of time was no problem (smart Governor). We are continuing to social distance. Enjoying the coolness and beauty of the islands.
Maine is quite possibly the most beautiful state during summer

My husband and I spent last week at the Massanutten Resort in Virginia, focusing on outdoor activities.  It went surprisingly well.  The resort is doing a great job at maintaining and enforcing social distancing, and we were in a condo with no interaction with other guests except in the restaurants, where tables were outdoors and six feet apart.  The one surprise was in going to the grocery store four miles from the resort in rural Rockingham County, where the vast majority of customers were not wearing masks and the staff, who were, had clearly given up trying to enforce the state mandate.  It was so good to get away though.

We bareboat chartered a sailboat on an unfamiliar lake. My Captain husband spent a month preparing, learning the waters, choosing and re-choosing anchorages, reviewing the RULES... We had the week of our lives, so happy, content!  We moored at empty anchorages, walked almost deserted woods and beaches, felt the freedom of the breeze, sun, clouds and house of our own underway! We played games, talked with each other, swam, practiced boating skills . Though the idea initially seemed far fetched, it likely saved this summer for us. The planning and the activity involved a one month escapade of peace and serenity.

Kudos to everyone for obeying the local quarantine rules. I recommend Civil War battlefields for the pandemic. We went to Antietam and it was empty.  We packed our Yeti full of food and stayed at a B and B that was rotating rooms used. Also, buy an EZ pass so you don't have to stop at toll booths.

This all sounds so amazing that I find myself instantaneously, severely envious...and thusly irritated that no mention is made of how they found the house in Maine. What platform? Airbnb? Local real estate office? A family friend? How??
That spot in Searsport Maine looks like heaven on Earth.

I lived in Maine many years and still consider myself as having been from there. For a family with kids under ten or so, renting  a house in a small coastal village is a wonderful vacation. We did it in South Gouldsboro for a week one summer. We were able to canoe out to islands just slightly offshore and beachcomb spots not overrun by tourists, go for long bike rides, visit a nearby farm, and do lowkey stuff that didn't rely on buying a ticket or parking in some crowded spot. Nothing wrong with an "On Golden Pond" week.

When I saw the picture, I knew it was taken in Maine. My husband is from Maine and we have spent many summers in the Belgrade Lakes region. I had tears running down my face remembering loons, canoes, Gifford’s ice cream, and lobsters eaten on a picnic table over looking the ocean. But the best memories are of family members, especially those now grown up or no longer with us.
This article is tone deaf.
Reading about the Maine voyage made me feel like I was escaping back into a Robert McCloskey book. And what’s cuter than two babies in a bucket?

The factor of claustrophobia due to enforced confinement and toxic immobilisation unleashed by the inscrutable corona virus could be got the better of by moving to some ideal place of idyllic surroundings 
where time is tamed to our beck and call in fulfilment of all our impounded wanderlust.America,  the land of opportunities and the cynosure of admiring eyes from around the world, abounds in natural sceneries of  a fantastic canvas and ,for seeking souls and prying eyes, it yields an amazing choice of landscape of every sizzling description.One such place is the State of Maine, renowned for  its fabulous expansion of holidaying delights.While its climate is a wee bit on the extreme, conforming to its neighbourhood to the Canadian weather, even that climatic curve is less offending in terms of welcome to the visitors.There are finer spots of earthly delights spread over this land that beggars description.Nor is there . any dearth of geological joys for those who catch the drift.If the  evanescent viral presence will play spoilsport with our wishes and dreams, we, the Homo sapiens, do know and command commensurate techniques to sieve through its rigid intent and sneak our schedule of vacationing in spots of durable and redeemable enjoyments. Thus and therefore, there is absolutely no hitch  for embracing avocations of our wont.After all, God  has cast us  in His own mould to enunciate and embrace the nuances of mundane life, undeterred by obnoxious viral knots.

To me, the expected ratio pleasure/hassle in travel is too low.
In these trying times, it may be better to follow Psalm 37:3, "Trust in the LORD, and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed", and stay in one's own abode.

Determined to spontaneously escape a sweaty summer in NYC back in the late 80’s, a flight to Portland Maine was booked. Every event conspired against our efforts to get out of the city, including a car service driver who refused to turn on the AC and belligerently stopped for gas, causing us to miss our scheduled flight. 
Finally on final approach, a couple in neighboring seats were shocked to hear we were arriving on a Friday in August with no idea where we were staying. A woman who had overheard our conversation stopped me in the terminal and gave me the business card for a b&b on Cape Elizabeth. 
Less than an hour later I was sitting on a bench near the cliffs, my very first lobster roll in hand, watching a regatta of tiny sailboats circle in the azure water below. It took everything I had to not break down sobbing. I never felt so happy and relieved at the same time. 
I love Maine.

Well, wish me luck. Next week I leave my home in Prague for a road trip to the Alps, where I plan to hike for several weeks.  I'll use a rental car to get to Austria. Cases are very low here in Central Europe, but the virus is still here. We have 10-15 new cases every day in Prague. Not much by US standards but that is still a hundred people testing positive every week.  I figure, I'll be outside most days on this trip.  I'll stay in small pensions, in small towns. I worry a little bit about meals; indoor dining seems to be the weak link in my plan (along with some train rides). But hopefully tables will be socially distanced. Some places are better than others about that
Right now my backyard is the most beautiful spot on the planet. Fire pit, no traveling and no need to do so.

Go nearby. The fewer travel complications the better. Especially now that it is not at all certain you can cross even a state line without enduring a 14-day quarantine.

For me in Chicago, that meant driving to a smaller family-run resort on a lake (one of 10,000) in Minnesota. It was a fabulous, relaxing vacation, that left me refreshed to face the rigors of the big city. These pleasant, relaxed, smaller family-run resorts are a dying breed that need help, especially now. There's lots of them, in a big triangle from Maine to Tennessee to Minnesota.

I haven't been on a plane since 1991.  My last vacation was about 5 years ago when I loaded up my mountain bike with camping gear and rode across the Cascade Mountains and back.  I let the passport expire a couple of decades ago.  Whenever I think of leaving Seattle, I just can't think of anyplace I would rather be on earth.  I had planned on taking a kayaking class this spring and knock paddling to the San Juans off of my bucket list but alas, not this year.  So, I decided to start taking photos of all of the memorable places in Seattle for me and yesterday got the first couple of pictures.  It started by peddaling to another neighborhood I have not visited in 30 years to get a picture of where my first daughter was born at home a couple of months early.  Then, on to the former Pentecostal Evangelical cult I had joined where I met the ex-wife:)).  What a bike trip!!!!!!

I hope all of you reading find your own "Seattle" which totally removes all of your wanderlust.  Its nice to always be in your favorite place on earth.  And I haven't bought a gallon of gas in 10 years now:))  I see your global warming and raise you!

To those reading the essay about Maine, know that Acadia National Park and roads in the communities around it are now occupied almost exclusively by out of state drivers. It's getting thicker by the day.  Unfortunately, we are no longer, to use one of the condescending terms we frequently endure, "sleepy". I can't even begin to imagine that all the occupants of the cars suddenly now here have fully complied with quarantine requirements. And while I appreciate the that Mr. Lipton attempted to be conscientious, the advice that Mr Lipton could skirt the full quarantine to visit Acadia by buying a pass on line was not correct. The quarantine is the quarantine is the quarantine.  So, please, scrupulously respect the COVID 19 limitations to the letter. And when in doubt, as he was, this year just don't.   It has taken great sacrifice by all of us and excellent state and local leadership to keep our cases numbers among the lowest in the nation. Therefore we'd rather you didn't imperil us because you just had to have a vacation in the middle of a pandemic.  Sorry to be tart, but it's personal. Mr. Lipton drove right past my house on his way to Beech Cliff.

A short visit to an adjacent state to deliver some household goods to a relative resulted in unwanted stay at a roadside motel and exposure to numerous maskless people due to an unexpected car problem. As the saying goes about best laid plans... Alas, no more traveling for us until it can be done safely.

As a former Vermonter who has spent some summer time in Maine, that trip sounded the best to me.  Not only is it a beautiful throw back to simpler times, but the family could not have done it any safer.  Getting your children out of the house and into the fresh air is healthy both mentally and physically for them.
The flip to me was the trip close to my new home.   Staying in an Inn and going on wine tasting trips seems unsafe and unnecessary.  As adults we hopefully have the fortitude and resolve to weather these times by avoiding risky situations, wearing a mask, and drinking our wine in our own home.

We spent a week in the Adirondacks in Northern NY— it was a great, relaxed vacation. Spent almost all of our time outside hiking, kayaking, swimming, eating ice cream. Can’t ask for much more. But now I am missing Maine.

I've only read the Maine entry so far but I have to say—come on!  How on earth is traveling an hour to tour a national park and visiting a lobster emporium along with "most other businesses," even for curbside pickup, complying with a 14-day quarantine order? I bet the Maine officials who imposed the quarantine would beg to disagree.

You'd think maybe a pandemic would stop them, but apparently it's not summer if you don't travel hours to drink wine and be outdoors.

My husband John, along with our dear friend ML are just back from five days in Provincetown on Cape Cod.  The three of us have made this trip for the past 9 years so we knew the lay of the land, which beach we liked (herring cove) our hotel (the Provincetown Inn) and even the restaurants where we would feel safe eating outside or ordering in.  P'town has a mandatory Mask rule on the main drag, commercial street, which should be done across the nation.  But in short, we felt safe every step of the way.  We knew the hotel and the layout. We knew that our section of the beach was always sparsely populated even in "normal" years.  And we took a cooler full of food for breakfast and lunch, so we never had to go shopping and we only had dinners to deal with.  In short for us, the trip was not only relaxing but it broke some taboos - we will still be very careful and remain safe, but life can go on, even in the age of covid-19.   We plan to go back in August for one more long weekend before the summer ends.

This is why pandemic is raging. We did it and continue to do it backwards. We should have worked on opening essentials safely 1st. Sports, entertainment and travel should have been last. It may feel good, but it’s not a good thing to be doing or encouraging. Being locked down because we’re inundated with tourists is not right.

I have not picked mu my grandson born in February.  140,000 people have died of this disease.  I am an inveterate traveler.  I am a million mile butt in seat United flyer. Our town thrives on tourism - we love the enthusiastic spirit and need the money they bring here every summer. Thanks for visiting! What we don’t need is their maskless indifference and selfish indulgence to “get away”. Our homes were marginally safe to leave only weeks ago. Now, with thousands of visitors from hotspot states fleeing here and ignoring the reality of a pandemic, the locals will suffer long after tourists are gone. Please be safe at your own home and come next year. The mountains aren’t going anywhere.

I am a high school teacher in coastal Maine, and  I found the Searsport story really entitled and distasteful. Your coming here was a selfish act, and your writing a story about it, even more so.  I am sure that the people who rented you a home appreciated the income. But why did you feel it necessary to say, "No one was enforcing these rules. But we decided to honor them anyway?" To emphasize how virtuous you are? To signal to others that they can be less responsible?  We have made a lot of sacrifices in this state to keep our COVID numbers low. As a result, we MAY be able to start school in person. But yes, we rely on people to obey the rules, and be responsible. People like you, not only making money on an article about my state, but coyly pointing out that others might be able to enjoy themselves without being so responsible; you are the reason we can't have nice things.
Stay home. Wash your hands. Keep your distance.

I live on a lake outside Middlebury in the summer.  There are a fair number of year-round residents on the lake but by far it is out-of-staters who dominate in the summertime.  Driving on West Shore Road there is a new home built on two lots that were tear downs and it is out of scale with the general area.  The residents are from New Jersey.  The front door is about 30 feet from the road which can be fairly busy with a 30 MPH speed limit.  And they have the gall to post five signs along the road reminding people to please slow down. - Please slow down.  Please slow down.  Please slow down.  Please slow down.  It annoys me to no end when I drive by.  I honk the horn and would love to send them a letter asking them to return to New Jersey.

It’s called making a sacrifice for your fellow humans. I am amazed by how weak and selfish people are. Ugh.

a.) infuriatingly out of touch with the experiences of regular Americans (I could almost here Mrs. Howell in her finishing school accent when I read, “We preferred more exotic destinations: Mexico, India, Japan).

and:

This article makes me sad. This is just not the summer for a vacation. It's time to explore your own backyard. Maybe pull out a Thoreau reader and take a gander at his quote, "It matters not where or how far you travel,--the farther commonly the worse,--but how much alive you are." Please, for the sake of others, stay home. Is your dwelling really so terrible that you can't stay close to home for a single year? Are you that in need of diversion that can only be offered in far away places? It's not easy, everyone gets that. But this is for the good of all. My sweetheart and I live outside Boston and have been working from home and socially distancing rigorously since early March. We rent the same cottage for two weeks every year in North Truro, on Cape Cod near Provincetown, also in Massachusetts. We did not feel compelled to cancel this year. We brought and wore masks and socially distanced everywhere we went. The restaurants we ate at had socially distanced seating outdoors. Mostly, we shopped in masks at the market and cooked at the cottage. We rode our bikes while socially distancing. We went to the beach and socially distanced. Everything we did felt safe and responsible. We are old enough to be high-risk ourselves, so we didn't want to put ourselves or anyone else at risk, and we didn't. While I'm sure that some people who travel are putting others at risk, that does not automatically mean that responsible travel is completely impossible. It does not automatically mean that every single person who travels is irresponsible, selfish, and bad, regardless of where they travel and what precautions they observe. Blanket generalizations don't add any value to the discussion.

A MS cousin and her husband will drive to ME next week. Here’s her response upon learning of the state’s rules for visitors:

“I’ve been in touch with the lady that owns the apartment we have rented. She said that is a recommendation but not mandatory. I asked her if she needed us to take a Covid test and she said no. She also said there are no checkpoints into Maine.”

Lord help us!

After four months of not sharing a meal with anyone I drove to my sister’s in Montreal (10 hours) from the East Coast. I live alone in a big house four bedroom house filled with my stuff from living abroad the past decade and my frequent travels. I am 5 minutes from a mainly empty beach and I have a yard so I had had mental health outdoor time (and quiet)... After my online classes were finished and final grades entered I headed to family. 

We decided to rent a place on a lake north of Ottawa, but still in Quebec where we were sure not to be “plate shamed” for being from the province with the worst Covid-19 record in Canada (by far!). We packed both cars with groceries for any craving we might have and I took my three teenage nieces and they took the epileptic lab with bad hips. For seven days we kayaked and swam, fished and I introduced my nieces to a 1,000 piece puzzle In a huge lake cabin. In a pre-Covid world they would have been at my brother-in-law’s family home in Toulouse for family weddings and I had planned on visiting friends in Israel and my parents in Northern Alberta. I should be planning my return for a summer semester in Shantou, China and buying maple syrup for gifts and stocking up on Western groceries. Instead I’m stocking up on ethnic food ingredients to begin my 10 hour return journey next week. I’ll need to self-isolate for 14 days, no beach, no grocery store or Cost-Co visits. It’s an easy trade off to me for family time,

I know this property, used to drive by it many times living in that part of the state. Belfast and Blue Hill are also really nice - with beautiful sea-breezes and just enough off the beaten path to avoid hipsters, overpriced everything and too many tourists. 

While Maine welcomes our summer visitors, we hope they'll respect the rules of masking up and being cautious. Thankfully the population density here is forgiving. Enjoy the brief weeks of summer you get.

I think something folks need to understand is that a lot of these places that are becoming “social distance vacation” destinations are often times rural places with limited hospital resources. That being said, what happens if you unknowingly bring Covid with you on your journey, even if you’ve been taking precautions, and suddenly fall ill and require hospitalization? Or what if you visit a national park and accidentally injure yourself? People live in rural places—-they aren’t just wide expanses of empty land—-and they need healthcare too. Rural hospitals are already stretched thin and do not need the additional load from a bunch of people traveling from out of state or from more populated areas who need to get away from it all for a while.

I just drove 970 miles across three states (for family duty, not pleasure) and need to warn other drivers that with COVID has come a heightened level of ROAD RAGE. I heard this first-hand from an Ohio State Trooper. Some drivers are taking out the frustrations of the pandemic on their fellow drivers, and highway incidents have increased. Do take care.

If you travel, please, please take appropriate precautions before, during, and after. 

I'm probably going to my mom's house soon for a couple weeks because it's cheaper than a psych ward and I can bring my cat. (I recently almost did something very stupid and very permanent that isn't a neck tattoo...use your imagination. Family decision was made that I'm very not okay to be alone at the moment.) I've been isolating since March, staying mostly home except for groceries and laundry etc., wearing a mask. I plan on following any quarantine rules that Maine has for New Yorkers. 

If you'll be travelling, please do likewise. Even if quarantine rules are not stringently enforced, follow them. If you're taking a bus or a train or a plane, wear your mask. Your perfect getaway is not worth risking others; I know masks and quarantine are unpleasant but please endure a little discomfort so you don't cause a lot of it.
