it feels a bit tone deaf to be discussing get-aways and travel hacks for quarantine requirements while a national crisis ravages this country.

i too would love to get myself to maine - and i recognize that it's a privilege to even be able to consider it - but i think my responsibility to others (which includes minimizing their risk of exposure to the virus) takes priority over my personal impulse to remove myself from dealing with the pandemic. therefore, i'm staying right here in brooklyn.

I continue to be disappointed in several groups of friends whom insist on traveling despite the risks. Some of these people work in healthcare and have actively treated COVID patients. It appalls me the selfish behavior for they and their children in taking beach trips, road trips, and the like. We truly live in a super selfish and self centered country.

SO grand it must be to take that vacation you still feel you *deserve.*
But if you wind up reporting for all to see that "Wanting to avoid public restrooms, we also found a private spot in the woods," perhaps this is actually NOT THE TIME to be venturing beyond your county borders?

Honey do. 

The ultimate staycation experience.

god.... I was holding my breath as I scrolled down the article... so worried our town would be mentioned .
it really is a bummer to live ( 38 years) in a beautiful town that is mentioned in some magazine as a getaway, secluded, beautiful, charming, undiscovered paradise; because after the article it becomes none of those things.

What socially irresponsible people.   They are "quarantining" by visiting a national park?  Are any of these folks using public bathrooms?   They are all serving as vectors of the virus, inadvertently killing other people.  We will never get through this if people don't shelter in place like they did in other countries.

Please stop telling people to come here.
If you all love NY so much stay there.
Maine is not your playground or a fun place to move to where you can open a business nobody wants.

Considering how conscientious the writers of this article were, the vitriol of the shamers in these comments is really startling to me. Are we dealing with phobia cases? Do you have any idea how lax the vast majority of Americans have been in comparison to Mr. Lipton? People are eating out at restaurants and going for carry-out all over the place! Going to drive-thrus daily! Grocery shopping every few days! Having friends over! Shopping for fun! Many are doing these things before and after being at jobs where they’re exposed to many people a day. 
In comparison, I’m finding it hard to understand the grave threat in a family, who’ve had very little contact with anyone else for months, driving through your town without getting out of their car and then staying at a house and playing in the yard there. Or in doing contactless pickup (though I personally can’t understand why people pay for restaurant food).  Or walking alone on a trail. They’re not breathing on anyone, and a breeze is all it takes dilute airborne virus to safe levels. 
Demanding that people sit inside their homes for a year is not realistic or sustainable, and it will backfire just as scare-tactic campaigns demanding abstinence backfired during the AIDS crisis.

I think, if people are very careful and play by the rules (get tested pre travel, quarantine on arrival) some travel is okay. But people do need to be cautious. Most of these people showed caution, not all tho.
Step 1: have money or have friends with money...

Since when does "quarantine" include leaving your property for walks, bike rides, takeout, and a hike? 

This is just baffling.
That picture of the children in the tub on that gorgeous, sprawling lawn that you can see the ocean from, is the absolute best!
Rich employers treating their employees increasingly like serfs, while everyone else struggles to balance work, housework, childcare, and homeschooling.

It really angers me to see how people treat someone who is caring for their child. I hope that people who are able to afford childcare pay their employees equitably and treat them with respect, not as vectors of a virus or cheap labor. Just because you can get away with paying someone less, or demand that they do more, doesn’t mean you should. Nannies are professionals and should be compensated and valued now more than ever.

This solution should be nationwide. State and federal government should be providing funding for all families to hire their own childcare providers or share one with a trusted pod of friends / neighbors. The childcare providers can then supervise the children's distance learning and school buildings across the country will remain closed until we have the virus under control.

I'm really fascinated with the class dynamics of everything happening right now. The requests of the privileged, whose lifestyles and preferences often dominate the Times and its stories despite being representative of so small a percentage of Americans, are outrageous and deserve to be exposed more often for the ridicule they merit.

With all due respect to the Mattison’s, it seems to me that what you ask your nanny to do should be a reasonable request based on science.  It has been shown that take out food is very low risk.  To ask an employee not to get take out food on their own time borders on the unreasonable.  Glove wearing is also a double edged sword, unless you are using gloves to the gold standard, hand washing is just as good, maybe better.

Seems like the nanny could be the one asking for more since they are in a better position.  Out of all times not to be taken advantage of, this might be the one.  Parents are desperate and have no right to demand more of their nanny for the same or less pay.

Having been a professional nanny and tutor in college, I can say that being a live in version would be difficult. Just as it is hard to find a compatible roommate, it's even harder to find a family you're compatible with.

Not only that, but within the domestic worker professions, cleaning and cooking are very distinctive from nannying, which is distinctive from tutoring. To do all of those at once is, frankly, the parent's responsibility, not mine, and to do so, I would request to be paid for each separately, or at a higher rate for a package deal. Someone willing to do these, and with skills to clean, or cook, care for children, or tutor, will be hard to come by. Parents cannot expect to hire another parent -- and I think that's what many want right now.

 I believe the nannies should be able to request pricing that is equitable compensation for what they are sacrificing -- not a 30% reduction as is being seen in Brooklyn. 

I was paid $20/hr to babysit and $25/hr to tutor...and in Texas! If you expect both, pay at least that rate per hour for every hour I'm in your home. Anyone, especially in NY, expecting to pay $15/hr in a pandemic for childcare from someone with significant experience may need to reassess.

Why would it matter where you got it, Claudia Mattison, why would it be worse if you got it from Her?

“Successful will be if we get to the end of the three months with none of us getting Covid,” Mattison said. “Or if we get to the end of the three months with us having gotten Covid, and it not coming from her.”
this is how the wealthy run and exploit the world!
Nannies? Haven't seen many @ all working,think it's a nice opportunity for mom to be with her child. Know of some Dad's getting that opportunity too.

“Because she was paid off the books, she could not claim unemployment.“

This is illegal and exploitive, she should call the social security office. Then she will get unemployment. And the couple will pay appropriate Medicate and unemployment taxes.
Re: Covid antibodies preferred.  The BBC reported today on a study on antibody immunity done by Kings College London.  They found the immunity wanes within six months.
This is disgusting and straight out of Gilead.

This reminds me of how the well to do chose their wet nurses in the 19th century.  Instead of preferring  the nanny to live in and have COVID antibodies, they preferred the wet nurse to live in and have a dead baby.  For if the nurse's own baby was alive, she might want to travel to the slums where her child was boarded out, and God knows what diseases she might bring back with her.  See George Moore's "Esther Waters" for a fictional rendering of this sad story.

“Successful will be if we get to the end of the three months with none of us getting Covid,” Mattison said. “Or if we get to the end of the three months with us having gotten Covid, and it not coming from her.”


This is truly disgusting. If Ms. Mattison is so concerned about catching the virus, she should have taken a leave of absence. It's unfair to tie a bonus to what you believe to be the vector of this virus and it's unfair to micromanage Ms.Rodrigues' husband's comings and goings.
Nice to know people can afford to be this picky. They want to pay someone to take care of all their adult responsibilities, yet not pay appropriately. Hilarious.

There have been many articles already about this topic. These "employers" take advantage of their employees. They treat them like they are a dime a dozen, maybe even like servants. This was all BEFORE the virus, COVID.
They fire these employess on a whim. I have met a former employee and she was suddenly fired after taking care of the children since they were newborns. This was before this Virus came.  These articles, again, won't exactly make some snobby,condescending, ungrateful employers change their belittling ways.

Frustrated home-bound people with money hiring those who are on the margins in exchange for controlling their lives.  How many nannies are going to be exploited financially and emotionally?  These families are going to drop their au pairs at the slightest hint of a cough, and after paying them minimal wages without benefits.

You know what's a nanny's worst nightmare?  The husband.
"“Ideally, we’re looking for someone who has lots and lots of energy.." Hardest eyeroll ever. And what pay, pray tell, are you offering for this endless energy?
this story is almost as disgusting as all of the claudia mattison's out there. shame on them. maybe do a better job of family planning if you're not up to doing the task yourself.

It's a little scary to comment here because all the comments have been very angry and against the employer. I acknowledge there are class issues here and there are employers that are unreasonable or exploitative. This has been happening before COVID. I'm curious to know what people think about COVID related childcare needs. Not all families that have the money for a nanny are heartless, rich people. In our family, we are essential healthcare workers, even though our work is from home. Our work responsibilities are unabating and we also face the bleak consequences of COVID on almost every phone call. We need to hire a nanny and have gone from one extreme to the other when thinking of what we should require to keep our household safe. What do you think is reasonable? What would you ask of your caregiver if they were coming in and out of your home each day? Our daughter is also immune-compromised. We may be privileged in that we can afford a nanny, but were also cursed in that we don't have a choice to quarantine completely. We have to expose ourselves. So then we have to figure out, what is the safest way to do that?

While I don't have children, I can relate to some of these parents because I recently had to hire an aide to take care of my mother after she broke her left humerus.  She literally cannot take care of herself right now, and I can only do so much while working full time from home.  

Like these parents, I realize that I am more priviledged than they are.  But I am also spending money that I don't have, trying to make sure that my mother survives this.  I certainly can't afford to pay more than I currently am.  

I have not tried to control what they do outside of the home, but wearing a mask while near my mother doesn't seem like too much to ask since she is immunocompromized.  Especially while she is eating.  One of our two aides is wonderful.  The other one seems to think I am a) made of money, b)doesn't take basic virus precautions like washing her hands, and c) won't do anything unless specifically asked.
Of course, the data are starting to show that antibodies fade and one can be reinfected but that won't stop moms-on-a-mission.

There are a lot of negative replies to this article, however, for some uneducated women who lack computer skills and the ability to get an office job etc well the job of nanny would be appealing, it’s job and there are certainly worse ones.  And in these difficult times it is very understandable the concerns the employer would have about health and safety and would have every right to limit the coming and going of their staff.  Being a live in nanny isn’t for everyone but it works for some.

I for one wouldn’t want that risk of hiring a stranger (especially during the virus) and I do think most people should take responsibility for their own children, I just want to point out that the job does exist for a reason and some women would rather have that job than no job.

Probably the person offering $15/hr is either having financial issues themselves, or is negotiating. You can't exactly ditch a child you already have when your employer cuts you from the payroll. It's not just demanding nannies who have financial difficulties.

I’m a nanny and also have a teaching degree. My opportunities and job requests are very different from those of other nannies I’ve worked alongside who don’t have college degrees or don’t speak English as well. I often get mistaken for the mom by other nannies and other parents. I can charge a higher rate due to my education level and my full time experience and although I’m ok with doing light cleaning and cooking related to the children’s needs, I’ve found that some families just want someone they can ask to do everything for a much lower rate. It takes a lot of energy to care for someone else’s kid, especially when the parents are around 24/7 due to COVID so to ask someone to do everything else on top of that for 10 hrs a day definitely deserves a higher pay rate no matter someone’s ed. level. Families want someone on call on weekends too and expect you to say yes. I’ve heard unfair stories surrounding COVID matters as well. Demanding the nannies to be quarantined but then not fully quarantining themselves or getting upset when the nanny says they aren’t comfortable w/a plan and annoyed that their “nanny is deciding their plans now” when they could just not bring the nanny on the vacation trip...Being able to throw money at things you don’t want to do is a privilege and I wish more families realized that nannies are people too and have lives of their own and also need rest. If you want them to take on extra work then ask first and then pay them what they deserve.

First, read or re read the classic "The Nanny Diaries" by Kraus and McLaughlin, which was written in 2002 but is still applicable.

Second: through out history, kids were raised either in big extended families with many aunts, grandparents, older cousins and siblings.  OR by households with servants or slaves who were responsible for the babies and children. 

Finally:   the "Leave it to Beaver" or "Donna Reed" show  mode is very, very recent and no longer relevant  (this is aimed at those posters here who chide the working moms for needing help with child raising at all).

Childcare workers, whether in the home or in childcare centers should be trained adequately, held to a standard and well paid with benefits like sick leave and yes, shock! a pension.   How important are our kids to us as a society?

Wanted, Nanny.  Must have high IQ, a master's degree, love (my) children.  Must not require sleep nor day off.  Must regard the ability to spawn by employer as the sole and compelling reason being subservience always.  Must perform all mommy duties.  Must cook, drive, take care of homework.  Run errands.  Medical degree preferred, nursing degree definitely a plus, and a degree in education is a must.  Must let mommy enjoy all pleasant bits, and manage all the unpleasant parts of parenting.  To discourage lecherous father, must be dowdy and plain.  Must be seen not heard, and better yet, not even seen.  And now, possess right antibodies.  A salary is not ruled out, but must pay for accommodation and meals while serving.  In some weeks, must expect a bill instead of a pay check.  

Really, in this day and age, is this too much to ask?

I was most struck by the story of the nanny who was now being required to wear a mask, because her own young child was attending preschool while she worked. Wouldn’t it have been simpler to allow her to bring her child along to her nanny job? There would be less risk of Covid-19 being spread for both families, and the nanny’s charge(s) would have an extra playmate. One would think that a nanny with a child would be a plus, in a time when people are clamoring to reopen schools because children are missing out on social interactions. But perhaps that would humanize the nanny too much.

Some buildings in New York are prohibiting nannies into the building unless they are living there full time....there will soon be a glut of apartments for rent or purchase in the city. It is untenable for an increasing number of families.
At the risk of being castigated, the freedom to contract (or not) is implicit in all of the stories in this article.  If the terms of employment are awful, keep looking.
What I find *interesting* is that there was no mention of what the families were doing to protect the nannies. It appeared to be a one-sided conversation.
Shouldn’t the hiring family sign a contract as well? Especially if the nanny has not had COVID.  So how about a bonus if the nanny gets sick because the host family is careless?

Being a professional maids trainer from a housekeeping company, and being an experienced person conducting training sessions for hundreds of maids and nannies, this article comes quite interesting to me. I found it a bit strange the idea of the parents to look for nannies who were tested positive for Covid 19 but somehow it made sense. I'm working in Dubai and here in our government approved domestic workers agency we are keeping all the security and safety points in check before completing any maids contract and sending them to the hiring families. We have seen a hike in demand for the private nannies who are capable of teaching the kids during these pandemic days and hence, for the live out nannies, the company made it must to wear new PPE kits every day to ensure the safety of herself and the people she interact with. I have seen some comments here showing their concern over nanny's security, but I have a belief that if a family is strict on how a nanny should behave during her work period, the family will definitely care for their own safety. So, it doesn't seem to be a big issue for the nannies, at least in my perspective. Regards, Anna Mike Maids Trainer at https://www.housekeepingco.com

Great article! But one fundamental flaw, America is no longer part of the developed world. None of the indicators, from level of personal freedom, literacy or life expectancy match those of developed countries. The US lags behind in all those areas. I think it’s time American’s realize they’re a third world country wearing a Gucci belt.

Corporate medicine, whose only goal is to maximize profits, minimize costs to the bare minimum to operate day to day and cannot respond to any anomalies like COVID-19.  The heads of the corporate medical system only see patients income and care little about the quality of their care.  This was already evidenced before COVID-19 by the fact that Americans pay the highest cost in the world for healthcare, with the least favorable outcomes compared to a very large number of other nations.  COVID-19 has shown a very bright light on how broken our corporate medical system model is.

Public health efforts have a negative impact on the bottom line, no one pays premiums, no kick back from industry. Governments had seen these investments as not worth while.  

We are paying the price. The lesson will be quickly forgotten and our children or their children will pay the price

Time increase taxes on the 1% to fund decent public health structures. Time to take a harder look at the corporate healthcare system in this county where profit is more important than outcome or quality of care. Time to rethink our decentralized fragmented healthcare system where it is everyone for themselves. The myth that "competition" produces a viable healthcare system has been exposed. The lesson, loud and clear, is that you cannot have a viable economy without a viable public health care system. Consumers who are sick, unemployed or dead will not buy enough products to keep the corporations solvent. Good public health is in everyone's best interest.

I thought it is primarily a matter of social distancing and wearing a mask. Even the article said that when reopening started and some relaxed regarding these big two methods caseloads jumped. So, why is funding an issue if the most effective weapons we have are the responsibility of individual citizens?

Public health as a whole identifies hot spots for health concerns, examines causes and then develops plans to mitigate cases. There should be a strong local effort for example with localized increases in  lead exposure from drinking water or local STD upticks, but when the health concern is a pandemic that has tragically ripped through all 50 states, the response must be controlled by a national public health team supervising that all tests are standardized, of sufficient quality, and equally available everywhere, all PPE is available equally in all states, and most importantly mandating national guidelines to prevent spread. Poor Dr Umair Shah is left to prevent a local tsunami of cases and of course is helpless.  Tony Fauci is in part to blame for only issuing concerns and warnings  and NOT demanding national efforts, building up national testing, travel guidelines, opening up timelines, etc. He is the physician’s voice and had the public ear at tens if those mom and pop shop trump COVID conferences. It is in most ways too late. We are indeed a third world country as a result of an abysmal public health response.
In many ways the USA is a developing country. Especially outside metropolitan areas, incomes, education, healthcare are on a par with ‘emerging’ countries- except they are going down, not up.

How is U.S. Healthcare underfunded when it’s the highest percentage of GDP in the world? There’s no other country In the world that spends more on healthcare in total dollars and percentage of GDP. That kind of invalidates any correlation that’s attempting to be drawn between healthcare spending and COVID response.

A  healthy public is an economic resource in production and in consumption.
Sickness affects the economy.   We know this now because COVID19 has made it painfully obvious.
Health of American  citizens should be a top priority, not an afterthought.
Public health funding,  health education, and universal health insurance are essential in moving forward as a nation. 
Democrats should emphasize  this.   I know Republicans won't.

A great failure of the public health system has been the decades-long official line that a high-carbohydrate, low-fat diet is healthy. That and the huge increase in availability of processed foods (I suppose it's hard to blame the public health system for that, but we can certainly blame the American aversion to regulation of our industries, as well as our love for convenience) have been major factors in the increase in obesity in Americans over the last 30 years-- and obesity is now a known risk factor for severe symptoms from Covid-19.

After the post 9/11 anthrax attacks, the public health infrastructure at all levels of government received a massive boost under the Bioterrorism program. The the funding from HHS alone was $10B to build frontline labs across the country to deal with just this issue. So saying public health has been under funded “for decades” is simply not true. What did happen was the same thing that’s happening now: public health funding was politicized so funding could be directed for political purposes, not to where it would be most effective. In 2002, the funding was directed to powerful congressional districts. In 2020, funding is being misused out of sheer incompetence. Just ask NYS Department of Health Wadsworth Laboratory why it took so long to fund its replacement lab (even though it caught fire in 2012) and State of California why they didn’t get funding for labs under the bioterrorism program. The point is: whatever scenarios are playing out now, no one built politics or incompetence into their response plans. This is a crisis of our own making.

Judging by percentage of GDP American health care should be among the world’s best. But, as others have noted, most of that wealth is evaporated by graft, excess profits, and plainly ineffective investments. 

But let’s not ignore the American culture which enables this to take place. America has always leaned more toward cures and treatments than preventions, a very expensive habit.  And let’s face it; we’re not really close to even thinking seriously about changing, are we?  Nope. We’re a culture of over-militarized police (rather than social and mental health programs) and pills (rather than health loss prevention).  It’s much better business.

I think it also has to do with Americans’ general valuing of individualism over civic responsibility, cooperation, and community.  Health is thought of as just another individual consumer choice or reward.

The US was doing fine when people were sheltering in place.  It's not the health system, it's the "can't be bothered" generation that would rather dance and drink in a crowded bar than save a few old lives.

And this is the same generation that believes it can make the necessary sacrifices to reverse climate change and improve the world in so many ways -- changes that will require so much more than merely putting on a mask.

The article next to this one in the digital Times details how cases have exploded along the Rio Grande. 

Not because of lack of tracking, or insurance.

But because its "warm, family oriented" culture has repeatedly ignored warnings and guidelines about Covid.

Surely that is also part of public health.

The current pandemic is not a one off. Scientists have determined that bats carry about 500 viruses that could infect humans. We cannot change the culture in other countries where killing and eating exotic wildlife is acceptable. Unfortunately, an outbreak of a deadly virus can spread across the world in a matter of days. And then there is the specter of biological warfare. This virus has illustrated how an ill prepared country can be brought to its knees by a public health emergency. And then there are the upcoming as yet unknown ravages that will result from climate change. Not having a strong public health system in the 21st century puts a county on a path towards self-destruction. Improving and maintaining a strong public health system is and will continue to be a matter of national security. We need to turn this ship around.

From the ground in Houston, life looks almost normal. Traffic is virtually back to pre-Covid levels, the grocery stores are full, and retail stores and restaurants are open, albeit in a limited capacity. Office buildings are almost empty, with office employees working from home. Most people are acting responsibly, wearing masks in public, although there are a few people who refuse.  I don’t sense a wave of panic. I’m sure the perspective is different at the medical center here. Local news reports say the public hospitals are full and have transferred patients to private hospitals in the suburbs.
Excellent article. Interlandi articulated and explained things I've felt/wondered about here in Austin.

Interesting article about the complexities of the system. However, I am missing any mention of the problem of sick leave in the US. A substantial number of employees in the US do not feel free to call in sick and must fear loss of income or job loss if they do. Going to work while contagious remains the only option for many, thus contributing to the spread. Part of the public health care discussion and health coverage for all has to be about sick leave.

I live in Germany and am extremely grateful for robust employee protection laws. Employers are legally required to provide at least six weeks of sick leave per illness at full salary. After that, employees who are insured in the statutory health insurance (public health insurance) receive about 70% of their last salary, paid by the insurance. This can continue up to 3 years. Thus, cancer patients do not get fired. Even if a person does, for other reasons, lose their job, insurance coverage remains, funded by other systems.

We feel safer knowing that people do not have to drag their viruses to work, and generally instruct our young colleagues to suppress their strong work ethic for a few days and sit out their colds at home.

This article accurately describes the chronic underfunding of public health, especially compared to our healthcare delivery system.  Yet it was telling that almost all of the photos were from the healthcare system.  Public health work continues to be invisible.

It is a great article. Thank you very much. I think we, as a country, have failed to come up with a right set of metrics to determine success. Everything is measured by Wall Street success - Stock Index etc. This pandemic still will not get the attention it deserves, even after thousands of deaths, because Dow Jones is still at 26,000. I do not even understand why it is at 26,000 today. True measures of success should have been access to decent affordable healthcare, safe working environment, decent retirement protections, clear air and water, affordable housing, affordable education, healthy investment in science and arts and fair and just judicial system.

Holy... It seems there's a need for strong, compassionate leadership at all levels, not something modelled after the gun lobby's response to everything. Unfortunately, it seems that a large chunk of Texas looks like that... 

Also, if there's one issue that could make the rich and "insulated middle class" realise that they are part of a broader system, that needs to be treated holistically, other than war, this would be it. But I can't feel optimistic that this will bring a divided people together. Thanks, Ronnie, Jesse Helms, and the countless Republican senators for ensuring the demise of sanity in your ranks.

When I lived in Japan and France, who just gave it’s healthcare workers a billion in raises, on student and then work visas, my European and American friends and I received excellent and almost entirely free healthcare. The governments of .civilized. countries made their citizens feel as if their lives and wellbeing were of value. Citizens health and wellbeing is the point of good governance. By contrast, here in the United States, if you can’t provide the one percent a source of income, you are thrown away like trash. Betsy Devos further epitomizes this utter lack of regard for the wellbeing and health of American children. The ACA, by making healthcare a for-profit industry, forcibly extracting billions from the healthcare system and using our sick bodies as a means for profit is the ultimate insult to the soul of our nation. One of Biden’s crowning jewels. The vote to invade another sovereign country knowingly based on a lie which resulted in ongoing death and despair, and Obamacare. Will we vote in government that joins the rest of the civilized world in time to enact the Green New Deal, in time to honor the health and wellbeing of our citizens, regardless of wealth or access to great power, and work to also honor and save all life on Earth?

This is just another reason why our levels of income inequality are a terrible idea.

Allowing the vast majority of money and future gains to go to a sliver of the population means less money for public health, so when things need to be paid for they are either cut or raise taxes.

Of course when you're wealthy you have greater political power it's easier to get services cut when you're not interested in paying more taxes, especially when you have money to pay for private medical services who are on call 24/7

I just did my son's taxes.  He is in college, and receives scholarships and grants, along with taking out loans.  He asked why he owed taxes from his summertime income.  I answered,"Republicans".  They have been cutting aid and taxing that aid more and more in an effort to keep kids who were not born wealthy, from being on an equal footing in life, with those of the wealthy, largely because so many of them have children like Donald Trump, who could not make in life without his way being bought, and then having his tracks covered.
Now we have another, even more existential problem:  A starved public health system that cannot function without clearing their statements through the most corrupt, political government that any living American has ever had to put up with. 
Add to that, the starved public education system the Republicans have been starving since, you guessed it: school integration, and you see our existential peril coming closer and looming larger, because people who follow this administration's disinformation are not smart enough to know a lie, even when it is spoken openly, and is literally standing on their necks.

Here in the Cayman Islands, we have successfully contained the virus with a 10 week lock down, isolating new arrivals and residents returning home from all over the globe by air and sea, quarantining those that test positive, and contact tracing.  We did all of the things that global experts (including American experts) said that we should do, and the result has been a low infection rate and only one death.  The person that died was a visitor by cruise ship with underlying conditions.  No citizens or residents have died, very few were hospitalized with symptoms and the majority of infected were asymptomatic.  

So why has this little 2nd world country succeeded where the powerful resource-rich United States has failed?  We all did what the experts told us to do.  We took the recommendations of experts seriously, put rules in place based on expert guidance, and the entire community followed the rules.  We didn’t question or push back.  We didn’t wave our individual rights around and refuse to conform.  We as a community did what was right for all in the community.  That’s where America has failed.  They lack unity and a common sense of responsibility to do what is right for the entire community.

The unnamed problem is capitalism, specifically the refusal to understand that health is not a commodity. But in the US it absolutely is. And the NYT, like the ruling class in the Democratic and Republican parties, dismissed the call for a universal national healthcare system during the primaries. The wealthy always had their needs covered.

Why is US losing the COVID19 battle? 

First, commonsense is amiss in all states. People have stopped thinking. Step outside and not many people wear masks, restaurants and servers don't seriously consider social distancing rules. Even a tuk tuk driver in Thailand dons a mask, second country that reported COVID19 and able to minimize infections with a low death rate of 58. 

Second, having strong leaders matter. We are leader-less with states left to fend the COVID19 battle on their own.

Third, our healthcare system is fractured. When Todd is getting a $7000 COVID19 bill and Mary is has to pay $34,000, there is a dysfunction in the system. 

Fourth, never mind. Vote in November!

Great article. Other than the brief mention of university public health departments becoming more “academic”, the role of those departments is obscured. First, what do you mean by “academic”.? Second, these institutions have much to answer for. Johns Hopkins and others absorb huge federal and state grants and should be vocal avatars of public health. How many graduates do they turn out each year? Where do these graduates get jobs? The private sector, predominantly. Perhaps requiring schools to train more (scholarships for some public service) would result in more attention. There used to be programs that paid nursing school tuition in exchange for a few years of service in underserved locations. I am told these ended. Considering the cost of higher ed alongside the need for various professions in different communities—why not put the money into scholarships. Instead the government pays private, often underperforming, companies to do the job which means each dollar spent must fund the profits of company, the oversight of the company, and attempt a national coordination. Just ideas—I’m no expert.

I deeply respect Fauci and believe he has the nation’s best interest at heart, but I wish he would have a pragmatic discussion with our country about end of life planning (EOLP).  With his age he would be the perfect conduit to have this discussion with our country. 
In a pandemic, when the nation’s med. resources are stretched, does a senior in a nursing home want to take up an ICU bed when their likelihood of having any quality of life after surviving a Covid case that requires an ICU stay is nil. 

Doctors and nurses are overwhelmed, and we need as a country and as citizens to wisely invest limited resources. If hospitals are overwhelmed with extreme long shot cases, it diverts resources from survivable heart attacks, strokes,etc.  An ambulance transporting an 89 year old from a memory care unit may not be able to assist a 55 year old survivable heart attack victim.  It is a zero-sum game.

 My aunt, a nurse, had to have the difficult conversation with my 93 year old grandpa regarding a DNR clause in his EOLP. At first, he said he wanted to be resuscitated.  Thankfully, she lovingly explained to him that if they had to do CPR he would likely break multiple ribs. She further explained that his likelihood of survival would be low and if he did survive his quality of life would most likely be much lower. He logically and thankfully changed his mind. God bless you Aunt P.

 Fauci: Be brave, be bold, be a hero and have that difficult conversation with our country. We need it.

I am sorry, I have to disagree. Yes, i.e. Germany has a much, much better system of public health. But that didn't bring our numbers down. It was two things:

1. A leader (Angela Merkel) who saw what was coming early on, knew what to do, had the courage to do it, was open and clear in her messaging, never lied, never belittled, never sought any kind of gain for herself, who just thought about the people

2. A people that trust such a leader, that follow orders, that can think for themselves, that know their best interests, that have the stamina to sit on the couch and binge-watch for weeks on end without going crazy.

One might also add that the general social structure (aka "Socialism!!!" if you listen to Fox) helped a lot. Companies were able to furlough workers easily - because there are laws, established in the 60's, that make sure workers get paid "enough" to survive by the state. In the U.S. Congress had to hop through loops to establish something similar.

Or take health care, from the viewpoint of a worker. Got fired? No problem! Your health care continues for three month, no matter what. Once you apply for unemployment benefits it continues until these end. And after they end and you go to "ALG-2" you STILL get health care.

Because of that people were much more willing to follow the rules,much calmer, kept shopping. And because of that our peak was low, our curve flat, our economy saved.

Our mother died on June 16th.  She did not have Covid 19. But, despite that she was not getting the care she needed and no-one could see her. Finally towards the end her doctor said he would visit at her home but he never made it because my brother found mom on the floor and got her to the emergency room. Now, finally in the good care of the ER physicians they did a full workup and found that she had cracked vertebrae in her neck and infected fluid around her heart.  
For almost 5 weeks mom was unable to get the full care she needed, prevented by quarantine and limited access to doctors who were overwhelmed.  
Our mom died quietly, sleeping as my youngest brother and sister were nearby.  It was heartbreaking.  
My self, our middle brother and my sister were in Florida, Maryland and Arizona and grandchildren and great grandchildren were spread across the country too.  Only two of our brothers were able to attend the funeral.

Health departments no doubt are underfunded.  Certainly a great deal more could have been done to slow down the spread of covid had we had a national pandemic response ready in January. These behaviors cost health departments nothing, and are, quite frankly, a very small burden on us as individuals.  By now, everyone knows this, and it is a national shame that we can't get better compliance.

Moreover, we dis-incentivize people from entering public health and public education with low salaries and high debt, working conditions designed for failure, and public disregard, scapegoating, and out and out vitriol and violence.

Imagine at the outset you were in charge and told that, if people in this country were truly informed about what they were up against with the COVID-19 virus, they would refuse to expose themselves to infection at work, at mass gatherings (such as department or big box stores and cashier lines, bars and restaurants, schools, churches), group amusements (sports, concerts, amusement parks, tourist ships, political events), and traveling (buses, subways, airplanes. cabs).  Add in that there could be  no assurance that successful therapies or a vaccine against the virus could ever be developed and put into general use. And also that, if it lasted more than a year, everyone would run out of money and default on all financial obligations (mortgages, rent, pay to employees). That is, under these circumstances, that the economy in the country and perhaps the whole world would collapse beyond anyone's ability to put it back together and that some big pieces of it would never recover and might never again exist absent some generally accepted medical miracle.  Would you then decide that what you needed to do was  be sure all these facts about the virus were made clear and understood by everyone?  Or  would you do your best to hide and distort them for as long as possible, hoping for a medical solution, and tell people to ignore the risks, which you would minimize, get back to work. and resume most group behaviors, all the keep the money wheel turning? We are experiencing the answer.

All restaurants & bars should be required to use disposable silverware & plateware. We can no longer afford to continue to infect our population centers because of outdated protocols that continue to are spread Covid 19.

Restaurants & bars are not required to properly disinfect silverware & tableware in order to eliminate Covid 19. It's not just a coincidence that when they reopen, there's an immediate spike in outbreaks, & it's more than the lack of social distancing.

Most bars use just a 3 compartment sink to 'clean glasses'. They briefly dip the glass in dirty soap water, then dip it into a sink of water, & then briefly into sanitizer.

Unfortunately, the sanitizer requires 1 minute immersion to to be effective instead of the 5 seconds that it usually receives. Watch any bartender & you will see how quickly they just dip the glass in the 3 sinks - it's an overlooked weak-link in our viral defense efforts.

A restaurant dishwasher has to handle each piece of silverware, plate, glass & cup after it is washed in order to stack & sort. If he is asymptomatic, presymptomatic or has just touched an infected plate or surface, he is going to be infecting you when you plunge your silverware into your mouth that he grabbed with his infected fingers. 

As a former restaurant General Manager, I can tell you these shortfalls often reach appalling levels of cross-contamination during a busy shift. These protocols were never designed for a pandemic.

Public health and private healthcare are on a direct collision course. In private healthcare it's a "bad" month when there are fewer beds filled, i.e. when public health is doing a good job. The calculation is more complicated during this pandemic; hospitals want to be full -- but not too full -- but underlying the basic problem of keeping people well is literally the bottom line. For example one hidden scandal in the US is how many people die of the flu which is largely preventable.  Why aren't hospitals giving out vaccinations for free?  Because profits depend on treating  hundreds of thousands of flu patients.

The goal of US healthcare must be keeping people well; only then healthcare be in sync with public health.

This is an excellent article. It goes deep into the reasons why this country is losing the battle against COVID19. There are several important issues brought up, but the two that jumped off the page at me are 1:  Americans don't like to be told what to do and 2: We have no national health plan to respond to a national health crisis. 
I lived through the Polio epidemic of the 1950s. There was a national response and nearly every child was vaccinated and the virus all but disappeared. Now we have the anti vaxer movement which pedals misinformation that may lead to thousands of people refusing to get vaccinated. We may not be able to attain herd immunity if this becomes widespread across the country.

Pure selfishness won't get us out of this debacle, consideration for your fellow citizens and doing the right thing will.
We also need to take a hard look at funding for national health plan to be able to deal with the next crisis to come along...and it's not a question of if but when it will happen. 
We need to somehow get a national response plan in place. It's too late for this pandemic, but we need to get to work on one for the future...now.

In medicine, the patient is the individual. In public health, the patient is the community. We look “upstream” for root causes and social determinants of health. This is why we recognize how poverty affects health and education outcomes, making those with a lower SES more vulnerable to infections (based on job status and housing vulnerabilities).

We forget that clean water (chlorine and fluoride, less tobacco smoke), clean air, safe milk (pasteurization), family planning (contraception), vaccination, and safer cars, job sites, homes, and food are all the results of public health efforts.

I’m proud to be a 45-year public health worker, despite almost all of our efforts uphill and underfunded. We don’t have the glamour, but we get the results.

Truly, we do it for you, not for ourselves. So let’s give the public health leaders a break, and realize that our advice is to help us all, as a community. We are all in this together, like it or not.

This is a natural disaster on a global scale. How does one win against a tidal wave, earthquake, tornado, a once in a hundred years flood? You can prepare for the events and humans rarely prepare well enough. The term I heard at the beginning of the pandemic was "flatten the curve." Which is interesting. I guess some came to think that flatten the curve meant "stop the spread." But those are two different statements. I thought flatten the curve was to get the hospitals and social services ready for the inevitable surge in cases that were going to show up in ALL communities at some time. But what we got was that people looked to New York State and once they were over their hump as to case load a lot of those in the country seemed to think that the pandemic was over. The curve was flattened but it was far from over. We flattened the curve then parts of the country opened up and the clusters grew at an alarming rate. But not really if you look at NY States path. It needs to be said that the pandemic takes roughly 3 months from the beginning to the end of a large cluster growth and decline cycle. And flatten the curve NEVER meant that we weren't going to HAVE to have it in our communities. We were just filling the sandbags getting ready for the water to rise. It not an "IF" it happens, it's a "when."

As I see it, the key issue in this incredible essay is this: "Public health interventions work best when the forces of politics and culture are aligned behind them - when elected officials provide the necessary resources, and citizens abide by the necessary strictures."

For this to be reality, there has to be a necessary level of belief in the mutual well-being and interdependence of individuals and the community (i.e., society). America has never succeeded in teaching our young the values of what Erich Fromm termed "The Sane Society." The resulting concentration on Emersonian Self-Reliance, extreme individualism and concern only with one's own rights have given us a culture that barely recognizes the communal nature of public health and security. We struggle with this even in the current catastrophic emergency.

The political pendulum-swinging between Republican and Democratic understandings of America's well-being demonstrates the true meaning of our dilemma as a society: we have no shared unity or a political vocabulary to express it. And for me at 85, it means I have never seen any society-wide problem faced  and solved during my lifetime. We are stuck in a kind of primitive thinking about individual "rights" that guarantees we will never achieve, as a society, a permanent awareness of all being in the same boat. Cultures may change, but very, very slowly. And so, we slowly drown.

Had Trump instead listened to the experts and encouraged governors to follow their guidelines for reopening, many thousands of people might be alive today. Trump and his supporters have aggravated the situation to the point where we may be dealing with this virus for years until (and if) an effective vaccine is developed. We seem to have an amazingly ill-informed populace that believes whatever Trump tells them. As Mark Twain said, “In religion and politics people’s beliefs and convictions are in almost every case gotten at second-hand, and without examination, from authorities who have not themselves examined the questions at issue but have taken them at second-hand from other non-examiners, whose opinions about them were not worth a brass farthing.” As we’ve all seen, Donald Trump’s opinions are not worth a brass farthing.

While I understand the challenge of the "panic, neglect, panic" cycle, I can't forgive the lack of leadership and willful ignorance of our elected leaders. I'm appalled by the needless loss of life and suffering that come from their inaction and desire to serve the greedy.

We have a president who is undeniably ignorant about history, is obsessed with economic fantasy to ensure (he believes) his reelection, and who disregards any scientific data but who bears the major responsibility for the current unnecessary  pandemic tsunami in this country. In fairness to Trump, the failure of government to adequately fund public health programs after this crisis of catastrophic proportions is not new, but hopefully in the imminent and foreseeable future we should learn from history, invest in preventive public health programs so that the next COVIID can be more systematically and thoroughly addressed.

Viva Hidalgo. Viva Shah. Thanks to the Houston Chronicle for pursuing the information to understand the pandemic. That way, the necessary public health decisions won't have to be so fiercely fought.
We'll also need many more government officials who value science, can look ahead, have a spine, can recognize and overcome mistakes, are secure enough to not have to always look certain and "in charge," and value non-glamorous things like inter and intra-governmental communications.
If we don't do these things, including of course better prioritize public health, as these pandemics are not going away, we'll have to update our "Jersey curses" to better "innoculate" future public health professionals to what they'll be hearing.
Thank you, Jeneen!

Great analysis. I would have liked to see more comments on the quote from Tom Frieden that the base of the pyramid of public health is "[s]ocial measures that mitigate economic inequality." Normally the wealthy suffer less from the underfunding of public health than does the middle class, who in turn suffer less than the lower class (although no-one escapes the cost entirely - see "The American Health Care Paradox"). Funding public health would require us to value our own lives and health more than we do our social status.   

I suspect the next pandemic will find us again unprepared and unwilling to do what we know works. But maybe being surrounded by people disabled by COVID-19 in the coming years will help us remember the cost, as knowing disabled polio survivors has helped me remember. Even though those lower down in the hierarchy are (as always) suffering the most, as in every epidemic we really are all in this together.

This is an excellent article and very well written. As a previous public health nurse (in Canada) I can attest to the fact that qualified public health nurses have been saving lives with patient education, preventative programs in areas of maternal child health, smoking cessation, AIDS education, teen pregnancy, diabetes education,  the list goes on and on. It is cost effective and operates to empower people to become informed and take control of their health. Covid-19 will respond to preventative public health measures. It can be controlled with education by qualified public health personnel out there helping citizens through education and teaching and support and complements the medical and clinical resources. Unfortunately community health programs lack the qualified public health registered nurses or hire less qualified people to do the jobs that should be done by qualified RN’s who have the requisite public health education and skills. I found it interesting that the article is about public health but most of the photos are of people in hospital. Public health is community based. Not hospital based. Contact racing is hard laborious work but it was instrumental in controlling STD ‘a, tuberculosis, smallpox and other diseases that ravaged entire towns cities and countries. We need to get back to basic, sound, effective public health principles.

It is a truism that the best treatment for a disease is not to get it in the first place.  Who is responsible for the epidemic of obesity, for diabetes, for many chronic diseases?  Public issues some health education addressing such issues.  Medical doctors in the sickness care system sometimes offer education and coaching followup but mostly it is pills, gastric bypass surgery, and onward from Obesity to diabetes, heart disease, and dementia.  Yes, each stage is a  partial cause of the other, and in the end, death!

Other causes include poor education, housing, and nutrition.  Most causal factors for this situation are in the control of, yes, you and me.  Public health budgets can double but they would not make much of a dent in the problems.  Why?  Our society has chosen personal physicians for their care and unfortunately, those physicians do not handle the prevention issues well.  Why?  The food system is outside their control.  Also, the quality of research on the issues is spare and NIH funding for it is nil.

So what should be done?  Unless the public health departments want to compete for rh role of the primary physician, forget it 
fund more research and pay for coaching and counseling to help individual cope.

I am a dual citizen of Rwanda and the USA. Despite many gains, Rwanda is still one of the 50 poorest countries in the world. Yet they instituted a lockdown, a curfew, handwashing stations, and rigorous testing and contact tracing all over the country. From previous experience with TB and HIV and preparation for possible Ebola, they had cadres of community health workers that worked hard to inform people. Four months into the pandemic, in the most densely populated country in Africa, total cases in a country of 12 million are still under 1,500 with 4 deaths. Everyone wears masks and there is a 9 PM curfew. It has been hard and the main cause of cases is people coming from border countries with the virus. But I applaud them for self-discipline and community effort, which we seem to lack so severely.

We are not losing the battle against Covid-19. Here are  some positives.

1. Therapeutic treatments will arrive soon.  When someone contracts the novel coronavirus, his body’s immune system launches a defense, including producing antibodies that circulate in the blood to help identify infectious invaders. These circulating antibodies offer some protection against future infection. Scientists have now engineered clones of these antibodies and they are showing to be effective both therapeutically and to prevent infection. They work by attacking the spike protein of the coronavirus, which is how this virus gets into our cells. Stop that from happening, and the virus can’t replicate inside the body.

2.Rapid, low-cost saliva tests are coming that will allow 100% testing of the population.

3. More people are wearing masks. Even the man in the WH wore one the other day. More states and businesses are requiring them. Face shields are better.

4. Consensus has finally emerged that airborne spread is happening. Even the CDC and WHO have accepted this fact, albeit belatedly and reluctantly.

5. Past exposure to common-colds is playing a protective role for some people.  Studies show that 20 to 50 percent of people who had never been exposed to the novel coronavirus have immune cells — known as memory T cells — in their body that react to this new virus.  

6. Vaccine trials seem to be working and they could be available by October. 

7. More than 60% recover from Covid -19.

Terrific piece that delivers on the promise of the title. Thanks to the author, the editors, and the entire team that produced this important article. I will return to it again and again in the future as I try to make sense of the many threads that brought us to this tragedy.

The article is an excellent overview of US public health history, but documents public sickness more than public health. A person's health is largely determined by nutrition, and the AMA has abandoned its post to Big Ag and Big Pharma in recent decades. 

The food guidelines 'pyramid' has promoted highly refined grains and sugars that have left most Americans facing obesity and type 2 diabetes, these being the 'underlying conditions' cited in nursing home deaths. Ketchup in school lunch programs is categorized as a 'vegetable'. 

The media ignores the fact that mortality for those under the age of 70 are no higher than for bad flu seasons of the recent past. Scientists are warning that the poverty that prolonged lock downs exacerbate is beginning to account for the apparent rise in deaths. 

At the same time poverty alone among people of color is seen as the cause of their higher death toll, whereas the biologists point out that skin pigmentation is a larger factor, toward avoiding a deep deficiency in vitamin D, our central hormone critical to resisting upper respiratory infections. 

The majority of American are deficient, and deserve to know about it.

Nutrition underlies all public health, and public sickness policy will always be held hostage by the factory foods industry, until it is rationalized outside the influence of Washington lobbyists.

But public health has also missed the boat on prevention. Our entire system is based on the war that Pasteur began when he showed a small invisible microbe as causing our disease. We have progressed to the point that we realize the resistance to our antimicrobials that the war has wrought. But we have not gone back to look at Claude Bernard, Pasteur's contemporary and foil, who argued that the "soil", i.e. where the microbe was planted and the defenses they had by virtue of natural selection, were just as important. Those defenses make us healthier but no one is looking at them or how to make them work better. That is a role for Public Health, but in order to do it they need to get their orders from someone other than the generals running the war.

Americans have been conditioned for decades to judge the nation's health solely on the basis of the economy. How healthy we are, how well-educated we are or how happy we are have become secondary at best. The results of that mind-set are perfectly portrayed in this article.

Directly above this is a piece about the virus’s spread through the Rio Grande valley. 

How did it spread there? By families who ignored the risks, and who selfishly and stupidly stuck to their traditions of “pachamgas,” or large family gatherings, and their culture of telling themselves that “nothing bad will happen.” 

Spend all you want on public health. But at the end of the day, the public’s health depends on millions of private decisions. When these decision makers aren’t the sharpest knives in the drawer, we’re going to see rapid and broad spread. And to the degree that there are disparities in intelligence between population groups, we’re going to see disparate impact where disease spread is concerned. Just like we see with school performance, earnings and homeownership rates, family stability measures like the prevalence of single motherhood, and yes - the rate at which violent crime is committed and the incarceration rate. 

The sooner we acknowledge this, and apply authoritarian measures to help the less intelligent amongst us protect themselves from their own bad choices, the sooner we’ll beat this pandemic. Europe is doing much better. So are the societies of East Asia. Unlike them, we are far more diverse. While our Euro and East Asian descended populations have COVID rates on par with their counterparts in Europe and East Asia, it’s our minority populations that need the help. This is a crisis. The central problem remains. In the United States the concept of Public Health - Research, translation into clinical practice, implentation is completely foreign.

An examination of Universal Health Care in any one of the many advanced countries that offer it would provide the first lesson for Americans about this concept.

I do not mean New York Times examination but rather systematic well funded research by American researchers who study how UHC works, one country at a time. 

Both Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders would have benefited if such research giving an overview country by country had been availabele.

I do not have any hope that Joe Biden on his own will have the energy and knowledge to press for UHC lets say in the 2d 2 years. A Vice President who does have such is what we need.

Here a footnote I now regularly add: I work for Swedish Ob-Gyn researchers who are studying the possibility of bringing the single most important element of UHC to one or more Sub-Sahatan African countries - Bill and Linda Gates Foundation funds work focused on this goal.The element: Universal and free 1000 days of pre, peri, and post-natal care for every mother-child combination. Perhaps the Gates duo should support such for backwards America.

So, the key reason that we're losing the battle may be  this quote from the article: "The People of Texas and officials at every level were bitterly divided over how to balance public health and private liberty". There are all kinds of problems in that statement: Private liberty, as if that is possible. Individual freedom is only  possible in a community that works together to achieve common goals. This word "liberty" is a political weapon that each person can interpret their own way- liberty to walk safely, vs liberty to own the gun and pull it out in public. Liberty to speak out vs. deciding what speech is perceived is harmful. It seems that humanity has not yet learned that individuals will still mostly work for their own interests versus work to figure out the common interests of their community. This country (and in this case, Texas in particular) is losing out in many ways to the self interests of politicians, business men, and our administration. Be it in the area of health, social justice, health care, etc., Younger people are beginning to wake up to that. Better get out the vote folks (in person, or by mail).

Even before covid19 found its way into the USA, for years before that time, as a Registered Nurse I was alarmed at the number of people who could just enter the country without immunizations and blend into the country.
Public health was a focus of every parent’s responsibility in the past.
People with STDs and tuberculosis were quarantined and forced to treatment and their contacts were traced by our local health departments. 
There has been a profound breakdown of public health responsibilities in the past few decades; public health fell of the cliff; as a kid, I recall the terror we faced at the possibility of contracting polio and even as a kid I was so grateful for the Salk and the Sabin vaccines. 
There has been a failure at all levels of government for investment in public health.
Hard to find someone who cares about such things anymore.

July 20th was the 6 month anniversary for when the first case of Covid-19 was reported in the U.S. If one assumes, after an incubation period of 7 days, that single person infected a second person , who then infected another person etc., by the end of 6 months there would be 67,108,864 infected people. That is the worst case scenario of what one is dealing when an infection is spread in an exponential manner with an "R naught" of 0. It does not account for the existence of  other infected individuals on that date. 

If we do nothing else before a vaccine is available, the least we can do is to wear a face mask, practice social distancing, and not to go out unless necessary. Such measures do in fact work, as evidenced by the results obtained in NY and in some of the other northeastern States.  In the absence of adequate testing, personal protective equipment, hospital beds, ventilators etc., hospital admissions were brought to pre-covid 19 levels within 4-5  weeks with good leadership that encouraged the public to adopt such measures. Is that too great of a sacrifice to make in view of the results likely to be obtained?

Why can’t we manage to respond to this coronavirus challenge in any competent or coherent way? Why can’t we respond in a way that is, at a minimum, on a par with other developed nations? Why, why, why? 
There is now a large body of Americans who actually can’t respond in a competent and coherent way. When large segments of the American population refuse to follow any guidelines of physical distancing, behavior, or mask wearing, there is a basic reason. They just can’t. They can’t bring themselves to follow directions. They can’t bring themselves to believe there are any consequences to their actions. They can’t bring themselves to believe they have any responsibility or duty to their fellow Americans. But the question is: Why are so many Americans living in this state of mind?
After decades hearing the extolling of the self and self-aggrandizement, including in-your-face examples for the public that nobody of wealth or connections ever pays consequences for actions, can Americans realistically be expected to have the physical and emotional capability to recognize a greater good, any authority, or any knowledge greater than their own experience, let alone have the discipline to follow directions or guidance even if accepting that a problem exists? The evidence indicates not. What we see in these scenes around the country of heedless and dangerous activity is what our America has become in 2020, an America that just “can’t”.

The bold truth of the matter is the USA deserves this pandemic.

Our conduct and leaders brought this to fore. 

Shame on America.
